=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have had the opportunity to playtest this game in wave 3 and have played in 6 times in less than 2 weeks!  This game is fabulous, and definitely one of a kind.  The end game condition is similar to Euphoria where it ends on stars, but having the vp multiplier based on territories, stars and resources takes it up a notch. Not only do you have to be worried about the last star going out, but you also have to keep track of your popularity.

There is so much good to be said about this game, I enjoy it the most with 3 players and we were typically able to finish a game in under 75 minutes.  There are not very many games that pack so much punch in such a short time. Highly recommended!

RATING: 6

Your overall strategy is mostly determined by the action board you get because the 2/3 coin bonuses are impossible to ignore. That being said, the end-game timing and scrambling for area control is very good.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A 5 might be a bit harsh, usually I'd give this game for the experience that I had a 6.

This rating isn't because of a devastating loss, I actually won my first and only play of it. But it became pretty clear that this game has a runaway leader problem, which probably has to be balanced out by the other players having to unite against the leading player. That the game manual requests that people refrain from actually keeping count of who is ahead in points and how many points are to be gained by an action doesn't help, it seems like it just wants to mask this issue. In our case, it was a little race at the beginning, but the game was pretty much decided after three or four turns, and this in part to the initial setup and the very first random encounter. After half of the game, we could have stopped, the outcome was clear and there was no possibility at all that I could see for the other player to get back into the game, without having done anything wrong himself when playing the game. The unbalanced secret goal cards probably added to this: While one of mine was a breeze to accomplish, both of the other player were rather hard to fulfill.

The game is definitely playable, as in: the game mechanics are working together, but they don't complement each other well enough. When looking under the hood, leaving all that bling (the opulent visuals of the game) behind, the mechanics seem to be tackered together so that there is just some variation and choice for a change of the game state when playing. Despite it seeming very complex at start and when looking at it on the table, there is actually very little "game" to be found in this one.

In hindsight, the game hints at being deep and immersive, but actually there isn't much to it. The only good thing about this is, it's actually quite easy to teach. If you want a game that is designed a lot better with a gameplay similar to this one, then I'd recommend to get Eclipse or Terra Mystica, for example. Skip this one instead.

RATING: 7
What Scythe does, it does extremely well. This is a euro-game that has been optimized to its logical conclusion -- and I like it. All of the fiddliness of something like [thing=177736][/thing] or even Terra Mystica has been stripped away, and you're left with a very appetizing core. 

I've enjoyed my plays so far, and would relish some additional time in this universe. Given time, Scythe could bump quite high up the list of my favorite euro-games, but I haven't played enough to draw that conclusion just yet.

RATING: 9
Plays very differently depending on the combination you get & maximizing your combo's potential is essential. I haven't played enough to know whether all combos are well-balanced. Fun, tense game that provides a variety of paths to victory. Beautiful design & components. Excellent streamlined engine-building gameplay. Things that keep it from being a ten: some fiddly rules that feel like they could have been streamlined, a little low on interaction for a game with combat, and finally: the encounter cards not coming with thematic intro text to describe the situation  and doing mostly the same thing. The encounter part could easily be fixed in a mini-expansion, and that alone would probably be enough to push it up to a 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Awesome concept stunningly executed
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Scythe is the most anticipated game of the year 2016. Fun fact: scythe is used for both farming and war. Personally for me Scythe is an alternative to Terra Mystica, both are great games.

Mechanism and Heaviness:
It's basically an action-selection game with resource management and engine building. Solid mechanic. Multiple paths to victory. Very similar to The Gallerist, each turn you choose 1 out of 4 sections with 2 actions available. You can do the top-row action, or bottom-row action, or both (top-row first), or neither. In summary: move, produce, bolster power/ popularity, build structures, deploy mechs, upgrade & enlist recruits. There's no rounds or phases. It's medium heavy. It's thinky. If you like thinky Euro games like Terra Mystica, you'll like this game. Straightforward and intuitive gameplay. The depth of the game relies on the strategies players apply during the game. Almost no downtime, the turns can go very fast between players as resources are limited. Clear iconography.

Theme
It's alternate-history Eastern Europa circa 1920s. Building your small empire on the map. The factions, the miniatures and encounter cards gives more thematic feeling. The encounters provide more options to get more resources, and if you spend more time to read the flavor text on the encounter cards, you get to immerse yourself into the worldbuilding, similar like Arkham Horror game. Can be retheme as Game of Thrones or Lord of the Rings if you want.

Components and Setup
The components are superb and top notch, so many different shapes of tokens, different types of cards, the character and mech miniatures looks great on the board! The setup feels very much like Terra Mystica with starting resources (military, combat cards, objective cards, popularity, money) and units + buildings on personal player boards. Wooden token management on the mats like in Terra Mystica and Eclipse. There are several decks like combat, encounter, objective (just need to complete one per game) and factory cards (extra action space, gained when visited The Factory for the 1st time). 

Factions and Replayability
Well-balanced asymmetry faction and mech abilities like in Terra Mystica. 3 out of 4 mech abilities are to improve mechs' and character's movement, while the other 1 is to improve combat. Variability created by random pairings of faction mat and player mat for each player. Terra Mystica base game has 14 different factions, with Fire and Ice expansion has another 6 factions (10 different coloured boards), Scythe base game has 5 faction boards and 5 player boards, with 25 different combinations. With the Invaders from Afar expansion, there's gonna be 49 combinations! The replayability is high. Different faction, different starting available terrains, different strategies. You've got to adapt to your surrounding.

Actions
TOP: move/ gain money (by moving, there can be combat/ encounter/ factory), bolster military power/ gain combat cards, trade resources/ gain popularity or produce on tiles (different tile different resource, resources stay on board with worker: wood, oil, metal, food or worker); BOTTOM (pay with resources): upgrade (move cube from top row to bottom row for discount), deploy mechs (special faction abilities), build structures (mine/ monument/ armory/ mill) or enlist recruits (1-time bonus and unlock action-reaction). Dual benefits of the upgrade system - increase top-row action benefit and decrease bottom-row action cost. Some small reminders: mechs share abilities with character, not workers, which include riverwalk; mech and workers can transport resources; mill is an extra territory for production; enlist ongoing bonus include activation from active player and immediate neighbours.

Combat
Threat of combat is constant, but not mandatory. Deterministic combat systemu sing power dial and combat cards like in Dune/ Rex (also Game of Thrones, Forbidden Stars, Cosmic Encounters). Add numbers on power dial (up to military power to spend) and numbers on combat cards (2 - 5, depend on number of units on tile except worker). The combat resolved fast, unlike those other games. Sometimes a game can be without combat. Each faction need only to win 2 combats to put 2 achievement stars on triumph track except the Saxony. Combat will lower attacker's popularity if there is any retreating workers from the opposition faction. There are no units/ structures destroyed, only retreating to home base.

Endgame
Endgame condition triggers when 1 player put 6 stars on the triumph track after fulfilling various requirements. The stars will come out very fast towards the end of the game. Unique endgame condition, very similar to console gaming with the achievement stars on triumph track. Most money win - popularity (love) reminiscent to Euphoria's morale track affect how much money collected for each stars, territories controlled (The Factory counts as 3 territories) and resources controlled. Plus random structure bonus scoring tile. 
  
Solo Variant - Automa
There are 4 levels of difficulty, Autometta for easy, Automa for normal, Automaszyna for hard and Ultimaszyna for hardcore. The Automa cards make the solo variant plays very smoothly. Mostly the Automa units would aim to reach The Factory. The solo variant is as good as The Gallerist's. 

Final Thoughts
Scythe is a keeper. Fans of Terra Mystica, The Gallerist, Eclipse and Game of Thrones will be at home with this game, with extra ability to play solo. Reputable designer of Viticulture and Euphoria fame. Watch Rodney's Watch It Played video before playing the game really helps you understand how the game flows. 

Expansion
The expansion with extra 2 factions is a must, the board just scream for epic 7-players game! With the base game, it's War of the Five Kings, with the expansion, it's gonna be Battle of the Seven Kingdoms! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Includes Scythe Invaders from Afar Expansion

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
3 plays / 5,6,7 players

LIKE: So many powers to explore, and a lot of different setup combinations. Having the two board combo was interesting. Beautiful art and highly produced bits. The war tension was fun and not overly threatening (except at the end). Very similar to Antike.

DISLIKE: In higher player counts, I felt the mid-game stalled and I became bored. Some player powers feel better than others. The encounter cards were boring. The player boards are fiddly. The theme did not add anything for me. Turn-order feels off, because ending the game early denies other equal turns.

OVERALL: This game plays very similar to Antike, but Antike plays faster and feels streamlined. Scythe does have its fun moments, but it also had moments where my turn didn't feel that interesting, so it would drag a little. I'd rather play Terra Mystica, or Viticulture-- Scythe relies too much on its theme to elevate it above the hordes of modern games.

Played again, and my thoughts are the same. Not sure why people like the game so much, but maybe the game is better with 4 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game really lived up to the hype for me.  Sure the artwork is great and the theme integration is well done, but it is the gameplay that stood out.  It's definitely more of an efficiency Euro than a dudes on a map game, but I like having the option of attacking if necessary.  After three plays, I'm hoping to try out all of the other factions.

I have some concerns about replayability because there isn't much emergent gameplay here, but it's still a lot of fun.

Update : After five plays this is still a 9.  I still really enjoy it and there is still more to explore.  I haven't tried the black or green factions, and I have no idea how to win with the blue Nordics.

6th play with the green faction was fun!  Just need to try the black faction now.

7th play with the black faction.  Still really enjoy this game and I think there is more to explore.  Looking forward to more plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Absolutely gorgeous art and great (over)production. I especially have to admire the art because it looks as elegant, lively and inspiring as fantasy themed art can. This alternative history thing really rouses your imagination. It is a shame that the graphic design doesn't quite fulfill the same standards since the symbols can be a bit hard to read and most of the essential information easily escapes the eye on a quick glance.

Playing is quite fun but, surprisingly, falls into the category of euro games. Looking at the game and reading the fluff makes you kind of expect more rumble and action. But no. You're collecting resources instead and turning them into victory points. 

The game starts extremely slow and you feel like making no progress at all. After a while it picks up pace and players start to advance on multiple fronts in parallel. This results in a quick game end. Or maybe quick is a wrong term here because you can see it coming from a distance already, but you just reach each goal on consecutive turns, which creates a sensation of suddenness. 

The biggest achievement of the game is The art, but as a game I would call it ok at best. Nothing wrong with it, but instead of euro style grinding a proper mech clash would've been more interesting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I got to playtest this game as part of the massive blind playtest. I saw it evolve through several iterations, all the way to its [nearly] final state. I love: the artwork, the asymmetrical player mats, the "upgrade" part of the engine-building, the realistics resources, the metal coins, the Euro-style problem-solving coupled with the threat of Ameritrash territory fight. The actual combat system isn't my favorite, but even after playing more than a dozen games, I can't think of a better way to incorporate head-to-head conflict over territory into a eurogame, so I guess it's actually as good as can be expected.
The number of player mat - faction mat combinations make replay possibilities very large, as does the game's flexibility with number of players. I've played with every possible player number and they're all good (another thing that increases the replayability is that the game plays differently with different player counts).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Scythe feels a lot like Eclipse to me, for some reason, despite the two sharing very little in the way of mechanics. Every time I play, I get the itch to pull out my second-favorite space epic. (This is not a bad thing.)

As with most Stonemaier Games, Scythe's art and components are absolutely gorgeous. The game itself is both well-balanced and fast-paced, with some interesting strategies and different ways to build an engine. My only complaint is that combat isn't quite as common as I'd like, but the threat of it is palpable and gives the game an interesting "WWI stalemate" feel. The Automa solo mode is solid—definitely a big plus for me.

(Euro; 2x)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I absolutely love this game!  It strikes an excellent balance between planning (strategy) and response (tactics).

I like how the combat/pvp nature of the game is well balanced - there is such a dual-edged nature to combat that players think long and hard before committing to them and it can be strategically advantageous to eat a loss rather than over commit and obtain a victory.  In addition (and this is for games of 3+ players), you have to consider how winning 1 combat weakens your overall ability to defend yourself and opens you up to combat from other players.  It really is well done.

I also like the engine building.  It's not a complicated engine, but the operations required to establish the engine and utilize it are varied enough that players have many choices to make.  In addition, those choices tend to be very deep - they are the tip of the iceberg, a snowball that may or may not lead to the ultimate goal (global world domination or something like that).  It's the depth of gameplay that keeps me coming back.

I like the dual nature of upgrades.  You uncover a benefit and cover a cost.  It's such a nice way of offering compelling, meaningful choices with real consequences.

The variance in starting position/mats is fantastic!  The combination of faction + player mat makes for some real differences in terms of the best strategy to utilize.  And then you have to consider the goals, which may or may not be worth pursuing.  Plenty of choices!

I love the art in this game.  Pastoral and very thematic.  The illustrations help frame the game in a larger context.  It wasn't strictly necessary, and not everyone likes or enjoys it, but I think it adds character to the bigger package and presentation.

Production value is excellent!  Even the base game is high quality.  The additional pieces (metal coins, board extension, realistic resource tokens) are much appreciated!

I strongly recommend using glass markers/beads in place of the cardboard exploration tokens.  The cardboard tokens get lost among the board's colorful artwork.  3d beads are *MUCH* easier to see and improve gameplay.

My primary criticism is that games will often end with an unequal number of turns.  This is something that [u][url=https://boardgamegeek.com/article/23299059#23299059]I discussed in the forums[/url][/u].  I have two "answers" for this point.  My first inclination, as suggested by sethvanorden in that thread, is to use turn order as a handy cap modifier.  Very easy and very understandable.  My second thought is to give a small compensation to those players who received one less turn - an award on the order of 5 coins or so.  Small, insufficient, but enough to reduce the sting and say "I feel your pain but I'm not giving you 100% insurance coverage."  I think either or both of those will help.

Overall, this is just a fantastic game.  I think there's enough depth to keep me interested for a long time without overwhelming players.  Also, the play time hits a sweet, [i]sweet[/i] spot - 2 hours once people are familiar.  There are potential swings and not everything is 100% balanced, but it shouldn't be.  This is not a pure abstract - it's a thematic euro.  You want it unbalanced enough to provide options, but not so off-kilter that the whole system wobbles out of control.  And it hits that spot beautifully.

Try it.  [gameid=169786] may or may not be your cup o' tea, but I'd give it better than even odds that you see and appreciate at least some of its carefully crafted beauty.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
1st play: Thematically this game is awesome.  Post-war mechs being repurposed as farm support, limited but purposeful combat and an amazing production with metal coins, giant board and plastic mechs.  In terms of mechanics I'm not so sure.  It felt like there was more downtime than there should have been, and very little interaction between players.  The optimization game of trying to double up actions made for some thinky bits and when you pull off a combo it's satisfying.  As always, I hate when games could easily have equal turns but choose not to.

2nd play: After said and done, an average game.  The mechanics feel a little more clunky than they need to (with dual actions each move but each player having different combos of dual actions it's hard to keep track of each other player's playerboard.  Knowing which factions can go to which terrain types and which factions combo trading with mechs vs trading with enlist.  The result is a pretty multi-player solitaire game.  The theme is great though.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[i]2016/12/27 1 play 3p[/i]

To me Scythe feels like an evolution from Eclipse. Same hexagonal play area (but not modular), same central galactic core (factory), asymmetric powers, space ships (mechas).

Scythe lacks an exploration phase, and the opportunity for players to build their galaxy by choosing how to place system tiles.

Also, there is no mecha customization, whereas spaceship design is a strong suit of Eclipse.

In Scythe combat is much more streamlined, which is really a plus, but it's much less epic than with Eclipse.

Scythe offers more modularity in the asymmetric powers by randomly combining two player faction boards, whereas Eclipse has fixed boards (but more of them with the expansions).

Artwork in Scythe completely crushes Eclipse. Scythe art is beautiful and distinct, Eclipse artwork is generic and uninspired.

Eclipse plays nine turns, Scythe endgame is activated by achieving 6 "goals", which is a mechanic I disliked.

I had the feeling that Scythe played faster than Eclipse.

Scythe has a popularity mechanic, whereas Eclipse only has a puny "traitor" negative tile.

Scythe has a seemingly great solo module, but as I don't own neither Eclipse, nor Scythe, that is irrelevant to me.

Given the choice, I'll play Eclipse any time over Scythe. The tension, epic scale, diversity of strategies are much grander in Eclipse than Scythe.

Please, design Eclipse with better artwork, and fix the combat mechanic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Personal Collection
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Worker placement light, combat 'dune' type light, wargame bloodless light as you don't even need to rebuild. Theme is great but not important. Miniatures are pretty nice but not exactly necessary. General overall production is of great value.

The removing cubes to gain more and cost less for second action is not new, but works fine here. I can understand why there are only six stars needed to end the game, as most resources within the player playmat would have been exhausted. Small feel of Agricola meets Dune. 

The end game boils down to coins, with area control and resources being measured for success. No victory objective. Just senseless battles for an area that may not even be connected to your empire. 

Cards add a more variety to victory and makes the game already chaotic as it is. Kemet feel to it, but thematically weaker.

RATING: 7
A solid game that I think will continue to improve for us.

Our first play through was at 2 players. Being our 'learning game', it was a bit slow and quiet. We had two combats, one victory for each of us. We felt lukewarm about it, but hopeful.

Our second play through was at 4 players which was a definite step up in fun. Multiple combats, everyone employed different strategies, resulting in completely different stars placed across the board - unintentionally, at that! We all attempted to play to our specific asymmetric strengths, which was awesome. I also noticed a step up in strategy having a game under my belt, so I can see the opportunity and desire to refine my plan next time around.

I look forward to more plays. This went from a low 7 to a solid 8 by my second play. Early to say where it will land in the long run.

I'm interested in the expansions, but only if the game has legs on its own for a while more.

I dunno... this just never hits the table so it may be on it's way out.

RATING: 8.93
Another fantastic game from Jamey Stegmaier! Not quite as good as his wonderful Euphoria, but pretty close! And although it has Euphoria-like elements, it strangely reminds me of a cross-breeding of Polis and Age of Empires! Indeed, it reminds me of a lot of games; and that's the only problem I have with Scythe:

I love games which incorporate tried-and-true mechanics, but have an added twist to them which breathes new life into the old mechanic. I can't really find such a twist in Scythe. However, since all the mechanics work impeccably well (and one's turns are super fast), that doesn't make Scythe a bad game by any stretch of the imagination; but it does prevent me from giving it a straight 9.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The game has no arc. It has an anti-climactic and abrupt ending. There is a serious runaway leader problem. I can usually tell who is likely to win halfway through, and there is rarely anything anyone can do about it. This is largely because the methods of interaction in this game are so extraordinarily unsatisfying.

You can "attack" people, but only occasionally and situationally will you really hurt them. Combat feels empty and flat. There are rarely serious consequences to losing a combat. In fact, good combat decisions are virtually always pre-scripted if players are playing competently. It's an incredibly important and yet lifeless aspect of the game.

I'm not saying scythe is all bad. It has a unique character and some interesting euro decisions. But I believe that scythe is also about an inch deep and a mile wide. It looks and feels epic. But the weight of decisions are somewhat flimsy and largely about being slightly more efficient than the other guys and gals. The asymmetrical player boards are all different flavors of the same thing. Practically the only difference from game to game is if your faction synergizes especially well with your player board or not.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
An interesting game with some lovely mechanics, beautiful artwork, and game play that is neither too complicated nor too simple. Though it is not without its flaws.

You control a faction that has to farm resources and build mechs and buildings in order to gain victory stars. Play ends when the first person gains thier 'n'th vistory star. All players then recieve money for each building, mech, farmer and territory that they control, the amount you gain is dependant upon your poplarity. The winner is the person with the most coin at the end.

Once you understand the mechanics of the game it runs very smooth and each persons turn is very quick, the only 2 downsides I can pick with this game is that there is too little written on the encounter cards. I can see how they are trying to let the artwork tell the story but it only really works for the person that takes the card.
The other downside is that I don't feel like the spending of resources is properly managed. There are 4 upgrades that you can spend resources on and 4 resources to spend. Each upgrade costs an amount of 1 specific resource, meaning that certain resources quickly become redundant. It is a small gripe but it doesn't feel right. Why doesn't a mech cost 'X' metal + 'y' oil? Why is it just metal? Why does a building only cost wood? Why not wood and metal and food?

Despite these 2 gripes it is an engaging game that is beautifully made with a lot of love. Overall it's a great game that will hit the table in the future.

RATING: 10
I'm a Kickstarter backer who couldn't be more satisfied.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have only owned Scythe for a couple weeks now but have somehow managed to convince people to play it with me roughly 8 times already. I have played with 1-4 players so far, played with each character and action card at lead once, and have taught the game several times now.
Here's what you need to know:
There is little to no "chance" in this game. Other than the randomization in setting up the game (which is optional), the only luck is in some of the card draws (combat cards, encounter cards, factory cards) and even those will certainly not determine your fate. Ultimately this game comes down to strategy and a better player with a better strategy wins.
The solo mode is awesome. It works extremely well and, once learned, can be fast paced, challenging, and novel each time it is played. The autonoma is not crazy and unpredictable, but rather follows a general strategy consisting of building up, then crossing the rivers, then moving in the direction of the factory and you, and then getting aggressive real fast. While it may seem as though having a general pattern like this would cause repetitive gameplay, it doesn't; it simply makes the autonoma more like a smart strategic player who does what he needs to do to win and keeps the pressure on you to play well or play dead.
Explaining the game is surprisingly easy, though admittedly an involved process. All of the gameplay in Scythe thematic, meaning that nothing in the game exists just to make the game function, it all legitimately fits with the theme well. This results in much of the mechanics being very intuitive and memorable because it makes sense that it would be that way in real life.
Though the game is intensely strategic, I have found that non-game-geeks can actually really enjoy it. Several people I have played with have finished the game with a comment like "I usually can't sit down and play a game like this for more than 20 minutes without getting bored out of my mind, but this was actually really fun!" 
It doesn't have to take 2 hours. In fact, only one of my playthroughs thus far has exceeded and hour and a half (not including explanation) and that was a 4 player game with 2 new players and everyone was a game geek. Most of my playthroughs have taken around an hour, and probably could have been shorter if people knew the game well. You can really decide the speed of the game by how aggressively you play; if you just push to get stars as quickly as possible, it is conceivable that the game would end in 45 mins.
Overall, the game has been nothing but a good time so far and a great challenge. I look forward to many more plays and I will very likely buy the expansions before too long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Due to hype my expectations for the game were high. The game has outstanding production quality, but otherwise it didn’t feel any special. Scythe tries to be robust by having the same kind of controlling mechanisms as used for example in Terra Mystica. In the game you keep forgetting to use your benefits, since they are not given in clear phases as in TM. Scythe tries to be thematic in its fantasy world, but the theme is basically integrated to the plastic components of the game. Also, you expect Scythe to be conflict oriented game. However, the number of combats is limited since after the second successful battle there is really no point of attacking anyone.

RATING: 6
A well designed, 4X civilization builder that reminds me of both Eclipse and Clash of Cultures, which are both very worthy designs.  Of the three, I might actually prefer Scythe which is saying something, in part, because I like the variable starting conditions and the way victory points are distributed at the end using popularity, objectives (stars), hexes controlled, and resources controlled.   

The art is dystopic, appropriate to its theme, and the components in the collectors edition are top notch.  Combat seems to be dialed at about the right level.  Our five player game played surprisingly well for that player count.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Like Concordia, I can see why this game is so popular.  The mechanics and theme are very well thought out and integrated.  Also like Concordia, I didn't particularly enjoy the experience.  In this case, I was so stressed out playing it to really enjoy it myself.  I was really turned off by watching "enemy" mechs stare down all my workers, threatening to run them off, etc.  For some reason, I just couldn't detach myself from the theme to really enjoy it.

RATING: 8
So far I've enjoyed every playthrough of Scythe. Yes, gameplay is solitaire at the first half of the game. Yes, certain faction - player mat combinations can be easier to figure out than others. Yes, combat is not a tiny bit exciting. However, these facts are not flaws. These just make Scythe what it is. A very well thought out, solid design. A fun game with very high component quality even compared against contenders at the same price point.

I still have to play a lot more to explore Scythe as I haven't even tried Polania yet. Let's see if it'll live up after a few more plays.

RATING: 9
Great action selection game with some gorgeous artwork. The rules are deceptively simple. While it's a resource management game at its core, there's a nice little twist with the resources are stored on the board itself which can be stolen by opponents if they get desperate or if you let too much of a good thing accumulate in one spot. While it looks like this might be a combat-heavy game, it takes a back seat to the rest of the gameplay.

RATING: 3
Rating after one 2-player game:

Wow, I'm astonished at how little I liked this game. Although it doesn't take that long, I was very bored and fed up with it after the first half, already. The game is a quite dry euro - something I usually don't mind at all - fiendishly disguised as a gunblazing ameritrash game. I was aware of this fact beforehand but could not get over this disconnect, nevertheless.
Nothing in this game excited me. Most actions fall into the categorie "pay some, get a bit more of something else", or move (with the potential threat of combat). Combat also does not spark any tension in this game. Worst case and your workers and mechs get pushed back.

Some of its charm is intangible, since there is nothing terribly innovative about the mechanics themselves, but Jamey has hit a home run with this one! Can't wait to play again.

RATING: 7
Had the pleasure of being taught this one by the designer himself. Hard to track triggers for bonuses based on actions others take, as well as generally knowing what people are doing and what their capabilities are unless they fully "narrate" their turns. Instinct is that 3P would be the perfect count if the map were shrunk for it, but it also looks like that would require a house rule. Combat was rare with our group, and we had a semi-broken "re-use a factory card" combo in play. I'm nit-picking a bit because these are the only parts that really stand out to me, the info and the sizing. On the whole, a very solid game that I'd gladly replay. And on a second, I took a step back in performance and immediately wished for a redo because now I may finally get it. It's growing on me.

RATING: 10
Best kickstarter experience ever.  Received this weekend - earlier than expected.  The production is amazing.  The quality of the components, the gorgeous artwork, the beautiful board.  

Game play was great - a neat combination of euro mechanics with tactical board positioning, resource management and (at least the ever present threat of) combat.  The tension between players stands out on multiple fronts: the tactical game play, the race for the factory, and the race for six stars.  I love the asymmetry and you think twice about engaging in combat - especially with workers present on the other side.  

I think this game will stand the test of time in our household.  Love it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There are several aspects of this game that I think are noteworthy.  One of the most obvious is the artwork (absolutely stellar) and the production quality (well above average).  As for game play, it is notable for the fact that for a "big" game, downtime is not too bad, nor are turns too quick in passing.  Play time and turn time really hit the mark quite well.  The variable setup in player factions with a fixed board layout is quite good and a nice twist from the normal variable board and fixed players.  It is not entirely clear if everything is fully balanced when you consider the faction combinations and encounter benefits.  So some swings in the game can and will happen.  For a game with more mental input, it could be a deal breaker, but Scythe somehow manages to feel both big box and light at the same time.  It's a solid game and it will be interesting to see how it holds up over time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game. The only reason I am not giving this game a 9 is because Russia is seriously way overpowered, but more on that in a second. I love the depth that Scythe brings to our shelf. Players choose a country of origin to play as, and each country has a unique player mat with an anchor ability that serves as your best-bet strategy. Basically, every country is going to play the game a bit differently. On your turn, you can choose to do one action set. A set is broken down into a basic action (top) and an upgraded action (bottom). The actions are the same for every player, but the actual paired set of actions may be different for each player. If you choose to take both actions in a set, you must do your top action first; however, both actions are optional. Sounds too good to be true? It is. Whatever action set you chose to do on your current turn, will be unavailable to you on your next turn...unless you are freaking Russia! I'm a little peeved about how ridiculous that ability is. Other than that, I love Scythe. Well worth the investment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I spent over two weeks of my life in a warehouse boxing hundreds of copies of this game to mail out to all the Kickstarter backers (you're welcome) so I figured I'd need to get myself a copy.  Here goes. 

A little difficult to learn, especially if you're new to complex Euro games like me, but once you get going, it's a blast. Lots of strategic thinking and management of resources, which changes each game as you are randomly assigned your player mat. Also a very exciting end-game scoring mechanic.  However, it felt a little light on player interaction. 
On my first play through I was disappointed by the costly and not-incredibly useful combat mechanic, but eventually I learned the necessary strategies to make it an effective tool (lots of little attacks/feints, and a liberal use of combat cards. Also, Polania's submerge ability. Fight guerilla style, not all-out war). 
That being said, don't expect combat to ever take the center stage, no matter how good you are at it- it's a tool you occasionally use rather than the basis of the game.  If you want a wargame, this isn't it. 

All in all, a game that starts slow and gets better and faster as it goes, both within each game itself and across multiple playthroughs.

RATING: 6
1/14/18: Played the kickstarter edition with the nice pieces and the larger board.  The bits and the artwork are very nice.  Nice but nothing exceptional.  To me it was clearly inferior to something like Terra Mystica or Eclipse.  Maybe I'm just being a grump because a lot of newer games that I've played recently for the first time of this genre have felt like nothing special.  Once you build everything from one resource, there is absolutely no reason to get any more of it.  To me it seemed that the decisions were going to become relatively simple after a few game plays, and I'm sure that with more plays there will be more direct conflict.  With 5 players the winning score was around 40 (second place was around 20), and the materials indicate that it should be around 70, so maybe we're missing a big part of the game.  

Some good points:  All the kickstarter materials are available from the publisher's website, so if you missed out you are not forever screwed.  I like that people are hesitant to engage in combat, and sometimes you may decide not to put a lot of energy into a fight.  It  plays well with 5 and 7, and kept everyone engaged.

Games that I'd rather be playing than this: Eclipse, Agricola.

RATING: 8
Expanded thoughts after some solo play and three live games: Beautifully made and mechanically interesting euro hybrid. Shares DNA with Terra Mystica and Rex, and belongs in the same family as Hyperborea and Romolo O Remo. Changes dramatically depending on player count - 2p is quite tense and confrontational, despite the board space. 3p becomes more tentative and economic. 5p is a little long, but brawly and a bit more chaotic. It's interesting at all these counts.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As a rule I don't like war games. Usually conflict is resolved by random chance and rarely has something to do with who has managed his ressources the best. Scythe mends that problem for me. 

In what can only be described as a three and a half X rather than a 4X game Scythe manages to make the best euro war game yet. You have to prioritise the right ressources and the right actions to make your strategy count. 

I feel the best way to describe the game is to break it apart in each of the four Xs.

Explore - Your character is going on an adventure, whether he's focusing on a lot of encounters, making it to the factory first or just partaking in combat, he is going to have a fun time. The encounter cards is so beautiful that I would love a poster of each just to hang it on my wall. 

Expand - The fact that you can only move two units one tile at the start of the game makes the expansion part very very slow... and it is brilliant.  Your decision to go to the forest instead of the mountains could be costly or could it?

Exploit - This is one of the best parts of the game because it ties so beautifully together with the other 3 Xs. You choose where to produce resources, but instead of just taking them to your own resource pile you keep them on the board. 

Exterminate - This is the half X. You cannot exterminate your opponent, but you can cripple them. With the slow moving units being knocked back to base is a huge set back and so costly that people will rarely engage in combat where they only "might" win. It has to be dead certain. If someone is producing a lot of resources near your units you can start threatening to take them off him quite quickly. This can escalate quickly into a cold war instead of an actual war. Which is what war usually is, a lot of posturing but the results of actual combat is so expensive that you'll try not to engage unless it's absolutely necessary or you are guaranteed a win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Scythe is a unique American/Euro hybrid that leans more towards the euro-side of thing. For instance, players can attack each other but are strongly discouraged from doing so (If you displace workers, you lose popularity, which reduces your VP). But the heart of the game, which I also find quite intriguing, is the action-selection boards. See, each player has a unique board and a unique starting location. Trying to understand how to string various actions together with the abstract elements on the game board is what make the game feel so puzzley. Combined that with a strong race element, you have a puzzle that feels very tense to play.

So what not to love? For one, the blind-bidding and certain abilities (randomly draw combat card from a opponent's hand) adds silly luck to a rather thoughtful game. But perhaps more influential, certain nation/action-board combinations seem to be easier to play or have more viable strategies. That being said, combat in the game didn't bother me as much as I anticipated. For one, combat is deemphasized but still important as it can earn players starts and can screw with the engine of another player. And because of the strong race-element in the game, having to modify one's plans... because your opponent took a hex with a needed resource... can be a huge annoyance/hindrance. Thus combat cleverly becomes more about posturing than actually attacking other players, which I like. 

Don't get me wrong, Scythe is a well-designed game. For instance, the action-selection boards can be upgraded so that they get bonuses for specific actions that players take... thus encouraging players to focus on what other players are doing, which makes the race element even more palpable. But I'm a gamer with fairly narrow preferences and Scythe manages to be a mix bag of things I love (puzzles) and things I dislike (blind bidding, luck, etc). It's such a rich/unique game that I will still play it... but it's not one that I'm going to proselytize.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Just got the art connoisseur's edition in last week and had my first official play this weekend at our game group.  Two had play tested with me before and had 1 new player.  The game was awesome.  

Everyone loved the components and raved about how much appealing they made the look and feel of the game.  The coins and resources were a particular hit.  Others at the game day kept coming over to pick up the pieces and feel them.  The mini's were also well liked.

As far as the gameplay, the original playthrou9ghs I had were during the play testing phases.  The game really has only gotten better through the process and was immediately one that the group was saying to bring real army for play.  The balance, variable ways to win and uniqueness of the game prompted many unsolicited comments of how praise for the game when we finished.    One of the comments was how rich of a game could be played in a relatively short time.  

Great game and beautiful components.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Végre sikerült Kaszáznom nekem is:) Ez tényleg rohadt jó basszus! Azt eddig is láttam, hogy pofátlanul jól néz ki, de a játékmenet is bejött. Mielőtt elfelejtem: a játékostábla kicsit Terra Mystica (sőt Hansa T.) utánérzés volt. És maradjunk ennél az elemnél: az már eleve nagyon jó indítás, ahogy a setupot megoldották, a bemélyített helyekkel. Az meg a másik, hogy nagyon szuper hogy a piros és a zöld ennyire egyértelműen jelzi hogy mit fizetek, mit kapok, sok játéknál ezt cseszik el. Csak 2 népet láttam eddig, de nagyon tetszik, amit az egyes népekből kihoztak, még a térképes elhelyezésükben is elég nagy a szórás (pl. japánoknál nincs akadály a térkép túlfelére), remélem sikerült kb. egálra tesztelni őket. Az alapkoncepció is nagyon rendben van. A 10-ből 6-ot kell (vagy nem is feltétlen kell a győzelemhez ugye) teljesíteni, sőt pl. a németeknél lehet mind a 6 ugyanaz, ezért tuti sokutas a dolog. A mi játékunkban (ami próbajátéknak is felfogható) is teljesen más irányban tapogatóztunk, mégis 1 lépésen múlt a győzelem. Hiába fejleszt ki valaki mindent az egyéni tábláján, egy vesztes csatán lehet mindent figyelembe véve ~ 20 pontot is bukni, meg bekavarhat sok fajspecifikus dolog is. A csata egyszerű de tök jó, egyedül az volt fura, hogy a döntetlennél a győztes nyer:) Tetszik a középső mező kiemelt szerepe, 5 játékosnál ez tuti sok izgalmat és konfliktust generál. Nem is tudok belekötni, azért adtam elsőre "csak" 8-ast, hogy legyen hova javítgatni még (meg azért, mert nem igazán szoktam 9-10-et adni 1 parti alapján). Legközelebb szólóban is ki szeretném próbálni. A legújabb generációs játékok egyik mintapéldánya: nagy hype, gyönyörű külső, mindent tud amit az elődök, de azért van néhány elegáns kis apró újítás is benne, és tök jó élményt ad. Nem véletlen adják ki magyarul, aminek örülök. 
És a sok pozitívum után egy kis negatívum: a bazi sok kieg:)) Én kiegfüggő vagyok, talán ezért is érint érzékenyen, hogy egy vagyon lesz, ha ezt mind be akarom szerezni. Ami alapból nem szokott zavarni, de itt már az alap játéktáblán lévő 7 fajból is 2-t kiegként vehetünk csak meg. Ritka, hogy már egyből vagy 10 kieggel jön ki egy játék (bár a bgg-n ezeknek a fele csak kellékeknél van fent). Új fajok, szebb pénz, plusz kártya, szebb nyersanyag, stb. Persze őket is meg lehet érteni, elég jó a játék ahhoz, hogy sok bőrt le lehessen húzni rólunk:) A játéktábla növelés is mindenképp ajánlott kellék egyébként.

RATING: 10
One of the best. This one always makes it to the table, and the whole family loves it. Scythe is very well balanced, and just asymmetrical enough to make each play engaging and interesting. 

We have found ourselves saying that this faction or that one is overpowered, but with continued playthroughs we are finding that new strategies appear, making more and more options viable. 

The engine building is amazing, and you really have to stay on your toes. You can make a mistake here and there and still do alright, but you can get de-railed quickly if you aren't thinking ahead.

If you don't have this game, get it. And then get the Invaders from Afar expansion.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.2
Played it at Essen 2016. The game has amazing, beautiful art, gameplay..at least the early gameplay is very streamlined for the expected difficulty and the encounter cards ar so much fun. these things along with the different factions really draw you in the game and you get to feel the atmosphere. Question remains open if combat is up to par and if the game doesnt become to monotone once the best strategy for each faction becomes evident. Depending on that I would increase or decrease the rating for half a star. Overall a great game and only the high price prevented me from buying it.

RATING: 8.6
This is a very nice production, and the game features some nice mechanics, including the restraint on aggresiveness (which calls for smarter military tactics) also seen in games like Eclipse. It also has a unique development system which is not easy to master, something also seen in Terra Mystica. However, I was not ecstatic with the overall gameplay synthesis of these mechanics. Particularly, I dislike the fact that I have to scan the map regularly, either to iterate my resources or to foresee enemy player advancements. I also did not find the game that innovative as a whole. Overall a nice game.

RATING: 7
Not sure if I expected too much but I was a bit disappointed of the gameplay. Some people give 10/10 points but it's really not that good.
Production Value is fantastic, Art work is outstanding.

It does tick a lot of the right boxes. But by the end of the day you want to spend money on a game that you will actually play and this game has only hit the table a handful of times. There are other games I just like to play more often. Matter of fact, I like to play all other games (apart from the Fatansy Flight games I own) more often than Scythe. 

I love to open the box of Scythe. I enjoy the game but that's it. I finish the game , pack the box and put it away. Not in a regretful way but it's not like I feel like to play another round. Other games I own leave a feeling of satisfaction much as Scythe but also an urge to think about the next time I can play this game. 

Scythe... doesn't do that to me. 

If you are looking for a very good ENTRY level game. This is it. I would recommend it as that. Otherwise, you may want to have a few test plays before carving out the money.

RATING: 8
solo approved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Beautiful production that tries to provide a little something for everyone. Looks good and plays fast, although tends to end quite suddenly. There's a nice engine building aspect to appease the eurogamers, and a simple area control and combat system to attract the rest.

The engine building side is much more pronounced: There's very little actual combat in the game, just a constant threat of opponents moving into unprotected areas. Movement seems initially too hard and subsequently too easy - Pretty much all locations on the map eventually appear to be no further than two hexes away because of the numerous shortcuts. This makes visualizing the board situation way tougher than it needs to be.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Special Edition. One five player game in so far. Took about 1.5-2 hours going through the rules and 6 hours playing the game + eating. It's an ok game based on the experience. I would probably have enjoyed the game more if it was designed having more layers in mind. For example, combat could be more interesting, game doesn't have a shared market place where players can purchase items under other players nose and there is no alliance victories. I might still give this game a second play in the future since I think the other gamers enjoyed it more. However personally I feel there exists better games out there. For alternatives, I would suggest looking into Eclipse or Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game (these 2 are awfully long though). For shorter games than those two consider New Dawn or Nations.

RATING: 9
I love Scythe. Beautiful, complex, elegant mechanics, downright cool theme, what else could you ask for?

I'm not so hot on the kickstarter model though.  You can only buy this game right now on Amazon.... for $125... but you still won't get the expansion?  Why would you release an expansion at launch? That should just be included. (especially since it's required to have more than 5 players)  It's just a money grab. It's not a deal breaker because this game is great, but I just don't think the way this game and other Kickstarter games are produced is always a good thing for us, the players.

With that said, I might buy it at $125 and another $25 for the expansion.  It's just that good.

RATING: 9
A beautiful game with some really great mechanics, that I can not seem to win. The main selling point here is with the upgraded realistic resource tokens and metal coins in addition to the gorgeous artwork, you really feel in the moment of the imagined post-war w/mechs vibe of Scythe. 

For the life of me though, I am terrible at this game. I've played it 7-8 times at this point (oct 31, 2016) and am pretty sure I've yet to come in any place but last. The game rewards players for using their factions' abilities to their full potential, but for some reason I just can't quite develop a real skill for the game. Still a great game that's always fun to play, though.

RATING: 6.5
Managed to be part of the playtesters for this game. A truly enjoyable experience as I have never playtested a game before. Thank you for Jamey of Stonemaier Games for the opportunity.

It took a while to craft all the pieces and assemble the parts required for the games. The map was printed on A3 and it was still not enough then I had to cull components from a number of games.

A regret was that I was not able to do more playtesting and I did not get the Art version of the game because the initial idea was that the art book will be separate from the game. Still I am stunned with the quality of the final product. Looking to play again with the final version.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Initial Impression: I've only played with the Collector's Edition and I have to admit that the artwork and component quality exceeded my hyped expectations. The board is colorful and spacious. The card artwork is wonderful. I especially love the indented player boards, something I wish more games would have. Of course, I'm blown away by the resource tokens. The gameplay is very surprisingly quick for a game of this nature, with a deliciously restricting number of options per turn. Keep in mind that this is not a wargame, or even a hybrid. I find this to be a very well tuned, enjoyable euro with war theme. I find that your strategy will be defined for you at the beginning of the game by the faction boards you receive. At that point, it becomes a concentrated game of optimization and a race to accumulate the most VPs before the game trigger ends. Overall I enjoy this game alot and look forward to many more sessions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Scythe is a game that mixes a number of aspects into its game play, including engine building, asymmetric player powers, area control and a sprinkling of combat. The mixture is quite good. It's well-produced, smoothly designed and plays in a reasonable time. The somewhat basic puzzle of optimizing your play in view of the faction and player mats works well in combination with how the board play develops. In the early game, you work on your engine. Towards the end of the game, the board play becomes more important. If you have the right set of players around the table, there's subtle board play to uncover. Add in a well-made solo-mode and you have a very good package. I look forward to playing it. 

Promos/Extras/Expansions:
Scythe: Invaders from Afar (2016)
Scythe: Promo Pack #1 (2016)
Scythe: Promo Pack #2 (2016)
Scythe: Promo Pack #3 (2016)
Scythe: Promo Pack #4 (2016)
Scythe: Promo Pack #5 (2016)
Scythe: Promo Pack #8 – Power dials (2017)
Scythe: Metal Coins
Extra Automa Deck

RATING: 10
Art Connoisseur Edition.

Love the artwork and the overall production quality. The realistic resources are a nice touch.

Euro worker placement, with some player conflict and a good deal of variability depending on the faction and faction mat you are dealt. 

It actually took a couple of Automa plays to see game strategy a little more comprehensively. Even after several plays I only feel like I'm barely scratching the surface of understanding how to play Scythe well. Perhaps I'm a bit of a slow study and perhaps it speaks to the depth of this game, or maybe a little of both. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A terrific game that is definitely worth the hype.  I love that players can decide how best to play the game (passive, aggressive, or in-between) and that most of the game has very little luck involved.  I think the best part of the game is that turns play quickly, and so there is very little down time.  Even though the game takes 2 hours to play, it definitely doesn't feel like it.  Plus, the artwork on the board and the game pieces is awesome; the board itself is basically art worthy of framing!

This said, however, it does take a bit before the game makes sense, and the sheer amount of rules and options per turn can easily overwhelm new players, though I appreciate that the game design keeps players from having to think through too many decisions each turn.  The length of time to play a game (the box is right about that two-hour mark) also means that this will, sadly, not make many appearances at our game table, but it is nice to know that those who have played it like it, and there is the "Automa" edition in case I get an itching to play but have no one to do so with!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.2
Great game, but faction/player board combos can create some balance issues.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
Way overhyped. The game feels like an unnecessarily overcomplicated Terra Mystica and doesn't feel cohesive between early-mid-late game. It's nearly impossible to tell where you stand in points as compared to others until the last turn or two. Granted I didn't understand all of the rules fully the first time through, but the game design made no attempt to make the rules flow any easier. The layout of each player's tableau was so unintuitive, I was genuinely surprised it made it to print in it's current iteration. After an arduous game (where the winner scored nearly 70 points above our competitive second through fourth place players, not all of whom were new to the game), I was told that some of the races weren't even playable yet (or that all couldn't be played at the same time) because an expansion pack hadn't been put out yet. If your game isn't finished, don't publish it. I'll probably give it one last go now that I'm familiar with all of the rules and my friend seemed to enjoy it, but my first experience left the most sour of tastes in my mouth. At this point, I wouldn't recommend Scythe to a friend.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
Where to start?

On top of its obvious excellent aspects like...

- amazing art, theme & well... beauty
- great mechanics, presented visually in an almost perfect way
- superb components (especially with the real ressources)

...it explores sort of new grounds in the genre (which is really inbetween genres) by making the threat of war somewhat graspable and equally meaningful as escalation itself.

We had every of the above mentioned aspects hundreds of times before and yes, even better (except the artwork perhaps)... but the sum of it all is simply a work of art.

A fine-tuned elegant & beautiful machine, where all the important parts are coming & and working effortlessly together.

And just as a personal sidenote: This has been my very first Kickstarter campaign, and even if I observed and backed some more in the meantime, Jamey's campaign has been possibly the best foundation and experience... not only for a crowdfunding newcomer but for crowdfunding in general.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

1) [GameId=169786]: Retail reprint May '17 version.
2) [GameId=199727]
3) [GameId=211731]
4) [GameId=205121]
5) [GameId=223555]

7) Kickstarter [GameId=211733]
8) Scythe Metal Coins : 80 custom metal coins in denominations of $1, $3, $5, $10, and $20. 
9) Board Extension
10) Scythe Legendary Box

All game components from core game, expansions stored in Scythe Legendary Box.

All other boxes (Core Game, expansions) & game inserts thrown away. 

Extra: Core Game box has foam organizer. This enables store core  game & many expansion components with ease in the core game box.

RATING: 9
The hype seems to be real. Though this game has the threat of combat, it is more of a Euro, resource management, engine building game. The art and components are very good. The random setups with the player boards seems to guarantee plenty of re-playability. The stars are a little confusing as one can easily win even if they only have four stars, depending on how they are doing with the rest of their areas. I don't think 7 player is great, though the two new factions are interesting. Adding the realistic resources and metal coins enhances the experience. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love this game. Took a few games to see how good it is. It's a combination of Risk and Settlers of Catan, with all the luck taken out (no dice) and way more complexity and strategy. Lots of paths to victory. Lots of variety based on what character you're assigned. The game design is also amazing.

RATING: 9
Very underrated game, bit of a sleeper hit really  ;-) ( I have 5 plays now).

I just finished a 4 player game with 3 other hard core gamers at a monthly meet up.
I opened up the board, then added the extended board ......there were gasps.
I knew this  game was going to go down a treat with this group and I was very interested to hear their opinions, which I value a lot.

Approx 40 minutes into game play, Ade proclaimed " this is awesome, I want to play it again!" ( that doesn't happen often).

As I said, these guys mop up anything thrown their way and as a group we have played some epic hard core games such as Di Macher,  Rune wars, Dominant species , Terra Mystica,  Magic Realm.

So how did the guys rate Scythe? . "Love it, awesome, give it an 8" , "best artwork I have ever seen in a game - ever!"  another 8. , an 8.5 also . These guys are super mean with ratings so this is very high praise indeed . 

All want to see the "Art book" , which I do not have.

I love the fact that this game can be set up in 10 minutes and took down and into the box is not much more.  

Pros:
It's quick set up
It's quick to groc
Many different mechanisms that seamlessly meld together
Super smooth game play 
It's fun!
It can get tense
Great playtime 
Outstanding components
Breathtaking art

Cons
We don't own the art book (yet)

Fantastic game. Love it.


In full disclosure,  I have an affiliation with Stonemaier games .All comments and opinions presented are my own and I stand by them.

RATING: 9
Beautiful artwork. A+ component quality. And the game is good too! The game is a Euro that hints at its American elements which is a plus for me. If anything the game feels a bit too solitaire-ish (especially at low player counts) but even if you aren't fighting you're still always maneuvering like it could happen. Lots of replayability. The game isn't without it's flaws (semi-scripted opening, end game can be a let down) but I don't consider them major issues. I don't expect this game to ever leave my collection and look forward to playing the expansions.

I love this game every time I play it. I'm hoping Wind Gambit will "fix" the end game issues but even as is this game is great.

RATING: 9.25
Yeah, this is really good. Scythe delivers on a solid, clean, easy to understand design. Yet, you have many tough decisions to make throughout the game. Which strategies to pursue for stars is really intense. We played 3 player with the black faction winning. He was able to get to the Factory first and had a great card which boosted Popularity. Combat is not necessary, but can give 2 easy stars depending on Power and Combat cards. Also, this game is beautiful. The minis are spot on and the board is amazing as well. Easy Top 10 game for me and it will see many plays in the future. And, it has an Automa for solo play! Winner, winner, mech dinner.

RATING: 6
90% of my first play-through was spent staring at my player board. Mechs and character minis are gorgeous but they don't actually do very much. I was disappointed to only get one of my four mechs off my player board and use it only twice in combat. There's a lot more to this game than I experienced on my first play-through and the game will be more rewarding for those who've crested the steep learning curve. However, what I observed was players moving around a lot of little bits, mostly on player boards, in order to accomplish very little on the main board. If this game were more streamlined and more combative, it would be awesome.

RATING: 8.7
have you ever wondered what wwi would be like if everybody had huge mechs instead of poison gas and trenches? well scythe won't show you that.
have you ever played settlers of catan and wished you were playing a better game? well look no further, here's scythe. will says this game is a euro. apparently europeans love to ruthlessly exploit the land and stockpile resources...
i loved this game even though its a euro. however my main gripe is, combat is kinda discouraged. like why do i even have this mech? its for killing shit. not to be a peasant bus. and why do i get unpopular for stomping on enemy peasants? of course they hate me, they're the enemy.
the collectors edition is nice. there's metal coins, well sculpted resource tokens. a massive board. is it worth it? actually yes.  
small children will enjoy the themes of nationalism, militarism, the exploitation of natural resources, and the benefits of serfdom. would highly recommend as indoctrination tool or light weekend fun.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
Very glad I backed this one on Kickstarter. It is that perfect mix of theme and mechanics. On the surface it may look like a war game. But in it's heart it's an optimization/engine building game. It has a pretty steep learning curve but once you get into it, the game becomes a quick game also. So very involved gameplay in a relative short amount of time. Love that. The rules do a great job of teaching you the game and it's always easy to find stuff when questions come up during the game. Even the solo variant is enjoyable!

Then we have to mention the components. Mini's are decent, love the resources, money and dual layered player boards. But the real star in this department is the artist (Jakub Rozalski) who made a work of art for every card and player mat. The art is so evocative and beautiful that it in itself creates most of the theme. When you look at the bare bones gameplay, it is pretty dry. But Jakub's artwork transports you to this alternate reality and adds a ton to the game. Minor component issue: you really need the board extension, the standard board is just too small.

Gameplay: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::star:
Fun/Social: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Components: :star::star::star::star::star:
Rules: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:

RATING: 7.25
By all of the standard gaming norms that I follow, I shouldn't have enjoyed Scythe as much as I have. What I mean is that it follows the standard formulaic Euro mechanics that we have been accustomed to, but the presentation, components, interaction with other players and the fun factor have elevated it into a delightful pastime. It also helps that it doesn't overstay it's welcome and that the design is intuitive and easily explained.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent Euro-style/largely deterministic game. There is enough variation with the different combinations of cards and characters to provide very different experiences and preserved depth with repeated gameplay, further enhanced by the expansion pack. It is complicated to set up and follow the rules correctly the first couple of play-throughs; however, after several games now, it seems to be simpler than Terra Mystica or Eclipse, but with many comparable features.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Kickstarter collector's edition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Tried on tuesday august 2nd - twice!

Aaaaaaand, we have a new "best game of 2016 so far". In all fairness I have barely played any 2016 games, but this one is indeed very good. Looks like the hype was justified. We managed to finish two games in 3 hours and I'm am very satisfied. The only thing I'm not satisfied about is my decision not to back it on Kickstarter. I had all but decided to take the plunge when I heard that one of my main gaming buddies was backing it. Since I already own too many games that main gaming buddies also own, I decided to skip it. On the other hand I want to own the true great games and this looks to be one of them. There are plenty of things to like here:

- Production quality is top notch. Sure, gameplay is more important, but production quality enhances your gaming experience. At least it does to me. This is a great EURO with quite a few miniatures! How awesome is that? I love miniatures but usually don't like the trashy games that has them. More euros with miniatures please! This is a major part of the reason why I will probably end up buying the game.

- Variable factions. Factions with different powers are awesome. Eclipse or Terra Mystica wouldn't be the same games without the factions and neither would this. Factions create excitement, variability and the eagerness to play the game more to try everything out. In short, I love factions. Furthermore, the upgrade boards are assigned randomly, so its not just a matter of having a particular faction, but also a particular upgrade board. Excellent variability!

- Upgrading. Upgrading is awesome and there are multiple ways to upgrade your abilities here. It is a truly fascinating part of the game.

As I have only played it twice there are also some uncertainties:

- Are the factions balanced? I don't know yet. Also I would hate it if it became so that the faction more or less dictated how you should play. I hope the game never becomes scripted.

- Interaction? I'm sure interaction will increase with more plays, but during the two games we had, I think we were all absorbed with our own game.

- Game length. The game was MUCH shorter than expected. We started at 7PM, talked briefly about some key rules, played the first game, tore it down and set up a second game and played the second game and we were done at something like 10:10PM. As for pure playing time we were probably looking at 80 minutes per game for 4 players. If you focus too much on upgrading stuff, then the other players will finish before you get many stars on the board. In both games we had a player who didn't get a single star on the board at the end of the game.

Anyway, my takeaway is VERY positive. This is a game that will be sure to delight the euro crowd. Time will tell if the game is as good as it appears to be.

Preliminary rating: 8.5

RATING: 9
Excellent strategy and civilization-building style game. I love the asymmetrical aspect of the game. Every faction plays differently and has different advantages they should capitalize on. I feel that the game has the right amount of combat too. Large portions will be a tense Cold War scenario, but the combats that DO happen usually decide a good portion of the game's outcome.

I love the game with 3 and 4, 5 is a bit crowded, I will never bother playing with 6.

Edit: Upgraded rating from 8.5 to 9.0 after several more plays. This has become such an excellent puzzle of engine-optimization. I really love the challenges you're faced with thanks to having a different player mat each game.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played several times at game night, and I have to say while I am impressed, the game isn't exactly my thing. It is very heavy, complex, and lengthy (the box play time is kind of hilarious to our group). I do think it is a tad over rated in the fun department, since the game ends abruptly and has a fairly weak theme in my eyes. With the exception of the Polania Republic class, I never really "feel" like I am a certain type of group one way or the other. It just feels like normal "dudes on a map" most of the time - not a bad thing, just not normally my kind of thing.

However, it is a masterpiece of mechanics and design. The board is stunning, especially if you have the expansion for it. The tokens and wood bits are nice quality, and the game shines even brighter if you get metal coins. The way you determine actions is very inventive and unique, forcing you to think turns ahead of where you currently are. It plays like a well oiled, fascinating machine of economical growth and power. As weak as the theme is, and as dry as it can be from turn to turn, it does become a beast greater than the sum of its parts to me. A fascinating experience, to be sure. 

If you like heavy Euro's, you are going to love this game. Even if you don't, it might have enough on offer for you to find enjoyment out of it anyway.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The hype is real. Get this game.

My only complaint with the game is the end can be a little sudden some times, but i really like this one a lot.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
CE 10516, 
I first saw this game at Essen 2015, but did not get a chance to play in a demo because there were too many people that would get to the table first. The kickstarter for this game came out soon after Essen and I pledged for the basic edition on my first time. After working out the pros and cons of "do I want realistic resources or not, metal coins or not, extended board or not" I finally switched my pledge to the collectors edition, and I am so happy I did. All the components are fantastic and now I have one of the rare collector's edition that many people are wishing they had. 
Made by the same designer as Euphoria and Viticulture, you can see some of the elements that worked so well in the aforementioned games put into Scythe.

RATING: 9
I love this game. Almost 100% strategy and little luck, outside potentially getting a sub-optimal setup. Great production qualities and atmosphere. A lot going on, which keeps it interesting.

I can't give it a 10 for two reasons:

1. It's not for the faint of heart. Hardcore gamers only!

2. If you get the wrong people playing - the "analysis paralysis" types - the game can take 4+ hours and nobody has fun. The funny thing is, it's usually the fault of the people who are MAKING it no fun by not playing expeditiously.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Initial Impressions:
-------------------------
Interesting optimization game with some of the best art ever put into a game.  The combat system sure seems like blind bidding, and I am not sure I like that part of the game very much, but the combat really ends up not being the most important aspect of the game.  The decisions are tough, and there is an interesting mix of objective cards, encounter cards, structure bonus cards, and faction / player boards to keep every game feeling different.  This game is more Euro than anything, but it does a nice job trying to fit in a theme, and also be a dudes on a map game.  Keeper for sure (the components in the collectors edition are unreal), and would be shocked if this didn't make my top 10 of 2016.  Played well at 2p, and very interested in trying it at the other  player counts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I waited to complete 5 games before rating so to not fall for the hype. We played only 2 player games so far (some back to back). The rating could easily go up for multiplayer games (or down with time).

Whilst there is nothing unseen before, the mix of mechanics works very well. The theme is very strong and well integrated for what is a Euro-game about maximizing efficiency at it's core.
The game encourages, but doesn't force aggression and the amount and importance of combat completely depends on the players.
Component quality is great except for some peeling edges on the player and faction mats.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Love the game, very much lives up to the hype, a shame some anti-hype people hace started to dislike it almost because of its popularity
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first play through was with a group of 3 strangers, with none of us having played the game before. 

We were lucky to have a seasoned player nearby to help us get started and explain rules and tactics along the way. I recommend having someone like this in every first play through. Short of that, setting up and just diving into the game is the next best option.

It is a complicated game to learn but a very fun one to go on a journey with, especially since watching players figure out different tactics produces many "a-ha!" moments in your own understanding of the mechanisms behind the game. 

It does take a few turns to get a fair handle on what to do and how to go about it. The wonderful thing is that even if you have no idea how to play strategy when you start, once you finally formulas one it isn't too late to play it and feel the benefits of it. 

After the game was over our group had a great time discussing what we learned and how to do better next time. 

really fun game and highly recommended. Also very pretty.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Absolutely AWESOME ! I take away 0.5 point because they don't have the 2 remaining factions in the core game box. Don't waste your time on reading this comment.Go get it now. 

The whole package is right here... Area control, War machines, Cool art work, a hybrid between Ameritrash and Eurogame with just a little downtime. 
 
Two thumbs up from me.
