=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The variable player powers feel imbalanced (including base powers and mech powers), the exploration cards are too luck heavy (e.g., getting the sweet pay $4 for a mech card in the first round is huge), and the tech advancement feels clunky.  The center hex bonus of getting a new personal action (factory card) is a big deal, and it's hard or impossible to stop the leader from grabbing the best factory card quickly because movement is so heavily restricted early in the game.  The game seems wrought with rich-get-richer problems since players that get an early lead can begin to steamroll the map (with extra dudes and +1 movement) and race through the tech tree (player board), while other players scrape to get by with little/no catch-up mechanisms.  There are too many assymetric powers to memorize and guard against.  Also, it tends to be advantageous to pick on the weakest player(s) to earn cheap/easy stars for combat.  There is definitely a game here, but one that needs to be studied and perfected based on the silly assymetry and fixed/viable strategies for certain factions (e.g., blue seems to be weak unless played a certain way).  I just don't have the time or interest for this level of devotion to a game, and I'd rather play something that is less punishing for someone who doesn't know or doesn't follow the natural/optimal strategy for their faction.

Note to self:  There also seems to be an imbalance toward going "all or nothing" with production considering the steep costs of deploying mechs and building structures, meaning that you're better off keeping several worker dudes together in a single hex to make gobs of one resource rather than collecting multiple piles of goods that need to be defended and could allow you to do 2-3 different secondary actions.  It's just too hard to defend resources, and the game mechanics are too slow to make it a viable approach.  By the time you get to do all 3 actions and bonus actions and build your production engine, an opponent's army of mechs is probably knocking at your door.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've had three plays (one of which was solo) and I'm now confident I can rate this a 10. Is this the perfect game? Probably not. No game can be all things to all people. However, this one ticks so many boxes it comes out on top. 

Scythe delivers 80% of the epicness of Runewars or Mage Knight in under 2 hours playtime. This alone means its going to hit the table 5x more often than those games. The game is thinky and strategic rather than laugh-out-load chaotic. The infrequent combat is a big advantage with my kids where battles invariably leave someone in tears (I'm not talking figuratively). Games start gently with players building their economy. Towards the endgame the play becomes quite tense as players bang out stars and people are scrambling to maximise their endgame scoring position or exploit an opponents weakness.

Clearly the theme/art/components are gorgeous. The game-play doesn't break new ground in any one area but remains excellent in all areas. This game is the ultimate all-rounder.

Probably the weakest aspect of the game would be at low player count where the player interaction is low and the finite range of starting setups (25 faction/action mat combos) and lack of randomness in play means that it could get a little stale. Still, I'm a long way from experiencing this myself and there's an expansion already scheduled for the end of the year which will increase the faction/action combos to 49 to boost replability. At higher player counts, player-player interaction means games can take unexpected turns and replayability will be unlimited.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.25
Scythe is a solid game with a bad theme/mechanics disconnect. At its core its an efficiency optimizatioh game. You're doing a set amount of actions on the map and you're trying to do them in the optimal order. There is conflict to shake things up and interfere with your plans, but it's not a central feature. You're awarded stars for reaching certain milestones and usually that means there's no point in continueing this path anymore. You build a strong produce / build engine and then you ignore it for the rest of the game. You build 4 mechs. You aren't going to use them, but the 4th gives you a star. So you build him put him on a tile somewhere and forget about him. Then you might complete an objective, which meant in our game that you do a weird move action and distribute your pieces in a weird order on the map, and then claim, that you did something important.

Freedom of strategy is rather low. Your starting position and action board encourages a certain optimal path. There may be more variants but in the 1 game I played I quickly figured out that for me there was only 1 opening I should play with only slight variations of going into mid game. Late game means finishing stars from your checklist in order to finish the game and you have some similiar options of where to go there.

It's a fun puzzle nonetheless and I could play it quickly without thinking too much, but I felt it was too long and solo-ish for the depth that it offers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Interest concept and a well crafted game.  Got that mid 1920s Communist Balkans Steampunk feel.  Fun to play, but a bit odd in that you don't really fight each other much.  It's more a game of maneuver and action management than a game of conflict.  It really is a Euro game, so a player looking to fight with their Steampunk mechs may be disappointed.  You CAN fight, but you can easily win and never really be more confrontational than to chase your opponents and their workers off of a few hexes in the course of a game.

It does look gorgeous when set up and the components are very top notch.  I did like it and would play again, but feels like their should be something more to the game.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
With James.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game is a bit on the weighty side, but only because it combines so many game elements and styles to execute a nicely balanced game.  Worker placement determines what actions can be taken in a given turn (by moving a pawn between action fields), and workers on the map determine what source of resources are produced on resource collection actions. Military units are moved around the map in a conquest mechanism that allows the ownership of territories as long as the units remain. Buildings can be placed onto territories to provide a more permanent claim to a territory, though military units will take precedence. And, there are elements of engine builders in play as your capabilities can be incrementally improved throughout the game. Each player has control of a different nation, where each has different "powers" that they can take advantage of.

Combat results in additional victory points for those that prevail, but isn't a necessary element to achieving overall victory, and units are only relocated, not destroyed when a loss in battle occurs.  Many games, especially those with a smaller group of players, can be completed without a single battle taking place.

With the Invaders from Afar expansion, up to 7 players can play at once, though that can get a bit crowded and end up taking a long time between your turns in that situation.  The expansion also adds in two new nation types with different behaviors provided for each, so even if you are not interested in 7 players, it does offer some increased play variety with those two new nations.  Plus, you get to make use of those two starting locations that are on the map that you already own.

Overall, this game offers a wonderful balance of game play, given how complex it is, and how many ways can be used to achieve victory. There is some element of "run away leader" that can take place, but leading nations do have some added costs given to them that makes performing some needed actions more expensive and can allow other players to catch up if they don't neglect their own development.

Finally, the art work, as shown in the images attached to this BGG entry, is amazing in detail and quality.  There are little "easter eggs" scattered throughout the map that are fun to find, and the overall "look and feel" of this game, with the detailed models as well, greatly enhances the experience of playing this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
120
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Very pretty game that had my attention from the start. Now that I've had a chance to play I'm glad I invested in it (not the cheapest game by far but you get a lot in a big box). The comparisons to Terra Mystica are quite appropriate in the way the pieces move about your Action board unlocking  and modifying costs and benefits. The resource management aspects have a familiar feel. This game involves area control as well but has the extra element of combat missing from Terra Mystica. Both games have a lot of moving parts and faction specific characteristics to be learned and exploited. Scoring is via ongoing accumulated money plus an end-game scoring which converts game elements (stars, controlled hexes and resources) into further cash - the most cash deciding the winner. Our game  went over three hours but bear in mind we were five players all brand new to the game; so, as usual, i expect the game time to come down.

One caveat to that game duration prediction is the mental mini-max player who, unless he is super fast at mental arithmetic, can slow the game to a crawl toward the end if he laboriously calculates where everyone is and recalculates everything in response to any number of final moves he may make in order to maximize his final position. The question many players will eventually have to contend with is: do I pull the trigger now (just because I can) or do I hang fire for another turn or so in an attempt to maybe pass one more player or maybe even win? Sure, lots of games have that aspect but it appears that this game is especially so owing to the way the end of the game is triggered (placing the sixth star ends the game immediately). Still, I enjoyed the first play (partly due to winning I expect) and look forward to learning more and exploring the various action/faction board combinations . 

One big issue always is staying power - will this game stand up to repeated playings? I've played Terra Mystica a fair number of times and it retains its interest, and I hope the same will be true for Scythe as well..
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Not the 4x I was looking for that's for sure. Play is smooth and easy to explain, which makes it great for clubs or situations where you have to explain a game to a new player (seemingly every time you break a game out). I like the way development is on your board and just works with minimal book-keeping. However the overall game feels less than the sum of it's parts.

It's too euro and too tactical for me - you can't really go in with a plan as that depends what faction you get but the multiple paths to victory are really just the same called different stuff (ie. you do the same thing to get them), and the map is too symmetrical - by the end everyone can get everywhere so there's little point in having any variety as it doesn't matter.

Overall, I'd play it but no desire to own or seek out a game.

*** Update, dropped rating to a 4 as I'm done with this (after 4 plays), first play it was 'ok', 2nd/3rd felt samey, by the fourth I'd had enough, it's too heads down, too euro, too tactical. The asymmetry is nice in theory but doesn't impact much, the missions you get that supposedly give variety don't seem to matter. Probably worse aspect is I think all 4 games felt the same, you have to get resources, you have to build mechs, you have to explore and put a few buildings down ... everyone does that, and just when you're at the point when interesting stuff could happen the game is over with 6 stars. If I'm going to play this sort of game I'd much much prefer Terra Mystica, where the races really do make a difference.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
10x10 2017. Really interesting combination of dudes on a map area control with light combat, engine building/resource production, 7 different factions with special powers (when including the expansion).  There are also 7 different player mats which are pretty similar but can change your engine building strategy somewhat.  The theme of farming/war comes through very strong.  For example causing opposing workers to retreat decreases your popularity which heavily affects end game scoring so you can use you workers as a sort of shield.  Of course they're also vulnerable if they have a bunch of resources sitting there for someone to steal.  It's a neat push and pull and even though combat doesn't occur that often it does happen in pretty much every game so it's always on your mind.  The mechanism of selecting a pair of actions is really cool- hard to describe but pretty easy to get used to.  It requires some planning in the short to medium term to be efficient.  The game encourages you to pursue a bunch of different things at once so you'll need to succeed in several different facets to win.  So your strategy is always sort of "do everything (or at least 3 or 4 things) and do it efficiently" you can't just say I'm going to just do combat this time for example (unless you are the Germany faction).  I love the setting and art- in fact this is my favorite art in any board game.  The encounter cards are cool and the game tells a bit of a story if you let your imagination get into it.  One of the uncommon cases where the hype was right.  Fantastic game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Awesome game with very little luck involved.  The map is well designed and laid out perfectly as to not give one faction an advantage over the other.  With a lot of board games I play I find myself "house-ruling" certain aspects of the rules I don't agree with or like.  Not with this one.  A game based on skill, there is a lot of room to improve how you play from game to game.  I own the Invaders From Afar expansion which gives you access to all 7 game factions.  We had one seven player game with the board extension which was truly epic.  There are so many ways you can win, and with the different combinations of player mat vs faction board there are a variety of strategies to employ.  The art and theme are fantastic. The single player Automa mode is challenging.  Had to play several times before I was able to beat it on normal difficulty.  A game like this; easy to learn, hard to master, great theme; will see my gaming table many, many times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Played this with Jamey Stegmaier at GenCon 2015. Was so excited to get our copy after the Kickstarter!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Currently in my top 3 "New to Me" of 2017 games.  

It's a modern euro race game where winning the race may not make you win.  Players score points for controlling territory and getting stars with each multiplied by how "popular" the player is.  

As soon as someone gets 6 stars, the game ends immediately.  So, as the game gets close to the end, there's some jockeying as players try to increase popularity and territory control at the same time that they try to trigger game end (and deny the other players the chance to do the same).  

A lot of people say this is multi-player solitaire, but I don't see it at all.  The first two or three turns (each turn is a micro-action), players are just worrying about themselves, but by turn/action four or five, players should already be bumping into each other.  If one player has bumped up their military and the other player hasn't, battling can be an easy star (or two).  This continues till the end of the game as players generally lose military might when they get into a battle (win or lose), making them vulnerable to other players and, potentially, causing a quick retreat from the contested area.  

but, this isn't just a war game.  Lots of focus on producing goods and gaining popularity and even a little bit of abstracted exploration.  Absolutely love this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
CABS 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Played only solo so far.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Beautiful game with great mechanics. You can tell how much love with into the design of this game. Highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Scythe is presently my favorite game. The map and artwork are engaging and the gameplay is fun and interesting. Despite the fair amount of strategy, the game moves well at any player count. The different factions and player mat keep things fresh, and expansions enroute will only add to the variety. This game rewards planning, efficiency, and a sense of timing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Scythe puzzles me.  I really, really enjoy playing Scythe and yet have a hard time saying exactly why I enjoy it so much.  I think this is because Scythe comes together really well for me, so that my enjoyment is somehow more than the sum of the things I like about it. 

I like that Scythe's actions are relatively small, which allows the play to move around the table quickly.  I like that you have to do a different action each turn, so the game asks players to constantly think several moves ahead in order to be efficient.  For example, I know I want to move toward an encounter, so I take a turn to get resources to be able to use the bottom action paired with my move action.  I really like the variable player boards and faction boards that make each game different and make each faction play differently.  I think they have been balanced very well to provide a different feel without giving an unfair advantage.  I like the tension between working toward end game goals (stars) and in game money - I think the way money is used in this game is brilliant.  And, of course, the theming and production of Scythe is over the top awesome.  

My main quibble with Scythe is the ending, which is abrupt and can often come as a surprise.  It feels unthematic and a little disorienting.  I have yet to have any clue as to how I am doing before the scores are totaled - I have won when I thought I was behind, and have been hopelessly at the back when I thought I was ahead.  This is at least partly due to my own inexperience, but it is also because of how end game score is calculated - the game asks you to place stars throughout the game, but they are only maybe 50% of your total score.  So doing well demands that you keep careful track of where the rest of your score is coming from, and make sure to optimize that too.  

Overall, Scythe is a game I will probably always want to play.  A great experience in 2 hours or less.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
SOPHIE
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
K tarot - 70/120mm, Standard USA - 57,5/89mm
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Un estupendo juego de exploración y cumplir objetivos. Lo que más me gusta es la inmediatez del turno. Lo único que hay que hacer es escoger una acción (y opcionalmente ejecutar la siguiente acción asociada).

El juego es asimétrico (tiene siete razas diferentes con habilidades propias). El panel de acciones también es diferente para cada jugador. 

Hay bastante interacción y el juego en realidad es una carrera. La partida termina en el momento que un jugador obtiene seis estrellas (que se pueden conseguir diversas formas).

Es adecuado para jugones. Muy entretenido. Partidas dinámicas entre dos y tres horas. Si se sabe jugar y se es rápido, a 4 jugadores se puede jugar en hora y poco.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Es un juego ambientado en unos hipotéticos años 20 de postguerra en el que cinco potencias (hasta siete con la expansión) luchan por tener la hegemonía de la europa del este. La ambientación tampoco es gran cosa. Cada jugador tiene una combinación de tablero de potencia y tablero de acciones. 

En tu turno, sólo puedes realizar una acción (colocar el trabajador en una casilla del tablero de acciones).  Y al hacerlo puedes optar por no hacer nada, realizar una acción de la parte superior o además, la de la parte inferior. 

La asimetría en las potencias y en las combinaciones de potencias/tableros de acción dan una enorme rejugabilidad. El juego termina cuando alguien consigue colocar las seis estrellas de objetivo conseguido. Se pueden colocar estrellas cuando:
- Cumples una carta objetivo secreta
- Ganas una batalla
- Desarrollas todos los merch
- Haces todos los updates
- Completas todos los alistamientos
- Construyes todas las estructuras

Hay dos tracks en el juego que son importantes: El poder (sirve para los combates, básicamente) y la popularidad, que básicamente es un track de multiplicación para otros parámetros del juego.

Al final del juego, todo se convierte en dinero (territorios ocupados, estrellas conseguidas, materiales, etc) y  el que más pasta tiene gana.

Está muy entretenido. Las acciones son sencillas, pero dan mucha profundidad al juego. La asimetría de las facciones (y tableros de acciones) son los que aportan mayor interés.. en buscar cómo aprovechar las ventajas de tu facción, con el tablero que te ha tocado.

Es una delicia para jugones. Para no jugones, mejor no intentarlo. Les va a parecer muy lioso.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The more I play this game, the more I like it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2~5人
最佳4人
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
If you like Castles of Burgundy or Agricola, then you will probably like Scythe. I could take or leave those games.

I liked it first play, but felt it would get better. 10 plays later, and the flaws have become more and more clear.

Firstly, it has an interesting action selection mechanism. Fairly accessible due to the streamlined rules and theme. Pretty.

However, despite its accessibility, setup/rules explanation takes longer than you would like for a game of this weight. There's enough minor randomness that it's annoying, and it's questionable why it's even there.

The variable player powers are some of worst I've ever encountered. Plenty of games have boring powers, but these are totally artificial, made to break rules that are only there to be broken. I wonder how fun Scythe would be if you remove the penalty for attacking workers, made combat stars limitless, or got rid of the obnoxious starting islands completely.

And the coup de grâce. There is little to no interaction. Combat is at best rare, and pretty much optional if you want it to be. And that's it. There's no other form of interaction. You gather resources, shuffle around cubes, rinse-repeat, maybe attack a lone mech for a quick star, then the game ends.

I sound like I hate it. I don't. It's fine. But it's just another game in a long list of low-interaction point salads, and other games do what it purports to do better.

If I wanted a Euro game with combat, I'd play Tigris & Euphrates. If I wanted a game which involves upgrading bits on your board, I'd play Terra Mystica. If I wanted a mid-weight Euro game that's accessible, I'd play Concordia. Though it's definitely the prettiest Euro game around!

RATING: 3

Overall, I'd rather play a game that includes chaos but make it work (Kemet), or allow for the methodical progress of your grand strategy with minimal interruption (Terra Mystica).

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
We tested this with 3 players now, and I have to admit I'm hellishly impressed.

I skipped over this at Spiel 2016 because at first glance it seemed like there was mostly an element of military territorial control, and those are not just my type of games. Never read up about it either.

After now seeing a few reviews and hearing from friends about it I realized I misjudged this, and I got it.

And I should have gotten it sooner..

The presentation is *gorgeous*, the balance seems to be nice from the little I've tried yet (we had the Poland player dominate during the game but *not* win, which was a nice reversal), and the playtime/setup is less obnoxious than I thought it'd be for a game this weight.

Also, and I give it huge credit for this, the way the faction and economy boards combine to change the gameplay experience is great. A worker placement / economy game with a rather epic or 4X-style sense to it, despite still having a rather short playtime.

Two thumbs up. Impressive.

RATING: 9
Kickstarter collectors edition 1243/11320
(with a late buy of the artbook)
Legendary Box

sleeved

This is the most hyped game I've ever seen...and I jumped on the Kickstarter-train with a very expensive ticket. I hope I don't regret it.

I unpacked the whole thing.
Wow that looks pretty cool. Too bad I didn't order another set of realistic ressources and another set of coins. I like the components. They are really fantastic.

My only negatives are:
-the blue coins. I don't like the color.
-the design of the combat wheel (I would have preferred a design like in Dune or anything from FFG where the number shines through)
-my boards warp a bit but not too bad. Nothing that needs to be replaced.

That's it.

The artwork is absolutely beautiful. I like it so much that I ordered a picture of it to hang it to my wall.
[EDIT: By now I have four pictures on my walls.]

The rules are well written and the design is very elegant. Nothing is dispensable. Perfect.

The gameplay is simple and fun and intense and diverse.

I don't want to continue the hype but Scythe really stood up to it and Jamey Stegmeier showed how it's done once again.

RATING: 6
COllectors edition ks 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
An interesting, surprisingly light Euro-Ameritrash hybrid. I say "surprisingly" because, despite all the bells and whistles in that huge box, the game at its core is a pretty simple area control game with some neat, easy-to-understand scoring mechanisms. I love that you can score points for doing all sorts of things, making combat only one small part of the gameplay. In this regard, the game reminds me of Eclipse: apart from some small skirmishes, players generally spend the game diversifying as they gear up for the aggressive endgame.

If I had one complaint, it's that the goals are a little too easy to get, and are mostly fulfilled by all players the end of the game. So, by the end most people will have built all of their mechs. Most people will max out their workers, etc. 

I wish there were more ways to specialize (i.e. to score more points within a particular strategy), and thus vary your strategy from game to game: so, a "mech strategy" would incentivize going heavy into mechs early, and then provide more ways to score with them. A "worker strategy" would do the same within that track. As it is, each play of this feels kind of "samey."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A good game but it tends to play pretty solitaire. As it turns out, through several plays there is rarely any competition for territory and therefore combat is typically done for the star and not out of necessity. Would like to have seen that element added. Otherwise a cool engine building game.

RATING: 10
Waited 2 years before playing it and putting my hands on it. I don't really follow hyped games and ignore games that take longer than 60 minutes to play since I rarely have the time to play longer games. I mostly play with my wife but I started playing games solo like Pandemic Iberia and discovered how fun it was even just playing by myself. So I searched for some of the best games that play solo and multiplayer and Scythe was the one that interested me the most. I debated a lot over Viticulture but I already have worker placement games. Since I got it I played 4 times multiplayer which was awesome and so easy to get into and teach. The game goes by so quickly you don't even notice. After 2 hours I wanted to keep going. I also played 2 player in exactly 1 hour and that was also really fun. Then I played solo and found that learning how the Automa works is really easy and fun since you still play like in a multiplayer game. I am so excited to play with multiple Automa once I'm faster at playing the Automa's turn. Overall this is an excellent game that plays in quick for this type of game and simple but deep strategic game play. Plus I love the world it's sets in. I want posters of some of the artwork.

RATING: 9
KS Pledge with board extension
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I won my first game (or should've if the rules were explained properly/enforced about placing buildings). But why would I not need or even want to play scythe again? It's a very smooth euro, great production, escalating engine, contains all the mechanics you would want. But because of what it seeks to deliver, ie a stellar euro, I have issues with some parts of the game. 

1. The output randomness of the encounter cards. Yes there are 3 options. But there's no denying that there will be some options which are optimal for some boards and sub-optimal for others. 

2. Which links to the second problem of the assymetry. Scythe as many have stated seems to be an efficiency engine of your top board and your bottom board. And unless you draft (which seems silly and unnecessary) you will find that some board pairings are better or just instinctively more suitable to some players than others. Yes I know it's been playtested to death. But I think Scythe was meant to be a euro that wowed you on its first play and enticed you to play more and had the legs for more plays. I think it fails on the first count because people can have such varying first experiences. 

3. It gets boring. Yes we played 6p so downtime was probably more than anticipated. But again, everyone felt like they were waiting for their turn and worse, everyone was staring at their boards instead of the map in the middle. As stated many times, scythe is not a 4x. It's not close especially when one can ignore the map (turtle) and win. 

4. I think i have issues with the popularity and combat stars. Particularly that you can't lose the star once you obtain it. Yes, it's a race. But the popularity track then becomes infinitely more important than the combat because it affects end game scoring. Hence, it favours the player boards that enable cheap popularity bumps towards the end of their engine (that's my gut feel). 

I say this knowing I only had one play. But knowing that I'll be ok without a second.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My very first impression was 'this board game is huge, where should I store it?' Pretty well summed up how my group needs a bigger table and in the end, we play Scythe always on the floor. Yep, you got it right. We do need always to have more than two mats in order to keep them in shape. Mechanic-wise, I think this game can be seen as refreshing but not yet revolutionary. I like how we should play the game, but there's this lack of interaction between players beside the combat. Economic-wise, it's good that to generate economy, we do not have to be dependent on the dice rolling. Every choice matters. I would like to wait for the expansion, as for now, the replayability is quite low since Scythe has this static and quite restricting yet beautifully drawn map.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played once, not super impressed. Very messy, scattershot, unfocussed design - tons of levers to pull, but in practice extremely constrained choices. An odd mix of an efficiency design with a point salad aesthetic - a ton of tracks and different ways to score points, but an economic development engine that forces you to specialize.

This style of unfocussed design really doesn't do a lot for me. I had just played 504 the previous night, world 468 (Military, Roads, Production). The general feel of the game is actually kind of similar - a sort-of wargame where the main activity is actually building up your infrastructure - but because 504 is such a focussed design, it routinely gives you interesting and important choices and it feels way more engaging. And to be clear, this game (468) was actually not good. Before this I've played at least a dozen different 504 games and they've all been interesting. This was the first one I've played that clearly had some issues, mainly just that it went *much* too long in the face of players flailing with the objectives (games with Military really want to be fairly short). But even so, to me it was much more consistently interesting than Scythe. I'd actually rather play most of the "modern", more interesting Risk variants (Star Wars, Star Trek, Halo) than Scythe. Now in fairness, Scythe is really not intended to be a wargame - it's really a development game with a combat system bolted on that seems to have been designed to be as uninteresting as possible. If the game had any sense it would have stuck to its development theme instead tacking on a half-assed combat system. But it still has a lot of the same feel as a king-of-the-hill wargame.

Having said all this, I think Scythe is decent for what it is. If you like Feld games and 4X games, you'll probably find something here to like; it works, it's not terrible. I just find this sort of kitchen-sink design unappealing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Outstanding!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I really really like this game. I've played it 6 times in 2 weeks. Two of those games were solitaire style against the Automa, the other 4 have been with a group of 3-4 players. I think the game mechanics are really well thought out and designed to make the game balanced and fair for everyone. There is a bit of a learning curve for the strategy. Playing the game is actually surprisingly simple. Playing the game effectively and winning is more difficult. What I mean is each turn is very simple. You choose one action every turn and you pay the costs and reap the benefits. But choosing the right action and then choosing the right way to use that action to reap the maximum benefit is a matter of planning and knowing your opponents and can be challenging for some. There are tons of choices in Scythe and that's what I love the most about it. Everything from actions, to upgrades, to benefits, to encounters, to movement, to combat, is a choice. There is no other game that leaves so little to chance and so much to choice. So a turn is simple but knowing what to choose can be difficult. Very good strategy game that balances economy, power struggle, and popularity. If all you want is combat with random dice rolls than this isn't for you. But if you are looking for a game that brings together the many choices a real leader has to make in managing a military campaign, being popular with the people, infrastructure, recruitment, resources, upgrading equipment, and even politics then this does that better than any other game I have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

fun and gorgeous game.  elegant mechanics and quick gameplay that i really liked though i sort of felt misled by the combat component of the game that was not as interesting, tense, or impactful as I thought it would be.  hope to play again.

RATING: 10
Excellent territory control and resource management game, highly recommended!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Another excellent game from Stonemaier Games! I splurged on the fancy components so the game looks fantastic with the large board, the realistic resources, the minis, and the overall artwork. I love the different asymmetrical factions and mixed player boards for tons of replayability. Definitely a game where multiple plays will be required to fine tune a winning strategy. I wanted to do everything the first time I played and quickly realized that it was not going to happen before someone puts down their 6th star. Looking forward to many more plays!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
Excellent 4x-style hybrid Euro/AT design. It leans the farthest towards Euro of any hybrid game I've played, clocking in closest to Eclipse I would say. Like Eclipse, managing your personal board is a huge part of the strategy as optimizing efficiency and synergy among your actions in combination with the developing situation on the map is the key to victory.

The choose-your-own-adventure encounter cards and randomized player board are the two spectacular elements here that stand out.

Also surprised how dramatic combat is with the combination of Dune/Kemet combat systems. Results can be swingy and brutal, although the outcome for the loser isn't too punishing since units just go back to base in this game (like Kemet).

The only thing I waffle on is the fact that the game provides incentive to avoid combat as you are penalized in popularity (a key VP metric) for attacking farmers. This is a large part of the game's identity and does pose interesting decision points ("Should I push that hex and risk the popularity loss to gain my much needed combat star?"), so it's not a huge issue. 

The setting is amazing and the art gorgeous, but the seams become visible at times when trying to justify mechs travelling through mines to warp about the board or not being able to cross water until you develop proper technology. These aren't deal breakers, just little things which may bother a hugely thematic gamer.

This feels very well designed and coherent for being such a sophisticated game. It's a treat to experience and does so many little things right. From the splendid tactile feel of placing cubes in little recessed player spaces, to pushing mechs across a map, Scythe is quite the game.

-----------------------------------------

Full review: http://geekandsundry.com/reap-what-you-sow-in-scythe/

RATING: 9
De los mejores juegos de mesa que he jugado. Tiene de todo: administración de recursos, control de territorios, manejo de cartas, objetivos ocultos, conflicto directo y, ¡un excelente tema bien adaptado en un juego de mesa! Los juegos del tipo 4X siempre me han parecido de los mejores, y esté me gusta aún más porque el combate no es tan agresivo como en otros juegos, haciendo a este juego un poco más "familiar". RATING: 8
Very fun game, however it is also very complicated.

The board and the faction/action mats make the board game flow easily and game play intuitive, once you know what the symbols mean and how to use them correctly. The board is incredibly well-thought through with each faction having clear advantages, disadvantages and strategies.

Strategy plays a massive part in every aspect of the game; from knowing what moves to take in the future to knowing how much power to wager in combat. It is by far the most strategic game I have ever played. 

My recommendation is to look up "how to play scythe" in youtube before playing or even reading the rule book. Once you know how to play the game and teach others to do so, it is a very rewarding and exciting game.

RATING: 9
Very nice game. 4X Lite. Finishes in about 2.5 hours average. Gorgeous components (full disclosure: I got the Collector's Edition). Smooth rules and systems. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An engine building solitaire game with movement/combat on a shared map grafted on to it. It is a pretty nice combo and it works. The micro-turn concept works well to keep the downtime to a minimum at higher player counts. And I rather like that the way combat works makes war have consequences, and makes you want to hide behind your citizens to make it unpopular to attack. 

It is very well produced and fun to play. I like the encounters, the factory bonus, and the slightly different boards. Lots of nice little touches. I worry about balance in asymmetric games like this, but the differences seemed minor enough that it can't be that bad and there is enough interaction to help it self-balance.

The engine building puzzle is also interesting and seems like the player count will significantly effect how you go about things. And for this to play in 2 hours is impressive. As hot games go, I will take this miles before something like Terra Mystica or Eclipse.

Attacking with the mechs may be more sparse than initially expected, but the tension created by the threat of attack is just as effective for area control and board manipulation. Wind gambit adds significantly to this tension. Love love love this game.

RATING: 5
I can see why people love this game, but it’s not for me. It’s well-designed, gorgeous, and intricate. However, I’m completely over it and never want to play it again after the 4 times I’ve played it. It drags on, and I dislike how little luck is involved, and how other players can just stomp all over my little engine of growth. As an engine-building player, I like games where I can build up my own little economy, as I do with something like Terraforming Mars. I have strong negative feelings about this game - too many rules to keep track of, and too much area control/offensive strategy for me. As a more passive player, I hate how other players can ruin my little engine. I don’t dislike this as much as Mansions of Madness, and I can see how people enjoy it. But it’s not for me, and please don’t make me play it again!

RATING: 7
I want to try this again, but I'm suspecting Scythe isn't going to be a game I fall in love with. It is an objectively fine game, but I found three issues that bothered me. First, with five players, there seemed to be a long time between turns (and I'd expect balance issues with less than five players). Second, I flipped through the objective cards, and there seemed to be some balance issues. Some of them seemed straightforward, others nearly impossible. And last, I felt, at least for my faction, that the game was exciting at first but fizzled towards the end. I was able to plan several turns in advance, and like in Euphoria, each turn gave me little progress towards a goal (despite having unlocked several upgrades). The combination of making little progress each turn, being able to plan so far in advance, and having a lot of time between turns was frustrating.

RATING: 7.4
Slightly overrated in my opinion. 

Scythe is a well-presented strategy game with reasonable game time, approximately 1-2 hours per game. The game comes with astonishing art and well-produced tokens & minis. Sadly I'm not a fan of its game mechanic: too few player interactions, predictable starting strategy and linear gaming experience. RATING: 9
[b]Includes Scythe: Invaders from Afar.
Includes Scythe: The Wind Gambit. 
Includes deluxe action tokens, encounter and faction tokens from Meeple Source.
Includes metal $50 coins.[/b]

Scythe is a game that scratches a lot of my gaming itches. Dudes on a map. slick action selection almost similar to a rondel. Quick turns, various tech options... it all runs very smoothly in a reasonable playing time.

Add to that some straight up fantastic artwork, excellent components and a unique theme, and I suspect this game as the potential to be a long-term keeper and possible favorite.

Update: first play with four players, and it just reinforces my appreciation of this game. Even better, all four of us really enjoyed the game, and it just goes to show that I think I'll be able to get this wonderful game to the table again and again.

I'm a happy Kickstarter backer :)

Update. Five plays now and I'm happy to see that every game has felt different. Scores have been in the 40s and in the 100s. The game has seen a bunch of combat and almsost no combat at all. Scores have been incredibly tight and lopsided.  It really boils down to the collective tendencies that the players bring to the table. My interest hasn't waned.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
The game was playing into 2 phases strategically. In the first phase, players compete with Encounter tokens and factory action cards.  This phase is very intense.  Players are trying to fully utilize their resources effectively to unlock their Meches and get "lucky draw" from the enounter prize.  This is pretty cool.  But after all the encounter tokens have gone, the game goes into the second phase for which I can say it becomes a multi-solitaire game.  The character seems not to be very useful and all players like playing their own production in order to gain VP without or having limited interaction.  I'm quite disappointed about the game switching to such a multi-solitaire mode indeed.  It's quite heart break that the Scythe becomes such an anticlimax game!
Scythe 開局後基本可分兩個階段，第一階段是鬥快搶encounter bonus 和factory 的額外行動列, 雖然抽encounter bonus 都是幸運大抽獎, 總算是緊湊的競爭, 不公平是不太重要關鍵是鬥快捷和好玩。但到場上的encounter bonus 己搶盡, 遊戲變了斷層各自各做自己的追分。變成multi solitaire game.  遊戲變得虎頭蛇尾。有點失望。

RATING: 9.5
Really enjoying this game--even playing PnP with still-under-development files. It seems like a big mish-mash of mechanics and scoring upon first look, but it all gels so well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great design which scales very well, allows a lot of freedom of strategy of winning and with a huge amount of replayability. For example since the options on the player mats are all slightly different and the combination of mats will be fairly unique every time you play there is not it seems a single best starting strategy and your opponents might do something very different to you and still be making the best moves for them. This difference is further reinforced with every faction having its own special abilities and upgrade powers for the mechs and character. Drawing of factory cards, events, secret objectives and building placement bonuses all add to this, as does the fact that there are a lot more possible ways to earn victory stars than it is possible to earn in a single game.

Fantastic that this game scales fairly well to up to 7 players with the expansion as it is often hard to find good boardgames for 5+ players that fit everyones playstyle.

The component quality and design is excellent and the artwork is outstanding.

There is a lot to this game and the only downsides is that the event cards are a missed opportunity to evoke a sense of adventure and theme (passing around the card to look at the artwork is too slow and people quickly lose interest in anything but the reward options). I'd suggest taking inspiration from Above and Below.

The complexity and amount of rules could be considered a negative, but the fact that the game starts slow-paced and early choices are less important than later, as well as the excellent advise and player reference cards for how to approach learning/teaching the rules makes this quite painless for the most part.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
All that Scythe allow you to do is to manage your faction as any other game i ever see on the market. It's easy to gat through its mechanics and the rulebook help a lot in this. It's clearly explained and let the players "discover" the game step-by-step. The diffrent factions with different abilities and the "high-tensioned" interactions with the other players, gives you the sense of an immersive experience which is the target of the producer. Yes, we are in front of a "setted" eurogame, with an awesome rivisited history comes from the Great World War. You can feel the hard work of the producer to get it into play and implement that with the mechanichs. From your movement to the born of a new worker then the crafting of a big and strong MECH, your slowly get more power and influence on a big part of the east Europe. One last amazing thing is the possibility to play it in solo mode, with the "Automa" rules which are included in the core box. That mode add more components into game but allows you to play alone at home, when your friends can't join in. Everything about this game smell like a fresh wind and is so funny have a long night of gameplay on it. So, i advice this game to all the Euro-lovers but also to all of them who love a big game with a spectacular strategy! Like it so much!

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Players must expand their empire, explore the world, exploit for resources, and sometimes bump into enemies. The conflict in this game has a lot of negative impacts and is very minimal. It's a beautiful game with wonderful components.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Cons:
- Takes a long time to teach to new players.
- Some bad decisions early on can be unrecoverable, feelsbadman.
- Inefficient play can feel bad, but is also the main motivator for improvement. If you can't overcome this feeling and understand how to improve, you're just left feeling bad.
- Game can end abruptly and feel unsatisfying.

Best Aspect:
What I like most about Scythe is the variability combined with clear restrictions and goals. 
Most games you are playing a faction/board combination you have not seen before which helps keep the game fresh. When starting the game with a new faction/board combination, you have some clear goals and restrictions placed before you. You are restricted by what hexes you start on and what the strengths of your faction are. Your board has some stronger actions and some weaker actions. Some bottom row actions are difficult to pull off for you and some are easier. 

This helps you think about the game systematically but also in small discrete sections. In fact most things about Scythe make you think this way. You need 2 oil to upgrade, and there are only so many ways to get that 2 oil. If you're set on upgrading, then you have to figure out which of those ways you will take. Unless you're playing red, you can't use the same action twice, so you're incentivized to think at least one turn in advance.

Scythe also has some clear strategies and ways to play that help you offload some of the difficult decision making. Performing a bottom row action is almost always good; plan out your turns to perform a bottom row action every time. Getting a star is good; build that last mech to get a star. Encouraging this kind of thinking helps lead to further strategic thinking. Planning moves in advance, producing only as much resources as needed, being as efficient as possible are all encouraged by the core design of Scythe. 


Other Notes:
- Great player board design. Once you've learned the basics of the game, the board is set up to help you remember what each action does in further sessions. It feels clever and presents information well. For example, moving a cube from the top to the bottom through upgrade clearly shows how a top row action improves and how a bottom row action becomes cheaper. Only Con here is that you might have to pick up the pieces frequently if you don't remember what you gain from removing a piece.
- A little something for everyone. Some area control, economy management, combat, etc. None of them are the sole focus of the game, however, so some may see this as a con. For me it enables a diverse set of players to enjoy the game. 
- Art is great. 

9 and not 10 because I imagine there are optimal strategies for each faction/board combination that can make the game boring or feel solved. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Scythe: Invaders from Afar (2016)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a fun game, but I believe it is overhyped.
The artwork, large board and many playing pieces are great, and it was a lot of fun to try to get stars on the board through building buildings, performing upgrades etc.  However, for a game with heroic characters and war mechs, there was surprisingly little combat in our 5 player game and if anything even winning battles caused a net loss for the attacker.  So in the end, the actual game is a straightforward worker placement/resource farming game like so many others, except a bit crappier. In my opinion the warfare side needs to be made more central to the game.
An odd experience.

----
Update Jan 2017.  Have played 4 times now.  Played a 7 player game tonight, and with all the times I have played, the person who won was the one who camped in a corner and was lucky enough not to be attacked by other factions, usually as a result of geography and luck. I find that somewhat unfair.  It is still a fairly good game.

RATING: 10
Kickstarted.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
4 Plays so far, can't wait for more. One was basically a 2 two player learning tutorial. The three player game was absolutely great. I usually don't go this euro but I very much enjoyed these puzzle like mechanics, and particularly enjoyed trying to take top and bottom row actions on the same turn, deploying mechs and their special abilities, the factory cards, and encounters. Combat is fairly sparse and the system is very simple but it is impactful when it happens. Can't wait to play again. Can easily see this rating going up. Won my first real game on a 3 mech assault on the factory for the final move. 

Update, rating likely staying around 7. Definitely prefer the game with 4+ to encourage interaction. Would like to have a bit more, as this is about as euro as I can go it seems.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I'm not a fan of Stegmaier games. So I really wasn't expecting to like this. And I didn't. But it was perhaps better than I expected, as my expectations were quite low. I simply do not ooh and ahh over the fancy bits, particularly in the souped up version that I played. The game play is ok. It's a pretty standard resource conversion game, similar to other Stegmaier games. But what really kills this game for me is the combat. You have one strength pool for your civ, and you choose how much of it you're going to burn in a blind bid with your opponent. As if that weren't bad enough, each player also has a hand of combat cards, which are also included in the blind bid. This is one of those games where you want to either win by just barely, or lose by a lot. Which comes down to bluffing and double think. Those who like that will love the combat in this game. It's simply not for me. Which is a shame, because the player tableau aspect seemed fairly reasonable. And I will say kudos on the production quality of the player boards. The indentations to keep the cubes in place works great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
One of the best games I've played in quite some time. This really lets players decide their own paths forward, while they agonize over not being able to make all the moves they want to. While there is a combat element, it's not something you ever *have* to do, and all battles are resolved very quickly.

I like the shift in roles and starting resources, so each game will feel unique. The bits are all very nice and the art is spectacular. 

If I have any knocks against the game, it would be that there is a fair bit of downtime with the AP-prone, and the advertised playing time feels wildly off unless everyone is very experienced at it. Can't wait to play again, and will be looking to get my own copy soon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Scythe was at least somewhat of a positive surprise for me, although it violates my general gaming preference #8 (see my profile) in that it is partly about singling out particular opponents to attack or maybe cooperate with, bringing with it the issue of kingmaking. So far it looks like the problem isn't too strong in this game because it doesn't emphasize actual combat that much (but, as has already been repeated often, it is much about the mere threat of combat). Moreover, the problem is partly compensated by the general charm that moving units on a map can have for me.
The main worry I have about the game is that different combinations of faction plus player mat turn out unbalanced, i. e. better combinations might turn out to be too much better than weaker ones. Particularly, at least at first and also second glance, it looks like it might be too unattractive to draw a player mat that has its 3- and 2-coin-actions for the resources that the starting peninsula of the faction doesn't have. Particularly with one of the 3 player mats on which the upgrade action costs 3 oil. Most particularly Polania with the Industrial mat. To not even speak of the overpowered Rusviet+Industrial because that has already been banned semi-officially. However, so far I am still mostly willing to give the game the benefit of the doubt that the (still allowed) faction-player mat combos are not too unbalanced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
STATUS: Keep

Designer: Jamey Stegmaier 

Publisher: Stonemaier Games

Price: 

Player Count: 4 (best)

Notes: 
Scythe is a good looking game with great components, at its heart it is an optimization euro with asymmetric play. It has borrowed a mix of mechanics from various games and it tries to be more than what it is. Game play amounts to no more than light player interaction - which is mostly for area control and combat if required. I found that the combat cards values were a bit to "swingy." Scythe rewards optimization, but ultimately it is a race game, and ends before you know it. You need to be aware of what is happening on the board and be prepared to play for end game from the start. A turn that is not optimized, is a wasted turn. The designer has said that it is a 4x game ... I struggle to see it to be one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love this engine-building Euro hybrid.  

There has been much debate about the "4x" name on the box, and I agree that Scythe doesn't really hit all 4 X's.  There isn't really any "Exterminate" because combat doesn't destroy your opponent's Mechs (or workers).  The loser in combat has to move their Mechs (and/or workers) back to their Faction's starting home base.  That's definitely a hindrance as far as the territory control goes for the combat loser, but it's far from an "Extermination".

However, what Scythe does exceptionally well is engine-building and territory control wrapped up in an immersive alternate 1920s Eastern European history with incredible artwork and beautiful game components.  And that's why I personally love this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I'll only play this game if I'm in the mood. It's a slow-start end abruptly euro game with a small bit of combat that may or may not be exciting. The first few turns highly outweigh the next 70% of the game. There is a notable snowballing effect. Some factions are slightly unbalanced. 

The player mats are ingenious though, and the art is gorgeous with high quality components. It's also a relatively quick game for what it is, which is why it's strange that it feels slow - I never felt excited during games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The single most overrated game I have played. I just don't get it. "It's like Terra Mystica with mechs!", except the mechs don't go around trampling on everything and game play is not as good. It's just a thinly disguised euro-game.

The rule that you aren't supposed to calculate who is winning is stupid. It's supposed to avoid AP and make it easier for new players, but experienced players can tell who is winning without the AP and it just stops a skilled learner from performing well against them.

The initial objectives are unbalanced. Again they are supposed to make it easier for beginners to get started with the game, but it turns out the skill is knowing when to try and achieve your starting objective and when not to. The nature of beginners is that they will try to get their objective regardless as in a game with so many options it's something to cling onto. Then they get upset when by achieving it they've wasted all their turns going off on some sub-par strategy and the game has ended out of nowhere.

The plastic components are terrible. The wooden ones are quite nice though.

There is a warning built into the game. On the quick suggestion card for beginners it says something like "Don't try and do everything. Try and do FIVE or SIX things well".

RATING: 6
Ended up cutting this.

Better with more players, as interaction can mess up what is otherwise a very linear optimization game.  At lower player counts, or with no interference, this is very much an "engine-building-for-engine-building's-sake" game.  

Near the end, you'll be doing things for the sake of doing things.  E.G. Enlisting recruits only to get the star, building a mech or two just for the star, etc.  It seems silly - building a mech should be something cool, but here I'm doing it for no real purpose, just for the star.

RATING: 10
So far, I am really enjoying Scythe!  I have to start off by saying that the artwork is absolutely amazing! (almost drool worthy!)  The artwork really helps the theme come through!  I love the encounter cards - which is probably the best part of the game!  It is fun to share the artwork around the table and then read the choices for each card.

Guess what? Not only is the artwork amazing, but the miniatures are too!  Some of the faction mechs are so cool looking!  I really like how the mechs have been designed to look as they might function.  For example, the white faction mechs can move onto lakes and dive under water and appear elsewhere on the board - these mechs have what look like a submarine cockpit.

Component quality is off the charts!  I love the wooden pieces too!  Every faction's workers are cut differently - and even these are shaped to go with their faction.

Finally, game play is fun!  The rulebook is easy to read and I didn't have a lot of trouble figuring out the rules.  There are a lot of moving parts in the game, so this game takes awhile to teach to new people.  Once players get going, the game starts to move nicely and there isn't much downtime - which is good.
On the negative, I found it challenging to remember some of the rules and make them clear to my friends.  River walking rules (and some others, I cannot think of at the moment) make the game feel a little clunky.  I think with more experience though, this problem will remedy itself.

So far, I really like this game and I am salivating to get it to the table for another play through!

Edit: The solo experience changes my score for this game to a 10! Now after playing Scythe solo, I love the game even more!  How awesome that I can enjoy Scythe by myself as well!  I didn’t feel like I was playing alone.  I could enjoy my individual play as usually experienced with human players because the solo variant is so well developed.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is great.  Very well balance engine building game that rewards you for completing certain actions that really make the game great.  It starts slow with "what do I do first" question in mind but gets better and better each round as you start to unfold your strategy.  Numerous ways to earn points.  Unique player boards and powers gives plenty of replayability.  Combat is fun and challenging but only amounts to about 20% of the game and most near the end of or 3/4 the way through game.  Beautiful board and pieces.  One of my top 3 games.  As always your first play might only be 5-7/10 on rating scale but goes up each play after that once you learn the rules and strategies.  Even if you lose you're thinking about strategies and game play for next play.  A must have for any strategy board gamer.
(other games: Castles of Burdundy, El GRande, Hansa Teutonica, TIgris and Euphrates, Caylus, Dominion)
Ease of learning: 3/5
Complexity 3/5
Cutthroat:2/5
Luck: 1/5
Replayability:4/5

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Enough has been already said about graphic design and quality of the components here. I won't add anything new. Scythe looks just gorgeous and it's a pleasure looking at all of this. There's definitely a reason why you pay so much for the box. Impressive.

I really like the world that is represented in Scythe. Blending hard-working farmers and yellow fields with huge mechs made of steel sounds overly weird in theory, yet it is extremely appealing to me. Here, mechs are more a tool created for purposes of transporting workers and carrying goods, not fightning. Combat appears, but is not that important. The threat of war is in the air, yet rarely those big machines use their powerful weapons. The question is, who will take the first step? Who will risk losing their popularity amongst the men of Eastern Europe only to gain control over some territories or resources?

Don't be misled, though. This IS a game of economy, resource management and engine building. One of many, you would say, but the aspect of area control, combat(honestly, how many euro games have it?), thematic encounters giving flavour and some spicy randomness(great, great art on these ones) and units you can actually move on the map makes Scythe distinguishable from other games from euro universe. This is a game that rarely brings something new or surprising. Instead, it combines a few great ideas already used in other games. The thing is that these mechanics are mixed in a really smooth and elegant way, allowing players to have a very pleasant experience while playing the game. One of the biggest advantages of Scythe is everything being clear, understandable and reasonable. Although there are plenty of rules, new player get them quickly and rarely have any questions. This is also thanks to the excellent action-selection mats that have very intuitive iconography. Having mentioned these, the idea of cubes, buildings and other wooden components that you can put in them is genius. Nothing will ever fall down due to the accidental hand move or something! Other games should have that done the same way(Terraforming Mars, I'm looking at you).

So is this perfect? No, by any means. Scythe is really solid mechanic-wise but not especially outstanding. None of the gameplay elements are jaw-dropping because you've seen all of these already. One of the fresh things is that resources always remain on the territories where they were produced. This simply means that if you don't spend them fast enough and you lose control over the territory where you've gathered them, well, you lose them as well. And your opponent gains them, which is even worse. This is an aspect that I like a lot, as it creates interaction between players. 

But is the matter of being not original or especially groundbreaking really an issue? Absolutely not! The combination of elegant rules, smooth gameplay with little downtime and constant action, beautiful graphics and great mix of euro and ameritrash mechanisms results in a game that you want to return to. This is an euro that doesn't look like an excel chart, involves player interaction(even combat!), territory control, randomized events... so if you're a fan of games that involve area control, assymetry, messing with other players and are strongly thematic, but you want it to be much more economic and less fighting/killing, well this is for you. Just don't think of it as a war game. I think this is a main reason why some people were dissapointed. Don't treat it as a 4X. It requires a different approach. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Very strong euro style game with many interesting elements: resource management, engine building, area control, etc.; the amount of combat is up to the players; the different ways to gain six stars is appealing to me; replayability is good; main criticism to the game is the lack of player interaction, but I think it has enough: competing for area control, keeping an eye on how far opponents are on the triumph track and keeping in mind at which taken action neighbors gain profits; limited luck factor; downtime is short; houserule: Rusviet should not get player mat no. 1 (Industrial) and should not be able to use it’s faction ability to place their player token on the factory card on sequential turns, otherwise the game will be too unbalanced.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
1-5 players, asymmetrical 4x euro game, heavy weight, 120 minutes.

Rating based on 3 solo games and 3 plays with 3 and 4 players. I can perfectly understand the hype, which was primarily based on art work and theme, and as far as I;m concerned the game delivers on its promise. 

The different factions all have their own unique abilities which make for a different game each play, also combined with the random player board, which calls for a different strategy each play.

People looking for a heavy combat game will be dissapointed, as combat is minimal in the game, however the threat of combat is constant, which, in my view, works very well.

I've tried a few games against the AI on easy (Autometta) and normal (Automata) level and that's also a nice experience, which allows you experiment a bit with the combinations and strategies. COnsidering to acquire additional Automa packs in orde to play against mutiple AI's. Also might consider buying the expansion, which adds two new factions to the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My retail copy includes the expanded board and promo card #41. 

It's ok, but not really what I was looking for. It's a euro through and through, nicely produced with fabulous art--if it looked like other euros, no one would be talking about it. There is little real confrontation--you battle to get the points, not to dominate. The contrived board bugs me (symmetrically placed tunnels, dopey river crossing rules that make no sense) as does the very nature of a multiplayer 'war' game where everyone spends all their time staring down at their player boards trying to plan out which actions the game will let them take. 

I think there are lots of better euros, if that's what I'm looking for, and also many Ameritrash games that do this in a much more exciting way. It bugs me that so many people seem to love this game...I keep thinking that I need to play it more to figure out what I'm missing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
This is no doubt a good game, whatever the way you look to it. 
It has a great visual impact, though one also can think it is overproduced, a trend that has arrived with most recent games.
All the upgrades, the quest for resources, the power developments, the area conrol, etc, makes Scythe one of those games where a player always has something useful to do, regardless of his turn or situation on the board.
However, there is not much interaction (or that interaction can be avoided almost to its extreme) and an atacking player is often more penalized on atacking than the defending part.
Besides the natural assymetry between factions in a game like this, there is also the question that some initial starting grounds seem a bit unbanlanced.
Overall, in spite of beeing a good game, i think i would prefere to play a game like Blood Rage instead (for instance), since it has most of its elements and runs more swiftly, more fast and more fun (and it´s ultimately more cheap!)

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
First let's get this out of the way. Scythe is basically an overproduced euro...

And I LOVE IT!! 

This game is all about efficiency and posturing. With the threat of war. It has a very ominous vibe throughout the whole game. 

I think people see mechs and think that this is all about dudes on a map and combat. If you go in with that attitude you will be very disappointed. This game is about building an engine and managing resources. You need to try your best to figure out which 6 stars you will be going for and then go. It might very well be that combat and area control will be a path to your victory or it might be setting up an engine of pumping out tons of resources and avoiding all combat as much as possible.

As far as calling a game a 4x or not. I hate how people can get so riled up over terms. I don't care if it fits into that "box" or not. I think the game does an excellent job of giving you the feeling of a 4x game all within a shorter time. (a hour and a half) For me that's why I often prefer to play Scythe over those other games. 

It won't be very often that I could get a group together to play some epic 6+ hour epic game. So I play Scythe instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Preliminary rating as I have yet to play a full game, but having played a few rounds to get the feel for it, I only expect this rating to go higher after getting a chance to finish a full game and a few more.  This is a 4x game, and the unique starting conditions along with the variable combinations possible should make the strategies not "locked in" depending on which combination you get.  I'm looking forward to playing this again, hopefully soon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Great ideas fatally flawed by lack a real publisher telling the designer to cut the bad ideas. Same problem with all of Stonemaier's games.

The combat system is overly simple and flat given he has the audacity to call it a "puzzle" and compare it with Kemet. Kemet, Dune, and Rex are the systems that this combat is based off of, but know what? They had variety of effects with their combat cards and different ways to screw your opponent over. This is just about numbers. No tricky way to outsmart an opponent as long as you use more of your combat value. And if you're the defender and try to get smart by using more power than your opponent predicts, guess what? You've just set yourself up for another attack, and whoever gets to attack you next gets a free Star. Combat needs a vast overhaul or gutted entirely from what would otherwise be an outstanding resource management game.

Then we have the encounter cards which show art and leave the story to you. Yeah, your options on the encounter cards are completely rediculous nonsense. If you wanted a "choose your own adventure" feel then get into it more! Look at what Above & Below or Near & Far have done. Again, trim the fat or actually bulk this up to par with the great economic side of the game.

Then we have lots of severe thematic disconnects from the game. Most annoyingly is how some factions only know how to swim across rivers to "villages or mountains," but forests or fields? Yeah, they don't know how to swim to those. Another faction does, but that faction is clueless on how to swim to a village.
I understand how tunnels are adjacent to one another, but how on earth does one faction have villages be adjacent to one another for movement? Another faction has lakes adjacent, even for waterways that aren't connected at all so "Dive" doesn't explain it. Did "The Factory" also make some fancy teleportation devices???

I just want to play the resource management part of this game, which is such an awesome idea. Too bad I can't play it without getting frustrated at its attempts to branch into combat & storytelling. And for the record, I love Ameritrash games, I'm not just a Euro fan complaining that some Ameritrash got mixed in with the game. What I want is the Ameritrash to be well done, or cut out completely. Don't half-ass it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is a terrific strategy game where you have to choose from a number of different paths. Choose wisely!

RATING: 10
Beautifully crafted game with cool components, cool theme, intuitive to play, intuitive upgrade mechanism, excellent game flow and much more streamline than other games in this genre

DO NOT EXPECT THIS GAME TO BE AN EPIC AREA CONTROL GAME WITH A LOT OF FIGHT GOING ON BECAUSE YOU SEE THOSE COOL MECH ON THE COVER! This game is about engine optimization, resource management, with a little of area control and a few pinching your neighbors and take all of their stuff.
