=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Reasonably fun, beautiful game.  Reminds me a lot of Antike.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Absolutely outstanding production quality-- amazing pieces and gorgeous artwork. Very smooth gameplay with depth of strategy, ingenious mechanics, and a robust scoring system. It has a faintly steampunk vibe in terms of the gadgetry and war machines.

This game has quite a few novel game mechanics that are hard to describe easily. They need to be experienced to really understand how they fit together to form a "big picture" of gamepley. The game is slightly asynchronous, with each faction having a slightly different start area with randomly diversified actions (the player mats have slightly different actions on each, and are not tied to the factions) making it possible to have many different possible start combinations for huge replayability. 

The mechs, and the movement and combat mechanics make this a very interesting blend of war game and area control. With "combat power as a resource" it's easy to maintain enough of a strong front to discourage players from attacking you, and you cannot simply build all your mechs to have military dominance. More mechs means more area control, but mechs contribute relatively little to combat themselves, beyond directly enabling it. Sending multiple mechs to attack a lone character only really makes a difference if you are otherwise close in terms of combat potential.

The game end is triggered in a slightly different manner than most games. There is not a predetermined singular objective, nor is there a fixed number of rounds. Instead, there are 10 possible objectives, and once a player completes 6 of them, the game immediately ends. This means players are encouraged to try to specialize and focus their empire on some of the possible goals, Each goal offers perks along the way regardless, for example, one of the ten goals is "to deploy all 4 mechs". Obviously deploying your mechs is inherently good, regardless of if you're trying to accomplish that goal. Every player almost *needs* at least one mech to improve their overall mobility.

Mobility is one of the most important aspects of the game. Scythe is a very *dynamic* game, you almost never entrench anywhere, or set up shop, or build a base, etc. Your mechs and your workers are the meat and bones of your operation. There are "structures" but they mostly offer minor passive bonuses and cannot be destroyed or moved, so they require very little investment to defend once placed. The map itself is initially restricted by rivers, your character will be restricted to 3 hexes of land near your starting base. In order to leave this area of land, you'll have to either construct a mech that adds mobility features, or build the mine structure to unlock access to the game's tunnel network. To add a 4X feel to it, there are "encounters" on the map, which are roughly similar to "ancient ruins" from Sid Meier's "Civilisation". These encounters present the characters with a few simple options that award various prizes. Which faction, player mat, starting objectives, and initial encounter you draw completely shape how you play the game.

Resource management is also done differently in Scythe than in most games. Resources don't go into a "player supply" area off the board. If you pump oil out of the ground, it's now sitting in barrels next to the oil rig that produced it. If a player takes control over your oil rig because you couldn't defend it, they get to keep the oil that's there. Workers produce the resources, and they can also move it. So you could have a Mecha and accompanying worker travelling the land, producing what is needed then moving on. Leaving lone workers unprotected is unadvised near the center of the board, as roaming enemy mechs and characters might find them easy pickings for some easy resources. Conveniently, though, resources can be spent from any hex you control, so metal from the far mine on the board can be used to deploy a mech in a different area. Essentially, you don't have to worry about schlepping goods around and setting up supply chains. Resources are also unique in that each resource corresponds to one and only one purpose. Oil is for upgrading your actions to be more efficient, metal is for deploying mechs, wood is used for building structures, and food is used to gain "enlistment" bonuses that add an interesting dynamics to the seating order and action economy.

When you "enlist", you simply choose one of the four production actions, "build", "upgrade", "deploy", or "enlist". When the players to your immediate left or right at the table take the selected action, you gain a small bonus. This is slightly counter-intuitive as the word "enlist" seems to imply you get more people, or soldiers, or something, but "enlisting" simply derives benefits from other players actions in the future.

One of the smoothest things about Scythe is the way actions are taken. Essentially each player has 4 regions on their player mat that they can choose from. There is a top-row action, and a bottom-row action on each section. The bottom row actions are the ones I mentioned previously, "build", "upgrade", "deploy", and "enlist". The top row actions are the more fundamental "move", "produce", "bolster", and "trade" which allow the manoeuvring of pieces, production of resources, gathering of combat strength, and acquiring otherwise unavailable resources or popularity (respectively). The unique thing about the player mats, is that the exact costs and rewards of the bottom-row actions are slightly different across the player mats. For example, the "agricultural" and the "industrial" mats have different oil costs for upgrading action efficiency, and different mats award different coin/point bonuses for performing different bottom-row actions. This gives each player a slight bias towards which end game goals they should be pursuing to maximize their score. Additionally, the player mats group the top and bottom row actions in different combinations. Some players have "upgrade" on the "move" section, while others have it under a different section. The reason these regions matter, is that each turn you select a different region to perform the actions of. You cannot keep moving repeatedly, you have to alternate with a different region each time.

Each faction also has unique perks. For example, one faction actually allows the player to take the same action over and over, whereas others allow workers to move across rivers without the aid of mechas. 

All in all Scythe is a fantastic board game with amazing quality components and compelling gameplay. I'd be happy to take it off the shelf any time. 10/10

The only drawback is the complexity. This game isn't for the faint of heart, and I would only recommend this game to avid board gamers. It took close to 90min to explain the rules to my family and some rules confused them to the end. The game is quite tricky if you're used to the likes of monopoly, risk, or snakes and ladders.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
One play in, playing with someone's game that was completely decked out with all of the Kickstarter goodies. Absolutely beautiful game, with great looking components. But what about the gameplay?

It's decent. You get some variation with the different factions, and they in turn draw random action selection cards each game, so no two games should be quite the same. The area control aspect, with resources stored in specific tiles rather than in the usual generic pool of stuff, results in some military tension that most euros lack. There's combat, yes, but it's not a path to victory by itself since it typically costs you popularity and that can cost you the game in the end.

This is not a wargame, so if you were looking for something like [i]Eclipse[/i] with a different theme then you're going to be disappointed. I also think that there's not going to be a huge amount of variation between games owing to limited movement and actions to select from, especially in those early turns. My instincts tell me that it'll be good for a dozen plays or so before I hit that been-there-done-that feeling. Still, that's not bad.

So, a game I probably won't be picking up myself, but one where I'm happy to play someone else's copy from time to time.

Update: Another game in, another victory. This time in a 7p expansion game. Even though I won, I don't really feel like my decisions were especially profound, which doesn't say much for the gameplay. Also, I wouldn't play 7p again as there's too much downtime, and no real catchup mechanism for players who get beat on early. Plus, those objectives cards can vary pretty wildly in difficulty, which isn't fun if you're one of the people that got a tough one.

The more I think about it, the less enamored I am with this game. If I'm going to play an action selection game where board state really matters, I'm always going to pick [i]Dominant Species[/i] over this. It has a much richer narrative with much more difficult decisions. Seriously, try to recount a game of Scythe a week later and talk about what happened. I'll bet you can't say much beyond, "I performed some actions and got some points. Dave attacked me once", or some such.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
Purchased this game knowing nothing about it other than it was popular. I know know why it is highly regarded. The game scratches so many different itches and does it in a very smooth way which I think it makes it palletable for various gaming groups!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is all based on my opinion.  I've played Scythe around 20 times so far.

While Scythe is not necessarily the "best" in every category - that is to say: 
it's not the most thematic (i'd argue this as Scythe is likely ONE of the best)
it's not the most strategic
it's not the most war like
it's not the best area of control/influence
it's not the best euro
it's not the best american/non-euro
it's not the best at most things... BUT..

It IS GOOD/GREAT at all of those.  In every category that this game qualifies for, it's good/great.  Not a lot of games can say that.  Most games are great at a couple things...but lack in others.  Not the case for Scythe.  It's insane to pack so much in a game.  It reminds me of the first time I played Terra Mystica or Twilight Imperium 3.  It was such a surprise to find a board game that encapsulated so many different wonderful things (that make board games great) at once.

Scythe is HIGHLY replayable. Extremely engrossing.  Easy to teach/understand.  It's just a little more complex than Catan - so if you're looking for a good introductory game for people that are on the fence on more advanced board games, I'd recommend Scythe with any of the other "intro games."  However it can also be extremely complex if you play with the right group of people.

I don't think I need to say anything about the art or the theme of the game.  It's clear ahead of nearly anything else in recent memory.  

Due to the above reasons, I'm ranking this game as "Outstanding"  10/10 "I will always enjoy playing."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
[January 2018 - 7.4] Drops a few notches as I'm just not getting plays out of it. Might return back to it.

[October 2016 - 7.6]
I still don't completely know what to think about Scythe. I like that it's going for that balance of Euro with a little more "dudes on the map" interaction, but I'm not sure it quite pulls it off. The game is beautiful, but I feel like the board is a little busy in its design. 

The metal coins are outstanding. And more games should learn from Scythe with its inset player boards to keep cubes in place. The upgrade mechanic is ingenious, where you get the choose not only the upgrade, but then where that cube goes for a further discount in your bottom-row actions.

While there's a ton of choices in the game, it's about maximizing the engine for only a few things. You can't do it all, and there's a bit of a puzzle aspect to it.

The theme is there, but you tend to get so bogged down in the mechanics that it can get lost. Explaining the game for the first time can be a bear, but once people get it, it gets moving.

In the end, it's fun, but not exciting. I'm not super interested in what the others are doing until they're on my doorstep or at the very end of the game. There's no tension of, "please, please pick that option" or "what will they do?" other than battles, which happen less than you think.

I think Scthye is trying to be a little of everything and because of that falls short in a few areas.

RATING: 4
Stegmaier is the best producer in the board game industry. The art, components, graphic design and continuity of aesthetic in Scythe are unparalleled. Unfortunately as a designer, his philosophy seems to be that the question of balance won't come up if you utterly bury it in content.

And he's right. Many gamers these days largely do not care if their session was decided at setup as long as they can blame the imbalance on luck, [i]as if random setups that cause runaway leaders are not the designers fault[/i].

TLDR: Although gorgeous, Scythe is not a good game.

RATING: 9
best of last year
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game is in no way balanced. Certain factions can attack other factions without fear of reprisal because of the riverwalk mechanic. Certain faction's powers or mech abilities are DRAMATICALLY better than others. And it is FAR too easy for a single player to bully another player and completely take them out of the game with literally no chance of that bullied player coming back into the game ever.

In short, this game LOOKS amazing, but is easily one of the least balanced asymmetric games I've ever played.

The game's Automa is, however, brilliant, and saves this game from being a 1 star game. I'd like to rate it higher based solely on the Automa solo mode, but yeah, that's a bad idea when people might be buying the game with the main purpose of playing with friends.

As a final note, this is avaliable on Tabletop Simulator. I WOULD recommend the purchase there as it is MUCH cheaper than the physical version, you may find you like the MP fine and don't mind the horribly unbalanced gameplay (or don't mind house ruling around it), and, at the very least, can play the Automa version there with some nice automated setup. Especially since the expansion was added recently for free, it's certainly worth the 5 or 10 bucks they're asking for the digital version.

RATING: N/A
Viticulture + Tuscany has become a favorite for my wife and me, so am interested in anything new from Stonemaier.  However, it's also not a sure bet.  After a breif infatuation with Euphoria, I found it to be ultimately unsatisfying.

I have watched some playthroughs and read the rules for Sythe.  I can certainly see several influenes blended into this game: Terra Mystica, Kemet, and Jamey's own designs.  I also see shades of 51st State, even though that is not mentioned as inspiration. 

I am sure the production will be stellar, but I'm not seeing anything in the gameplay that attracts me.  It reminds me most of Terra Mysitca, but not as good, and I ultimately didn't care that much for TM.  It just seems rather dry and procedural, an impression that was only reinforced by Jamey's run through.  I enjoy resource conversion games, but this one seems like an overblown way to do it.  I think I will pass on this one for purchase, but would like to play it sometime.  If it holds up well in the ratings once the shine wears off I'll take another look.

RATING: 6
Engine building efficiency race with the potential for board interaction. It’s similar to Terra Mystica with its player boards, player powers, hex map, upgrading of engines, blocking, and game weight. It’s different in that it allows direct conflict, stealing of resources, and movement of units. The game rewards familiarity; people who have played more will definitely beat new players, so it's not ideal for a crowd with mixed experience.

RATING: 6
I really cannot understand the hype. I mean, I do like the game, but is it a masterpiece? 

Yes the production quality is excellent, the game mechanics flow well and the game is enjoyable to play. But it didn’t strike me as something that good to justify a Top 10 rank on BGG. Clearly a lot of people think it is very very good indeed. 

Perhaps the miniatures and the conflict within the game has brought a bunch of non-Euro playing Ameritrashers into playing the game? I can understand that, by those standards, the game will feel and play very differently to what people are used to and so could feel like a new concept in gaming. But as a Euro-only gamer I didn’t feel that.

I like Scythe, don’t get me wrong. I really enjoyed my play and would happily play it again. But I just didn’t think that it was out-there amazing, and perhaps my expectations had been built up too high?

RATING: 9.5
Scythe is the whole package. Great theme: post WWI where where unique sci-fi technology has been discovered and utilized. Great mechanics: variable player powers, action-selection, area control and worker placement/resource management. Great rule book that is easy to follow. High quality components: the minis look and feel awesome, the cards are of good stock, and the meeples are all unique for each character. This is the type of game where the designer fine tuned the tiniest of details to make the experience that much richer. It has a ton of replayability because there are so many different combinations of player mats and action mats. Strong, in-depth strategy. The only reason I couldn't give it a 10 is because it requires more time than my group can commit on a regular basis.

Definitely worth the price. Top quality game and components. Don't think about it, just get it.

RATING: 7
The solo game is good, a step above the Viticulture Solo experience (which is also good). 

The complaints of player boards strongly steering you towards a strategy are pretty accurate, but for me that doesn't bother me. Not all games have to be sandboxes. This is mostly a euro with just a hint of battle. The game does nothing new and exciting, but it recycles other ideas and throws a lot together in a relatively quick and concise package.

Id say its a great entry to longer 4X, Action Selection or Engine Building games. Games range from roughly 60 minutes to 150 minutes depending on count and experience. Expect play time to be drastically reduced with experienced players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Scythe has a bit of an identity problem.  When you get it moving, you realize that you're playing a cross-section of a bunch of other games that you have already played; it has a little bit of engine building, a little bit of 4X, and a little bit of skirmishing, yet in the end, while it does each little bit decently enough, it never seems to land in a spot where all of it clicks together.  There's nothing wrong with taking from other designs, mind you, and the mish-mash that ends up on the table actually isn't too bad.  A little overproduced, perhaps, but nevertheless a decent if not stellar design.

Keep in mind that I had no expectations walking into this, so none of this is peppered with bias; the only thing I knew about it was that the cover art was fantastic.  When you strip away hype and cult of the new, what you're left with is a game that plays at a pretty fast clip.  Our game had 4 players and would have clocked in under an hour, but we're a pretty social bunch so there was a lot of talking instead of playing, but even then, it was over pretty quickly.  Each player had a random faction and a random action board, which I found pretty interesting.  The asymmetry of the action boards means that what you're dealt is ultimately going to determine your best strategy, something I duly ignored in favor of getting mechs out onto the table (I came in about 20 points behind 1st and 2nd players).  I'm not so sure I like the idea of having that decision made for me, but it seemed to work out okay.  The only caveat is that your starting position, therefore, can seriously hamper what you ought to be doing as determined by the actions you can take.

Players aim to walk away from the table as the richest player by the time any one player accomplishes six achievements.  Obviously, this means having the coin in your hand, but there is also end-game scoring determined by your accomplished achievements, left-over resources, and how many hexes you control - how much you earn from each of these depends on how much you invest in gaining popularity with the people of ... wherever this takes place.  The whole end-game trigger is the weirdest thing in this game and seems kind of pointless to chase unless you are the points leader.  Why bother when someone else can do the work for you?  You don't want to ignore it completely, mind you, since it is one of the key points in final scoring, but mechanically, this system kind of clashes with the rest of the game.  When a player completes one of several achievements, they get a star.  When any one player gets six, the game ends.  In and of itself, a star does nothing except bring the game to a close and only then is it worth points.  In a game that is about getting a good engine going so you can reap the rewards, a star that provides no such reward seemed a little left-field to me.  The best illustration of this is the objective cards - each player will start with two and can accomplish one, but the only reason to spend time and/or resources doing this is to get a single star.  That's it.  No benefit whatsoever.  At a high level, it doesn't break the game or even make it worse - it was just so counter-intuitive.

The map, then, is laid out pretty well provided you have a full compliment of players.  Your start position (determined by your faction) is so terribly important because of what you might hope to accomplish when you look at your action board because your neighboring hexes in your isolated island only provide a specific combo of resources - got a board that takes advantage of wood, but your nearest source is across an early-game impassable river?  Welp, good luck to you.  However, with under the full compliment of players, you have a good chance (as we did) that some players will have a distinct advantage in being unopposed while expanding.  I think a small provision here to lock off an area of the board for fewer players would greatly benefit the game and increase the tension.  Otherwise, the art is delicious if somewhat too earth-toney at times, but there's just so much beautiful painting all over this game.  

It's a shame, then, that the interesting theme isn't really present in the gameplay.  At least I didn't feel it was expressed that well and the game is ultimately a very mechanical experience.  It's not quite a Euro, though, but it isn't quite 4X either.  This is what I mean by identity problem.  Your engine and action selection screams Spiel de Jahres mainstays, but your map exploration and combat are something more akin to Fantasy Flight (in particular, I was reminded loosely of Dune/Rex on that front).  And all through it, the very unique and fascinating theme doesn't really come out in the mechanics.  It tries, of course, but it's a little too gamey for it.  Not really a deal-breaker, but it is a missed opportunity.

TL;DR - Scythe is an overproduced quick, fun game with terrific artwork, but it's not really going to knock your socks off.  It will be popular for a few months, perhaps, but it doesn't seem to have the staying power of its inspirations.  It's definitely decently designed, but it could have been so much more had it just focused a little bit instead of trying to kitchen-sink the whole deal.  Definitely try, but only maybe buy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Spew Forth and Watch You're Empire Grow

The rich artwork and theme integration make most, if not all, of my other games seem pale in comparison.  The only other game I know that has felt this rich is Viticulture.  Stonemaier games is doing something with their game aesthetics that I don't think anyone else has caught up to yet.  Brilliant stuff.

I've found the fluidity of the game to be both intriguing and odd.  In most of the more complex games I've played there's usually a round structure or something that stops gameplay while some sort of general game maintenance occurs.  In Scythe you start and then you end once that sixth star is placed. 

There are no rounds, ages, new things that become available, or resource spots that need refilled as the game progresses.  Once you start you just go until the game ends, and because you're only using one of four action spaces each turn, the game feels really smooth, but also extremely repetitive.  You're just bouncing back and forth between four action spaces do the same things over and over and over and over, and yes that's what games are, but most have something built into the game to break up the monotony like rounds or upkeep.  You and the other players are just thrown onto the map with some boards and bits and take it one action at a time until the game ends.  There are no hand resets, no chit refills, no running out of actions.  There aren't any in-game upkeeps, and I feel like that's some sort of design achievement for a game with so much in it, but again, it feels odd because that's just not what I'm used to.    

Perhaps, partially stemming from that, the game has a feeling that there's a lot going on, but there isn't much to it.  There are a lot of rules to go over, there are several types of resources,  three tracks on the board to move your pieces around, different types of units all with their own movement rules, four decks of cards, a map loaded with icons that isn't free to roam around until you unlock certain things; you have two boards in front of you with all sorts of wooden bits, symbols, and text.  A ton of stuff!

But the game is actually kind of easy to teach, despite all the stuff.  The game plays extremely smooth thanks to great iconography, taking one action at a time, and no in game upkeeps to worry about.  So you see all this stuff and listen to all the rules and your brain is like, "wwwaaaaaa," but then you start playing and your like oh this is pretty easy, but it looks like it should be hard, but it's pretty easy, why isn't it hard, is this all there is to the game despite there being a ton of stuff in front of me?  And then the game ends because someone placed their sixth star and you're like, "oh I guess it's over.  I don't know how I felt about that.  It wasn't unpleasant.  But was it pleasant?"  

And that's kind of where I'm at with Scythe.  You start the game with three units on the board and pretty much try to unload all your wooden and plastic bits from your player boards onto the main board.  It's not unpleasant, but I don't know if it's pleasant and I think it's because there are some subtle innovations working under the hood of this game that are tricking my board game senses into wanting to not like it just because the smoothness of it seems to be at odds with the one ton of game that sits scattered on the table in front of me.  I'm expecting something heavy, but it doesn't feel heavy.  I'm expecting my brain to short circuit from playing this game, but it never happens.   Scythe defies my assumptions and expectations of it, leaving me somewhat bewildered.

The truth is I probably overthought the whole thing.  Which is what happens when I write.  I think I was hoping for a game that had more tension and drama, but what I got was repetitive micro turns, a multiplier track, an odd end game scoring bonus for building placement, and some encounter cards that all feel like they do the same thing.  

A few reviews and comments say, "This is not the best game ever."  My personal feelings aside, I don't see why this game couldn't be.  The mechanics are solid.  The balance feels tight.  How the systems of the game function and interlock is intriguing.  And again, the theme and artwork are awesome!  Even though it lacks the special sauce for me, it has all the right ingredients of several other top ranked games, so I guess time will tell.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My initial thoughts, after only playing three times, are overwhelmingly positive.

The game plays incredibly smoothly, despite the rules dump needed at the beginning of a game for new players. The replay value feels huge thanks to the variability of the faction/action mat combos plus all the different, and very valid, strategy paths. The component quality and art are of the highest I've seen. The only other game with comparable quality I've come across is The Gallerist (and possibly Viticulture w/ Tuscany--no surprise there).

The game also doesn't over stay its welcome. First games with new players will be a little slow, but experienced players will know what to do to get those early game engines running quickly. I'd say the playing time is quite accurate for experienced players.

The only real negative thing I can come up with is the larger board with the extension takes up a tad too much real estate. Luckily it really is a non-issue as you can just use the smaller side.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2016-09-23 : First play of this well-designed engine builder with really great components. The player board layout is the crown piece of the design, the only thing I'm a bit concerned about is that given a set of starter boards and your starting board position there may be a single most optimal way to play, given you little choice and harming replay-ability. But those are concerns for subsequent plays. Also, while definitely a fine game, it's not what the hype made of it - not by a long shot. A solid 8 for now.
2017-02-25 : 3 games in and with 3 wins with 3 different factions using 3 different paths to victory I can say with some assurance that while the player boards give you some help/direction in choosing your strategy, you're not locked into one and it all depends on what the other players are doing. Not so pleased with the board graphics and layout choices as some, so it remains a solid 8
2017-02-28 : 4 games in and the game feels played out with nothing new to discover- time to let it rest for a year.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I do enjoy the main action selection mechanism and the7 available factions will provide a lot of replayability. Very great production and solid gameplay, but hasn't hit quite as a high note with me as others.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Absolutely gorgeous! Beyond that, this is an interesting euro game with limited conflict. There is a lot to like in Scythe of my one play experience and the few videos I've watched. I've tempered my enthusiasm due to a few niggly things that I'm worried about in the long-term with the game:

-6 stars and it's over, with potentially no equal turns. I know this is 'somewhat balanced through the player boards.'

-Not sure about the balance of the factions.

-I don't like the revisions/iterations Stonemaier makes with Viticulture, and to a lesser degree, Euphoria due to various issues. Scythe seems better, but only time will tell.

I have only played this once, so take anything I say with a grain of salt. My choice of euro with restrained combat is The Golden Ages.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
There seems to be a trend these days for very splashy big box games with "wow" factor (lush artwork, fun theme, or fantastic figures). These games always seem to jump to the top of the rating ladder, yet I feel they do so without a ton of substance. Their look definitely hooks in the Ameritrash players, but games like Scythe also dangle an element of a strategy to lure in the Euro players like myself. I stepped up to bat and gave it a swing and hit one to make it to first, but it was no homerun.

Now don't get me wrong, I've long since preached that games ought to have high production levels, or at the very least have a professional look, but this is not a great game worthy of the BGG top 10 in my opinion. It works in several ways: quick players turns, good cause and effect (your choices directly affect the game), fantastic flavor, visual appeal, and I enjoyed how it improved the "Eclipse" mechanic of removing cubes to unlock powers and added an additional element of unlocking extra abilities based on where they are moved to. I did not however enjoy the wonky battle mechanic (it felt like something from a Fantasy Flight game) or the flimsy resource management.

I'm not sure how to put it, but I felt like I was playing a GI Joe toy battle at recess with pasted on rules and a lot of "boom, crash, bam" noises from everyone's mouth. The big fighty mechs don't really do much battlin' and your hero kinda just wanders about looking for lost choose-your-own-adventure pages.

It works, but it really is firmly on the Ameritrash side of things.... no Euro game would allow for such a weighted turn order.

}
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like the engine building in this game, but I'm not sure if the factions are perfectly balanced. Also, playing the game is mostly fiddling back and forth on my personal player board and there's quite weak player interaction. It's possible to play solitaire on one corner of the board over the entire game if no one is interested to attack you. I won one game this way. I usually tend to avoid conflict, so I think it's positive that there are many other ways to victory. After all, there is not much combat in this game, usually fighting part begins at the very end of the game.

However, most of the player interaction is that you follow what the other players are doing on the map board and try to react on their moves, and to get to some places before the others. Also, it's necessary to pay attention on your neighbours’ actions, as some of their actions could benefit you if you have used the enlist action. 

After being that critical, I still would like to play this game more as I think there are still many interesting things going on in this game. Also, the game components are gorgeous – especially the miniatures, I would like to paint them. I would not be surprised if I happened to buy this game some day, I think it’s possible that this game gets better with more plays.

RATING: 7
From a design perspective there is not much to critisize. The different clans seem balanced, and provide each player with a unique strategy, and the same can be said for the action boards.  However, from a gameplay perspective some of aspects fall a bit short. For instance, the early game is incredibly limiting, and players fall into scripted openings. And though I enjoy the star-based end game trigger, it appears that a few are more or less mandatory. Completing secret objectives, and winning a battle, are much easier to accomplish than maxing out the power or popularity tracks. All together, the decision space appears to be bigger than it really is. The biggest win here, surprisingly to me, is the world building. The premise and setting alone will likely lure me into several more plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It is a time of unrest in 1920s Europa. The ashes from the first great war still darken the snow. The capitalistic city-state known simply as “The Factory”, which fueled the war with heavily armored mechs, has closed its doors, drawing the attention of several nearby countries.

Scythe is an engine-building game set in an alternate-history 1920s period. It is a time of farming and war, broken hearts and rusted gears, innovation and valor. In Scythe, each player represents a character from one of five factions of Eastern Europe who are attempting to earn their fortune and claim their faction's stake in the land around the mysterious Factory. Players conquer territory, enlist new recruits, reap resources, gain villagers, build structures, and activate monstrous mechs.

Each player begins the game with different resources (power, coins, combat acumen, and popularity), a different starting location, and a hidden goal. Starting positions are specially calibrated to contribute to each faction’s uniqueness and the asymmetrical nature of the game (each faction always starts in the same place).

Scythe gives players almost complete control over their fate. Other than each player’s individual hidden objective card, the only elements of luck or variability are “encounter” cards that players will draw as they interact with the citizens of newly explored lands. Each encounter card provides the player with several options, allowing them to mitigate the luck of the draw through their selection. Combat is also driven by choices, not luck or randomness.

Scythe uses a streamlined action-selection mechanism (no rounds or phases) to keep gameplay moving at a brisk pace and reduce downtime between turns. While there is plenty of direct conflict for players who seek it, there is no player elimination.

Every part of Scythe has an aspect of engine-building to it. Players can upgrade actions to become more efficient, build structures that improve their position on the map, enlist new recruits to enhance character abilities, activate mechs to deter opponents from invading, and expand their borders to reap greater types and quantities of resources. These engine-building aspects create a sense of momentum and progress throughout the game. The order in which players improve their engine adds to the unique feel of each game, even when playing one faction multiple times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A really fun mashup of euro style action selection and area control with an almost ameritrash feel. I always enjoy asymmetrical factions in a game if they are balanced well, and Scythe takes it to a new level with the mashup of faction and action boards - allowing each combination to push you in a slightly different direction. 

Component quality is off the charts, the player mats look amazing and are very high quality thick cardboard in two layers that holds pieces in place. The minis are stunning and look good even unpainted. Art for the game is phenomenal and really creates an immersive world that I really hope is explored more. 

The game can slightly suffer if everyone is not on the same skill level, as some of the important aspects do not make themselves immediately obvious but if all players understand the game it makes for some very tense play. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The components are spectacular.  The game has plenty of variation, with different factions and player mats, structure bonus tiles, (secret) objective cards, encounter cards, and factory cards.  This makes for a lot of variation, and will change the way your strategy plays for each game.  The larger sized game board is ABSOLUTELY LUXURIOUS.  The game seems initially complex, but once you actually start playing the game is straight forward.  The only problem my gaming partner and I have had is that combat seems undervalued.  In fact, I found there were times when I wanted him to attack me so he would take the popularity hit when my workers when back to my home base.  I can't wait to play the Automata (solo) variation.  I think this will be one of the great games of 2016.

RATING: 8.5
Enjoyed playing this with group of 7 (expansion), and though I lost hard, I would want to play again. First game with 7 is impossible since it’s easy to get trapped early. As a newb, I finally had an idea of what I ought to be striving for past the halfway mark, but by that time, had gotten wedged in and was unable to do anything useful for the remaining third of the game, except pretend I was playing the start of the game over again. 

Downtime is a killer with 7, though, so I’d be more inclined to play 3- or 4-player game.

EDIT 1: bought my own copy (Collector’s Edition, no less) and have been playing solo with Automa. Set up is involved, but I’ve played worse (looking at you Trickerion), and looking forward to trying Scythekick app to help with that, as well as to handle the Automa — I constantly forget to move the round forward with the Automa.

Solo play has helped me with getting a handle on the action mat and how to optimize that, something I was unable to do well while playing 2-6 other people.

Now looking to getting Invaders From Afar and Wind Gambit expansions to try.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I’m conflicted on how I feel about this game. I find some parts of it really clever and then other parts much less so. The action selection system is the highlight, and I find it fun to try and become more and more efficient with my actions while racing to the Factory to get a bonus card. The problem is that the 2/3 of the game is mostly solitaire planning on your board with little to no regard for the other players. 

Only when players get to about four stars and start looking to combat each other for those last two do things start to get tense. And the combat is not nearly as interesting as its inspiration from Dune. There are no funky combat cards that can create surprises here; it’s all just numbers. And after you spend your power on a battle, you're now a vulnerable target to someone else (which is an intentional design choice). It feels flat.

It may be a lot to ask, but I wish the game had some other form of player interaction besides heavy-handed combat because I just don’t find it nearly as clever as the other aspects of the game. The cognitive load of having to track what powers players have and where their pawn is on their board makes it nigh impossible to anticipate what other players are about to do. Frankly, the whole combat aspect feels bolted on to create some player interaction.

So on one hand, you have this personal player board where have total control to plan out what actions you like to take, and then on the other there’s this chaotic colosseum where you hope people don’t notice you as much as others. 

I’ll never love this game, but I can see myself playing it 3-4 times to get my fill of the action efficiency experience and perhaps steal a win (update: I did just that). This comment sounds more of a downer than I intended it, it's just that I think the design is imbalanced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fun gameplay, no down time, great artwork, brings nothing new, theme plays no role in the game.

RATING: 5

This game definitely could have used a lot less things and more refinement of some core concepts.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
It certainly is not really the 4X game it seems to advertise being and whilst there are combat mechanics this is much more euro than anything else with an interesting, engine building mechanic at its core.

The initially very limited movement leads to a rather slow build up of forces, and indeed in our game we never actually made it into combat with one another. 
There are plenty of options on what to aim your engine towards and various categories which you can 'score' a star in. Once a player reaches 6 stars the game ends and points are scored based upon how popular you are with your people. This is an interesting mechanic as the more land you grab to score with them more unpopular you become within your faction (especially if you keep stomping on other players taking their territory). Having a large stockpile of goods scores many points at the end of the game but your popularity takes a hit everytime you force your people to work your fields. 

Random factions coupled with random player boards, adds a lot of seemingly different play options, however I am a bit unsure how differently this would actually play each time.

RATING: 10
Los componentes, tanto las minis como sobre todo las ilustraciones, son increíbles; ahí va más de la mitad del precio. Después es un euro muy bien montado, ágil, rápido, fácil de pillar... Creo que lo mejor que tiene es que, aunque parezca que tiene un despliegue brutal, se pilla muy fácilmente y los turnos son muy rápidos y diferentes (en cada turno tienes que elegir un bloque de acciones entre cuatro bloques posibles, y eso te fuerza un poco a que cada ronda hagas cosas diferentes). Juegazo, y el modo solitario funciona muy bien.

RATING: 9.5
After the first few plays, I have fallen in love with Scythe! It is elegant and intricate in every way. I am so excited to play this game more. There is so much room to improve upon your own strategy and there seems to be no best strategy. Beautifully balanced and alot of variety between turns and games. The world of Scythe is grandiose and its spectacle is unique and engaging. I would be satisfied just reading and admiring the encounter cards and all the gorgeous and dynamic artwork in this game! Definitely the most beautiful piece of art, disguised as a board game, that I own! I look forward to future plays!

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Overall, pretty good, but I wish I liked it more.

There is a lot to like with the artwork, the engine building, the mechs, etc.  We played with 3 which felt a little wide open in the middle.  Everyone wanted to play again, although they said that in spots it didn't feel like the theme was as rich, like with the player mats.  But I felt you got a lot of game for the time commitment, only 2 hours for our game where everyone was new.

A good resource management, action selection, game with minis.

Played again with 5, 4 humans and the Automa bot.  Much better than with 3 as there was a lot less open space.  I'd recommend higher player counts of 4 or 5.

You definitely have to work towards the synergies your player mat and your starting resources create.  Use what you can produce and trade for what you can't.  Aim to build a mech on your 2nd or 3rd turn (it can be done if you trade).  I would go for the Speed mech simply so that you can move a bit more, and use the Mine to get access to the tunnels.

Always make sure that you are gaining coins, as that's VP.  In my last game, I rarely took actions that gave me extra coins and at the end of the game, 2 other players already had 25 coins or so each before starting to add the end game scoring.

I like Viticulture EE by the same designer more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Where to start with this amazing 4X game! Thematic alternate history of the 1920's set in Eastern Europa, asymmetric factions with mechs, worker placement, area control, and combat (although not as frequent), with multiple ways to victory and differing strategy. The artwork is amazing in this game and looks absolutely beautiful. You get really immersed in the game from just the look and feel of the game. The components of the game are made with great quality and the Mechs look really sweet! The variety of setup that players can have adds to the replayability of the game and changes the way you approach the game and the strategy to use for each new game. The player board makes the game flow well and makes the choices very intuitive for the players and makes tracking the upgrades and actions easy and understandable. The game felt very overwhelming at first when learning how to play the game but becomes very easy after playing a few rounds. There does not seem to be that much player interaction and the bribing mechanic is very trivial and I do not see any purpose of it since players do not have to honor it. Despite this, you will have to pay attention to what the other players are doing and try to disrupt their plans at opportune moments and adjust your strategy according to what others are doing. The engine building aspect of the game is done very well and it is shown very clearly on the board game in an understandable manner. The different paths in the game and the asymmetric player board adds a very deep strategical element to the game, where you are trying figure out the most optimal strategy and efficiency while paying attention to what is happening on the game board. There are complaints of the game where it becomes to feel the same as the game is based on being efficient and the lack of combat and player interactions can make the game stale. I can see how it may end up to that point after a few playthroughs but at that point for me, the game would have been worth paying for. My game groups loved this game and one of them really wanted to play another right after we finished our very first game of Scythe. Although in the first game I was the last place and got destroyed, I was very happy and excited to play my very first game and craving to play the next time where I will be able to make better decisions and have a better grasp of the game. I am looking forward to the expansions for the game and for multiple plays of the game in the future! Easy board game recommendation and this game really deserve the hype and rating that it gets.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Scythe is such an achievement in board game design! It's impossible to miss how much passion and attention to detail went into creating this; with its gorgeous art, captivating setting, interesting mechanics, and rock-solid euro-style gameplay. I must say, however, that with this game I realized that euros are not my favorite type: while attempting to optimize your turns to build your engine as fast as possible--and having to consider numerous aspects simultaneously--is a very interesting and strategic mental exercise, I missed the higher level of tension that other, more confrontational games offer. That being said, for those who like engine-building/worker-placement/area-control strategy games with an awesome theme, I don't think they get any better than this.

RATING: 9
I played it 3 times in the first week after it arrived, even Puerto Rico didn't see this type of table action. 
I am now up to 5 plays at all player counts except 2 players (the solo mode is exceptional at simulating an opponent) and it works at all of them. 
Yes there was a lot of hype but the game lives up to it. 
It's an absolutely stunning production, which you can't be indifferent to. Plus the game is actually phenomenal. The turns are simple, the rules are easy to grasp (amazing iconography helps), engine building mixed with combat and area majority.  What is there not to like?!

Might be a 10 after more plays.

RATING: 8.2
Splendide; clairement le plus beau jeu auquel j'ai joué. Extremememnt complet. A voir sur le moyen terme si c'est asez varié et ouvert. Danger de partie qui explose en vol. A deux les cartes ont trop d'impact. A plus il est possible que les cartes 2 soient trop handicapantes. Le systeme de combat est vraiment pas pafait mais l'expérience de jeu demeure très bonne.

La fin de partie est souvent décevante; il faut la modifier de manière impéative.

On a fait un 1er test avec les cartes de combat alternatives; ça marche plutot bien mais c'est Wordy.

1er test avec le vainqueur donne X-2 au perdant pour chaque carte joué; c'est simple et ça marche.

RATING: 8
Absolutely astonishing and beautiful and I don't even like eurogames (!).

Played it with 3 and 5 players. With 5 players 3 were new to the game so it actually took 5 hours. But it was good fun all up until the very last minute and we played with people that aren't even gamers. 

Only down part is, as with a lot of games where you spend eons of time building stuff up and collecting resources, when somebody sweeps in (especially later in the game) conquers you in battle and you lose all the stuff you wasted 3 rounds getting....you kinda wanna quit. You don't see the point anymore because winning is now gonna be very hard. For some people that's fine, but if you're a sore loser like me then it sucks. But, hey, it IS also the name of the game! So nothing wrong with the balance or mechanics or anything. The battle part is actually very good and fun :)  

Tots wants this amazing game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A komponensek gyönyörűek, a kivitelezés csodaszép. Egyedül talán a minik minősége nem 100%-os, de az is igaz, hogy nagyon magasan van már ezen a fronton a léc manapság. Nem kell megijedni azért ezek is 90%-osak. :)
A szabály elsőre soknak tűnik, de elég gyorsan összeállnak az akciók. Önmagukban, mert hogy összefüggéseiben átlássuk a játékot, ahhoz biztos kell 3-4 party. Szerencsére maga a játékmenet elég egyszerű, mert csak körbe-körbe akciózunk, nincsenek fázisok, nincs játék közbeni setupolás, adminisztráció, semmi. Egy kör is egyszerűnek tűnik elsőre: két akciónk van csak, egy felső és egy alsó.. Még így is vannak egész hosszúra nyúló körök, szóval nagyon jó, hogy ezt ilyen egyszerűre vették. Még elsőre is lement kicsivel, több, mint 2 óra alatt, szóval a dobozra írt játékidő reálisnak tűnik,
Érzések: kifejezetten jó játéknak tűnik, rengeteg újrajátszhatósággal, rengeteg felfedezni valóval. Csak minden mat megismeréséhez elég sokat kell játszani vele, és akkor még nem beszéltünk az építési bónuszok és a factory cardok által adott változatosságról. 

Jók az elemi lépések, mert ha pörgőssé nem is teszik a játékmenetet, de legalább tolerálható szinten tartják a holtidőt. Mondjuk ötösben azért elég nagy elszántság kéne ahhoz, hogy nekiüljek. 

A csatától nem annyira kell tartani, mert tényleg nem vészes mennyiségű, bár ez azért függ a játékosok vérmérsékletétől is. Nálunk három fővel összesen 5 csata volt, de nem agresszorkodtuk szét agyunkat első játékra. A harcot elég egyszerűre vették, viszont így kicsit semmilyen lett. Gondolom kockásat nem akartak, így maradt a kártyás+ nyersanyagelköltős változat, ami eléggé hasonlít a blood rage csatájára. 

Az első játék viszont fárasztóbb volt, mint amire számítottam, nem tudtam volna egy újabb partyt lejátszani. Nekem már megterhelően hevi kategóriába esett a játék, és az ilyenek nehezen kerülnek elő, még ha alapvetően jó játékok is. Ez persze még változhat a rutin a megszerzésével, csak kicsit csapdahelyzetet teremt. :)
7
----------
4-5 játék után már nem érzem megterhelőnek, ami igen jó pont. Kiinduló szettek kiegyensúlyozottságáról azonban messze nem vagyok meggyőződve, de jó móka mindent végigpróbálhatni, és agyalni rajta, hogy hogy lehet belőle kihozni a maximumot.
8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Scythe is an engine-building game that mostly concerns itself with action efficiency questions. There is an interesting action selection system (unless you are the Rosviet Union) but players spend the largest part of the game brooding over their own player boards while the only interaction point is the limited combat (which I generally am a fan of) that is most likely to occur when fighting for the final few VPs.
The end game seems a bit unbalanced but quite frankly, I find the game much too long for such a solitary efficiency exercise, so I'm kind of happy when it finally grinds to an abrupt halt.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Die 20er Jahre-Oktoberrevolution-Ästhetik gemixt mit Star Wars Retro Futurista, die durch überstilisierte, goldene Weizenfelder stapfen, ist grandios. Solch Crossover ist genau mein Ding. Die zielsichere Verortung im Pop hat mich auch schon bei EUPHORIA begeistert. Eine ideologische Färbung hinter den Fraktionen, die in einem Post-Weltkrieg-Szenario durch die Gegend streifen, kann ich nicht erkennen. SCYTHE lebt vonm intensiven Flavor und von dem atmosphärischen und materiellen Wohlstand. Es macht einfach Spaß sich mit seinen Mechs und Zeugs durch der Welt der Mad Max Bolschewisten zu bewegen. Spielerisch ist SCYTHE ein Wettrennspiel als weiterentwickeltes EUPHORIA: Hallo liebe Sterne! So ist das Tun von Dingen gegen Ende nicht mehr einem Spielinhalt gewidmet, sondern nur noch dafür da Sterne loszukriegen. Und das Freischalt-Tableau ist auch keine neue Erfindung, aber eine haptisch-visuelle Schönheit. SCYTHE ist eine sinnliche Abenteuerwelt, das sich seiner Effekthascherei nicht schämt. Wenn Pop es gelingt, sich selbst mit Spiel zu füllen, das es sich auch inhaltlich begründen lässt, dann darf es in meinem Regal auch gerne Platz für zwei einnehmen, die meinetwegen innovativer daherkommen, aber dafür mit weniger Möbeldesign. Man hätte SCYTHE auch als STYLE verkaufen können.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Finally got a chance to play this. Viticulture is one of my all time favorite games, this one has a similar vibe, only not as fun...in my very humble opinion. The player boards I found to be confusing and not intuitive. The battles seemed tacked on. I loved the encounters, but wished there was more of them. Eeeh, I feel like I am being pretty critical...but, as one of the hottest games of last year, I was expecting my socks to be knocked off...they wernt. I will say that it is gorgeous. The minis are fantastic...quality is amazing...I liked it, didnt love it.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Really well designed game. Fantastic artwork and superb connection of all these so many different actions that you can take throughout the game. By that I mean that after the first play everything seems to fall into place like and work together like pieces in a machine, and there is nothing that feels disjointed (like the priest track on TM, for example). Additionally, I think that -if well explained- how to win the game is rather clear as all your work and improvements gets translated into money at the end according to a very clear table on the board.
I also love how the direct combat has been integrated in this game without resulting into being too confrontational, and it is not terribly bad if you loose a fight.
It is a masterpiece. But I have to admit I spent the first rounds of the game thinking about a good excuse to leave the table it was totally overwhelming at first, and mid-game it seems it is never going to end. But after game, you realize that yes, the game will end and it can be understood, eventually all clicks into place beautifully. The word for it would not be complex, but an elaborated game both in terms of production and playing style.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I have rarely been so impressed with a game. Maybe it just hits my style perfectly, but the elegance of the design is something I'll aspire to for years to come.

RATING: 7
WON IN 401 GAMES BLACK FRIDAY GIVE-AWAY CONTEST, 2016!!!

I like it! I was a little surprised at what a plainly-fashioned Euro it is once you look through the chrome. But the parts work well together as a whole. I was a little nervous about playing it 5-player the first time, but turns moved through quickly.  There's some fiddly stuff going on here and there, but nothing overly frustrating.  After two plays I think I'd like it better with 4 players. I continue to feel motivated to play it again and attempt to do better. I'm unsure at this point how many plays it would take before I was tired of - what is essentially - a resource acquisition and player board upgrade game.  There is a lot I find interesting in Scythe, but I think there are one or two other games that do better what this game also seeks to achieve. Still, it's a beautiful game to look at, definitely feels distinct among other "Euro/Ameritrash" hybrids, and it doesn't get boring.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
fabulous
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game that lives up to the hype, with quite quick and easy play and plenty of replayability. One of the best games I have played. 

Positives:
Quick turns
4 action spaces with actions that get better as you play
Deterministic combat (and combat a really small part of the game)
Cool components
Variable factions, that are very different to play. 
Great combination of systems with popularity track and military track that went up and down according to actions. 

Negatives (really trying to find any): 
Use workers to deter opponents from attacking...not really intuitive. I hesitate to leave a worker on his own, but taking the tile leads to no battle (that can give VP) and minus to the very important popularity. 
In the end picking stars and VP is all it is about and trying to improve your civ is not the best action (or in some cases not useful at all), just go for the stars. 
First player is great to be and you get nothing for beeing last. I was first and ended the game and therefore got to do more turns than everyone else. 
Resources are needed in great quantity to do things, so you need many workers there and once you are done the resources from that spot are useless, they give VP but just lay there...a bit unsatisfying. 
Feels like alternating between produce and upgrade should clearly be the best strategy. But if that is possible depend on the faction you are and the board you get. If it is possible for you, you have a great chance of winning. 
Too much space on the board. Fighting for space is not needed, so battles are mostly to interrupt someone and to get stars for winning battles. Would be great if it was useful in the game to win battles also.
Too much importance of being the player that end the game. 
Randomness from misson draw and exploration cards can impact the game too much. 
Draw one combat card before battle can decide the winner of the game. More randomness that each does not decide the game would have been better. 

Still a great game after 4 plays with huge variation between games. Some games end before you want them to, one game with 3p only took 50min but what a game. So many interesting choices and so much progress during the game. Love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
INITIAL IMPRESSION
Enjoyed this Euro "4x" game.  I would say this game is more about resource management and utilizing your player board/special abilities more than anything. The opening is a bit solitaire, everyone is isolated until they get certain upgrades to let them move out

The interesting thing for me in this game is the massive amount of scoring options in this game. Almost everything will get you an objective star but popularity is important to make each of those worth more points. Also there is territory control and when to end the game

My only negative was the timing of when the game ends because the first player in our game got 1 extra turn more than everyone else, which was the difference. But we also may have played the turn order wrong with which starting boards we had

RATING: 6
Played once with experienced players.  I won with the Yellow Faction and it seemed too easy - the choices were too limited and the amount of tension just wasn't that great.  Combat happens, but the consequences are trivial enough that it seems like not big deal if you lose.  The tech tree (building mechs and upgrading) provides a small amount of differentiation, but not enough to feel like it is very significant.  Most of the time you have one decision every few turns that is significant, and it is typically binary - then it plays out in sequence for a turn or two, and then you have another.  I pretty much did what I wanted with very little or no significant interference.   It just lacked tension and excitement.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my favorite games at the moment. Something that actually lived up to the hype.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
4X games have had a hard time hitting my table because my wife just hates building an empire with the thought that someone could just come and ruin it all in a turn. In that kind of games, there is definitely a fine line between exciting tension and frustration, which also depends a lot about the personality of the players around the table. 

For instance, Game of Thrones The board Game unapologetically encourages conflicts, fights and low-blows as it believes players do seek interactions. To us, this is too aggressive. 

Archipelago focuses on Euro type of indirect interactions with a race to deplete resources or secure the best opportunities on the markets. For us, this is just too un-exciting.

Twilight Imperium believes players do seek positive interactions as well, and therefore offers alternative types of interactions, like trading, politics, etc.

Scythe tries another alternative: Cold-War type of tension. Each player has this army of mechs and temptation to use them to attack the other players is high. But the winner is likely to be the one who is firm albeit popular (both with the virtual farming community and with the other players). Because rewards for combats are just not worth the effort. The smartest players will have an army to ascertain their power but do not strike first.

And disappointingly, this tension is the only type of interaction between players in the game, as Scythe at its core is an economic engine builder, and most of the action happens on the individual player mats. The engine is fun to build and well balanced but nowhere as fine-tuned as an Agricola or a Dominion.

So we've added some interaction as an house-rule. When a player is supposed to pick an encounter card and read it for him/herself, we instead have another player do it and describe the picture with the different decisions (but does not give away the benefits) for the initial player to choose from. Inspired by Dead Of Winter or Time Stories, I guess.
It helps with immersion and player interaction, but I appreciate that it affects the balance somehow as it makes encounters less impactful.

We have only played the game as a 2-player where player interaction is at its lowest, but overall, I can see that beyond the outstanding art, the game is good and elegant. To me, It isn't the best design ever, but it is enough to make me want to play it again and again, with more players, maybe. But those players would have to be selected carefully to avoid ruining everyone else's experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Second solo on Autometta level was a win 84-56.  Having the starting faction farther away made a huge difference.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Well... I wanted to play it a few times before I rated it, and I can safely say, that I really enjoy this game.

More importantly, my Fiancee really enjoys it! :D

There are a lot of choices to make, and it's a bit of a puzzle without being Terra Mystica level brain burning - this is important since, although it's a euro at its heart, there is combat and encounters and a little bit of that ameritrash swing.

After the first play games typically run 1.5 hours in my experience and yet they always feel epic and end while the game is still fun.  In fact, that is one of the better aspects of the game that I haven't seen a lot of discussion on: you can't/ won't do everything in a game, and neither will your opponents, which means that as you try to anticipate your opponents and outmaneuver or outwit them you can make mistakes, costly mistakes in a game that is all about efficiency.

Let me say that again, this game is all about making efficient moves.  It's really addictive that way - and I love when you are forced to make a less than optimal move because, well, you aren't ready to take that bottom row action but you really need to move your mechs or your opponent can literally walk into your territory and take all your resources.

There is something almost chess-like about think turns ahead for yourself, and also trying to anticipate your opponents.

But this IS NOT a multiplayer solitaire as some have said.  I don't know where they are getting that from...  There a number of interactions between players, let me count the ways:

Combat, not that often, really, and yet some games has a lot of it.  This is because once someone starts a fight, it tends to lead to new fights as your opponents spend precious power and make themselves vulnerable.  But as it has been stated (repeatedly, although for good reason) the threat of combat is as important as really combat.  No really!  For the exact reason I highlighted above.  Maybe you don't really want to invade your neighbor, but you put your mech next to his unguarded territory precisely so he has to take a less than efficient action!

You will race each other for the encounters, which as the swingyest and most ameritrashy part of the game and really, really add a lot to the constant fun and replayabilitiy of this game.  I love that these encounters alone counteract the possibility of dominant strategies making the game feel stale because the player who adapts based on the fortune of these cards will beat the player that is fixed on doing his/her own thing.

There is also an action called "enlist" that allows you to make money based on other peoples choices!  Thus, anticipating what actions your opponents will make can earn you an important advantage.  It reminds me of 7-wonders, and creates that same sense of interaction even as you do you, and your opponents do what they do.

Although, this does lead me to my number one criticism.  By and large the theme of this game is great.  Honestly, I wouldn't have KS'd it if was based in space.  But alternate history 1920s with Mechs?  Yes please.  However, what the heck is with the enlist action?  Who are you enlisting?  Why are they moving from the bottom board to the top board?  Are they mech pilots?  How were the mechs moving before the enlists people?  Why are they represented by cylinders?  In a game that otherwise does a great job on every detail (I love how resources and worker are wood and heroes and units are plastic) this befuddles me! 

Overall, great game.  If it stays fresh and fun after repeatedly play, I might even move up to a 10!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Highlight: 2016.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
First time I played I just let the game wash over me so I could admire the beauty of what $59 and patients brings. The second time I was critical and it is still a ten for and here is why:
The game has some many great things from some many great games. 
El grande has the secret dial for where you will place your mepples. Scythe uses this as the fog of war with extra battle cards. 
Minitures or my personal favorite "board games with Scott" says dolls have be painted made designed for play for a long time. 
Scythe not only has will detailed mintures but a purpose. Plastic can battle but wood can not. 
Settlers of catan allowed you to start at one location and then built were you wanted to go with the constraints of players on materials you need to gather. 
Scythe does this uniquely with rivers and lakes that you will have to travel around. 
Proxima Centria has this terrific tech tree that has four different technologies that you can built that then support your later purchases. 
Scythe has a simple upgrade tech tree that then your faction becomes more efficient with your building. 
Hyperbola is a wonderful 4x game getting technologies or extra moves and extra cubes to advance your clan to getting closer to gain area control of all section exspecially the middle tile. 
Scythe allows you to get an ancient technology that allows for an entirely new two new action selections to choose from. 
Dominare is a game that you can move your influence of people on a board depicting spaces of different political sections. Once you put you influence into a space of someone esle hard fought political investment their cubes can disappear like they were never there. 
Scythe has battle but the mepples and mechs and character do not go away. They just go back home to lick their wounds to come and fight again. 

This is just five game explains of many more to find in Scythe. Just from the five games I have mentioned about a $300 investment to the low price of $59. 
I feel that it does what it is suppose to. It is a game that gathers great mechanisms from the greatest games made. This is why the game should number one. 
And the next game that surpasses Scythe should be a game that takes a bit from it too.

RATING: 8
Collector's Edition from Kickstarter. Everything about this game appeals to me, from the theme and Jakub's artwork which initially intrigued me and attracted me to the Kickstarter to the lavish production. All of that is very well, and I certainly don't own any other game with anything approaching this level of aesthetic appeal, but what about the game? Well, it actually exceeded my high expectations and I find myself completely absorbed in the experience from set up to end of game scoring. Every decision, every action taken, every move anticipated. And then find myself thinking about it for hours afterwards, eagerly looking forward to the next play.

Yes it was hyped. But for me, it hasn't disappointed at all. Potentially my favourite game of all time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love what this game is trying to do, and I love the way it looks. It's an elegant little machine with interlocking moving parts that you can upgrade and build to get yourself to victory. The production values are second to none, and every part is designed with thought and care.

The game has engine building, it has area control, and it has resource management. It does also have combat elements, but don't go into it expecting a full 4X or you'll be disappointed.

My main complaint is it always goes longer than the box claims so it can be a bit of a marathon. I've played with 4, but I can't see myself playing with any more than that as it would just take too long.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Scythe is without question one of my favorite games if not my favorite game. It is certainly the one I suggest first and can easily play all day. It is designed so that just one strategy isn't always the winner and you don't know what you are going to have to try and do to win until the game is laid out. It also has aspects that appeal to many, resources, expanding your territory, gaining wealth and of course if you like warfare and conquering. It is very well balanced and probably one of the few games that the same couple of people aren't winning all the time. It holds my attention and I'm not reaching for my phone while waiting for my turn which for me, says it all.
When we first started playing this game many of my gaming friends who are women took one look and said no way. After playing though, almost all are hooked.
Can't recommend this game high enough.

RATING: N/A
Impression after the first game: Disappointing! Definitely it needs more plays to get in the game and the strategic possibilities. It is a 4X game without explore and not really exterminate. It needs more variability, primarily the board. The only variability are the factions and the cards and that's to less for a game like this.
So, I think it's an overrated game. In this day and age a game needs more than a great artwork, a alternative background story and an overhyped kickstarter campaign!

RATING: 9
1-5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I think this game is the best for what it is and most people that don't like it didn't manage expectations for what that is correctly before they gave it a try. I like to describe it as "who can farm the best while winning a popularity contest before a big giant robot fight to end it all." 

No one else says this, but it feels like Concordia to me. Takes about the same amount of time (if every one knows how to play, but for teaching new people Concordia is much faster and simpler), same sort of resource optimization, and similar degrees of player interaction. Concordia might do the last part a bit better, but this has more interesting optimization/conversion problems, looks a billion times better, and gives you a better feeling of tension/conflict. Since, you know, you're a burgeoning civilization, and not just yet another trader.

RATING: 5.7
I regret to say that I bought this game in December 2016 based solely on hype, the beautiful art and BGG player feedback, but this game is the reason why you should try before you buy. When I played it solo, it felt uninspired and plodding. But I assumed that was due to no human interaction and a wide open board space created by basically a two-player set up. But after playing it with four players, my thoughts haven't changed. I'm just not excited about this one. Now, I'll get flamed for my poor rating and that's OK. I don't know how to excel at this game and I'm sure that factors in here somewhat. But even if I got better and more efficient at the game, I just know I wouldn't find it fun. There are some cool design elements in this game and the production quality is off the charts awesome, but unfortunately, this one is not for me.

RATING: 3

RATING: 7
A beautifully produced strategy game. Thanks artwork and components are great, and I love the player board with bad relief and the bonuses under the tokens. It's the first time I used the term "user experience" to describe a boardgame.
Gameplay is more about unit and resource management than fighting for the map.

The main downside for me is the map. Everyone starts in safe areas then can advance to the middle, where there will be fights. It's pretty much symmetrical and, as such, boring. If I was expanding the game I'd start by making a new map.

RATING: 8
Ok, with three plays under my belt I think this is pretty damn good.  Of course I was made wary by the hype, but it's got a solid core of Eurogame with some nice 4x elements.  Vaguely reminiscent of the way Dominant Species marries worker placement and wargame.  Only played 2P so far, but it seems to work very nicely at that player count, and each game has felt pretty different as we've worked with the different factions and player boards.  I guess I can imagine the game getting same-y or feeling like it's on rails after a dozen plays, but I'm not sure that'll happen.  Very interested to play it with 3P or more.

RATING: 9
Way more enjoyable than I anticipated it to be. I was aware that the game had area control and combat so I expected to not particularly enjoy it, but those aspects of the game are only as important as you want them to be. You can focus your energy on scoring stars in different ways like upgrading, building and getting out all of your workers. You can't ignore the area control aspect completely, but it's definitely not necessarily the focus. This game truly does seem to have something for everyone, plus the artwork is stunning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I think this is one of the best examples of what modern board games are becoming. Intellectual, beautiful and impeccably designed. 

Component wise this is the star of board gaming, but in some ways I think it suffers from that as many dismiss it as being just a very beautiful game without substance. However, there is a really good game here too!

It certainly gets better the more you play it, so perhaps the first few playthroughs might feel a little flat for some, but it's grown into a fantastic game for me. I think it's improved quite a bit with the Wind Gambit expansion (maybe 8.5 without).
