RATING: 8
Boardgame / 1-5 players
Jamey Stegmaier / Stonemaier Games
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After one play of this game, I know it will be one of my all time favorites. I love the variability, quick turns and exceptional art. The mechanics work well to make a very balanced game. A few things I wish I would have known in order to make the first play more enjoyable: 1) the manual recommends stopping halfway through the first game and tallying up points so that all players get a better idea of what scoring will look like. This would have been very useful during my first game as I expended all my resources and put popularity as a lower priority. 2) We didn't pay much attention to the factory, but actually if you control it (literally just have a mech or worker on it) at the end of the game, then you get 3 VPs. 3) The expedition cards have really cool stories on them! Be sure show the art and read the choices out loud when you grab an expedition card. It adds an extra layer of depth to the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Scythe was my personal Pandemic Legacy story. Once I tried it, despite a terrible first game I loved it and couldn't play it enough! It's my first Kickstarter regret story also; I purchased the retail edition as soon as it became available, and have since picked up some of the extra stuff like the bigger board extension and extra power dials, but I do wish I had those metal coins and realistic resource tokens!

Scythe has shot to the top of my personal top ten, and is only the second game I've deemed worthy of a perfect 10 rating.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Bought this at SPIEL16 for €80. Played it 5 times now and frankly I'm pretty much underwhelmed. Sure: the artwork is top notch as are the minis and the game components.

But from a gamers perspective, Scythe is just a "solid" game. It tries to be everything at once without excelling anywhere: ressource management is pretty simple: on commodity can buy exactly one thing (mech, building, recruit, tech). No interdependencies, no variable prices, no limits at all. Pretty simple.

Same holds for the "battle" aspect. As soon as everyone has upgraded their mechs, there are no places to hide. Just build up military strength, jump on the weakest opponent and crush him. Its as simple as that.

Finally the narrative aspect. The so called encounter cards have always the same structure and therefore simply just provide  bunch of free ressources.

All in all, Scythe is a just race to reach as many goals as fast as possible. The number of options while working on that are far more limited as one might expect. From all 2016 games games I'd prefer Terraforming Mars over Scythe at any time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
While mechanically Scythe is a well made game, it definitely is not the game advertised. This really is a Euro game of efficiency that tries to toss in a few other mechanics to fool you into thinking it is more than the sum of its parts.

If you are looking for a good Euro efficiency game in the vein of Terra Mystica (not quite as good but almost) it is worth a purchase. If you are seeking a great combination of a Area Control 4x game with deep 4x mechanics in a Euro package, walk away, you will be disappointed.

RATING: 7.5

Bins
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Downgraded score to five after multiple plays. 

A mediocre game hidden inside a bubble of overproduced art and insane hype. The mechanics are all about engine optimization, but the different engine parts don't tie in with each other nor with the theme in any meaningful way. 

The ridiculously busy board is a jumbled mess where terrain features and restrictions on movement is redundant as everyone is just warping/jumping around anyway. Combat is generally a meaningless option to go for and is also done in a pretty uninspiring way (just spam combat cards). 

The actual gameplay, while mildly engaging at first, quickly becomes a dull affair where you're basically trying to empty your player board as soon as possible by repeating the same shallow moves over and over. But my main gripe with this game is that it lacks a fundamental part of good board game design: player interaction. There is none. And that sucks. 

That a game like this is ranked so highly just goes to show that the general public will always prefer shiny things over substance, I guess. Or that hype is a powerful force. Or perhaps both.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really enjoyable "machine" building with a lot of options! Asymmetric factions, all with their own very unique and powerful strengths. Intuitive rules, but it took one playthrough to get the rules to stick. Great art! I recommend adding the realistic resources and metal coins (they add a lot of feeling when playing!). Also the board extension is a good buy. Decent diversity as you replay it. Not as much combat as you'd think, which I liked. The two downsides are (1) that one or two factions are much tougher early and mid game if you don't get the right "machine" with it, and (2) that the end turn can sometimes be a bit anticlimactic.

RATING: 9
Played with 2 players. The artwork and components are absolutely phenomenal, but given that it's Stonemaier and we got the Collector's Edition I am not surprised. The mechanics were smooth and interesting, and there were lots of great choices. Since we only had two, it tended more towards the Euro side of the spectrum (which is fine by me!) but I'd also love to see how it would go with 4. Definitely shot up on our list of favorites.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Yera

Se presenta como un 4X pero en realidad es mas bien un euro de gestion de recursos y colocacion de trabajadores. 

La presentacion es acojonantemente buena (sobre todo si te haces con los recursos y monedas de metal). 

Jugablemente es un poco teledirigido para el gusto de la mayoria de eurofans. en mi opinion es excelente, porque te permite centrarte (o al menos intentarlo) en la estrategia para ganar la partida y no en la metodologia de cómo hacerlo siguiendo las reglas mas o menos bienpensadas del juego, que es lo que ocurre en la mayoria de "euros culoduro". 

en mi opinion, consigue la profundidad de desarrollo de los mejores euros, con una presentacion muy ameri, y un desarrollo de juego muy fluido. 

probablemente lo "peor" del juego es que eso de 4X esta muy cogido con alfileres. expansion? check. y de hecho es uno de los factores mas importantes sinó el que mas para ganar la partida. exploracion? check. y es un factor bastante importante para ganar la partida. explotacion? check. y es un factor esencial para poder desarrollarte y ganar la partida. exterminacion? not check. cuando hay un combate (las pocas veces que los hay) se resuelve en UNA accion (bueno, no se para la partida 20 minutos como ocurre en runewars, eclipse o starcraft, algo bueno debia de tener), pero el tema es que al enemigo no se le extermina, solo se le manda a casa con una regañina, con lo cual lo de "exterminar" al enemigo, solo sirve para mantener ocupada la casilla por el motivo que sea que la quieres, y para ganar la estrellita (o dos estrellitas) de ganar combate lo que puede estar bien en el computo global de la partida (el conteo de puntos se activa cuando alguien hace 6 estrellitas de completar cosas que hacer).... pero por lo demas... no tiene ese factor de batalla gorda y aniquilacion del enemigo que tienen otros 4X como los mencionados, y en el balance queda un poco "flojo". de hecho es perfectamente posible ganar el juego sin entablar ni un solo combate, y no digamos ya ganarlo. 

aun con eso, en mi opinion un muy excelente juego. se merece el "9".

RATING: 6
Here comes the hype and right there it ends, again.

I'm already VERY cautious when it comes to hyped games, especially with that much chrome. Well, Scythe is not a bad game, but it's not great either. It's just another good game, nothing more and there are many good games out there already.

The game feels constructed and solitaire. It seems that the tunnels and the city space in the middle have been added for the sole reason to get the game moving atleast a bit.

The player board and the popularity track on the other hand are great, but the rest feels way too constructed, just to form anything around that player board.

Good and completely overproduced game, but nothing more.

RATING: 9
Finally got my preordered Scythe just before Christmas and have been enjoying it immensely. This is everything I wanted Eclipse to be: more cube pushing and (a lot) less conflict. The game is easy to grasp and flows smoothly, but there's a lot of depth under the chrome. Which brings me to the stunning artwork and all-around stellar production quality: it certainly doesn't hurt that the game is gorgeous to look at. (29.12.16)

Scythe keeps being great. The looks are a bit deceiving in that it's really a race to build the most efficient engine and rev it a couple of times to end the game. The spatial challenge in the form of the map makes it so you can't ignore other players and it brings a good dose of interaction. I especially like that when everybody knows how to play we have managed to play a 3-player game in an hour and the game flows very smoothly and it feels like your turn is all the time. (20.10.2017)

RATING: 10
I haven't played hundreds of games, but I've played several dozen. This game really changed my perception about what a game could/should/had-to be. No round structure, so no end of round upkeep. The artwork is exciting, every time someone pulls an encounter card I am excited to see it, even if I have seen it before. In my collection, it has the best component quality. It's possible it is my favorite game, but I'm not sure cause at any given time I'm excited to play a few games in my collection. But of all the games I'm usually most excited to play this one has been played the most by me, but part of that is a friend who also really likes it. I thought about giving it a 9.x to leave room for some game I wanted to rate higher but, if a game blows it out of the water for me I can always change the rating. I don't know what to change about it to make it better.

RATING: 8
There's so much to like about this game: the richly evocative theme, the elegant mechanics, the incredible production values.  I don't normally like games that involve players directly attacking one another, but it's very well balanced here in that winning a battle tends to be as costly to the attacker as to the defender.  The result is a dance of feints and tactical retreats rather than a bloody war of attrition.

RATING: N/A
In ZRH-EURA (locked)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Scythe lives up to the hype. It's a deep game that requires careful execution of a strategy to avoid falling behind, yet as combat creeps into the later game it also provides a means to set back the players who have pulled ahead. I love games with variable player powers and starting setups. In many ways, Scythe reminds me of Terra Mystica in that regard. You will be pointed in a certain direction from the start, but even with the same starting setup, two players may choose totally different ways to execute on it. The biggest drawback for me is the endgame, which has a tendency to bog down in calculations (there is very little hidden information). The penalty for taking too long is to be reduced on one of the tracks, but this is a kludgy solution that is also ineffective sometimes. (A player may be at zero on that track already and take as long as he likes?) I find this game to be intellectually appealing, satisfying to play, and also incredibly difficult to play well. You have to be ready for a heady experience, not filled with thrilling turns of fate, but rather the satisfaction of seeing a plan come together.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Scythe is all about efficiency, which means it's all about the excellent Upgrade action. I love the way it works, remove a cube from the top row action (making the benefit better) and add it to a bottom row action (making the cost lower). If you want to encourage more player interaction house rule combat so that the winner is awarded a star only if he was also the aggressor. 

Excellent game, with little down time (even at 5 players) that never drags with either of my groups.

RATING: 7.5
After 19 plays (of which ~5 multiplayer and the rest solo) I'm still not completely sold on the Hype Game 2016. 

Some games are interesting, others not so much. First turns feel scripted; the factions powers are really not that important (the mech powers are more interesting); the encounters lose their fascination quickly. I do like the map mechanics (movement, mechs carrying workers etc; tunnels).

The artwork is unreal but the implementation could be better, as I find the colors too muted.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
This is simply one of the best game i have ever played. The rules seem to be quite heavy at first but it gets clear very fast just after a few turns. The player boards where you are upgrading your factions are super well designed as there are holes which can be covered, or uncovered over time by doing it you will get even more upgrades. So basicly this functioning as a tech tree which is one of the most clever idea in my gaming experience. There is a really strong theme going on there with gorgous artwork and the highest quality components everywhere. I prefer a bit more interaction though but at least there is an option to attack each other even if this  happens on a very rare occasion. The interaction is more likely to watch over your neighbours and upgrading yours techtree to get more income till the midgame starts. The playtime was around 2 hours which is acceptable for such a deep strategy game. There is a little language independency but with one person at the table who knows the language can translate the few drawn cards easily. Well in the end im not sure if this has a good price / value or not as the pricetag is really high but you get a chunky box with full of high quality components. I feel huge replayability here as there are 5 factions which of course you would like to play at least two times. After i finished my second game i love this game even more. Fantastic correlation between the choosable actions.

RATING: N/A
Tabletop Simulator
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Scythe is a very nicely themed Weuro, with Stegmaier accomplishment stars for one-time achievements, but a rather thematic VP system ranking players on territory, power, goods, and buildings after game end is triggered.

Players have a choice of several actions, but cannot repeat actions in a Rondel like effect.

If reqs are met these can be double actions, so players have to set up and optimize their expansion engines.

Faction boards and action boards are separate as well, so each faction's overall abilities will vary from game to game.

The game includes and encourages Combat between players factions, but it also ceases to reward combat for most factions, which leads to some interesting choices.

The artwork is stunning, and the game is pretty awesome.

I expect this game to improve in rating as it is played more- this is simply a terrific product in all ways.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Complex, beutifull, fun and made by gamers. What else do you need?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great engine builder with some map movement and occasional battles. It's a clever hybrid, having such an abstract, heavy Euro core - the vain attempt at optimisation through the manifold combinations of nations and action sheets feels almost too contrived for my tastes and sometimes broke my immersion... but the wonderful illustrations around which the whole game is built tend to bring you back in. All in all the balance between dry engine building and thematic elaboration makes for a really good game (the artwork probably being responsible for the big hype in the end).
The big question: isn't something like Terra Mystica a very similar game, but more elgant?

RATING: 10
Played twice so far, and I rate it a tentative 9, with potential for improvement!  The game attempts to blend theme, (mostly) luckless mechanics and asymmetry while keeping the playtime manageable.  To this end it is extremely successful, and I look forward to assessing the longevity further down the line.  There are many moving parts, but each player is limited to three or four distinct options each turn which helps keep the game moving very well.

Another two plays.  Up to 9.5.

Played around half a dozen times now, and it retains its appeal.  This is one of the most well rounded games in my collection!  I think it deserves a 10.

RATING: 9
Eurostyle resource game with the possibility of war (but mostly deterrence). The game has the most elegant artwork ever, fascinating upgrading mechanism, it's an easy-to-learn game with fast rounds, where things start to happen early, with très fun explorer cards - and the game comes with metal coins! Endscoring seems made unneccesary complex (the game had been perfectly good also without the popularity multiplier), not too much player interaction during play, the mechs are too big for the board (yes, it is possible to buy a bigger board, but I will rather have smaller mechs), and the fighting part is a bit boring. Apart from that - love it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Upgraded my rating from 8 to 9 because I've played Scythe more than any substantial game I own and I continue to enjoy playing it and the more I play it, the more I learn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I love this game. Engine-building concept allows you to continuously pull in resources and cover ground on the gameboard. But spreading your nation's territory also means encroaching on another's turf. This leads to constant cold-war feelings while all players decide if they want to go to war for territory and combat victories, while sacrificing popularity (a final score multiplier). Plenty of additional actions, secret victories, encounter cards with bonuses, and player characters with unique abilities keeps the game fun after many plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The theme of the game is too far fetched. A big no-no for me. 

Movement rules in this game (you can move from tile A to B, but not from B to A) are bad.

Another flaw of this game is that the actions you take each turn are very unintuitive. There is no theme to the actions, they are just incoherent manipulations of the game board. The actions trigger many effects on the game board at the same time, and therefore taking actions feels more like triggering chaos than carefully and orderly expanding.

To me, this game feels like a clusterfuck with animals and mechs walking around in a post ww1 setting, using rules and game mechanics that want to be all, but fail in most aspects. Big disappointment after all the hype.

Disclaimer : I usually like low conflict euros. I have been really disappointed by this game. It really is overrated. The production might be gorgeous, but the gameplay doesn't live up to it : it's too linear, the game gives you the illusion that you have plenty of choices but in reality if you don't follow that optimal path set before you, you won't do well. The asymetry, while present, is only present in slight details and in the end the factions seem more or less the same. I'll keep playing Clash of Cultures and might revisit this one a last time before deciding to get rid of it.

RATING: 8
Beautiful and interesting.  A very fast, contrary to what it looks like, worker placement game. Requires you to put your full attention into the game, especially that there is a lot of parameters on your opponent’s action card that you must put attention to.  The military dimension is practically non-existent, which Is strange in the game that is being advertised with the pictures of mechs.  The story behind the game is neglectable,  but there are some comedy relief elements one would not usually expect in anything related to central-eastern Europe’s  history in first half of 20th century. Overall a pleasant game  - much lighter than one would expect, but still not an entry level game. Innovative mechanics. High quality components, worth the price.

RATING: 7
Components and art direction are fantastic and contribute in no small part to the rating for this game. It's just beautiful to look at. As far as the gameplay, I believe the pace of the game is odd. It starts extremely slow and ramps up way too quickly. I wish the game had different game ending triggers. Unless you are the one triggering the game end conditions, the ending is always anti-climatic and because of the nature of certain objectives you simply have no way to know when the game will end which makes it impossible for you to properly plan your strategy and more often then not, you don't see it come to full fruition. You could argue Terraforming Mars shares a similar type of game ending mechanic but in TM, you have more information available to better estimate and predict when the game ending will occur. I don't think Scythe does as good of a job at that.

RATING: 7
After having played this twice, I will say while the consideration of the action asymmetry different players have was done with care in most cases, the actual "freedom" one has is relatively limited. The board is tight, and false choices in one's own actions abound, for if your neighbors are inclined to take certain actions, there are few sensible options for you to perform. Though masquerading as a mech-based game, Scythe is more a euro-style action management affair.

PROS: AMAZING ARTWORK,COMPONENT! EASY TO LEARN DESIGN

COMMENT: NOT UP TO THE HYPE!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A nice mix of area control, engine building, worker placement(ish) and resource management. Has worked well at 2, 3 and 4 player counts so far.

Like: Each individual turn is quick, which makes the game feel well paced and keeps everyone involved. The pace of progression escalates nicely, as a 'slow' early game suddenly turns into most players having a star or two of the six needed, with the potential for more not far away. The 'race' nature of the end game makes for interesting choices around priorities, and control over that ending is a powerful dynamic - the "if I had one more turn..." feeling makes for tense, interesting finishes to games.

Dislike: It is possible to lose any chance of winning quite early on, identify that, and still have to play out 90 more minutes of game - it's good that it's clearly identifiable though, as it makes it easier to learn from. The combat isn't great, and can often just make a player a target for someone else to get free stars in the future. Some faction abilities feel more obviously powerful than others, although playing more may reveal different strategies to take advantage of different faction powers. A player prone to 'analysis paralysis' can really slow the game down to unbearable levels - there's no reasonable excuse that a movement action should take 15 minutes to figure out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Spiel'17 purchase

RATING: 10
Mind-blowing. Instant classic.

RATING: N/A
Collectors Edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Could have been a great game but falls short on many levels.  The World of Jakub could have been used to a much better effect, here it just feels like some pretty pictures with some plastic Mech's thrown in with an average game buried underneath.  

The game suffers from being over polished and play tested to death.  The game doesn't feel organic, and has no mystery left to discover after one play.  The pseudo 4X label is  just that, a pretend label, the lack of exploring in the game and lack of player interaction, creates a huge disconnect with the world the game is set in.  There are too many ideas thrown into one game that are under developed, and feel dumbed down.  

The players are never challenged to step outside of the rather simple collect resources for stars, game mechanic, which leads to a rinse and repeat game.  Having each race start in the same location every game is lazy design, and the river walk ability is odd.  The asymmetrical action boards are half baked, make the top area of each board tie in with the name, ie - the agricultural board has all the farming hex ability open from the start, but less movement, or zero bolster.  The highlight of the Game is the art work, the worst part of the game is the underdeveloped mechanics and lack of consequence, the game is to friendly, it feels like a child friendly, my first 4X, without the excitiment of exploring and exterminating.

Pros - 
Artwork
Overall Production
Easy to learn
5 player game can last 60 mins

Cons-
Each element feels underdeveloped
The Art and gameplay don't match
It has a 4X label and has only 2X at most
The Mech miniatures are some of the worst quality I have seen in a long time
a HUGE lack of player interaction, its basically a solo game for up to 5 players
Lacks replay value due to races being locked to the same start position
Immersion - A lack of
Solo mode

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very good quality components. Interesting artwork and theme. The game itself has some originality in the action selection mechanism (which is possibly the best part of the game), but overall it is an awkward mash-up of engine building that rewards specialisation with a VP salad approach that encourages diversity plus a half-hearted combat aspect tacked on. While combat is not a core element of the game, and generally only contributes marginally towards victory in a direct way, it can really derail a player who is attacked a few times in quick succession. All in all, I get the impression that the designer couldn't decide between an engine-building game, a Stefan Feld-style Euro or a 4X game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1

Factions are blatantly unbalanced (Black being the weakest in my opinion) and the game actually brings nothing special in the world of boardgaming.
It's enjoyable and lasts enough for a good game experience, with 5 players the downtime is a bit bothersome.

RATING: 4

The teleporters are clearly there to make up for the dreadful imbalance that the game would have without them...and they are a serious gimmick.  It essentially encourages 3 of the 4 players to pick on the weakest....which has happened in the 2 games I've either played or watched.

That does not make a game good.  It makes it bad.

RATING: 10
A well-realized game of worker placement and engine building, featuring exquisite art and components. By  Jamey Stegmaier.

The asymmetry here makes for great fun, especially at the beginning, when you draw your faction and begin to formulate a strategy based on that faction's abilities. Just a really great game, deserving of its popularity. I do wish every territory space featured an encounter token, because I enjoy the flavor those cards add, but that would probably speed up the game too much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Visually stunning artwork and easily accessible game.
This game was quick to understand for new players and does a great job of easing players into the game over a few rounds.  Although all of the characters are variations of the same basic formula, there is just enough variation to make mastering a strategy for each one a challenge.  Its streamlined turns made for an enjoyable pace even at high player counts.  The theme is well reflected in the beautiful board, metal coins and various cards.  The highly detailed miniatures are also great added value.
Overall, an excellent game that I'm sure to pull out many times in the future, especially with new players.

RATING: 10
Very "thinky" resource game with some very clever mechanisms, beautiful artwork and components (I have the Collector's Edition), plus the constant threat of combat. The Automa for the game (solo version) is also excellent and provides even more opportunities for this to hit the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a pretty slick game, in fact it's probably a bit too slick. Or really just a bit too streamlined. It felt a bit like the designer sanded most of the interesting parts off of the game.

It did what it was supposed to do, I was strategizing and planning a few turns ahead, but I didn't really feel anything to distinguish this from a long list of competently designed but uninspired eurogames. I think a good example is how the resources correspond one to one with the bottom actions, and how having some mixed costs would maybe just add another layer to the thought process. The whole game felt like that though, overly streamlined.

And I like the special player powers and the different faction boards, but it can be pretty frustrating when they don't align or when the goal cards don't align with them. It seems like you can mostly make it work, but it still doesn't feel good.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a very unique game.  While it has the appearance of an Amerigame wargame, conflict is actually only a small albeit not unimportant part of it.  This is more an economic game than a wargame.  The primary goal is to gain six stars, mostly via a number of economic parameters like building all your buildings or maxing out a rating but also by winning a couple battles.  Even then, it's not the person who ended the game who necessarily wins, although having stars helps.  The game is mostly about maximizing the payoff from each turn while juggling a number of considerations of which board position is only one.  Each turn you can choose one action but you can't choose the same action twice in a row so you have to figure out what combination of actions will get you where you want to be.  Each action also provides the option to accomplish an improvement of some sort, like a new building or a new mech to fight with.  Each such improvement also provides a unique advantage of some sort so you have to choose carefully.  Ultimately you're trying to max out as many things as possible (like build all your buildings or build all your mechs or all your workers) to win stars but you don't have time to do all of them so you have to decide which to go for.  Even then that's not enough because you also get points for number of spaces occupied and amount of resources accumulated and the points you get for these things are in turn scaled by a Happiness rating that you want to increase as much as possible.  The strategy decisions are engrossing but each turn is short so there is little downtime.  Not for the AP (analysis paralysis) prone though.  The quality of the game components is also very high.  There is a post-apocalyptic steam punk theme and a leader who can move around and pick up one of a limited number of mission cards for extra payoffs but this theming is very thin aside from the fun looking figures for the steam mechs.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is excellent.  More tactical than strategic, but a ton of game here when weighed against rules depth.  An extra half point for an engaging, easy-to-use solo module that keeps a lot of the feel of the full game but without me effectively dummying 2 players against each other.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
In spite of its gorgeous components and elegant rule systems, Scythe simply isn't that interesting to play. While it features a mix of mechanics - including tactical combat, area control, and Euro-style engine-building - it doesn't reward players for excelling at any of those things. Instead, players race to do barely enough to earn a star in any given aspect of the game. This, along with imbalanced and occasionally uninteresting starting player boards and powers, makes for a disappointing and lackluster experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2016-10-09

Initial Rating: N/A

I want to play Scythe, the hype has been incredible. It is, as of today, ranked 12 in BGG´s rankings and that’s amazing. I was originally a KS backer but after being burned by Stomemaier Games with Euphoria and Viticulture I decided to pull out. 

By being burned I mean I hate the company’s policy of changing the core rules of their games, it´s like they don’t test their games enough! Viticulture has 3 different versions and 3 different set of rules in 3 years since its release and that´s unacceptable to me. 

Due to this, I decided to institute my own policy of waiting two years to buy any game from Stonemaier Games. I will wait until they release Scythe: The Essential Edition with new and improved rules and all the expansions already in the box.

Current Rating: N/A
[hr]
2017-01-31

A friend decided to gift me the game and when I was buying it I realized it has already 5 different versions. Most KS games have two versions the retail game and the KS edition. Scythe has:

•	Scythe ‐ English special edition (2016) 

•	Scythe ‐ English retail edition (2016)

•	Scythe ‐ English premium edition (2016)

•	Scythe ‐ English only Art Connoisseur Collector's edition (2016) 

•	Scythe ‐ English collector's edition (2016)

I’m not even sure what are the differences! But I dislike that they exist. It seems Stonemaier Games thrives doing this, but after realizing this I bought Inis instead (a good game). I will play Scythe somewhere in the future and perhaps it is a great game, but I hate Stonemaier Games policies, so I won’t buy the game. 

Current Rating: N/A
[hr]
2017-08-27

Initial Rating: 7.0 (August 2017)

As I dislike Stomemaier Games´ policies, I didn’t want to play Scythe, but this month I finally found myself in a situation in which some friends invited me explicitly to play Scythe so I finally played it. I can say it is a good game but I was expecting better due to the incredible amount of hype.

The rules of the game are pretty straightforward, but there are many rules so teaching them takes around 20 minutes. It plays very fast for the amount of rules it has. It takes around 2 hours with 5 players.

The theme is cool, but eerily similar to Dust´s. There are many game mechanisms that doesn’t support the theme.

The game´s components are amazing, and that’s the other reason I didn’t want to play the game. Sadly, these days I always suspect a game when it looks great. This trend was initiated by Cool mini or Not and their great looking, but ultimately hollow games. Kickstarter is also guilty of that, many publisher offer great looking games with lots of miniatures but the game isn’t as good as the components. Fortunately, this isn’t the case with Scythe, it is a fun game.

The art is amazing.

It is best with 4 players. I didn’t read the rules but it seems you can also play it solo for people who likes this kind of thing.

Scythe looks like a combat, area control game, but it is much closer to an Eurogame with resource management. This is a huge plus for me. There is combat in the game but its impact isn’t as high as most games of its kind.

Scythe´s decisions seem more complex that in reality. Many times you do the same two actions over and over until you achieve what you needed. There are a lot of ways to score in the game (a huge plus) and there are ways to improve the effectiveness of your actions. The player boards are great and they help a lot to move the game at fast pace. From your starting position, you need to trace a short time plan and then execute it. To summarize, the game offers (somewhat) interesting decisions, but they aren’t very hard. The player boards and gameplay are reminiscent of Hansa Teutonica.

Combat plays a minor role in the game and if you lose a combat, it isn’t as damaging a most games. The combat itself is made in a blind bid way, it bothers some friends but I don’t mind it.

The luck factor is rather low, there is luck with the cards but I feel it is controllable. 

The replayability factor is high as each faction is different and new combinations can be created in each setup.

On the bad side, I heavily dislike that the game ends immediately as soon as a player gets his 6 star. This feels unfair to me and gives an advantage to the first players. In our game I was the first player and I won the game, but in the same round, at least another player would have gotten his 6 star as well. I would have preferred if each player has the same amount of turns.

I have bought and sold the game 3 times. I think I must be still mad at how Stonemaier games do business. I will probably buy it again in the future (2018 at the earliest), but I’m expecting a bad move from the Stonemaier Games. I still have very low confidence the publisher won’t change it somehow. I have all the promos for the game just in case I decide to keep it among my game collection. There is no reason to buy the game now as many friends have it. 

Bottom line, I have drifted away a lot from the “dudes on a map” genre, I no longer enjoy it as much as before, but I liked Scythe. It is a borderline 7.0 to me, barely a good game. It´s much more an Eurogame than an Ameritrash one. The decisions needed to play the game aren’t very hard and I’m bothered by the uneven amount of turns between players. I will (probably) eventually buy it. My desire to play it isn’t very high, but it is an enjoyable game and I would play again if requested. It is overrated though, I don´t feel it is a top ten game, but most of my friends love the game.
 
Current Rating: 7.0

[b]Jgoyes´ Awards: [/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Update: Beginning to feel that while it looks like a wargame and a well-timed strike can rob someone of a bunch of resources and give you a star, the really important parts revolve around Euro-efficiency-optimisation. Or 'bleh' in my book.. Sold
..........................
After 2 plays it's certainly good, a few more plays required to determine whether it's great or not.

The design is very good, with the interaction between the various game elements being the highlight. The first part of the game is Euro efficiency engine building, with squeezing the optimum efficiency being the key to fast development.

There's more interaction in the second half of the game when the mechs get mobile and conflict s at least a possibility - and a good way of getting your all-important stars played.

Only two plays in, and when it clicks it's great but you can find yourself fighting against the efficiency aspects, especially if your secret objectives don't align with your strengths. Unless we played something wrong, the Rusvet mech ability that allows moving straight to the factory seems very powerful - get there quick, choose the best factory card, and milk it to get an early, potentially unassailable led. (Experience may find flaws, or at least counters, to this tactic).

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
- This game is really interesting.
- I love the engine building aspects, the achievement system, and the encounter cards.
- I really like the concept of the factory in the centre where players can pickup a single stronger action card.
- It also has great aesthetics, and the different player powers/boards help differentiate players and give them direction.
- I'm not fussed either way on the battle mechanics. Battles can be a bit bland as the outcome is rarely surprising and doesn't have too much of an affect on the game (other than for scoring an achievement). Like most people say, this game is more about the threat of battle than actual battling it out, as players can generally chop each other down at the expensive of opening themselves up to an attack from someone else.
- The scoring system is interesting as a player's overall scoring position is not always obvious, leading to unexpected, and potentially seemingly unjustified/unthematic results.
- I wish the encounter cards weren't handled with tokens, but rather that there is always a chance of an encounter when you move into previously unoccupied (by you) territory.
- Despite the somewhat negative thoughts above, I really enjoy playing this game, as do my friends. It's fun to build a little empire, build mechs, unlock abilities, and go attacking (once or twice).

RATING: 6
First impressions (7). Pretty good. Still a few things I'm concerned about, that will likely shake out over repeated plays.
---
Second play (7), everyone did better score wise. I'm liking the game, but I fear there are some problems with it mechanically. Nothing that "breaks" the game, but things that definitely make the game feel like a seesaw. At the beginning of the game bottom row actions aren't completed very much (due to cost), so the bottom row feels wasted/inefficient. In the middle of the game you are using these actions, but there is a tipping point where you have exhausted their usefulness, and they go back to feeling wasted/inefficient (which feels really strange in a "Euro" style game).
---
Third play (7), I like this game, and I want to play it. I'm trying to figure out if I am judging it by it's KS pedigree, and my past experience with KS games, or if I honestly think the game has mechanical problems. I still feel the same about the bottom row actions.
---
Fourth play (6), OK I've pinpointed the part of the game that has been bothering me. I was deflecting it onto the action selection, but it's the star race. 

The star race makes the game tense, but for all but one person it also makes the game sour. In all four games someone has ended the game abruptly with a multi-star play, leaving everyone else caught off guard and a bit sour. 

Not because we didn't know it could happen, but because it's impossible to track everyone else's status and play your own game well. It's easy enough to track one star at a time, and plan a bit for that pacing, but the ability to complete 2 or 3 stars (common) and up to 5 stars (perfect world) in one turn really makes it impossible to do anything but concentrate on putting out stars (stars are the largest point swing). 

If it was a race to win, like Istanbul, you get your sixth star you win, I think it would feel less bad. But the end game scoring after being blindsided by a big play, and needing just 3 more turns feels like a kick in the stomach. Even the winners have had the same feeling, it doesn't feel good to win.

For the first time after playing I felt like this game was going to have to be removed from the collection, which is a bummer cause it's beautiful, and thematic and "cool" it's just too long for the way it ends, and that's just not fun.
---
Fifth play (6), Well this one was really lopsided. 106 to 41. 6 stars to 5 stars. I wouldn't say that the other player played poorly, just had a hard time closing the gap. I really want to like this game, and I do until it ends, then I feel bad. And I think it's just a little too long for it to feel bad at the end, even when winning.

Kickstarted
- Backed: 10/13/2015
- Funded/Payment: 11/5/2015   
- Est. Delivery: 8/2016
- Received: 7/14/2016

RATING: 10

ETA: 07/2016
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The artwork and production quality for Scythe are an absolute 10. They make you want this game to live up to the unique vision presented by Rozalski's epic paintings. You want to dominate the landscape and win the hearts of the workers! However, each time I played this month I became more and more aware of the disconnect between the incredible thematic art and the game's objectives and mechanics. This is not an epic experience game that tells the great story it promises, it is an efficiency engine game that is entirely focused on action-improvement, in which you win primarily by maximizing each category of efficiency faster than the other players. You work to get workers, buildings and mechs onto the board to do... what? Spread out? The problem is that simply getting them on the board IS the objective for most of the game. Once you get them all out, the game is pretty close to finishing.

Encounters are another vivid example of the thematic and mechanical disconnect inherent throughout the design. The artwork on the encounter cards is frankly the best part of the game. The art is so good, there is no text describing the encounter. Jamey wisely lets the art speak for itself. The cards present three moral choices: one benign, one opportunistic, and one exploitative. In a game that presents the juxtaposition of military and pastoral in such vivid illustrations, I want my moral decisions to shape my destiny - to define who I am - as a leader. Encounters present a great opportunity to accomplish this, but bafflingly work directly against the theme instead. There is no lasting effect of your moral choice. The cards then become anti-thematic and entirely mechanical. You are going to make the choice that makes immediate mechanical sense for your efficiency engine and discard it, rendering the implications of the moral decision utterly meaningless! Why set up the promise of a moral decision with no lasting moral impacts?? Why not design these cards to give an ongoing effect that reflects your decisions as a leader? 

Objective cards also miss the mark. What is significant about grouping pieces in a certain way or stockpiling resources for no purpose? Building goals like building all of your buildings in a straight line only serve to remind us just how arbitrary and disconnected these goals are from the brilliant 1920's post-apocalyptic setting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Amazing merge of wood (eurogame) and plastic (ameritrash) that works apparently well (after my first game), maybe the fact that the resources remain in the board, so they have to be permanently controlled, is the nicest innovation here. With some -not bad- feeling of chaos, and too many things to do in so little time, this game can lead to a heavy AP in deep eurogamers, this is a tremendous danger because its mechanics requires  celerity.

Superb edition after a great KS campaign as usual in this publisher, unfortunately the playing experience lacks most of the theme and the art. It's a pity, the publisher-designer contracted the services of a good artist, but the abstraction and the limited immersion do not completelly capitalise it.

RATING: 9
My initial rating after 2 solo plays is a 9. I hope to play every faction solo against every other faction (at least once - not all combinations) and to get some 2 and higher player count plays in soon. My rating could move either way, but probably not by much to the low side unless I find something wrong/broken, which I have not heard reported. The game is setup on my dining table and will remain there until I can get a handful more plays in - partly why it took so long to get the first game played.

Real positives (other than the fantastic production quality - kickstarter premium): Quick player turns. Strategies that are about 3 turns ahead. Combo'ing the top and bottom actions. Variability in setup. Though light, asynchronous starting positions. Very workable solo mode. Though I can see already that playing against the Automa is a different game than against other players.

Potential negatives: Slow and massive setup that can limit playing opportunities. (Though, it sounds like that isn't hindering many game groups, it is a problem for mine that meets in a game cafe with only 1 large table not dedicated to miniatures). Min-Maxing AP potential.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For Scythe, Stegmaier unpacked his proven principle of mashing up mechanisms from other widely recognized games. Most notably, it's Terra Mystica this time with the different faction powers and the positional play on the board coupled with player boards inspired by Hansa Teutonica. He recycled the game end condition and the fate cards from his own Euphoria. Added to this are generic resource management and engine building systems.

This is done professionally and as usual for Stonemaier games, with outstanding production values. Scythe is his first game that doesn't feel like a late-stage prototype. It's a heavy eurogame with the possibility for direct confrontation. However, playing Scythe as a wargame is a surefire way to losing. Military strength is mostly a deterrent, cold war style. The few battles need to be carefully planned and timed. The essential part is the efficient usage of primary and secondary actions with purposeful engine building as the prerequisite for that.

With all the hype for Scythe, I was all set for a disappointment. Having said that, I liked it and would play again. A solid game although overrated. A couple of issues make me wonder how this game ended up in BGG's top 10:

- "Set piece" nature: The factions always start in the same position. Only the player boards differ. Reading through the strategy guides on here for each faction, it's a bit like learning chess openings.
- Player order: The immediate game end will most likely lead to some players having a turn less. Given the importance of having the last move, this can be a decisive disadvantage without any compensation for being late in turn order.  
- Player positions: Being squeezed in between other factions is a disadvantage.
- Combat resolution: Sacrificing military strength for battles will leave players vulnerable. Sacrificing strength for a high-stake battle and losing can be devastating. Unappetizing bottom feeding can ensue.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Un gran juego - exige pensar los recursos y los movimientosque en cada turno. A diferencia de otros juegos con rondas interminables, en Scythe los turnos son rápidos y mantiene en vilo a todos.

RATING: 8
Three plays in, and this is my favorite design in a long time.  Make no mistake about it, it's not a conflict game or 4X, but it's even more unfair to say it's multiplayer solitaire.  It's pure Euro efficiency engine, but one where players have to ability to disrupt each other's plans.  The pragmatics of play are most reminiscent of Terra Mystica, in the sense that many actions lead to what I heard once described as "little kicks," meaning small boosts that release gamer dopamine for jobs well done.  However, the overall vibe reminds me most of Age of Steam because careful planning must go into the earliest turns based on board position and other starting gamestate, with highs and lows being predicated on concordance with an initial strategy.  I strongly suspect that weak play in early turns can torpedo any chance of victory, but them's the breaks in this sort of game.  Having said that, in terms of options, the more you look the more you will find, and I get the sense that the design has been crunched to the point that there is no one single dominant course of action.  Also, and much less important, it's physically beautiful and thematically non-obnoxious.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game blew my mind. Easy to learn, difficult to master - unlike many people claim (game is on rails), I strongly disagree. The first two "rounds" if I may call them like that, since the game can go so fast at the beginning can give some sense of being on rails since one of the base mechanics (and understanding deeper strategy) is to plan ahead. If I want to upgrade, I need Oil, The action to get Oil essentially tells you what to do - if you want to follow that idea. However hitting the first encounter can change your strategy and give new options (now I can suddenly build a building, although I had no Wood) which then can have an effect on your later turns and so on.
There is no bad decision in this game, but there are many not so good and better solutions to your overall approach, still as long as you understand, that the most effective way is to work towards activating both the top and bottom row actions, doesn't necessarily win you the game. Reading the board and now when to strike (and not talking about long drawn out wars, that's not what the game is about) - but a precision strike can throw back your opponent more than just a turn, it can be crippling indeed, if you don't pay attention.
So combat is not what this game is about, but knowing when to strike and how to keep your defenses up is certainly very important. Also knowing your faction abilities (and mechs) and how to implement those to maximum effect.
The other upside to this game, even at 5 Player count I had games going for a hair under 2 hours. That's amazing for a game of this scope. In my eyes it perfectly meshes all kinds of genres and mechanics into one elegant smoothly running machine. I have yet to encounter a combination that is "broken" since knowing how is half the game. Your opponents are essential to victory (and here is my other observation which most people and reviewers don't seem to mind) - yes, you can play solitaire and hope for the best, that your engine produces the most coins - however if you watch someone turtling in his corner, attack him! It's the best way to not only disrupt their engine, but also snatch victory, since losing areas and resources is huge in this game. I don't like to say that people who criticize this game "don't get it" or "play it wrong" and then blame it on the design but sometimes I do feel like that. Its a pity that some people think like that and try to reduce the game just to that particular point of view. It is easy to tear down a game to one aspect and then claim "it turns out like that, always" (which isn't true) - this game offers a lot, way more than meets the eye and after over 20 plays I'm not getting tired of it. The expansion just adds more of the great core game and ups the game in player count to 7. Haven't played that yet, but I don't expect it to last much longer than with 5, since the design is so elegant and smooth.
My Game of the Year 2016!

RATING: 7
Gorgeous production values, beautiful art and relatively smooth and nicely asymmetric gameplay. Surprisingly prone to AP as you better try to plan multiple turns ahead. I'm a bit doubtful regarding long term replayability as each faction always has the same stale starting configuration. I especially liked the encounter cards, good story, enlist mechanism and the fact that it is possible to do well with a peaceful approach. In order to do well you need to aim at doing two actions a turn as often as possible. On the dislike side I somewhat feel that you shouldn't be allowed to trigger the game end if you initiate a battle. I also feel this might be at its best as a two player experience.

+ Easy to setup for such a big game

- Negotiations and combat have to be limited to 1min each or the downtime will be too long in a 5 player game

RATING: 7.5
2017-09-20 - 7.5 - With a very big hype at first and decreasing my interest for the game after watching some reviews and the game itself being played I played it without too much expectaions. I found Scythe to be really good, solid game with a lot of interesting choices. The fights are rather unexciting, but the fact that you lose quite a lot of your strength after winning a battle is something that is not so obvious to figure out. The popularity track is a cool thing too. Player boards are very euroish and rather solitare, but fortunately there is a main board, which sooner or later forces you to pay attention what is going on there.
One more thing - Sctyhe plays unexpectedly smoothly for what it looks like and there is not too much downtime.
I liked the game and will gladly play it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Good game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Collector's Edition. Awesome game! I played it four times in the first week I owned it which I have never done with a big game before. Even my wife loves it and she doesn't really care for complex games with a lot of rules. This one hits the sweet spot between accessibility and complexity. I certainly wouldn't call it a gateway game but I could definitely see teaching it to and playing it with anyone that could handle games like Catan, Small World and Lords of Waterdeep.

This is my favorite game of 2016 and the best game/value that I have Kickstarted. It's early to call, but this game is almost certainly destined for my top five. This is the example that game publishers should be striving for in terms of components, rulebook, iconography, art, ease of access, replayability, accessibility and value.

Our first three-player game took three hours but our next two with the same players took only an hour and a half each (we played them back-to-back, it's that good). Turns are near simultaneous with three players, so there is very little downtime.

The game is very intuitive and after the first few turns, you know what to do and how most things work. From that point on, it's a matter of learning how to optimize your actions and developing an overall strategy.

There are five asymmetrical factions, each with their own special abilities. There are also five different player mats that have the same abilities but with slightly different costs and benefits. Each game you play, you get a different combination of these. Then you add in different secret objectives, different factory abilities and different end game bonuses for buildings and you get a heck of a lot of replayability.

If I had a complaint (and I don't) it would be that there isn't a whole lot of player interaction during the game. The board is big enough that you can pretty much do your own thing in your own corner of the map without much interference. I am sure in four or five player games there is a lot more interaction as players jostle for resources and space.

Super game! If you like worker placement and area control, you should love this one!

Expansions owned: Invaders from Afar, Wind Gambit
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It requires exciting and balanced gameplay.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Huhh, elsőre volt mit emészteni rajta. :D
A játék igazán nagyon szép, tetszik az a hangulat, amely a festmények, a játéktábla, a figurák és a játék során kialakuló helyzetek által megelevenedik. Ugyanakkor, mivel a megjelenés nagyon erős, tematikusabb játékmenetre számítottam. Persze ez az én bajom. :)
A mechanikák egy része egészen különleges. Két saját táblánk is van, és a játék során ezek változnak, a mechek táblára vitelével újabb képességeink lesznek, az akciótáblánkon pedig a fejlesztések által egyre olcsóbban, egyre több dolgot szerzünk. Ezen a területen is van egy kicsi egymásra hatás, ugyanis a többi játékos fejlesztései során is kaphatunk jutalmakat.
A táblán nálunk kevés konfliktus volt, és ami volt is, nem volt túlságosan markáns. A csaták kimenetele elég jól megjósolható, és úgy éreztem, hogy a vesztes sem bukik vele olyan óriásit. A játéknak ez a része azért kicsit furcsa volt, mert egy kiélezettebb küzdelem után mindkét fél veszít annyi erőt, hogy a nevető harmadik könnyedén elvehet akár mind a két játékostól területeket. Mondjuk a célokat tekintve szerintem olyan nagyon sok csatározásra nincs szükség, így talán nem jelent hosszútávú problémát (persze több fővel ez változhat), de magának a csatának a mechanikája egyáltalán nem tetszik, pedig ígéretesnek tűnt a tárcsaforgatás + lapkijátszás.
Mindenesetre rengeteg jó ötlet van benne, az én ízlésemnek picit túl sok a szabály, részemről hevi juró kategória, bőven van számolgatni-, kombinálgatnivaló.
A népek különbözősége, más-más területeken való erősségük/gyengeségük izgalmas elem, valószínűleg döntő lehet ezek optimális kihasználása, ennek átlátására biztosan jónéhány játékra szükség lehet.
Majd még jó lenne játszani vele, de egyértelműen nem az a típus, amire nagyon gyakran vágynék.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Euro mechanics are good, the rest not so much,
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Largely multi-player solitaire. Very twiddly and arbitrary feeling. No idea why this game is rated so highly. Kemet is much, much better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great look, great art, great components, satisfying gameplay, and asymmetrical factions. Love the theme and the engine building. It's not a heavy game and is really easy to learn. It is also not a combat game and isn't supposed to be, which seems to be a knock for many people. But just going to war is costly and likely has more negatives than positives, just like it would in real life. The threat and avoidance of combat is more intriguing to me than a strict battling game. I really enjoy the multiplayer solitaire aspect and I have gone for different strategies every play. There's still enough player interaction to make it interesting, but working on building your own engine without having to constantly worry about other players is really satisfying. Hard to find any faults with the game. A definite favorite.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
1 partida.

A la espera de probarlo con más gente, porque en partida a 2 jugadores el mapa se hace demasiado grande, por lo que hay poca interacción entre ambos y va cada uno a la suya. Además, la partida se me hizo demasiado corta, porque aún quería hacer muchas cosas y ya habíamos llegado a 6 estrellas.

Sin embargo, el juego promete a más jugadores. El cartón con tus acciones disponibles simplifica muchísimo la dificultad, que de otro modo tendrías que memorizar cada acción y sería mucho más lioso. En el propio cartón, hay hendiduras para saber dónde colocar las piezas y las mejoras... está muy bien conseguido. Otro punto positivo es el arte del juego, con sus ilustraciones, el mapa colorido, las figuritas de los protagonistas y mech, etc,

RATING: 6
Includes the Expansions:
Scythe: Invaders from Afar (2016)

Scythe is a pretty good game with phenomenal components. Once you get the hang of how the actions work, gameplay is fairly intuitive. I am glad I backed it on Kickstarter, but it is not as exciting as I hoped it would be. Perhaps this is because the act of getting stars is removed from the theme (which is otherwise so well done). Or, perhaps it is that the strategies don't seem diverse enough to add much variety over repeated plays. Or, maybe it's just that the decisions you make aren't very interesting.

The last couple of games we played just weren't that fun. I had no desire to get this one to the table, so I let it go.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
My favourite Game. Art, Components, Gameplay, the perfect match. Not toooo heavy, short actions, mixture of tactic and strategy, fight and euro. Something for everybody. If there is ever a perfect board game. This is the closest i know. 

The design of the gameplay is so great you can literally teach it too people while you play without 1 hour of rule explanation. It's so much fun to try out all different factions and player boards and their combinations and there are a lot of different ways to victory. Perfect Game with a bit of hectic at the end when the last stars are dropping.

RATING: 10
Simply a pleasure.

I particularly like how often in the game you get two bonuses together - such as when you enlist, uncovering a future bonus and taking an immediate one, or when you upgrade, making a bonus better and a cost cheaper.

I also was very surprised to find that, even in the retail edition, the player mats come double-layered with the indents for all your pieces! How deluxe! I absolutely thought that was one of the upgrades, and I flipped when I opened my retail box.

RATING: 7
The main board mechanisms of this game seem so good.  But everything about this game is random and variable depending on unknowns not on player choices.  Several blind Card draws in the game, encounters, military cards, achievement star cards, which all have a substantial imbalance possibility with them.  The faction abilities also seem imbalanced, but I've not played enough to ferret out the good from the bad.  Matching the top and bottom boards, if randomly done, can be imbalanced, someone may get move and produce tagged with bottom actions that can nearly always be used while some cannot depending on starting resource locations.  Just not my cup of tea, don't really want to play again.

RATING: 7
Area-control euro with player interaction. Almost too good to be true...and it is.

90% of this game is a beautiful solitaire. Production quality is amazing, but the game itself just isn't there.
The element I feel is the most lackluster is combat. I understand the cold-war tactics that the game mechanics force you to employ, but the deterministic nature of it can often push players into mid-game stalemates.

Update:the third expansion seems to be a run for the money. Adding story instead of fixing the core problems with the game.
Only reason this remains in my collection is my wife enjoying the multiplayer solitaire aspect.

RATING: 9
When I played Scythe, I knew it would be in my top 5 favorite games. I grew up playing Risk and this scratches a similar itch even though they arent extremely similar. The upgrade system is pure genius. I love that doing bottom row actions almost always allows you to have more than 1 benefit. Im a big sucker for variable player powers in games and each faction plays differently than the others and makes you adjust your strategies accordingly. Can be kind of confusing for new players, but once they learn the basics, it is actually quite simple.

RATING: 9
Rating after just one game, will adjudt as I play more. Really nice game, easy to teach and to learn (in terms of available actions and how to play). Great feeling of the strenght building up an of the lethal threat of the opponents... Shall I continue to develop or attack? Great components, awesome artwork and theme. Will see table time for sure and it'll take a while before I'll feel I know/get bored of it. All 4 players had a blast! and I haven't been so excited post play for a looong time (ask my GF, we drove for 1h30 the day after the play and talked about it the whole way... she hadn't play and thus, basically almost fell asleep as she couldn't picture anything I was saying, but from my excitement wants to play it to see for herself.)

Update after 7 plays: yep, this is a strong 9 for me... had the opportunity to play it with the same person and new ones (including 'non-gamers'). although with new players to game can drag on, it always ends up with the whole table liking to loving the game...great experience for everybody. Myself I do like the fact that every faction plays differently as well as every player mat. the game stays the same but the path to follow are always a bit different and this is great as it thus plays out quite differently... probably my fav game of 2016!

Update after > 10 plays, still loving it, playing it with the 2 first expansion and still having a blast... will stay in my top for a while...

RATING: 9.98
7/9/16: Unbelievably Beautiful!

Extreme depth in the planning for the scoring round. The game is deceptively set-up to encourage to work towards objectives that help you to trigger game end(stars), but the real meat of the game is balancing the game end trigger with setting up for the scoring round and navigating the in-between!

Phenomenal, asymmetrical game play. This one is a winner

Update 7/27/16: Just played my 10th game of Scythe. It just keeps getting better. Also, an excellent solo game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
Scythe is even better than I hoped it would be!

+ Beautiful and well though out components
+ Intuitive rules
+ Fun! Combats are simple and don't have devastating effects for the loser which we like in our gaming group. 
+ Lots of variability even though the board is static. You have to adapt to different player boards not follow the same route every time.
+ Quick rewarding actions (some players can of course have AP on their first game, but all in all it's a relatively short game)
+ Good selection of mechanics that work well together. Interestingly, I didn't enjoy Terra Mystica nor Dune and I wouldn't even want to play Kemet but I do like Scythe :)

- While the rules are are well written and are not complicated, there are still lots of them. Thus, I wouldn't play this with people who haven't had much experience with board games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Scythe is a Worker Placement/Economic Engine board game set in an alternate-history 1920s period. It is a time of farming and war, broken hearts and rusted gears, innovation and valor. In Scythe, each player represents a character from one of five factions of Eastern Europa who are attempting to earn their fortune and claim their faction's stake in the land around the mysterious Factory. Players conquer territory, enlist new recruits, reap resources, gain villagers, build structures, and activate monstrous mechs.

Each player begins the game with different resources (power, coins, combat acumen, and popularity), a different starting location, and a hidden goal. Starting positions are specially calibrated to contribute to each faction’s uniqueness and the asymmetrical nature of the game (each faction always starts in the same place).

Scythe gives players almost complete control over their fate. Other than each player’s individual hidden objective card, the only elements of luck or variability are “encounter” cards that players will draw as they interact with the citizens of newly explored lands. Each encounter card provides the player with several options, allowing them to mitigate the luck of the draw through their selection. Combat is also driven by choices, not luck or randomness.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is not ameritrash, and neither an euro. I think is a good mix of both. Very original.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Love the variable factions and mats that give so many combinations and forces you to vary your strategy from game to game. It is deceptively simple to play though there is a lot going on and turns are really quick. Combat is realistic and strategic not luck based. they don't happen much which is appropriate for this engine builder. The threat of combat is the deterrent  needed and it can be costly.

RATING: 6
Mhh. Why that much hype? Yes, it's a good game and the miniatures are awesome. But it's also quite non-interactive and I can't see that much replay-value. The factions are the same for the most part. Their special abilities don't make a huge difference. Fighting and its mechanism is horribly bland and for the most part you're just trying to optimize your turn in this huge point salad. Long story short: I prefer games with more direct interaction.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very fast turn pace for a multiplayer strategy game with minis, though calling it a 4x is a loooong stretch, on my calculations the name is "Scythe the 2.75x game"

Explore:
This aspect is like half x, as the map is set and only few discovery events.

Expand:
This aspect deserves a full x as scythe is true areacontrol game.

Exploit:
This aspect also deserves a full x as you need strict resource management to achieve victory.

Exterterminate:
This aspect is quarter x as combat only determines who retreats
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.52
Unas ilustraciones espectaculares y una producción excepcional hacen de este buen juego una maravilla. No os dejéis engañar, no es un juego de combate y conquista, es más bien de gestión de recursos y maximizar el número de acciones realizadas. Muy recomendable para todos los públicos, siempre que sepan a qué están jugando.

RATING: 6
The game puts up a lot of restrictions to keep the players in check, which on the plus-side translate into accessibility. You get to do a little of, well, not everything, but a lot. And that is both a boon and a curse. There should be at least something for everyone here, though you’re not allowed to do very much of it. Choices are mostly very soft and efficiency is about studying and following your player board. If you want to stray you risk falling behind, wasting turns getting back on track.

Scythe doesn’t miss its mark completely, but basically I find the gameplay very artificial. Even though the main design works well within itself, it almost feigns being interactive and ’fun’ through its machinery while showering you with freebies left and right. Presentation is what got my attention originally and unfortunately that’s still why it gets the attention it does. Very much a try before you buy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A euro masquerading as a war game.  Combat is costly, infrequent and almost optional, which is fine with me.  The variable boards look like cosmetic difference at first but actually completely change the way you plan and play.  With all the different boards, there's actually a question about all factions & action boards being really balanced (same as in Terra Mystia).  Interesting choices, solid mechanics, a bit unforgiving on mistakes if playing with good players.  End of game can be a bit sudden and will generally screw 1st time players.  Production wise, this is solid but reuses the same bits as Viticulture which feels a bit cheap (the windmill in particular is rather anachronistic).  Needs a lot of table space.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
FIRST IMPRESSION:

Enjoyed my first play - game looks quite pretty on the table if you're using the collector's edition! Each player has different abilities and must pursue victory in ways that work best for them. Much like Hansa Teutonica, one can remove stuff from the player board to enhance and improve future actions...although in certain cases, it can also cost more (IE, production if you have a good number of your workers out on the board). Watch the popularity track - determines your multiplier for three different end game scoring conditions. There is some combat in the game, but it usually doesn't feel overwhelming - and one can certainly turtle/protect relatively easily. Each player chooses one of 4-5 actions on their turn which may have enhancements if you can pay the costs. I expect the game will play relatively quickly once people understand how to play. My learning game with 4 players (2 new including one who asked a ton of questions) took us 3 hours including rules explanation.

RATING: 9
Admittedly, the theme and style of this game are huge interests of mine, so that does help elevate this one even further. However, that being said Scythe is also a phenomenal euro/resource management/area control game. It borrows many elements and mechanics from other titles and blends them seamlessly into a tight and surprisingly energetic bundle. This is a heavy-ish game, but it doesn't overstay its welcome, it also ramps up at a great pace. The beginning feels very different from the middle/the end, lending to a satisfying 3-act structure. 
If you have even a slight interest in euro titles, give this one a try!

RATING: N/A
NIS
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Scythe est un jeu de plateau qui se déroule dans une période des années 1920. C'est un temps d'agriculture et de guerre, de coeurs brisés et d'engrenages rouillés, d'innovation et de bravoure. Dans Scythe, chaque joueur représente un leader déchu qui tente de restaurer son honneur et de mener sa faction au pouvoir en Europe de l'Est. Les joueurs conquièrent du territoire, recrutent de nouvelles recrues, récoltent des ressources, gagnent des villageois, construisent des structures et activent des monstrueux mechs.Chaque joueur commence le jeu avec différentes ressources (force, points de victoire, capacités de mouvement et popularité), leur choix de plusieurs factions spécifiques. capacités, et un objectif caché. Les positions de départ sont spécialement calibrées pour contribuer à l'unicité de chaque faction et à la nature asymétrique du jeu. Le jeu donne aux joueurs un contrôle presque complet sur leur destin. À l'exception de la carte d'objectifs cachés de chaque joueur, les seuls éléments de chance sont les cartes de rencontre que les joueurs dessinent lorsqu'ils interagissent avec les citoyens des cartes des terres nouvellement explorées qui vous donnent un coup de pouce temporaire au combat. Le combat utilise aussi un mécanisme de sélection d'action simplifié (pas de rounds ni de phases) pour maintenir le gameplay à un rythme soutenu et réduire les temps d'arrêt entre les tours. Bien qu'il y ait beaucoup de conflits directs, il n'y a pas d'élimination des joueurs, et les unités ne peuvent pas être tuées ou détruites. Chaque partie de Scythe a un aspect de construction de moteur. Les joueurs peuvent améliorer les actions pour devenir plus efficaces, construire des structures qui améliorent leur position sur la carte, recruter de nouvelles recrues pour améliorer les capacités des personnages, activer les mécanismes pour empêcher les adversaires d'envahir et étendre leurs frontières pour récolter plus de types et de ressources. Ces aspects de construction de moteur créent un sentiment d'élan et de progrès tout au long du jeu. L'ordre dans lequel les joueurs améliorent leur moteur ajoute à la sensation unique de chaque jeu, même en jouant une faction plusieurs fois.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Really good game, lots of replayability.  A lot going on but not overly complex.

RATING: 10
It's a well oiled machine. Once you get the hang of it, it plays very smoothly (the iconography and smart design is amazing). The art and build quality is top notch.
Gameplay-wise it's a great engine builder. Bear in mind that the area control aspect is there to help keep players in check, but it's not a focus.
First I disliked the abrupt ending but it really is another layer of skill to predict when the game will end and plan your actions accordingly. I often feel like I could've achieved so much more with just 1 or 2 extra turn, but it's not a bad feeling that makes me disappointed, but a rather good one to make me want to play again. This is my personal taste and YMMV.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
