=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Initial Impressions: If this is a 4X game as it was sometimes advertised as it is missing many of the 4X elements, and if it isn't a 4X game it is a good but far from amazing Euro.

The game seems more about completing objectives and managing resources so that you can always pay for the bottom action when you do the top one too (with a little bit of timing in case of opponent interference). Some of the ways to get stars also feel not really thematically tied at all (e.g. you have military power, but don't spend it). Therefore, it doesn't give the civilization building feel at all, and while there are upgrades they don't feel like you are learning new technologies, as they only make your other actions better.

It obviously lacks explore since the map is static and nothing is hidden, and its exterminate aspect while somewhat present is really weak. Combat is more a threat than something that actually happens frequently (in my game there were only 2 combats, and while I could see some play styles that would cause it to happen more frequently it still seems amassing troops is more as a deterrent). That you only have 1-5 combat units on the board at a time doesn't help with making combat more nuanced. I also don't like secret bidding especially for combat. 

The poor combat also hurts the expand aspect, as while you can get a lot of points for expanding the lack of constantly jockeying for territory makes the expand less interesting.

The game also seems like it would be fairly samey in the beginning of each game, in that despite the different factions/action boards/objectives/you can go for different ways to achieve stars each game, they overall feel of what you do is still similar.

The encounter cards just don't feel that thematic. The story behind each one feels too disjointed from the rest of what you are doing, and so while they have flavor art and text that makes sense with the setting they just feel like random resource bonuses.

As for why I rate Terra Mystica so much higher, to be honest maybe I was too caught up in the hype of it. I don't remember my play of it enough to have a good gauge of it is actually my type of game. If I do like Terra Mystica more, I think it is due to the balance of being near opponents so you pay less for settlements vs. being far enough away that you have space to build (whereas here it seems like you basically always want your workers far away from opponents, and mech relatively close), you can build more, the factions feel more different, and that while there isn't movement it feels like you can affect the land more by terraforming.

Despite all the things I mentioned I dislike about this game, I did enjoy it and feel that the relatively simple action selection turns tied to chaining of these actions, along with the added logistics of the spatial map was cool. It just wasn't super innovative or anything deserving the hype, the artwork, or its ranking, and so it left me really disappointed.

RATING: 8.5
Cool engine builder.  Stunning art and theme.  Shorter game than Terra Mystica with more interaction (combats, forced retreats) that you must take into account.  Efficiency is rewarded in this game big time and a few mistakes (wasted turns) will cost you.  More opportunity to be foiled by other players actions than TM, but careful players can counteract.  Fun game that lives up to the hype for me.  Will also add that the Tabletop Simulator version is of high quality.  After many plays though, certain boards feel like your optimal overarching strategy is predetermined.

RATING: 8
I FINALLY PLAYED SCYTHE.

And it was glorious. I understand the hype now. I don't know if I'd put it AS high as the hype does, but it's definitely a very solid game. I love the way that the worker placement works, and blind bidding combat is one of my favorite combat systems. I generally dislike area control, but this is definitely one of the best ways that I've seen to do it.

I was the Norsemen, Chrono was Crimea, and Patrick was the Ruskis. I think I liked my ability most out of them because it gave me a lot more movement flexibility (I made it to the Factory first and got the best Factory).

Chrono actually ended the game a turn before I could, but I still managed to pull ahead for the lead because I had more $ before points were counted. I'd managed to rarely use the actions that cost $ and made a ton from the bottom bonuses.

RATING: 8
The initial relation to this game being like Terra Mystica with the combat system of Kemet, while not a bad description of some aspects, is still woefully inaccurate.

It does have a board of "stuff" that you are trying to move onto the board, or elsewhere on your player board to increase abilities or create discounts. There is a resource you spend, plus cards, to perform combat similar to Kemet. However, the rest of the game is area control and trying to meet goals, all the while gaining yet another resource that increases your VP multiplier.

The game is fun, varied, balanced, and beautiful (even if you didn't get the collectors this is beautiful). It starts at an 8 with an expectation to rise.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
[microbadge=5][microbadge=2984]

Scythe is definitely a well-designed game, although a bigger question would be if it was also [i]fun[/i].  This is more ambiguous, I found.  There are certainly fun parts, but the whole suffers from some critical drawbacks.

First (and this has been said repeatedly before), there are too many disincentives for combat.  One of the places that Scythe succeeds over a game like Terra Mystica is that there is more direct opportunities for interaction, down to actual displacement and victory points via stars.  However, you are punished for even initiating combat due to the popularity penalty (unless you have the Polish Camaraderie ability), forcing you to rely on the threat of combat, which is generally disadvantageous to both parties involved.

Second, the speed of the turns feels off for what is supposedly a 4X efficiency game.  The rounds go quickly enough, with very little downtime, but the turns themselves are actually too short, giving you too little to do with too small of a result.  I would have been happier with slightly meatier turns in exchange with slightly longer downtime.

Finally, the amount of interaction on the board, while direct, is almost arbitrary.  Most of the game is played on your player mats, with the hex map and enlistment bonus technically providing interaction with only a few moments of actually engagement ever happening in the whole three hour game.  Granted, these few moments are often highly important and exciting, but there's too little of it.  Again, Scythe succeeds over Terra Mystica in this regard, but still fails compared to any number of 4X/efficiency games on the market.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Un jeu atypique de gestion et (un peu) d'affrontement. J'ai aimé la grande originalité des règles, le renouvellement des parties, l'affrontement "non violent" (les unités battues ne sont jamais éliminées, elles retournent simplement au campement de base).

Le terme 4X (que j'ai découvert récemment) ne convient d'ailleurs pas vraiment à ce jeu : il s'agit d'un jeu 3X et non 4X (les phases d'exploration et d'expansion n'étant pas différenciées dans ce jeu).

Enfin, je me marre toujours en lisant les temps de partie indiqués sur les boîtes. 90 minutes ??? Dans les rêves les plus fous... notre partie a duré près de 3 heures (comme je m'y attendais). Il faudrait voir, messieurs et mesdames les éditeurs, à ne pas prendre les potentiels acheteurs pour des couillons...

RATING: 7
A Euro game masquerading as a war game.  The game itself is a race to get six victory "stars".  Each player has a unique faction and player board and this is random at the beginning of the game.  So each game has a random setup although the board itself is static.  It is a resource collection game where you must take one action but optionally can take another action if you have the resources.  Generally, I like the game, but I don't know if is the greatest game ever.  It clever and the variable player mat and faction ability is unique.  The art and components are great.  

I like the game it is solid, but it is not the greatest game ever.

RATING: 9
This is a really solid area-control game with a lot of variability in set-up and a lot of ways to win. The asymmetry adds a lot of variety and it's cool to try out new strategies with factions you haven't played before, or trying out an aggressive strat, or even a pacifist one. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I only played about half way through the game so my comment may be premature. We just wanted to play other games. It's the best mix of resource gathering and map combat I have seen in a while. The game flows very smoothly. Everything you do costs you which stops the whole "runaway king" issue that many map styled combat games have. It had many different ways to win outside of combat and you couldn't win through winning combat alone which forced players to spread their strategy out. It's a very beautiful game and was easily the most impressive looking game at Dicetower Con 2016. The Only reason it doesn't get a 10 for me is because the first turns are almost mapped out for you and very slow... it would just be easier and quicker to start with more. A++++++++++++++ I cannot wait to spend my paycheck on this beauty. PS: A little bias: It has bears which I love AND the bear's last name happens to me my last name. A++++++++++++

RATING: 9
Has fantastic components with clear rules, and it scales well from 1-5. The mechanics and the theme coalesce into something truly special. Combines the asymmetric area control of Chaos in the Old World and Blood Rage, the personal player board economy engines of Through the Ages, and Rex/Dune's combat dial system with plenty of its own innovations. Oh, and the art is evocative and inspired.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I was skeptical of this game due to the amount of hype it received prior to being released.  However, Scythe has lived up to and surpassed my expectations.  

It's branded as a 4X game however it plays more like a standard euro game with added player conflict.  However, victory can be achieved without ever having to engage in player combat due to the variety of ways to earn victory points in game.  

Besides the amazing 1920s alternate timeline theme, the best aspect of this game is how the upgrade mechanism for your faction works.  Using resources collected and/or traded, players can pay to upgrade their top row actions on their player mat which makes them grant a larger benefit the next time this action is selected.  When upgrading the top action, the player also gets to choose any one of the bottom row actions to upgrade which makes these actions cheaper to purchase on future turns.  This is the first time I've seen such a mechanism in a board game and it not only works great but is very rewarding.

Replayability for this game is also excellent with each faction having a different faction bonus and initial set up.   This is then combined with player mats that have alternate positions for the top row and bottom row actions so that you generally will get a different combination of faction and player mat than your previous game.  There is also a large variety of encounter cards as well as factory bonus cards which also add variability into each game.

Overall, I can't recommend Scythe enough.  It's definitely one of, if not the top game released in 2016 as it appeals to euro games and ameritrash gamers alike.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A nicely produced game with superb miniatures and graphics. However, the gameplay suffered too much problem: discrepancy between starting powers, too many rules with not much decision each turn (many are too obvious, or others are being limited by the amount of resurces you have), the theme and gameplay doesn't match at all (I think it's better if they changed the entire setting to a steampunk/ sci-fi one would be better, as I can find no correlation between the map/ starting powers and 'europa'). With a game this complex and expensive the reward is simply too few.

RATING: N/A
Kickstarted. Collectors Edition. Still in Shrink.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I had the fortune to play the English Art Connoisseur edition multiple times, and it's gorgeous, with all the chrome and the bling one could hope for, from the book of the game art, to the metal coins, to the metal resources and the dual layered player boards with recessed/indented spaces.  I also had a chance to play the regular version.  I believe that the Art Connoisseur version is so impressive and so beautiful that it hides some of the weaknesses of the game itself.  Playing with the regular version, without being blinded by the chrome, the game is not as impressive and some of the weaknesses appear.
1)  Components:  excellent! (Art Connoisseur version)
2)  Rulebook -- very clear, with good organization and examples.  I like the fact that it basically encourages you to jump in and play with the knobs of the game, and even gives hints for an absolute beginner of what to do to get familiar with the game.
3)  Rules.  Clear, cogent, easy to understand and divine, make sense and are easy to remember, so that one can focus on the game.
4)  Variability/replayability:  At first impression variability is excellent, however after playing multiple times it is not as variable as it first appears to be in spite of the asymmetric factions.
5)  Mechanics.  The game feels very polished, does not use dice to resolve combat, has an interesting map, and plays fast.  However, the action phase often feels limited and can be repetitive.  Downtime is noticeable in spite of the designer's efforts to reduce it.   Often you feel the pressure to optimize your turn.  I found myself criticizing my sub-optimal choices, and I am not usually a min/max player.  The illusion is broken, the optimization puzzle is revealed, and this is not a feeling I particularly enjoy.
6)  Combat/luck.  No dice, combat is resolved in a satisfying matter with minimal luck, no dice, uses a mix of planning, strategy, and bluffing.
Everyone should get at least one chance to play with the Art Connoisseur edition, especially while the game is still a new experience.  Unfortunately, the enjoyment curve has decreased with repeated plays in spite of the many good things about the game and the tactile/sensory experience.  It went from a very high initial rating of 9 to the present tentative score of 7.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Others have said what I think, so I'll just copy and paste that:
It's ok, but not really what I was looking for. It's a euro through and through, nicely produced with fabulous art--if it looked like other euros, no one would be talking about it. There is little real confrontation--you battle to get the points, not to dominate. The contrived board bugs me (symmetrically placed tunnels, dopey river crossing rules that make no sense) as does the very nature of a multiplayer 'war' game where everyone spends all their time staring down at their player boards trying to plan out which actions the game will let them take.

I think there are lots of better euros, if that's what I'm looking for, and also many Ameritrash games that do this in a much more exciting way.
The production value is exceptional and the artwork gorgeous but the gameplay is simply mediocre. Easily the most overrated game on BGG.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Kickstarter.  Standard edition kickstart, but the components are still fantastic, and the art is exceptional.  It's a hefty box, and honestly I was a bit intimidated after watching the Watch it Played video, but the instructions are presented very clearly, and the iconography is pretty clear after you get going.  So far, I've only played one time on the easy solo game, but it was engaging and challenging.  Took a risk at the end to raise my hearts up in an extra turn, and the automaton pulled a no-op card, which ended up as the difference between win and lose.  The turn actions are all pretty clear, but lend themselves to fairly deep strategy, with a lot of interactions, opportunities converging on various fronts.

I'm looking forward to getting my gaming buddies in on it this weekend to get a feel for the multi-player.  A lot of reviews have indicated a lack of interaction, but in the solo variant there was plenty...there were at least five combats in the game I played.

Individual decisions are light enough that I'm hoping analysis paralysis doesn't become an issue, but that's my biggest fear with a larger group of players.  There's a fair amount to keep track of, but the components and design are tight enough that it gets fairly natural quickly.

Good chance the rating will swing +/- after a few more games.  Bumped to 9.5 after additional play, game friend approval, fun 3-player game, I got pretty whooped.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Simply gorgeous art. Outstanding theme, with a wonderful map of hidden gems. A shame the hex outline hides the moomin. Absolutely gutted I didn't go all in for the collectors edition at Kickstater, but glad I picked up a copy later down the line.

The gameplay is very social and addictive, without the hindrance of too much AP. As expected from me with a game of this complexity, I made many mistakes on the first few playthroughs with family and solo. Phil's expert guidance at Brotherhood of the Dice meetup soon put me to shame with his excellent rules guidance. Easy to understand rulebook despite my own personal setbacks.

The one criticism I have is that I would like more to come from the narrative element of this game. I understand this is probably unrealistic, but the art is so evoking of an epic journey of conquest and exploration. It seems a shame to only come across it so many times on the map (if you manage to get to an encounter token quick enough!). A negative out of a positive shall we say?

Genuinely exctied to buy the expansions (and metal coins/realistic resources).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
EDIT: Played it 21 times so far and my opinion hasn't changed.  The game is excellent and very well balanced considering all the variables you have to deal with.  I've played this game in all player counts except 7 and it works well in all player counts.  This is my #1 game at the moment with Viticulture EE + Tuscany expansion as my #2.

After playing it four times (two 4-player, one 3-player, one 2-player), this is one of the most finely crafted games out there.  I didn't buy into the Kickstarter hype because I wasn't a fan of Jamey's previous works like Euphoria, I thought this would be another game that didn't meet the hype.

While this is overhyped, it is still one of the most well-designed games I have played in a very long time.  It doesn't reach the depth of games like Food Chain Magnate, but this doesn't necessarily mean the game is bad.  It's like saying the Audi R8 is a terrible car because it isn't a Bugatti Veyron.

What makes Scythe work is Jamey understands the limits of the Tabletop medium and tries his best to convey dense important information in an understandable format.  It is a game with numerous components but it doesn't come across as intimidating because of its understandable icons and the layout of the playmats.  The interaction between the player mat and the map is a marriage between sensibility and intuitive mechanics.

Another great aspect is the game itself isn't that hard to understand.  The bulk of the gameplay is revolved around picking one out of four actions from your playmat, do that action, and your turn ends.  On your next turn, you cannot pick the same action.  Some players might argue that it doesn't feel like a "full turn" because your actions are limited, these micro turns allows the pace of the game to smoothly instead of long downtime between turns.

Finally, the game is an efficiency engine game.  Some players might be turned off to the idea, as I am one of them, but what makes Scythe work is the different mechanics.  Unlike efficiency engine games like Terraforming Mars, where you are merely grabbing cubes for the sake of grabbing more cubes, Scythe works because you can efficient in one area of the game that gives different mechanics over everything else.  For example, having a combo that is very good at building Structures allows you to view the game quite different than playing with a faction/player mat combo that is dedicated to deploying Mechs out quickly.  It's because of these different mechanics that the efficiency engine style of Scythe works so well when compared to other dry point salad euros.

Is it overhyped?  Yes, it's definitely is.  Is it a bad game?  No way.  It's going to evict a few games out of my collection for sure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game combines "area control" (without excessive combat),  with "economic development/engine building" (without the need for empire building), and goal achievement (that's more than simply a race). Each of the three aspects are scored/totaled for victory. 

The theme (steampunkish WWI Europe) is a huge lure for me. I love the puzzle aspect of getting your faction upgraded and powerful and mixing it with the strategy to achieve goals and control territory. You are very focused on yourself, but you must pay attention to others, as its not just a race to goal achievements, but being ready to capitalize on the points awarded at the end. The downside is the length of time to teach the game. Nothing is too complex, however, there is a lot of aspects to cover.  

Purchased: 10/25/16 (BoardGameGeek)

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
This game is mechanically sound, looks nice, and I would play it again.

BUT, it also has a shallow-to-nonsensical implementation of theme, a purely mechanical 'do stuff to do stuff' approach to gameplay, and left me finding it difficult to care about why I was doing anything except 'because the game demands it'.

The pursuit of stars feels like ticking boxes, or chasing Xbox achievements - as soon as it's done, you cease caring. Resources become near-redundant. Mechs are built, and buildings spring up, not because you necessarily want to build them, but because if you rush out all 4 you get a star. Even combat is often "I don't really want to, but..."

Yes, there's efficiency at the heart of the game, and enjoyment from puzzling through that, but it's an artificial heart that smoothly hums along. I appreciate it's mostly streamlined design, but I want to build, fight, populate, even farm for a more involving reason than 'because'. Too much polish, not enough guts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In my opinion this game is overhyped. Yes, it is beautifully made, lots of parts and so on, but greatly lacks interaction between players. Combat is available but most of the time you will stop trying to pick a fight after winning 2 battles to get those two stars on track. You just wait for your turn thinking what to do next. Could be compared to Game of Thrones 2nd edition, but GoT is a far more fun and challenging game - Scythe has far less combat and diplomacy. Yes, you can bribe and so on but most of the time you won't do that. Scythe is like taking Nexus Ops (move in hexes and try to control certain tiles for your benefit), Catan (for trying to hinder other players), Game of Thrones (combat and negotiations, but far, far less of those) and Power Grid (resource management). It is a good game, but most definitely not worth the ranking position it is at right now.

RATING: 9.5
Miniature Market Preorder.  Received 6/27/16.

Amazing variability.  I love how different each faction and player mat feel.  The variable encounters, structure bonuses, and objectives all make for a different game each time.  The tension in the game escalates well, as you really feel the pressure to accomplish more goals or increase popularity after someone puts that 5th star down.  I'm also beginning to enjoy the nuances of combat and the fact that it's as much about the threat of combat as actual fighting itself.

Original review here:
https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/1598580/would-you-build-empire-2p-review-scythe

RATING: 5
Played two sessions of 4-player games. 

Not much player interaction.

Easy to turtle the entire game. 

Combat has *huge* room for improvement. 

Artificially forced map constraints in early game = frustrating early game. 

End-game condition can come as surprise for most players, creating a disappointing experience. 

Randomized upper and lower boards setup is cool. I can see it working most of the time. But in 1 of my 2 games, I got a bad combination for the Combat faction. I tried to play to its strength as much as I could, and had one of the most boring game experience in recent time. Eventually won the star-race and ended the game, came in 2nd, felt totally under-whelmed.

Overall, Scythe is very well produced. But not as good as hyped.

Will not want to play again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love this game...

I love the artwork!

I love the mechanics!

I love all the little bits and pieces!

I...

Love...

This...

GAME!!!

This game has a great theme, and the player/faction mats are implemented so well! There's a one player variant (very cool), but this game can seat up to five players!

The one thing that stops this game short of greatness, and certainly it's no fault of the game itself, is that it is a fucking COMMITMENT! Seriously, if you're with a group of people who've never played this, be ready to spend the first hour explaining the rules... and then the next hour clarifying things while you play. I actually played a SEVEN player game once, and we spent 3+ hours on this bad boy. I mean, don't get me wrong, I had a blast, but I'm a patient man. I imagine some people will find the whole thing to be a slog, ESPECIALLY in the beginning.

I'd liken this game to... a roller-coaster. It does start out slow, yes, very slow... but after people start placing their second or third star, shit starts coming down like an avalanche.

Just play it, alright!

P.S. I'd recommend an insert for this, lots and lots of little bits and pieces per faction (x5).

P.P.S. One of the greatest things this game has going for it (in my opinion) is that all the miniatures (workers, mechs, leaders) are unique to their respective faction... THAT IS AWESOME! Even if they weren't color-coded you'd still be able to determine which unit belongs to which player... it would be a pain in the ass, sure, but you COULD do it, and I think that's awesome!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

You always feel like you are making a significant decision, and it's always a fun time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really enjoy Scythe and am usually happy when my gaming group picks it to play.  Each faction is unique offers a different strategy, although I will say some are clearly more powerful than others.  I enjoy the upgrade and building system, and I think that the theme is fantastic.  The artwork is also a high point, and the game components are high quality.  I find that the strategic choices are varied, and there are many different paths to victory (although not all are created equal...more on that below).  

A few minor gripes.  1) Balancing of factions is not equal.  Certain groups are more powerful than others, and it's not even close.  2) Strategy.  Depending on faction and play mat you can go online and find complex "openings" that essentially take most of the strategy and thought out of the game.  It's almost like Chess where you just pick your first 10+ moves, and then make very minor adjustments based on what your opponents do.  Because of this I find it best to play this game with less hardcore gamers (ie. people who try new strategies and ideas as they go).  Otherwise you end up with very similar games every time if people know these openings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Excellent presentation. That's the only feature I'm not conflicted over.
"Upgrading" your personal board is a fun puzzle, but is ultimately shuffling cubes around to construct a dry, game-winning mechanism, rather than building something physically, as well mechanically, pleasing (contrast with, for example, Farmers of the Moor).
It's good that you have to consider what the other players are doing on the map. However, trying to disrupt their system and prevent them disrupting yours is more annoying than fun sometimes.
I wouldn't want to play with five players again as the time between turns is too much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Curtis, Darcy and Diedrich
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

There was always the risk that this would be a case of style over substance but it is absolutely not the case, it's a deep and rewarding resource management game that isn't as combat focused as it might appear.

RATING: 7
Kickstarter
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played it once in two players.

It is not a bad game per se, it is bad for what you expect. 
I don't mind an accounting game, where I have to optimize the production of some nameless token, but when it is dressed like a wargame it really makes me mad!

Everything in this game feels like you are doing it just for the sake of it. Usually, one has an objective and he can use different game mechanics (strategies?) to achieve it. For example, let us assume that one has to conquer as many territories as possible. Then one recruits workers, in order to gain resources, then uses the resources to produce mech units and deploy troops, this units are then used to fight. Once the combat is won, one conquer the land and gets the victory.
Not in this game! Here you recruit workers because it is a winning condition. You deploy mech units because it is a winning condition, you enlist troops because it is a winning condition. When you have your big army you can.. ops no, you can't because the game is over and you already have enough points to win simply having your units there doing nothing.

Also: money as points?  Really? In a game with farmers and badass steam punk mech units on the cover, your goal is to gain as much gold as possible? The ultimate goal of your empire is money? Are you kidding me?

A total let down.

Pro:
The art and the miniatures are very nice. 
The game flows rapidly.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Update after three plays: solid resource management game. Catan on steroids actually. Player powers unbalanced and I still don't understand why there are these limiting movement rules, see below. This game is not bad, but there are many better games around.

After one play of this over-hyped game:
- Gloomy dark artwork, not much contrast. Not very functional. Ameritrashers have seen this so often, but Euro players are used to higher standards of bright colours and good contrast between them instead of varing shades of black.
- The map is supposed to show us Eastern Europe. Shouldn't the artist perhaps have taken a look at the actual geography of Eastern Europe, before he started drawing? 
- During the game most counter-intuitive is the movement action. You're extremely limited. Some parts of the map I couldn't go to, even though I had developed all of my movement tricks through mechs. After crossing rivers I could only enter into two types of land. Why so rigid, why so inflexible?  
- Having said all that, what remains is a solid game. A mix of known mechanisms put together in a new game. A race to get 6 stars for 6 targets you're working on. Resource production and conversion as we know it from many euro's is quite straightforward. A bit of fighting added to that. I want to explore this game more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game looks complicated and takes a while to explain, my group took about an hour before we were ready to even start the game. However, once we actually got into the game, it was pretty easy to follow. You only have the choice of moving your action selection pawn between four areas and (unless your character ability says otherwise) you cannot choose the area you chose last turn, making turns both fast and relatively simple.

Not that there isn't a lot of things to consider. Each player board comes with a differently distributed set of costs and rewards for each actions, meaning one player benefits more or pays less to put out mechs, while another can more easily put out buildings. Each board also gives the player options on ways to upgrade their actions to gain better benefits and reduce costs, giving you plenty of choices in what strategy you want to play.

What initially made me unsure of the game before trying it was that it looked like it could be combat heavy, but combat actually plays a surprisingly little role in the game. There are combat-related goals, but as you lose popularity for invading hexes with opponent pieces and have to spend power to fight the other players - both of which are not that easily earned in the game - and there are also goals rewarding you if you manage to max out those stats - you find yourself only rarely engaging other players in battle, which puts the focus more on solving the puzzle on how to make your randomly dealt player board work for you, which is what I enjoy the most.

Definitely a fantastic game, I highly recommend it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
great game!! love the theme and art. Complex enough to get a meaty game play in, but doable. Cant wait to get the expansions.

RATING: N/A
4p
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.75
For all the bluster and praise spewing out about this game I expected a helluva lot more than a Terra Mystica clone.  The combat is only good to score a point or two, the highly touted art is just present on some throwaway cards, and the plastic is ugly.  The board is difficult to read and the downtime unpleasant.  You have to collect these to turn into those so you can place that, like so many other games.  The asymmetry is present, but essentially everyone is heading towards the same thing and you get essentially the same endpoints, and since you spend the vast majority of the time doing things in vacuum, the assymetry is lost.  No, I don't see what the hype is all about, and I fully expect thsi game to fall into obscurity within a couple years.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
After this and Viticulture, I've tabbed Jamey Stegmaier as the "conventional designer." Scythe is a smooth, streamlined euro. I suppose I wouldn't turn it down but I would never suggest it either, because I play games for the excitement of conflict and the original ideas. And what great ideas this could've had, with its evocative art and imaginative world! The potential for world building through unique mechanics! In the end, Scythe is just a run of the mill engine builder & area control game. I wish they had chosen some boring Medival farming theme for this, so I can see a different, great game attached to the great art.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Straightforward engine building with a lot of extra flavor.  Play is intuitive and fairly brisk for such a large game, but games can still run long.  Combat is simple and quickly resolved.  Starts out quiet and solitary but becomes more interactive as time runs out.  Still has the table politics and "kingmaking" issues found in similar games despite it's Euro game framework.  Solo play very cleverly approximates human opponents.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Collector's edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Only one play so far, but I really enjoyed it.  As such, I wouldn't be surprised if my rating goes down after a few plays - after all, it's hard to go up from where my initial feel is.

The mechanisms for each action seem disjoint - but as they're separate and self-contained, means that it's easy to teach and learn as you go.  The actions mesh together into a pretty good emergent system.  Play goes at a fairly good clip, with very little downtime between turns.  I really enjoyed that the combat resulted in an arms race, in which you were vulnerable if you didn't build up, but had to sacrifice some of your economy to build to where you could defend.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Would like to play but trying to avoid buying miniatures games since I dislike when they become arguments in favor of quality or cost of a game. Did not see anything to really convince me otherwise in Joel Eddy's overview video from Gen Con 2015.

Update:
Got to play it yesterday (October 2016). I like the base mechanics of player boards and upgrades which is similar to Terra Mystica. I really did not like so much the way in which events and particularly the factory cards break the implicit economics. I could get mechs for 4 metal (later 2) and buildings for 4 wood (later 2) but one player could get a building or a mech for one heart! To make matters worse, he did not even come close to winning. Both getting an insane board position out of nothing (ignoring the normal effort that it takes to build stuff) and then not winning felt really strange. I do not expect that further plays will change this.
Moreover, there are way too many adjacency effects through tunnels and extra abilities and tracing who could go where is quite annoying. It always seemed like everyone else could be everywhere all the time...

She said there wasnt much to do after all the encounter tokens were gone (she liked gathering those!).  Im excited to try a 3 or 4 player game and see how that changes things up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the best games I've ever played! The replayability is simply astounding! There are five different factions (seven with the expansion) and five different player mats (seven with the expansion), making 25 possible combinations (49 if with the expansion)! There are so many options and ways to win in the game. You can concentrate on getting buildings, recruits or more workers, become more popular (Popularity is a type of "currency" in the game) or you can try to upgrade everything in order to make your economy more profitable so that everything will cost less and give you more. Or you can concentrate on your army, become more powerful (power is a type of "currency" in the game) and try to dominate more areas. For those seeking a war game with miniatures - which is actually why I bought the game in the first place - this might not be the game for you since combat is pretty rare in Scythe and the mechs are used rather to threaten your opponents and try to keep them away from you.
The feat that you store your resources on the board and that players can steal them is pretty neat and also rather realistic.
It is a complex game but once you played it, it should become relatively simple to play. Playing it with two players ins't too exciting since both players get to control nearly half of the board so I'd recommend using at least three players (I haven't yet played the single player variant, so I can't really say anything about it).
All in all, a very admirable and entertaining game where making choices takes up a big part of the game and with excellent, good quality, super detailed miniatures which make the game all the more intriguing. A must-have for people who love slightly complicated board games!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Jakub Rosalski steampunk témájú festmény kiállítására ráhúzott gazdasági-harci-stratégiai eurós játékként is értelmezhető a Stegmaier tervezőasztaláról kikerült sikerjáték.

Az egyedi tematika a játék minden komponensén visszaköszön: gyönyörű festmények a találkozás kártyákon, játékostáblákon, a miniken a harcosok mellett hol egy pézsmatulok, óriás medve, vagy egy farkas... És még a munkások is máshogy néznek ki minden klánnál.

Gyorsan beszippant a téma, amit nagyon jól kiszolgál a kiválóan működő mechanikája is, ami különösképpen a termelésnél sikerült egyedire (amit termelünk, "kint" marad a térképen, nem kerül központi raktárba, azaz felhasználásig az ellenfél által eltulajdonítható, ha lerohanja az adott tartományt). Nem csak az artwork egyedi tehát, hanem mechanikában is tud olyat mutatni, amit más játékban eddig még nem "használt el" senki.

Első olvasatra nem tűnik rövidnek a játékszabályzata, de tulajdonképpen minden logikus benne, egyszer kell végigmenni rajta + első játéknál néha-néha előkapni a szabályzatot és onnantól már nincs vele gond. Segíti a tanulási folyamatot a jól átlátható és gyorsan felfogható ikonrendszere (pl. a játékostáblán a zöld kockák - előnyök, amiket mi kapunk, piros kockák - amit nekünk kell fizetni).

A játék összetettségét és stratégiai mélységét jól mutatja, hogy simán lehet egyetlen megnyert harc nélkül is végső győzelmet szerezni benne, ha olyan virágzó gazdaságot építünk ki, amivel a többiek fölé tudunk nőni. Előnye mellett talán ez is az egyik hátránya: elég lelombozó maga a harc egyszerűsége, ami igazából elég gyakran egyik játékosnak sem érdeke. Emiatt sokszor csak "kerülgetés" és erődemonstráció van, mert az esetek többségében egyszerűen nem érdemes nekimenni a másiknak. Ha hozzátesszük, hogy a vesztes fél sem bukik akkorát - csupán visszakerülnek egységei a bázisra -, akkor meg duplán elgondolkozik minden klán vezetője, hogy akar-e némi hajtépést a tábla közepén.

A találkozások és a célkártyák nélkül is simán elmenne a játék, de némi színezés gondolom még ráfért, nem akart Stegmaier annyira szárazat alkotni. Így meg fel tudott használni még több mint 50 Rosalski festményt a játékhoz. Remélem a lengyel csávó a festmények darabszáma alapján adta el a jogokat és most már milliárdos...

Erősen javasolt kategória, mert a kicsit gyengébb harcrendszeren kívül nem sok minden más negatívumot tudnék mondani ellene. (Még mielőtt valaki félreérti: a steampunk festmények használata bőven a pozitívumok számát növeli.)

Valószínűleg soha nem lesz a top3-ban, de hogy sokáig az egyik etalon marad a 4X (eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, eXterminate) játékok kategóriájában, abban biztos vagyok.

!!!SPOILER!!!
Első játék után érdemes közösen a játékostársakkal rácsodálkoznunk a térképen elrejtett Télapóra, Loch Ness-i szörnyre, vagy Piroskára és a farkasra. "Priceless", ahogy a wall street-i bankárok mondanák.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
For the first few playthoughs of this game I wasn't sure what I thought of it.  As I've played it more, I've really grown to love it.  It's important to recognize what it is and what it is not - if you want a game that has a lot of direct conflict between players you won't enjoy this as much as it's mostly about building an economy.  But, if you like epic grand strategy games and want to play a game that does NOT have a lot of direct combat, Scythe is a great game.  

That said, each game is truly different and the powers really matter - often, your goal in this game is trying to find a way to maximize your power's specific advantages.  Sometimes that involves direct conflict.  

The game really plays best with at least 4 players.  However, I still am not sure how balanced it is between players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
the hipsters and bed-wetters have been convinced by a clever marketting campaign and overblown artwork that this is the best 4X game ever made. 

Truth is, Scythe is a dull engine building game who's only novelty is the asymmetric faction powers. There is not enough flexibility to engage my mind, nor enough options for creative play. 

the artwork is well illustrated but unfortunately makes the game harder to play.

As for the theme: sticking a few plastic mechs in the box is not enough. One just ends up doing action after action in pursuit of gold stars. WTF has that to do with the theme?

RATING: 8
A wonderful combination of different mechanics creating what is basically a mix between an economic engine building game with a touch of wargame.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
With family visiting to entertain the Little Fish I managed to get away to a full day of one of our local open gaming sessions. At this session I collected my copy of Scythe from the KickStarter cabal opened it up and set up and played immediately. 

My initial impression of the game is very positive. The components (I, of course, elected to back the deluxe version) are simply magnificent. Wonderful production values throughout with lovely evocative art, perfectly produced plastic miniatures (top marks for a first try at producing miniatures making the efforts of Treefrog Games with Moongha Invaders: Mad Scientists and Atomic Monsters Attack the Earth! look all the more shoddy) and the metal coins really do enhance the playing experience.

The gameplay of Scythe is also great - plenty of meaningful decision as well as the challenge of leveraging each faction's advantages and negating, as far as possible, their weaknesses. The way the player boards work also suggest there is plenty of replayability and this one will be a game that hits the table with regularity. 

I thought that Stonemaier Games was pretty cocksure putting an expansion (Scythe: Invaders from Afar) into development before the base game itself had been released but as far as I am concerned their faith in their product is more than justified and I will almost certainly be picking this one up when it becomes available. Top marks.

UPDATE:

I have played this with two and it's not the greatest. Needs more for it to really shine.

My first impression is that the game is solid, but not great.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Video Review - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QLR8z1Qy_yg&t=1s

Scythe is for me, a fantastic game. I love how Stonemaier Games rule books are complete but approachable and lead you nicely into the more complex game mechanics. Helpful guides are in all the places you would need them to be meaning that once you have read the rules, the double sided single sheet quick guide will be all you need to refer to for most situations.

It's hard to pick out my favourite part of Scythe. The open ended routes to victory certainly appeal to my style of play, but what nudges it for me is the player and action selection boards which work together brilliantly. The action selection method contained here and the way you can improve and upgrade these is a great feeling.

The actions you choose then play out on the main board where you will deploy mechs, workers and buildings in an effort to make progress towards achieving 6 of a possible 10 star options.

There are some niggles but it's hard to see how they could be avoided. There is a set up and tear down time to take into account and the game can drag with certain types of player. But ultimately these don't detract from what I think is a wonderful game and experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Was lucky enough to take part in the first wave of play tests. Thoroughly enjoyable experience, great to see how game is evolving.

Unless something catastrophic happens, which I seriously doubt, this will be on my immediate buy list. I enjoyed playing so much I am still playing it just to see if it can keep getting better.

I am now eagerly awaiting the KickStarter and seeing what the final components are like based upon the previous SM games.

06/08/16 
Played my first game with the released components. Needless to say quality of components is excellent, we played on the expanded board and it just makes things clearer to see and appear less crowded.

Was a five player game with only one other player haven played the game. After initial talk through of what you can do and what game win conditions were we all started to play ...ended up going to a tie-breaker with both players hitting 82 points, which was funny as I was on the middle popularity points whilst my compatriot managed his popularity better to hit top tier.

I won the tie break conditions ... looking forward to the next play as do not see it losing its edge for some time.

RATING: 7
A functional game that fails to excite me after a few plays. While I understood the euro nature of the game going in, the somewhat deterministic combat and plethora of ways to navigate the map made terrain control and positioning feel frivioulous. The end game typically was triggered by one of the players who let one mech stray from their army blob getting dive-bombed from across the map via the mine system for an easy last star made the ending feel anticlimactic, as the players focused on their own optimization more than the threat of violence. Combat only happened a handful of times during the game, and only when the attacker was essentially sure if victory. Unfortunately, the euro-churning optimization clearly deliniated who was the most efficient with their production and spending opportunities, and while that is fine, it doesn't leave a strong impression on me. Beautiful production and solid mechanisms make for a standard euro style game.

RATING: 7
[b]Like:[/b]
-THAT ART THOUGH!
-Tension of neighbours and positioning your mechs and workers accordingly

[b]Dislike:[/b]
-You don't care what your opponent's are doing until late in the game (less players = later)
-Don't really have the freedom to pursue what you want

This game is harder to teach than I initially thought, even though the game itself isn't that complex. This makes me feel like the game isn't "meaty" enough relative to the amount of rules it's got.

Now first things first: the game doesn't feel like I thought/wanted it to feel. It's a race, and you better not screw up too many times or you'll never succeed. It's hard to score a ton of points out of nowhere to catch up with the rest, unless you specifically planned for that beforehand.

I would've loved to have more freedom to play how you want to play, not try to abuse your player board as much as possible. I want to be able to win by upgrading my stuff because that feels satisfying, or by building an army of mechs, even though the mat tells me these give me zero gold.

Another (minor) annoyance I have is with regards to the resources. I don't like the fact that you can't hoard these and keep building stuff with it, since what you can build is limited. Sure, you can always spend them for a bit of gold, but it's just not the same (and usually not the most efficient way to play). This makes the resources-on-the-board mechanic kinda meh, which was kinda the idea I really liked about this game and why I wanted to get it over others.

Even though it's not the game I wanted it to be, it certainly allows for some interesting decisions to be made; tension can get very high. But I just don't like games where it just ends up with "Oh, you build your infrastructure in a little more efficient way than I did..." near the end of the game. Ticket to Ride creates the same tension with less than half the rules. It allows the same feelings of racing and "Oh God please don't go there!"

The game gets better with more people, which is always a good sign to me.

I do like the theme and art a lot better in Scythe though, and want to raise the score just for that. However, I just can't bring myself to rank it among other games I like better just cause it looks so good.

TLDR; "A mile wide and an inch deep"

These custom metal coins are designed specifically for Scythe by artist Jakub Rozalski. They number 25 ($1), 15 ($3), 15 ($5), 15 ($10), and 10 ($20), for a total of 80 coins. They range in size from 20-30mm. Photo depicts prototypes, not final coins. Estimated Delivery: August 2016.

RATING: 9
Latest update after 4th play.  Played with 5 - excellent.  Game plays better with more players.  With 3 its an 8.5, with 4 its a 9, and with 5 its a 9.5.  The only thing that is holding it back from a perfect 10 for me, is that I would like a bit more confrontation.  But that is just my opinion, and it might just be that the crowd I play with doesn't seek out conflict.  There is nothing wrong with that, and you certainly can avoid conflict in this game and still win.

This game requires 4 to 5 players to shine (like Wallenstein).  Finally played with 4 and there was a bit more conflict, but still only towards the last third of the game.  The game has a cooler theme and bits than Wallenstein, but Wallenstein has more interaction, tension, excitement and quite honestly fun IMHO.

Where Scythe differs from other games in this genre, is that it focuses heavily on building up your own resource engine in the first half of the game, to prepare for a "potential" conflict in the second half of the game.  Where in other games of this type, there are definitely battles going on by no later than the  3rd round of play onward, and EVERYONE fights, usually multiple times.

Bottom line is that I like Scythe quite a bit, but I don't believe I will be picking it up because of other games that I have with this type of play style (i.e. Wallenstein, Cyclades, Kemet ..) that I like as much, if not more.

RATING: N/A
BGR
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Definitely overrated, but still pretty fun.

Scythe doesn't do anything that fresh, but it does combine elements of a lot of other well-known games. Playing this gave me similar vibes to games like Tiny Epic Kingdoms (mostly), Terra Mystica, and Harbour. I found the game fine, but what really bugs me about it is that it suffers from that same forced progression that Euphoria has. The game starts out incredibly slow, but picks up steam as you go along. Both here and in Euphoria, however, I kept asking myself why the game was so slow to begin with. I love a developing arc in games, but not when it takes so long to get going.

Scythe is also begging for more player interaction. One thing I love about Tiny Epic Kingdoms is that, when you take an action, other players can choose to follow that action or gain resources, which makes every decision agonizing. Here, a lot of what you do ends up being "Okay, I'm going to move these guys".......everyone else takes their turn......"Okay, I'm going to produce resources." The downtime is pretty bad unless you're playing with an experienced group, and there isn't nearly as much turn angst here. I feel like if it was designed with this "lead/follow" mechanism included, the game would have been so much better. 

It's just so slow-paced, and it's almost designed with the concept of not letting anyone pull off a nice combo that often. Other than recruiting, which gives you a small bonus for others taking certain actions, this is largely a solitary experience. I do like that this game encourages an almost cold war feel in how you want to guard your workers in case an opponent decides to get nasty, but usually, unless your objectives and/or player boards dictate otherwise, combat isn't worth it.

As for things I like, I do think the components and artwork are astounding. I also really like the lore of the game. Everyone converging on this non-functioning mech factory to compete for resources and dominance is a cool idea, but much like Terra Mystica, I wish that there was at least a little bit of variation in map setups. The encounter cards are interesting as well. Much like Above and Below, you're not getting anything super immersive, but I like that you're given a choice rather than forced to do something based on dice rolls. Having your resources placed on the board is a nice touch as well, because they can be up for grabs if an aggressive player comes along, so you don't want to stockpile too much in any one location.

There are some clever elements to this game, such as how encounters work and how well-organized the player boards are, but ultimately this is a game you're either going to love or hate based on other games from this designer. I liked this more than Euphoria, but I still feel like Viticulture with Tuscany is his magnum opus. I just wish that he would do something fresh-feeling instead of the tired old worker placement being shoehorned into everything with awkward tracks that represent odd things like popularity and knowledge.

I might spend a little more time with this game to see if my opinion improves, but I think that I would rather play Tiny Epic Kingdoms, which covers much of the same ground much faster.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Scythe is a very hyped game and I can understand its appeal to new gamers. From a development perspective, it wipes the floors with older games. The player boards almost play the games for you with indentations that tell you where to place your starting cubes and clear symbols that tell you what happens after upgrades (=removal of cubes). The turns are smooth and streamlined and I particularly like how the next player can start their primary actions while the previous player completes his or her secondary actions, since they won't affect other players. In the unlikely event that you would find yourself bored between turns, the stunning art of the board and the components tell innumerous stories to get absorbed in.

However, the design offers nothing new to the seasoned gamer. You take actions to remove cubes to unlock abilities to remove more cubes until you've finally accomplished enough goals to end the game. The board is big enough for everybody so unless someone wants to be aggressive (which earns victory points but is also costly), each player will be doing his or her own stuff. In fact, my first game saw not a single battle. The game of unlocking abilities is better executed in a game like Hansa Teutonica, where the player keep getting in each others' ways, and this is also true in my preferred Stonemaier game: Euphoria.

I won't turn down an offer to play Scythe and I'll be generous with my rating thanks to the development but every mechanism that can be found here is better implemented elsewhere.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played 3 games in total. Game is a bit tricky to understand the rules the first time, especially with the top and bottom actions. Intuitively, you would think that you choose either the top or the bottom action. However, it's actually both. Overall, I find Scythe to be very interesting for at least a few games.

PROS
1. Replayability Factor
There is a small replayability factor with the mixup of Factory Cards, different player boards and 8 different races to play.

2. Interconnected Maps
The tunnels are great at shortening the distance between players, ensuring a fair battleground. Other war games tend to have uneven distances between players.

CONS
1. Railroading
Players tend to be railroaded down a single racial bonus. E.g. Black is a war faction with the ability to keep on gaining stars from battle. It wins if it win more fights. Blue has the ability to use the Lakes, allowing them to win with more map tiles since you can control Lakes. The initial resource distribution also railroads your strategy. E.g. Starting with Metal enables Mechs to appear faster, while starting with Wood allows more buildings to be built. 

2. Enlisting
The rewards for enlistment is limited to only the players on your immediate left and right which makes it sort of luck dependent as you will choose the secondary action that your neighbours play or you will get nothing. This creates a situation where luck matters as you hope that your neighbours give you a reward that is inline with your strategy. 

3. Objectives
It is actually possible to draw 2 objectives that are not inline with your strategy. Like a pacifist card with a war faction.

RATING: 8
"Scythe! Everyone's favourite economic powerhouse hiding behind steam-powered Mechs. It'd be easy to mistake Scythe for a combat based game, however in truth, it's a wonderfully filled engine building game with absolutely miniscule amounts of luck. The whole game depends on your strategy and your ability to make the most of your resources, as you build your empire vying for popularity, military might and economic supremecy. A bit unwieldy at first, Scythe is surprisingly simple and turns actually flow in a matter of seconds once you get going, leaving for little downtime. 

Ranked as the 7th Best Board Game of all time, Scythe won multiple awards including Best Thematic Board Game, Golden Geek Game of The Year award and Best Strategy Game.

Most importantly, it also won Best Artwork 2016. And we can absolutely understand why. This game is absolutely beautiful; every single image is a work of art and worthy of looking through for that reason alone."

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.9
Une seule partie jouée (3 joueurs). Je partais avec l'idée que j'allais m'ennuyer en jouant à Scythe. Selon divers commentaires écrits ici sur BGG, le jeu ratissait assez large côté "mécaniques" de jeu, sans nécessairement (bien) les approfondir. Mes lectures m'avaient également mis en garde sur l'aspect "solitaire" du jeu, où les intéractions sont peu nombreuses. Finalement, l'aspect "économique" du jeu, où il s'agit de développer son propre truc (et, au final, de "faire fonctionner le jeu", quoi!?) ne fait pas particulièrement partie de mes préférences.

En y jouant, j'ai effectivement retrouvé un peu tous ces éléments, mais le fait de l'avoir su à l'avance faisait en sorte que mes attentes étaient on ne peut plus basses.  Au final, je donne une note qui est supérieure à ce que je m'attendais à attribuer à ce jeu, mais qui est quelque peu inférieure à ma moyenne des notes attribuées sur BGG. Et je suis loin derrière la "hype" de la communauté, plaçant le jeu actuellement en 8e place, avec une note moyenne de 8.3.

Il est clair pour moi que je ne vois pas trop comment Scythe peut garantir une réelle rejouabilité, sinon bien sûr lors des parties *2, 3, 4... où l'on va tester d'autres plaquettes de jeu. Outre cela, j'ai l'impression qu'il s'agira toujours, hélas, de mettre en marche une machine (d'une manière répétitive d'une partie à l'autre et somme toute monotone) et de la faire fonctionner, avec un minimum d'intéractions réunies sur le plateau central. Un feeling qui s'apparente un peu à celui que j'ai éprouvé en jouant à Myrmes - d'ailleurs j'accorde des notes similaires aux deux jeux. On développe son truc devant soi et à partir d'un moment, une certaine collision peut survenir sur d'autres joueurs - mais bien souvent on est alors presque à la fin de la partie. Ou alors (bien que les deux jeux ne soient pas comparables), un feeling à la 7 Wonders, dans le sens où on ne se préoccupe guère de ce qui se passe à l'autre bout de la table durant 85% du temps.

Par conséquent, je suis bien prêt à redonner à Scythe une deuxième chance (à 4 joueurs), voire une troisième, mais je serais surpris d'en vouloir plus à partir de ce moment. Certainement pas un jeu que je vais vouloir acquérir.

"[COLOR=#003300]Scythe had the problem of "doing stuff for the sake of doing stuff." I don't need my fourth mech, but I need a star, so I'll build one just for that. I don't find that interesting: building a mech should be a big deal, not just a checkmark on your way to 6 stars. Same goes for combat and recruits and structures: I don't really need this thing, but I need the star from it..[/color]" [Daybreak (6)]

"[COLOR=#003300]Scythe has a light amount of interaction, mostly for board position. Yet, for the most part, you will do your thing, the others will do theirs, and rarely one will care to see what you are doing. It will be more an affair of "pass me 3 food", or "raise my popularity by 1", or "I'm building this, here". - Small interaction and even interest in what the other players are doing for most of the time.[/color]" [tiagoVIP (7)]

"[COLOR=#003300]The actions trigger many effects on the game board at the same time, and therefore taking actions feels more like triggering chaos than carefully and orderly expanding.[/color]" [hydra_be (4)]

"[COLOR=#003300]Scythe is an engine-building game that mostly concerns itself with action efficiency questions. There is an interesting action selection system (unless you are the Rosviet Union) but players spend the largest part of the game brooding over their own player boards while the only interaction point is the limited combat (which I generally am a fan of) that is most likely to occur when fighting for the final few VPs.[/color]" [fizzle (5)]

RATING: N/A
Jordan's
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Have: Invaders from Afar
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In an alternate reality 1920's Europe, players are one of five asymmetrical factions, moving units on the board, building mechs, building structures, producing goods, enlisting, upgrading or having encounters. If your mechs or characters meet an opponent, combat is decided by a combat wheel and a card modifier.  The game ends when one player achieves 6 stars, and VPs are counted. Stars are awarded for winning combat, objective cards, building 4 mechs/4 structures/4 enlists and so on.  Your score is modified by your popularity, and  VPs are awarded for stars, controlled territories and resources. You also get VPs for where your structures are located depending on the structure card that is flipped up. 

I like the part about trying to optimize your engine. I'm not overly fond of the combat system, and not too many combats will occur, typically toward the end of the game as people look to get more stars. The game can end with an unequal number of turns for each player, which I don't like either. I know this game is highly rated, but it just doesn't feel precise with all those asymmetrical powers, especially about the turn order.  The tactical element of attacking people is something that doesn't grab me, as it could change what was an economic game into a survival game and you could be unfairly attacked.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Competitive. Players start with diff. resources, diff. location & hidden goal. Action-selection mechanism (no rounds/phases). Upgrade actions, build, enlist recruits, activate mechs & expand borders. PL: same.

RATING: 9

For the most part my first play was able to be done by going over the mechanics once and just following exactly what is written on the game boards.  They're fairly unambiguous.  Overall I'd say it's a nearly perfect game and was loads of fun.  My group tended to compare it to Twilight Imperium, but the main difference (other than the obvious thematic one) was that Scythe actually seems as though it can be played in an evening.  My group will definitely be going back to Scythe again.

RATING: 2.5
The game is gorgeous, gives a great first impression, and seems much better balanced than I had expected given the asymmetrical starting positions... yet I don't enjoy playing.

The efficiency puzzle feels like it can often be solved before players have a meaningful chance to interact. This becomes even more noticeable if you don't have a full compliment of players at the table. The impression of balance also is false if you don't have enough player interaction to help even out advantages (ie: synergies) that might be randomly awarded at the start of the game.

Every session of this game has left me less impressed. At this point, I would actively avoid playing if given the choice.

RATING: 6
This is the most OK game I have ever played. Let me preface this review with this is one of the most gorgeous games to ever be produced, so if your wanting an expensive paper weight this is it. Combat is the most boring part of the game, but the good news is it hardly ever happens. You quickly learn that the combat is rarely ever worth the effort and resources, so noone engages in it. If your dying for the game, get it. You may enjoy some things about it and worst case you lose a few dollars in a trade. If your on the fence, this is an easy pass on mechanics. There just isn't enough game here. Perhaps my rating is so low due to the fact that is rated 6th game of all time. I wouldn't even put this in the top 200.

RATING: 7
Challenging game that you need to keep you head straight when working on a strategy as it may take a dozen turns to see it though.  I can see a number of house rules coming in, firstly a short term score system that at some point early in the game a quick tally of the scores is done so players can see what they are going for to score points (not a surprise ending which newer players will experience).  

I enjoy the solo elements of the game also, finding it a great way to learn the game and be better placed to teach others.  The solo computer is very good indeed at creating a challenging opponent and helping you mould your play style to suit the faction your playing.

RATING: 8.5

There is very little combat in this game, especially at lower player counts, but it's the *threat* of combat that keeps things interesting. Though in my games I noticed most people focus on their own, and maybe their neighbors mechs, and not people across the board (which makes it easy to get blindsided by them).  

Lower player counts end up more on the euro/multiplayer solitaire end of the scale. Higher player counts ends up on the more interactive end of the scale.

RATING: 5

2 player: 1:20
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Heavy euro with touches of strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
The free for all battles have been solved in a brilliant way: limited benefits, attacking workers is punished and the effects for the loser are mild. Battles are resolved using the Dune wheel mechanism. As a result of all this, battles are scarce, they are only fought when the attacker is sure he will win. They are there just to produce a "cold war" effect that will create tension and allow it to rise.

The economic part is definitly there. You need to carefully plan your actions in order to be able to do as much as you can in every turn. This is not as complex as it initially seemed, but it's a nice optimization job that will keep you busy.

Keeping the resources in the playing board is a brilliant and original idea that adds another [minor] layer of tactic depth.

What I found more surprising about Scythe is the game flow. It is quite fluid and we finish our 4-player first game in just 2 hours, after having played many turns each.

There are a couple of things I'm not fully satisfied with:
-> Not many ways to win. For each lower personal board, there are "optimal routes to victory" you can't deviate much from if you want to win. The rest of the stuff, including upper personal boards, just add features and minor modifications to those routes. Yes, even if you repeat with both boards, you won't be able to pull of exactly the same strategy, but it will be very similar.
-> The endgame is a bit anti-climatic. Most of the points will be awarded by area control, everybody will be spreading through the board as much as they can when they sense the end is near. And this is when the "punish the leader" effect will take place: players will tend to attack whomever they consider the strongest player.
-> I probably should not say this because I've only played 4 games, but I suspect that one specific lower board is better than the others (to the point of allowing you to perform 2 actions on almost every turn). I doubled my rivals in score when I played it, and it's not difficult to see why. They key is that all the boards are mathematically neutral, but the combination of the actions is not (some actions are better performed during the first turns, some can wait, some are better at the end...). 

First impression [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/184429/item/4254939#item4254939]here[/url].

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Gavin 2 / 2
Andy 0 / 2
Patrick 0 / 1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My favorite things about the game:

1. The artist, Jakub Rozaiski, is credited with, "world building and art." I love that Stonemaier Games acknowledged the critical role that the artwork plays in making this game so wonderful. Maybe more than any other game I've ever played, the aesthetics matter. This is by no means an indication that the actual gameplay is in any way sub-optimal [GFOP]. It's just that Mr. Rozaiski did, indeed, build an incredibly engaging world. And it absolutely elevates the game.

2. There is a fantastic balance of elements drawn from two totally different gaming traditions. It has all the resource production, chaining, and optimization of your favorite Euro, but with giant, walking war machines that will blow you up and take your stuff. That being said, the game is less about combat, and more about the threat of combat. If you completely ignore the confrontational aspects of the game, you will likely not win. However, as my 14 y/o discovered while playing recently, you can deploy all your mechs, mercilessly harass the other players with your ability to emerge from nearby lakes, drive off their workers without remorse (because of your special exemption from losing popularity for doing so), steal their cache of 7 metal bars, and drag that stack of beautifully-crafted, custom, wooden resource tokens back into the lake to which no other player has access, rubbing your hands together and laughing maniacally, and yet still manage to lose the game spectacularly, and all while having a really great time. 

[Aside]It was such a thoughtful touch to have the game's name reflect this balance.[/Aside]

3. The mixing of unique player boards and faction boards, along with the randomly assigned secret objective cards/factory cards provide a significant degree of replayability.

Drawbacks:

1. There is just no way to teach this game quickly. I've been teaching games for years, and consider myself to be pretty good at it. I wouldn't say that this game is difficult to teach - the actual turn structure is about as straight-forward as it could possibly be. But you just can't take any shortcuts while teaching. Rodney Smith's tutorial is excellent. And I know he puts a ton of work into streamlining his instructional videos. Be he needed every bit of the nearly 33 minutes he used to teach this game.

2. I found that it was really important to ask the players to clearly announce exactly what they were doing, as they were doing it. Because the order of the top-row actions on the various player boards isn't identical, and because of the variability of the costs and benefits of the bottom-row actions, it's really difficult to know exactly what another player is doing simply by watching him place his action token. And because the various factions have unique "unlockable" abilities that dramatically affect movement, it is difficult to keep up with who can go where. Especially when everyone is first learning the game, it's important to "police" one another's turns. This is not only to make sure players don't inadvertently break a rule (Oh, did I walk across a river?), but also to make sure they don't forget to gain a deserved benefit (Oh yeah, I was supposed to get 3 coins when I deployed that mech.) Finally, because the recruitment aspect of the game allows players to benefit when specific actions are taken by the players to their immediate left and right (think: Nefarious + Between Two Cities), it's really important to know what your neighbors are doing. Unless players announce their actions out loud, other players can easily miss possible bonuses while planning their next turns. As someone who HIGHLY encourages player to plan during other players' turns, I don't want to ever see this behavior punished.

Summary:

Get the game and play it. It's fun!

Addendum:

Though I've only tried it a few times, the solo, "Automa," experience is really great. I can easily see this joining the rotation of heavier solo games that I play when I have a free afternoon/evening (when does that ever happen?), along with games like Mage Knight, Robinson Crusoe and Cruel Necessity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
Gran bel gioco destinato a mio avviso ad avere un grande successo perché strizza l'occhio a molti giochi di recente successo come per esempio [thing=120677][/thing]. I materiale dell'edizione kickstarter sono superlativi con monete in metallo, risorse tutte differenti, miniature e quanto di più si possa desiderare. Stride a mio avviso l'abbinamento tra miniature in plastica e risorse/edifici in legno, ma sono veramente dettagli (mi piacerebbe conosce le differenze con il gioco che troveremo in commercio normalmente). Il gioco base esce con 5 differenti schieramenti asimmetrici, con poteri differenti, che si sfidano per lo sviluppo e per il controllo del territorio. Il tabellone illustra già la possibilità di espandere a 7 il numero dei giocatori. Proprio il tabellone determina l'andamento della partita con un territorio troppo vasto in pochi giocatori, e tremendamente affollato in 5 giocatori, questo a beneficio di un'interazione che diverrà sempre più forte. L'obiettivo del gioco è quello di meglio svilupparsi in popolarità, forza militare, sfruttare il territorio per edificare o costruire le proprie armate. I tanti aspetti da tenere sotto controllo e da analizzare rendono a il gioco profondo e longevo. Le partite iniziano in sordina, a rilento, in attesa che i giocatori costruiscano il proprio motore che sarà alla base della propria strategia. Gioco da riprovare ma per il momento, dopo avermi lasciato col fiato sospeso per tutta la partita, mi ha lasciato un dolce sapore.

RATING: 7.5
