=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Special edition. Very nice 4X game, highly variable setup and yet simple to learn. Not quite sure how it will stand repeat plays - rated 7.5 (July'16) but that could go +/-2

Credit to Joe Wyka for articulating my reservations about this game:
"The artwork and production quality for Scythe are an absolute 10. They make you want this game to live up to the unique vision presented by Rozalski's epic paintings. You want to dominate the landscape and win the hearts of the workers! However, each time I played this month I became more and more aware of the disconnect between the incredible thematic art and the game's objectives and mechanics. This is not an epic experience game that tells the great story it promises, it is an efficiency engine game that is entirely focused on action-improvement, in which you win primarily by maximizing each category of efficiency faster than the other players. You work to get workers, buildings and mechs onto the board to do... what? Spread out? The problem is that simply getting them on the board IS the objective for most of the game. Once you get them all out, the game is pretty close to finishing.

Encounters are another vivid example of the thematic and mechanical disconnect inherent throughout the design. The artwork on the encounter cards is frankly the best part of the game. The art is so good, there is no text describing the encounter. Jamey wisely lets the art speak for itself. The cards present three moral choices: one benign, one opportunistic, and one exploitative. In a game that presents the juxtaposition of military and pastoral in such vivid illustrations, I want my moral decisions to shape my destiny - to define who I am - as a leader. Encounters present a great opportunity to accomplish this, but bafflingly work directly against the theme instead. There is no lasting effect of your moral choice. The cards then become anti-thematic and entirely mechanical. You are going to make the choice that makes immediate mechanical sense for your efficiency engine and discard it, rendering the implications of the moral decision utterly meaningless! Why set up the promise of a moral decision with no lasting moral impacts?? Why not design these cards to give an ongoing effect that reflects your decisions as a leader?

Objective cards also miss the mark. What is significant about grouping pieces in a certain way or stockpiling resources for no purpose? Building goals like building all of your buildings in a straight line only serve to remind us just how arbitrary and disconnected these goals are from the brilliant 1920's post-apocalyptic setting."

This^ is absolutely spot-on. Scythe is an excellent [i]efficiency engine[/i] game and has superb art and components. I still rate it somewhere between a 7 and 8. Thematic objective cards would be the simplest improvement.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I agonised for months before I got this game. Was it just a load of hype from Kickstarter backers that pushed this game into the top 10? Emperor's new clothes? Were the nay-sayers correct? After my first play I thought it was ok but no way did it live up to what I was hoping for. It felt like just a moderately interesting Euro (and I like Euros). I'd much rather be playing something like El Grande.

On second play with the rules now imprinted in my brain something changed. We were sucked into this game and didn't want to come out. An excellent game which I cannot wait to play again. If you like deep and thinky with slow burning tension this is for you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Scythe...how do I love thee. Let me count the ways:

Can we start with the ridiculous artwork? Absolutely gorgeous! Thankfully, there's an amazing game beneath the art as well. I like the replayability and variability inherent in the setup with the player boards. It's amazing to me what is achieved with 4 basic actions.

The encounter cards can be pretty powerful, which is a way to get a nice boon towards victory. So, even though it's a lesser element of the game play, they can be exploited to good use if players are clever in grabbing them.

And I don't know why, but the simple fact that resources stay *on the board* feels like such an ingenuity in gaming. There is a lot to appreciate in that; it keeps the players' area decluttered. And speaking of the resources, the production quality is great. And the mechs are well-made; the characters (with their spirit animals) are super cool.

I could go on and on, but instead I wrote a lengthy review about why I feel like Scythe serves as a milestone in gaming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wygrywam raz solo z autometta a potem ja 75 Autometta 45 Kasia 43:)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Apart from the hype and great artwork / setting, - and having played only two times so far - I find Scythe to actually be a rather dull worker placement game with unnecessarily (as in "not adding fun") complex mechanics. Also, with the different faction board characteristics, it feels like the game is playing you, not like you are playing the game and THAT I think is bad game design. 

Once you worked yourself through the thicket of the complexity and understand what is required to win the game, you basically have a given recipe lying in front of you (in form of your faction board) that you "simply" need to follow as closely as possible and just avoid mistakes by deviating from it. This - apart from the limited interactions with other players on the gameboard - leaves you with very little freedom for strategic or tactical choices. Any deviation from the game's/faction's plan for you just puts you at a disadvantage vs. players who just follow the plan by (ab)using their factions advantages and avoiding the disadvantages. One wrongly placed cube will lose you the game vs. a player who knows it well. In that way it is a bit like tic-tac-toe...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great solo, awesome immersion. Love the fact that combat is there but not central.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Frank
Feb. 2017
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Initial impressions of this game confirm what I feared based on reports from others who have played it: This game is firmly in the Eurogame mold, with the main emphasis being on developing an action-efficient resource engine. Although this is not a bad thing in itself (in fact, it is done rather well here), the main problem for me stems from the fact that this game has practically no player interaction. Every time I've played this game, nobody saw a convincing reason to attack anyone else because the winner actually stands to lose more in combat than the loser!

In conclusion, if you like Eurogames that emphasize action efficiency and engine building, you will probably like this game. If you like games with heavy player interaction, this game is almost certainly not for you. Since I fall into the latter category, I have sold this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
3.31 (Expansions: Invaders from Afar and Dial Promo Pack)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Un de mes jeux favori du moment.
J'ai abordé ce jeu volontairement "à l'aveuglette" : avant de commencer ma première partie, je ne me suis absolument pas documenté sur le jeu pour une découverte totale. Résultat : j'ai pris une grosse claque ludique! Le thème est sympa bien que pas vraiment transcendant. Les illustrations et style graphique sont beaux. Côté mécanique, je pensais qu'il s'agissait d'un 4X mais il s'agirait plutôt d'un 3,5X car la partie combat (eXtermination) est très "light". Et je pense que c'est à peu près tout ce qu'on pourrait lui reprocher.
Les règles sont bien pensées et relativement accessibles. Une fois que l'on a compris la synergie qu'il peut y avoir avec l'utilisation de son plateau (plateau au top avec les petits renforcements) de joueur c'est un vrai régal que d'opérer cette gymnastique. C'est tellement cohérent que jouer à Scythe provoque un sentiment de satisfaction même si on ne gagne pas la partie.
Pour s'en sortir le jeu nous oblige à développer un peu mais pas n'importe comment.
La différence entre les classes peut orienter les joueurs et ce n'est pas plus mal car cela pousse à voir d'autres optiques de jeux (être plus agressifs dans les prochaines partie ou plus populaire par exemple).
Pour ma part je n'ai pas trop utilisé les Mechas mais bon, à voir comment jouer mes adversaires, ils apportent un atout majeur au jeu de toute évidence !
Que du bonheur, ma prochaine partie me tarde déjà !

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
With about 10 games under my belt, I'm upping my rating. I still want to play all the time, still willing to teach it, still thoroughly enjoying each game.

The biggest gripe I have, and this is consistent with most engine builders, is the snowball effect: the game can ends too soon! You just put in an hour+ work into finally creating a reasonable engine and strategy, and just before you get to use it suddenly all the stars are being placed and boom! it's over. Not a huge complaint, I still love this game.

Update: have probably played ~15 times now and I would still play it whenever anyone wants to. Have yet to do the single player vs automata. Top 2 game currently (Terra Mystica being the #1)

Update:
The end-game snowball effect is unfortunately not fixed with the latest expansion, though I do love the airships. Ultimately, I think that the luster of this game is wearing a little thin for me. Still In my top 5, still would play it almost any time... but soon I might have to make house rules to fix the "bugs".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After first play: I found it better than I had expected. There was so much going on the board! A bit of exploration, a bit King-of-the-Hill, a bit of technical advancements... On the spectrum of Euro-Ameritrash hybrids, is it rather on the Euro side in my perception, somewhere between Cyclades and Clash of Cultures, maybe? In spite of all the fighting, it is not as aggressive as Kemet or even Eclipse (with which it seems to have a lot in common, especially the manipulation of the individual tableau, but not the game feeling!). It is an optimizer for sure, with strikingly elaborate mechanisms. And why is it an optimizer? What is the qualitative difference to a 4x not knotted for Victory Point optimization? Very simple: Intuitive game does not work! You can occupy an opponent's building as you wish, even right in front of his door, but instead of being rewarded for it, you may be punished for the stupidity of chasing away a peasant. WTF?! Well, you just have to accept, or, as I recently read, "Before I get upset, I rather don't care," because this stupid circumstance does not alter the fact that I have not bored myself in this game for a second. It also has strikingly little downtime. However, other than Twilight Struggle, or Fury of Dracula, this would not be a game for which I would leave everything behind.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Scythe[/b]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (6):[/COLOR]

[i]Another game I need to play again before really nailing down my opinion/rating. After one play I'm not buying into the hype, I thought the game was good but not as earth shattering as people make it sound. The theme and artwork is excellent (well minus the board itself in which all the colors seem over saturated and it ends up looking somewhat garrish). I'm not sure that I enjoyed the race element to the game, I much prefer a game that has a set number of rounds or an end game condition that you see coming. Spending time developing a strategy only to have someone rush the end of the game doesn't appeal to me, even if that person doesn't win you still don't get to see what you were working towards come to fruition. 

I'm also not sure I like how combat is handled, if you're going to have combat in a game I want to fight. I'm not nearly as interested in using the threat of force to protect my resources and only engage in a handful of battles throughout the game. In the end I thought I'd love this Scythe and was convinced I buy a copy after I played, but for now I'm content playing when I get the chance. And while I understand the superficial comparisons to Terra Mystica it doesn't hold a candle to that game. Scythe is much more straight forward and far less demanding, and in my opinion, less interesting to play.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Probably one of the most hyped games in recent memory, thanks mostly to its fantastic artwork and quality design. There's been much said about the game itself, but not from someone who doesn't have a particularly interest in 4x, all-out war games. Scythe is a thematic engine-building Euro with some direct player-to-player action in the form of combat. The focus of the game isn't total domination and extermination of your enemies; it's the harvest of resources and protection of units. Mechanics are borrowed from typical 4x games (tech trees, specialized units, a sprawling map) as well as the best VP-obsessed Euros (resource-gathering from Agricola, single-action turns from Terra Mystica and others). For myself, I was hypnotized by the beautiful artwork and thematic material from the game, but as soon as I saw the hexes on the Kickstarter page, prepared myself for disappointment; I'm just not that kind of gamer. After playing however (first with two, then with four), I've found myself wondering whether I could withstand the strain of a typical 4x game. Maybe it's not complicated or long for me. For the present, the tension of Scythe is enough to sustain and build my courage up for Twilight Imperium. Every aspect of this game is brilliant: the replay-ability (the various factions combined with the specific player mats), the quality of the components (coins, meeples, miniatures), the artwork, the overall flow of the game, even the storage was meticulously designed and executed. I'll be having Scythe as a proud part of my collection for some time. Can't wait to play again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This is one of the most balanced advanced strategy games i've ever played! =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Engaging, but rather laborious to play - so many little turns are required to gradually eke out your engine, making it more of a labour than a labour of love. The decisions along the way centre around planning a number of turns ahead and doing everything in the right order to save as many turns as possible. The more efficiently you can play, the faster you'll earn your VP conditions. So you're engaged throughout in the challenge to be as efficient as possible, which is one type of gaming reward, but there weren't many laughs along the way. Having played once, I'm not overly itching to go through it all again. I can admire it and rate it for being good at what it does for the times that I'm in the mood for that kind of thing - it's just not something that will pull me back to the table in and of itself.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm amused at what this game is not. Scythe is purely not a worker placement, not a 4X game, not a war-game, not a race to 6 stars/objectives, not an engine-builder, not an area control game, not a trading-in-the-Mediterranean game, not a resource management game. . . , YET, it has a wonderful blend of all of it!! Even the stuff I'm not fond of (i.e. area contol), I love in this game!

Yup! This game hits me just right! Once you start playing, things start clicking. The theme shines through without being annoying, mostly because of the beautiful artwork and the thoughtful alternate-historical details. Learning curve, but an engaging one I hope. Much replayability. Games can go fast once players know what's going on. Perhaps some downtime, thus AP alert, but this can help when people need the off-time to figure out their plans. Many strategic and tactical decisions. Very decent 2-player, but the game changes a bit as the board fills up more with more players.

Reminds me a little of Nexus Ops and Antike. I don't believe it's as heavy as people say. Though people are complaining that the starting conditions for each player spoon-feed you on the strategy you need to follow, I don't feel that to be a negative for me because I still need to work any strategy around what others are doing in order to win; that is, I'm still using my brain and creativity, and still having fun. 

I can't wait to try out the Automa, and the expansion(s).

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Disappointed. Played one two player game. Definitely overhyped. I was hesitant to buy another Stegmaier game based on my very negative reaction to Euphoria (again, too much chrome, not enough game) but this is slightly better than Euphoria. Components and art are great but quality control is not. Broken meeple, various scuffed and dented mats, cards with bent corners. Will give it a few more plays. Hopefully better with more players.

The best part to me were the hidden encounter cards and the art on them. I couldn't care less about plastic minis.  It's very disappointing to see the general gaming public reacting with such fervor to Ameritrash toys/gimmicks like this.  This game would sit nowhere near its current ranking if the minis were blocks of wood of varying colors. 

Decisions were too obvious, too simple, and repetitive. Make resources, buy stuff, repeat. Game drags. Too long. Speeding up play by doing your bottom row action while opponent starts their turn didn't work either. The first thing my opponent said when I tried to speed up the game this way, was "I'll wait. I want to see what you're doing."  There was only one time where I had to think twice about something and that was a rare attack situation. Otherwise, we're playing solitaire. 

I did not like how easy it was to accumulate combat cards when you got the enlist actions going, especially considering that battles are very infrequent. I had 9 cards in hand at one point. What's the point? And your opponent getting benefit when you used the enlist action was too hard to keep track of and made zero thematic sense. Could drop this part and it would make little difference. Also seemed a waste to have only max one or two objective cards available when there is a full deck of them. There should have been more access to this, and less to getting extra combat cards. 

Too easy to get around the map with tunnel access everywhere, mines, extra speed. Keeping track of your opponents movement options also a chore as each faction is different. Not much interaction, and battles are a crapshoot as you just get lucky when drawing combat cards. Could easily get a 5 or a 2. No skill involved there. 

Game even worse with 5 players. Still very little interaction. Drags on far too long. Almost everyone was begging the star leader to end the game. 

My advice for future designers: find a good painting, then kickstart a game based on it. You too can raise 1.8 million. The box art is amazing, only wish the game was half as good. 

Update: rating lowered from 5 to a 1. Not impressed with Stegmaier's attitude and customer service. Refused to replace damaged parts of the game, even after sending photos. Understandable, as the 1.8 million was already spent on jumping beans and two pieces of precious cardboard were not available. Perhaps he needs to convert 2 wood to cardboard? Then posted my private emails in the BGG forums so his pack of fanboy wolves could go to town. Never experienced anything like it. So unprofessional, the mind boggles. Needs to assign someone else to customer service and take a vacation. 

Actual Stegmaier quote while posting my private emails to a BGG forum while refusing to replace damaged items: "Obviously my customers are incredibly important to me..."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Its probably not my favorite genre, but Scythe is a solid design with some nice ideas. I dont know yet how much the starting strategy is scripted (i.e depending on your position, faction and onjective) and it starts a bit slow. TBS: You can do a lot of nice moves and turns are reasonable fast in execution. The boards topology is very thought through and I like it that military is important, but not game-defining. All in all something Id like to explore further, even if Im not head over heels just yet.

I think the feeling is comparable to the other Stonemeyergames, so if you enjoyed Vinoculture and/or Euphoria you probably enjoy this one as well and vice versa. 
This is also true to the theme: While its certainly thematic, I have the nagging feeling the cool theme could have come out just a bit more.

RATING: 4
Not sure why people are crazy for this.  I like the asymmetrical player boards (not the factions, but the actual actions).  I like the resource gathering.  I detest the combat, and that you can be penalised for it, the 'weakest' faction not having combat cards, but stealing them before combat is way too good.  My first play I had the 'military faction' and handed out 2 victories only claiming one due to miscalculating when to use my 'power'. An interesting Game of Thrones Lite game with resource gathering.  But why not play Game of Thrones, or a resource gathering game.  I would put this into the gateway game category for people who want something heavier than Catan, but don't want a 'real game' like Game of Thrones.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Art Collector Edition - Fantastic presentation

This is definitely up there with the best production values ever seen in a game. The card stock is amazing and the custom resource pieces and money are really cool. Not crazy about the mech designs though. Love all the packaging and all of the card artwork is top notch.

Played one solo game to learn the rules and am a little disappointed. The automata cards are a bit fiddly, as is movement. There is very little tension too. I do love the idea of SM's automata cards (pioneered in Viticulture) but just wish they were a little easier to follow (I believe they are supposed to be once you get used to them). Solo play was a big draw, but sometimes the playing of a solo game of this type is occluded by all the housekeeping and rules searching being thrust on one person. I know where are some lovely player aids included, but the be honest, these are more memory aids than anything else. They make the game easier to play but not to pick up.

It seems like there is a big gap between the solitaire aspect of the first rounds and the potential conflict of later rounds -not sure how that is going to resolve itself but will wait to see.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Aesthetically this is, and will always be, the best looking game that I own. I'm still fairly new to this whole world of board games but I'm a huge fan of dominion, and now I am a huge fan of scythe! I have a lot of friends who love it as well which is probably why I enjoy it so much. Without the expansions I'd give this a lower rating, but the expansions really add to the game and are what pushed it to a 10/10 for me (especially the alternate endings that Wind Gambit provides).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Wonderful looking boardgame, astonishing components and artworks. Some nice design ideas as well, but...

First half: It feels like my board plays me, not the other way around.
Second half: I don't like the fight mechanic. It leads to a lot of "Phyrrus victories", the winner of a battle usually gets taken down by the next player immediatly. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
18 plays - Solid game. Interestingly, there's a lot of polar views about this one, but I have enjoyed immensely. I have enjoyed at all player counts. The game play can become a little repetitive due to the fact that the game does push you in certain directions and you'll discover the asymmetry to be a little more of an illusion over multiple plays. I felt the same thing in Euphoria: build a better dystopia, where the different factions actually were not that mechanically different.

The focus on farming and more subtle/ indirect forms of warfare (e.g. space blocking with peasants, which will cause you to lose popularity) make this interesting and different from other area control games. 

While some of the mechanics create thematic breaks (e.g. the classic crossing of a river, only to become stuck on the other side) the game is dripping in theme in other areas. Overall, I take the 'middle road' and think there's a decent balance between incorporating more euro style mechanisms (e.g. build four buildings in a line for VPs) and theme.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
FINALIZADO
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Based on one play: Yes the production value is really nice with a nice board design and nice player tokens. The game play on the other hand is less interesting as you upgrade, move or produce items to progress and attempt to reach six of the goals to trigger then end game (and hopefully win). This is more a euro style game than a battle game and overall there are much better games of the genre, don't be overall taken by just the components.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Scythe is a decent game, but there is entirely too much hype for a game that is basically an engine building resource management  euro.    Sure, there is occasionally combat, but due to the penalty an attacker must take, combat in most instances is discouraged.  Players often can do well by just focusing on their personal "tech" board and expanding on the map just enough to get the resources they need without bothering anyone else.  There is a lot of stuff bolted on to make people think it is some sort of 4X game.  The game ends up taking too long to explain and play for what it is.  I do enjoy it, however, and would play it again.  I would never spend the money to get my own copy because there are better engine building euros for a fraction of the cost.  I would put Scythe in the top 500 perhaps, but it is a joke that it is currently sitting at number 6.  I guess including cool plastic minis translates to several hundred ranking spots.  This is easily the most overrated game on BGG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I was involved in playtesting this game in Phase 1 of testing (7 plays) and now have the final version.  This game impressed me during playtesting because there are so many paths to victory and yet the game seems quite balanced.  This balance seems to have improved even more after our playtest round.  Physically, the game is beautiful (we got the connoisseur's version but all versions are very nice) and, particularly with the expanded board, looks amazing on the table.  And the gameplay matches the visual impression.  I will need to give it a lot more gameplay to give it a final rating, but right now this is a very solid game and I expect to want to get it to the table often.

RATING: 9
Best 4X Game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Scythe has a lot of the trappings of a civilization game--you move your units around a map board in order to use those areas for production.  While the game may not have a tech tree, deploying military units will give players access to special abilities.  There are two that really make it stand apart--the action system and the scoring system.  Players can take any of four pairs of linked actions (except the one they just took); these actions are the same but linked differently for each player.  As the game progresses, players can develop their player board to make each of these actions better, either decreasing costs or increasing rewards.  As for scoring, the game forces players to do a variety of different things, and once they've done that thing as much as the game will allow, they place a scoring star on the corresponding space.  Once a player places all 6 of his stars the game is over, but actual scoring depends not only on stars, but also money, territory controlled, and a multiplier factor.  This is a very interesting game, and while it's not easy to grok the strategy right away, the game flows very nicely even for new players.

(3 plays)

RATING: 5
Extremely tentative rating. So far it's only been 1 play and it was with 2 players. I enjoyed the game, but I feel like it'll probably shine with 3+. Map felt a bit too large with 2. The move action was a lot more useful then it first appears and getting to do the bottom action was a lot more difficult than the rules let on. I really like that all the player mats are different and each faction has different abilities. Adds a lot to the variability. Not sure I feel like the encounter cards are necessary, but adds a nice touch to the game so far.

Rating may go up a point or settle at around 7. A nice game, but nothing outstanding.

Update: A second play with 4 this time and while I enjoyed it more, I'm still undecided. A lot to like, but I'm not sure how I feel about the combat. It feels like something that needs to be there, but it's also like an after thought. The game seems to benefit less from attacking and more for turtling and getting your resources and stuff upgraded as fast as you can. More plays of this game may adjust my rating, but so far it's a 6 ±1 point of rating.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
*UPDATE (2-24-17).  Moving my rating from a 6 to a 7. Had the chance to play this game one more time (5 in total) with a completely different group of people who were all very competitive.  The game mechanics that I previously experienced as rather dull and repetitive, started to feel more like an exciting race to the finish line.  Definitely increased my enjoyment of this game. 

PRO: (+9 stars) 
+ What's not to love about beautiful art, 25 different board combinations right out of the box, and resource management with Mecs? (the stage is set for a win)
+ Fantastic and original story line that draws you in.
+ Variable play styles are welcome as you can play offense or defense. In fact, you can spend the whole game without attacking if you want and still win. 
+ Player boards and all components are top notch quality. Always a welcome and appreciated thing. 
+ Expansion, extended board, and upgraded resources available for purchase.  


CON: (-2 stars) 
- First 20 minutes of game play are interesting, challenging, and rewarding. Once you get a few workers out, get the river walk and +1 movement mech out, and do an upgrade or two, the game begins to feel like task completion instead of fun game play. (Which is a real shame)
- Mostly this is a game of solitaire with very little player interaction, minus the occasional combat or "hey you upgraded, I get a coin" statements.  
- The game board is a hot mess of "everything and the kitchen  sink." Visually, it feels overdone and the color pallet is less than ideal to stare at for 1.5 hours. Dull yellow, pea green, and bright red. (subjective opinion of course)

*IS SCYTHE FOR YOU? 
Well, IF you are a very competitive person, and are more focused on the outcome than the process, then you'll likely love this game and it's gameplay. IF however you play games for the challenge or player interaction more than winning, then you'll likely feel this game, like chewing gum, quickly loses its flavor.

Overall, the fun of this game is dependent on the group you are playing with. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Excellent
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After 20+ plays: I love this game at every player count I've played. (2, 3, 4, 5). 

At 2-player on a pre-determined map, yes, you can avoid each other and more or less freely roam, but I still feel the tension of having to produce stars and hex control as fast as possible, as I watch my opponent's each move and guess their trajectory, wondering how many turns I have left to get it done. 

Then at higher player counts- oof! wow. A different game. Territory is precious, and getting around can quickly get tricky. With experienced players, turns can whip around super fast.

The whole, "it's not so much about combat, as it is about the threat of combat" is so true and so great. Just the threat has totally messed with my plans; it's a mind game! The more I play, the more I appreciate this.

Replayability continues to be amazing, largely thanks to being able to play different combos of player mat and faction, plus the variability in what you're playing against (factions, mats, amount of players)- and so many different paths to victory. Every game, to have a shot at winning, I have to take a fresh look at what my best approach might be. Cherry on top is the achievements that push you to try to win under certain restrictions/conditions; with as much experience as we have now, we've won under some surprising conditions! (Including my wife, winning with less than 6 popularity!!)

Scythe also meets my criteria for having gender parity in the roles, then gets bonus points for having more women than men!

More bonus points for Jamey Stegmaier creating community around his game, and being super involved. You can ask a question in one of his Facebook groups, and have it answered in minutes, often by Jamey himself.

And finally, the quality components and original artwork elevate everything.

RATING: 7
This is a miniature 4X game, basically reducing exploration to event cards, giving only singular uses to resources, deliberately giving penalties to battling over certain areas, and offering zero player elimination.  The strategy revolves around constructing an engine, managing your Popularity, and making the most of your actions.

Is this a great game?  Not for the price point.  You can pick up March of the Ants for half the price and about the same amount of play time per session, you can pick up Eclipse for a little bit more for longer play times and a more authentic 4X experience.  Buy something else.

RATING: 8.72

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Overall, I was quite disappointed with this game. I Kickstarted it and bought into the hype only to find a game that corrals you down an ideal path. The big board and player mats give the illusion of options, but choices are surprisingly narrow. I wanted to like it so much, but after 4 plays gave up hope. It's an okay game, but I own 100s of great games, so it was never going to get played enough.

It borrows from several games that I enjoy (including Kemet, Eclipse, and Terra Mystica), but pales in comparison to all three. The combat feels flat, the resource management is simplistic, and the asymmetric powers are too similar to be really interesting. 

In the end, I turned it into a handsome profit, so I don't regret the purchase, but I definitely learned a lesson about 'style over substance'. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
- Lot's of rules, especially when playing for the first time, it almost took me 1 hour to explain (now I've played it myself, it will probably go faster)
- They point it out in the rules, but it is indeed easy to forgot to take the coins when you take the bottom action. As this can decide over winning or not, they should figure out something for that.
+ Game mechanisms interlock very well together
+ Wars are only a minor aspect of this game (something I hoped for as being a Eurogamer :-), but you feel indeed the constant threat of being attacked. reminds me in that way a bit of Eclipse, were the war-aspect is for sure bigger
+ There are different paths to victory: putting away your stars and pushing your popularity is clearly one of them, but don't underestimate the looting of cash during the game!

RATING: 9.3
Scythe undoubtedly deserves the tremendous amount of praise that it's been getting amongst gamers. It is a beautiful, shiny, well-oiled machine that is easy to pick up, but offers an immense amount of depth and replayability. Though it looks like a war game, it is much more of a euro filled with homages to different gaming genres, including war games, area control games, worker placement euro-y goodness, and more. It is, without a doubt, a work of Gaming Art.

RATING: 8
- Nice: Shortness for a strategy game
- Less nice: Feel like player boards / starting places are unequal.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Tentative rating, based on several plays of a near-final prototype.

Gameplay in Scythe consists of two main parts: engine building and combat. Engine building works fine. There are a few elements, such as objectives, that encourage you to try out different approaches. Unfortunately, these are often a bit too weak to lure you away from the otherwise optimal path.

The combat system is where Scythe doesn't work well for my group. Combats are fought out using a blind-bidding mechanism. It seems that the idea is that there are many small combats. However, there are serious rewards to be gained from combat, and in my plays, most players were not going to risk those rewards. As a result, there were mostly large combats, in which the attacker was reasonably sure of the win. So, there were few battles.

The artwork, which was one of the things that attracted me to the game, seems tacked on in some places. The Encounter cards seem as if they would have been better if there was a story explaining the situation instead of an image that has to convey the situation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.5
I want to like Scythe because it's a great production, but I find it boring and repetitive. The latter complaint seems wrong to me since most games I feel, are repetitive by nature, but Scythe lacks a bit of dynamic tension or tactical situations that break the dullness of doing the same actions over and over again. Combat situations are few and far between and when they do happen, they're largely anticlimactic. As awesome as the artwork and theme is, it doesn't really shine through the gameplay. Sure the actions all make thematic sense (maybe except the enlist action); they just don't amount to anything exciting or interesting for me. I should give it more plays, but at this point, there's just too many other games I rather play.

RATING: 5
Well, I got to play the current hotness and, overall, enjoyed the experience. We played with five players (probably too many), including one who went on the warpath early which strongly affected two others. In contrast, I was fortunate to eke out a solitaire game in my own corner of the map. The player boards are initially confusing (even with a good teach) and it is only through putting theory into practice that you really get the gist: the fact that each has their actions in different places caused some confusion around the table.
Learning what I *should* be doing took me most of the game, so further plays could allow for some actual strategising. I had the mech-building board and the dominating faction, but neither suited my play-style, so I ignored their powers for the most part. In the end, I was one of the two 'peaceful' nations (one attack each, all game) and won a very close tie-break. A cut above.

RATING: N/A
P: 1-5, T: 90-120 min
Work of Art; super high production value, artwork, minis, components (especially with collector's edition). Asymmetrical player mats (a.la Terra Mystica, which draws a fair comparison on paper) Engine building, area control. Low luck elements, player decisions have high impact.
-Heavy Euro game, plays longer than advertised. A 4X game that doesn't do all of it all that well; not a fan of the random/bidding combat (nor tactics rewarding piling on the weakest player). Theme is fairly weak apart from the artwork. Despite the individual player powers a criticism suggests a railroaded race of efficiency with replayability concerns. Price/availability concerns?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Art collector´s edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is an objectives based efficency game that uses a central board, so that players can attack each other. Actions are quick and simple, with each player placing their pawn on one of 4 action spots, and then resolving one or both of the actions that match that spot. The rule is you must take a different action each turn, which is where a big part of the puzzle comes in.

Every player gets a faction board and an asymmetrical action board at the start of the game. The synergy between these two boards, will determine your capacity for success in the game to a large degree, which is troublesome.

There are a few euro/ameritrash hybrid games, and I want to say the thing that makes this game special (aside from the beautiful components) is that when you produce resources, they sit on the hex until you use them, which means in theory someone could invade you and take them.

I do need to mention that where someone can move to is very hard to keep track of. Each player has a series of unique abilities they can unlock, not to mention that each player has different rules for how they can walk across rivers, not to mention the middle area of the board has a lot of teleportation spots, not to mention that players can build their own personal teleportation spot anywhere, not to mention one faction gets to use a type of terrain as if they had built their personal teleport.

This game took a few plays to grow on me. Once I had really internalized the factions and the mechanisms and the scoring process, I started to see the depth this game provides.

:star: Art, Iconography and components functional
:star: Clever or interesting mechanisms
:star: Reasonably low downtime between turns with mildly AP players
:star: Multiple plays stay interesting
:star: Low or mitigatable luck elements
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Raw enjoyment
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Tabletop Simulator Edition!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dieses Spiel hat Schwächen. Oft hat man das Gefühl, dass die Auswahl des Spielertableaus die Taktik vorgibt und man in vielen Momenten nur den vom Spiel vorgegebenen Roten Faden weiter spielt und kaum Auswahl hat. Außerdem ist mir persönlich der sechste Stern zu viel- das Ende des Spiels könnte deutlich glatter und eleganter sein (die Erweiterung, die dieses Problem behandelt kommt noch dieses Jahr).
Allerdings hat dieses Spiel auch Stärken, die deutlich überwiegen: die Völker haben unterschiedliche Fähigkeiten und Stärken, die meiner Meinung nach vollkommen ausgeglichen sind! Ich habe noch kein Spiel erlebt, in dem ein Spieler auf Grund seines übermächtigen Volkes gewonnen hat. Da dieses Spiel nur minimal vom Zufall lebt, hängt wirklich viel von der Taktik und der Erfahrung der Spieler ab und man erkennt eine stetige Lernkurve. Der Wettlauf um die Siegpunkte ist eine tolle Idee, da jeder Spieler unterschiedliche Wege geht und selbst beim Erreichen des sechsten Sterns den Sieg noch nicht in der Tasche hat. Mindestens genauso gut gefällt mir das Rennen zur Fabrik und die Verteidigung dieser. Spielerisch also wirklich ein tolles Ding. Was dieses Spiel aber wirklich einzigartig macht, ist der ganze "Firlefanz" drumherum: die Miniaturen sehen fantastisch aus- jeder Charakter hat seine eigene Hintergrundgeschichte (dadurch entsteht fast Rollenspiel-Atmosphäre). Das Artwork ist genauso grandios designed, wie das Spielbrett, dass viele kleinen Details zeigt, die man erst auf den zweiten Blick entdeckt. Teilweise beinhält das Spiel sogar Kleinigkeiten, von denen man vorher gar nicht weiß, dass man sie braucht (unterschiedliche Arbeiter-Formen, eingestanzte Tableaus), die das Spiel aber ausmachen. Mein absolutes Highlight: die Begegnunskarten, die in unseren Spielrunden schon oft für Lacher gesorgt haben.
Dieses Spiel ist mein absolutes Lieblingsspiel und ich kann mir nicht vorstellen, dass ich in naher Zukunft meine Begeisterung dafür verliere.

RATING: 8
A nice and gorgeous game (I have the kickstarter version with the 'natural' resources).
I still haven't tried the Automata solo versions. So far I have been soloing two, three and five player games. 
It's a nice resource conversion game with some elements of area control. It plays quite smoothly and there is a good deal of variation due to the different player boards and faction boards, encounter cards, factory cards, etc.
I don't think it necessarily lives up to the hype (since it got quite a significant level of hype), but it is a well crafted game and I am very happy to own it.
The extended board is much to large for me to try to use it, though at times certain hexes can get overcrowded with resources etc. The normal board barely fits to my playing table.
----
So far not overly enthused with the automata - it has a very in your face play-style. Will give it a few more chances, but so far I prefer to solo three-player games.

RATING: 9
Scythe is by far the best new game that I've played over the past year. The rules are rather long and the way the game is played is pretty different from most other strategy games. Once you get a hang of the rules and the flow of the game it becomes much easier and actually allows for quicker play. (Part of the way the game is played allows two players to do different parts of their moves simultaneously). 

Scythe also allows for more variety than most games offer. There are multiple different combinations of factions and different play board combinations. There are also multiple different objective cards, building conditions and random events that can happen each game. There are many different ways to win and to be successful. I'm discovering new ways to play every game. 

Overall, while complex and long (both aspects I actually enjoy), Scythe is definitely worth the time and has near endless replay value.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game is certainly well done. The resources, figures look awesome. A lot of nice flavor as you go the game as well. It seems to be a civilization style game, that is spread across the board so you can develop production. Territory is one of your objectives, nice element that you want to consolidate for production, but then spread out for final scoring.
Each turn you swap among 4 possible actions optionally can add one more, each location has 2 possible action you can perform. It is nice touch forcing you to go to another action. 
Clearing the player board reminds me somewhat of Hansa Tuetonica, where you can unlock additional abilities. However, completing an area seems to have more of an impact since is contributes to your game end and endgame scoring.
If you get locked out of other things you can go for resources or money since that is scoring option as well.
The popularity track is the multiplier for the end game scoring. If you neglect it it will be costly.
While mostly resource acquisition development game there is combat, to grab key locations and as part of one of your scoring, but the game is not dominated by warfare.

I like how each player has a slightly differing abilities, part of the game is learning how to use your faction effectively. All in all on I would enjoy playing again - now that I have better feel for it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played at: Asda & mine

RATING: 9.6
[ESP] Se describe como 4X, una vez jugándolo se puede ver que no es así, sobre todo por la parte de eXterminar.

De la parte de ser un 4X realmente las que más destacan son las de eXpandirse y eXplotar ya que el control de territorios da puntos al final de la partida, así como la producción de recursos depende de los territorios en que tengamos trabajadores.  Hay un poco de eXploración en la parte de los encuentros y no más. En lo que respecta a la eXterminación realmente es mas una guerra fría en la que eventualmente habrá combates pero en general el mismo juego no te incitará a hacerlo a menudo.
 
Una parte muy importante y en la que para mi reside el juego es realmente la combinación de tableros que le toca a cada jugador y el ir seleccionando de la forma más eficiente las acciones que se van ejecutando. 

Para mí es un muy buen Euro con el tema muy bien integrado, con selección de acciones,colocación de trabajadores y administración de recursos en el que hay que controlar territorios para obtener puntos de victoria al final, todo esto mientras todos están en una carrera por poner la sexta estrella. Para mi con todo el hype que tenía cumplió con las expectativas.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Scythe is an excellent game as long as you have the right expectations going in. Players who have never heard of it will almost ALWAYS enjoy the game immensely. I think that says a lot. 

- It's not a heavy or mid-heavy game. Don't expect that. Don't expect that level of strategy either. It looks MUCH more complicated than it is. It shouldn't have a 3.3 weight rating. I'd say 2.8-3.0 is about right. 
- Don't expect full on combat all the time. My problem when I played it is that I expected so little combat based on the reviews that I didn't invest in defending myself at all. I got rolled over. So combat definitely plays a real part, but its not primarily a combat game. 
- DO expect the game to end quickly. The game length is actually pretty short/quick. The game could end abruptly if you don't know how quickly people can earn stars are the end of the game. 

The biggest thing about Scythe is that people are comparing it to heavier strategy games and expecting that level of strategy and replayability or comparing it to other area control games and expecting that level of combat and interaction. It's neither of those things. 

Seriously the closest game I'd compare it to in terms of feel is Settlers of Catan. Obviously its nothing like Catan in terms of mechanics, but in terms of the "feel" it is similar. It is more complex than Catan, but not the level of heavy euros. The level of combat and interaction is similar to Catan without the trading. The economic/resource element is similar.

UPDATE 10/9/17: After playing it 3 times in a row yesterday and wanting to play Food Chain Magnate instead, this game has dropped a little bit for me. Had to downgrade it to an 8. There aren't any big moments in the game. I have to admit that it is a bit "plodding" like SUSD said it was. Kinda sad. Downgraded it to an 8. Still enjoyed my plays and friends still like the game. I still think it has a LOT of depth. I still haven't gotten even close to figuring the game out after 12 plays. But getting better in the game doesn't come through big realizations. It comes from playing slightly better or making a slightly better move. There aren't new concepts to learn, its just that you need to think further ahead and plan a bit better with the concepts that you already have. That's still worth something. And the fact that the game still plays really well with a lot of different types of gamers and can be finished in 1.5 hours for a 4 player game is pretty good.

UPDATE 10/19/17: After playing this a few more times. Getting beaten barely by a friend 52 to 40 in a 3 player game where he rushed 6 stars and playing Albion and Togawa a few times, the game has started to tick back up for me. There were BIG moments in these games whereas in my last updated I said that there wasn't big moments and that it was "plodding". The fact that some of my friends have finally started catching up to me in skill has made the game more tense and therefore a lot more fun for me. There ARE moments where I'm thinking further ahead than my opponent (or attempting to), reading my opponent etc. There have been concepts that I've been learning, such as popularity and territory control for the expansion factions when you cannot close the game out with the normal 2 stars from combat. I argued in my previous update that there weren't new concepts to learn, I guess I was wrong. Interesting how a game can shift. Upgraded the rating from 8 to 8.5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Due: Aug 2016
Oct 2015: Oh how it is terrible to love games. SM's kickstarter opened with a bang - and lots of people who didn't read the 'new SG game rules'. SM was going to do a different stretch-goal process so I didn't join the $500k day-one backers. I wanted to 'earn' a goal... public outcry changed the process 'back to the normal' SG-process. I'll probably try to be the $1M backer... possibly on day 9-10.

November 2015:  I got to play the demo copy JR Honeycutt had in Dallas.  I'm not a 4X gamer and I was struggling to understand 'the engine'. I was very inefficient and paid for it. Others were done with our play but I immediately wanted another play to re-engage with another route...

July 2016: I got mine but I've only played other's. Barely in and loving it. It might slide later but I always want to play now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I don't like Euros much at all. I gave this one a chance, and there were definitely moments of fun, but it's the same old point salad race to the finish line with no soul. The art is gorgeous, and everything else is pretty mediocre. I understand why people like it, but I think there are so many better games out there to play. In the end, all the players do the same things in a different order, and the one who did it better...wins! There is no story arc, no intrigue, no moments of triumph. I moved cubes from the top row to the bottom row better than you did. Or maybe I didn't. Honestly, the only reason I gave this a '6' instead of '5' was because I ended up playing a seven player game, and I love that large group feel of being in something together. Sadly, the thing we were in together was a Euro. : (

RATING: 8
Ethan's game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pros:
1. Efficiency. First and foremost, this is a game about efficiency. You plan multiple turns ahead being sure you can maximize each and every turn.
2. Variability. There are 5 different factions with a different ability and 5 different player boards each with a different set up. Every combo will play completely different.
3. Epic. This is an epic euro game. The theme is well integrated (especially for a euro). It's a huge sprawling board with amazing artwork on the cards and the board.
4. Multiple routes to victory. A player can focus on territories, battling, production. Everything you do is improving your board.
5. Solo. The solo play in this game is amazing. It's a little difficult to learn, but once learned it is excellent.

Cons:
1. Long teach. This game will take upwards of 15 minutes to teach. There will still be many many question while playing.

Summary: This is an incredible game. The artwork is great, the minis are great, the game play is great. After every play, you will be looking back to try and figure out where you went wrong, where was your efficiency reduced. You'll want to play again and often and experiment with all of the different combos you can play with.

RATING: 9
Man, my first game of this I didn't really like it and I was terrible at it. But I still thought about it and bought it anyways, because I saw the potential. Well, I played it again, and not only did it all click this time, and I did quite well, but I had a blast. This one easily jumped into my top 10-15 games. I love it and can't wait to play it again. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Unfortunately in my case the hype turned into disappointment. I was lured to the game by reviews and opinions saying that it's almost like a "Terra Mystica" with conflict. Well, it's not. It's a rather simple eurogame bloated with unnecessary chrome and components. The development part of the game is simple, really - turn four types of resources into four types of benefits (to build mechs, buildings, to develop "technology" and gain other advantages). No excitement here, no intricate strategies, just plain simple pay X to get a minor thing. Do some minor things for several rounds and hopefully someone will win. 

And then there's the conflict. Boring, too. Predictable and stale. Again, zero excitement even WHEN it happens, and it doesn't happen a whole lot (someone who doesn't fight even once may easily steal the win).

I don't know, it's just too... plain. Nothing new or interesting here, a game that's very, and I mean VERY basic at its core. It may be fun for people who don't enjoy heavy eurogames and want something more accessible that looks epic (because it's a good looking game, you can't argue that). If you expect meaty gameplay - avoid. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is phenomenal.  The art and theme are out of this world and make it a joy to play. The gameplay itself was was very well thought out, fantastic attention to detail. It's a lot of managing and building your engine, with a military aspect that is secondary and is more of an insurance policy. Learning this game took one play through, but the best part is that teaching it is a breeze and new comers will get it quick. This is a must for any collection.

RATING: 10
A time for extracting oil, reaping harvests, digging for steel, and amassing massive amounts of lumber; all the while repelling rivaling nations as you explore the mysterious factory. What a time to be a tyrant. Heavy euro area-control game. The best thing about this game is you can play it symmetric and asymmetric. If you'd rather sit back and play resource management and engine building, you certainly can. If you want to play more in your face against your opponents, you are allowed to do that. Its build-up to its release is very well-deserved.

RATING: 9
Scythe is a monumental game that plays fast. The artwork ist outstanding as is the quality of the game in general. I am happy to be an owner of it. My goal is to upgrade the material to have the maximum scythe because this game deserves it. 
Every game feels different due to great variety. If you do not want to fight, you don't have to. I like that. 
Why not 10? Hmm I play a lot solo games. Unfortunately the Automa solo Scythe variant did not impress be at all. It plays cold without any atmosphere and even matematically. That's not how I want to feel games. :-)

RATING: 8
For a game with such massive mechs stomping around, this is a surprisingly peaceful euro. Of course, there is room to blow stuff up if that is your goal, but I like that I have a shot at winning even if I'm just doing my own thing in my cozy corner of the map. Occasionally, it's fun to rush the center and grab some powerful upgrades or sneak into another players quadrant to snatch some tokens, but the I have the most fun just managing my resources and optimizing my action board. Can't wait to see what an expansion adds.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.546
Great Game.

You control one of 5 factions.   You try to build the best society by achieving different objectives (building, combat, other things).

Each turn you select one of 5 spaces on your board (the 5th is only available after you've traveled to the center of the board).  Each space has 2 possible actions you can take.  Won't be able to take them all, as you won't have the resources to do it.

So you control territory, manage production, build mechs, have encounters, manage you military power, manage your popularity, etc....

I've painted the miniatures.
All 5 Characters:
https://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/3897746/scythe
https://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/3901336/scythe
https://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/3901335/scythe

RATING: 8
Amazing production! This game just pops. Awesome mini's, a massive detailed board and player boards carved to fit each component.

Extensive set of rules to remember but all are fairly simple. The complexity seems to come from how one action impacts other secondary actions for you or even your opponent.

The multiple paths to victory seem well balanced. Enjoyed the first play and need to try out some different strategies.

RATING: 7

I figured I was in for a game that had more of a cold-war feel to it. And it kind of does, but it's not that dynamic. It' kind of a slow-moving game that's absolutely beautiful. It's easy enough to learn and play, but it can be a little bit of a slog. I have to play more to really get a good picture of it.

RATING: 10
When I first played this game it was different that what I expected.  For weeks after I couldn't stop thinking about it.  I ended up getting this as a gift and it quickly rose to my favorite game.

I've only played it with one person who didn't like it immediately - but everyone always comes around.  The mechanics are so smooth.  The way you gain efficiency over time makes this game ease into a strategic delight as you approach end-game.

RATING: 8
PROS:
-Great components, especially in the Collector's edition
-Great company & designer
-Fantatic production value
-Feels like a Euro sampler (little tidbits of everything)
-Elegant gameplay

CONS:
-Terrible solo rulebook (reads like a verbose draft)
-Game ends just when it gets interesting (not in the good way)

OVERALL: 
Great game to bring out when an engine-building game is desired! Plenty of replayability and at least there are mechs to play with no matter how well the game is going. The table presence brings a lot of attention, if requiring a lot of setup for the amount of play time.

RATING: 6
No desire to play this anymore. There are better resource management/production/building games out there (take Terra Mystica or Concordia for example, and as area control/combat game Scythe is just subpar experience. Mechanically sound but a bit repeative and soulless exercise, and theme really could be anything. A smash of different mechanics into one game. 

Going to zero popularity early on is the way to go since then you can just attack without any penalty, especially with some of the more aggressive factions. You can potentially destroy somebody game if they are not careful. It can be extra brutal with low player count.

Notes i keep forgetting!
-A structure can be built- on the factory
-Anyone can carry resources, only mechs can carry workers

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My Kickstarter copy finally arrived this week - and last night I managed to get a 2p game in against my wife. I didn't expect it to be especially great with 2p, it was mainly just a learning game. Predictably, she wiped the floor with me (she always does in most games, especially new ones - she won this 95 to 58, although I'm sure I forgot to take coins from my bottom row actions quite a few times). But I liked the game and could see plenty of potential. Most classic Euros lack a meaningful map on which players can interact in a direct way - one of the many reasons why Terra Mystica is my favourite game is that, along with everything else, it has a map on which players struggle and compete, and which determines most of the end-game bonuses. Although very different from TM in most other respects, Scythe has this to.

I also love the variability of the game, especially the 25 different faction/player mat combinations. Not to mention all the different Encounter cards, Factory cards and Objective cards. I hope this one goes down well with my main gaming groups (I expect that it will), because it's a game I'd really love to explore some more. I'm rating it 8 for now, but I can easily see this going up.

About the only small criticism I can think of is that downtime could become an issue in 4 or 5-player games. Unless someone attacks you you aren't involved in other players' turns - yes you can get recruit bonuses but this, while important to the game, doesn't involve you in any decisions.

RATING: 10
One of the best strategic game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
No Sçythe, somos povos de um leste europeu fictício que querem desenvolver seus países, desenvolvimento esse medido através de pontos de vitória. Conseguimos esses pontos de vitória dominando territórios, alcançando objetivos e gerando recursos.

Apesar de ter uma temática que lembra jogos de batalha, este é um jogo bem euro, no qual a porrada é controlada e pouco debilitante. Me lembrou demais o Terra Mystica, no qual segundo li ele foi assumidamente inspirado, por isso vou fazer a review comparando com ele:

- Povos / raças com habilidades especiais: assim como no TM, no Sçythe você ganha um povo que tem habilidades específicas, que orienta sua forma de jogar. Mas o Sçythe expande em cima disso, pois seu tabuleiro pessoal consiste na junção do tabuleiro da sua raça, com suas habilidades especiais + um tabuleiro de ações, que pode vir com diversas combinações.

- Mapa não-modular: Assim como no TM, o mapa é fixo, mas ao contrário dele, cada raça sai sempre da mesma base, o que deixa o início do jogo um pouco mais previsível.

- Formas de pontuação e condições de jogo modulares: Assim como no TM, no início e ao longo do jogo sorteiam-se diversos bônus, que dão incentivos do que você deve fazer no seu jogo.

- Tabuleiro pessoal à la TM / Eclipse: mesma mecânica de tudo que você tira do seu tabuleiro pra botar em jogo (ou em outro lugar do tabuleiro) passa a te dar algo que aquilo que você tirou escondia quando estava no seu tabuleiro.

- Turnos rápidos: assim como no TM, vc faz uma ação e acabou. Com a vantagem de que você tem ainda menos opções do que fazer: são 4 ações (5 se vc fizer uma fábrica), que começam ruins mas conforme você vai se desenvolvendo, vão ficando cada vez melhores.

- Sensação gostosa de desenvolvimento: que acontece no TM tb: quanto mais pra frente você está no jogo, melhor vai ficando sua nação e melhores são as 4 ações que vc tem disponíveis.

- Jogo lindo: nisso ele dá de dez no TM (que já é bonito) e em praticamente qualquer outro jogo: Sçythe é lindo, tabuleirão central gigante, ilustrações fodas, recursos são um absurdo - parece miniatura de maquete, e as pecinhas de madeira são estilo Viticulture.

- Mecanicamente, o que vi de mais inovador no jogo foi a ideia de que ao produzir um recurso, ele fica no tabuleiro central, no tile onde foi produzido, e só é seu se tiver alguém seu no terreno - e se outra pessoa ocupar - ou te tirar - do terreno, ela que vai poder usá-lo.

- Fora isso, ele na verdade é um apanhadão de mecânicas gostosas de outros jogos, particularmente do TM, manicuradas ao extremo pra funcionar muito bem. É super intuitivo, tudo funciona lindamente, mas sinto falta de alguma coisa mais diferente pra ser realmente top de linha.

- Uma coisa que poderia compensar a falta de inovação seria mais interatividade entre os jogadores. No nosso jogo, só aconteceram combates no final, e todos eles com o único objetivo de cumprir objetivo e ganhar ponto. Senti falta de eles serem mais decisivos para o jogo em si, de a ocupação de espaço ser mais apertada e forçar as pessoas a se esbarrarem. O fato dos combates não serem debilitantes é ótimo, perder não é um problema, mas eles poderiam ser mais importantes para o jogo. Fora ele, existe interação nos enlists, que permitem que vc ganhe coisas com as ações dos outros, mas em geral e só um "ops! vc fez tal coisa, ganhei tal coisa", e não algo que vc leva em conta para o seu planejamento. Tem interação também na disputa de quem chega primeiro nas cartas de encontro, mas é só uma corridinha bem suave. De forma geral, é meio multiplayer solitaire sim. A interação e o aperto estão bem mais presentes no TM, que pra mim é um jogo melhor.

- Numa nova partida, eu tentaria focar menos em objetivos e mais em ganhar ponto ocupando território pra ver se com isso o jogo fica mais interativo. Mas se não ajudar tanto, eu diria que é um jogo nota 8: muito bom, sólido, mas passado o hype não vai ser referência como é o TM - que pra mim é 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2da mano
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.3
(+) Beautiful components

(+) An admirably short game time for the epic scope and many mechanisms involved in this game

(+) Combination of fun mechanics: area control, engine building, resource management, ...

(+) Set up is pretty random

(-) The game itself is not very innovative

(-) The random set-up combined with the different player powers can result in unbalanced gameplay situations

(-) I think the short game time for such a title is a major advantage, and probably the only reason why I would consider adding this game to my collection, but on the other hand I'm not sure whether I want my games with an epic scope to play so 'quickly'.

(-) The combination of the different mechanics is fun, but because the game combines so many of them in the short game time, none of these mechanics has gotten implemented 'to the fullest'. The engine building is great fun, but only offers very limited choices, the area control is nice - but implemented on a very basic scale, ...

Game length: about 2 hours for a 4-player game.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A game that is a Jack of all trades, but a master of none.

As a solitaire, turn based engine building game, it is actually quite nice. Once you figure out the strategy of your faction and player board, the choices of how to progress become a bit formulaic, but the journey of finding how to optimize your moves is fairly enjoyable. It is faster and more satisfying in other engine building games, but is certainly not bad in Scythe.

In my opinion, there are three knocks against Scythe which takes it from an 8 or 9 to a 6.

1. Some factions and player boards are flat out better or more fun to play as than others. Some player boards don't mesh well with certain factions at all, making the game less enjoyable than it could be. It doesn't create an interesting and compelling challenge, it just makes you wish you had another player board to make building your engine more efficient and fun.

2. The combat in this game is neither compelling or satisfying. With so much of the game evolving around creating the most efficient economy, the combat feels rather out of place. Combat is almost never a satisfying, hard fought victory with stakes, rather a mild inconvenience for the person being attacked, which brings no joy to either party. The fact that one faction is so heavily incentivized to attack just feels out of place, and can turn the game into an unenjoyable slog.

3. Playing with players new to the game, or people prone to Analysis Paralysis, can grind the game to a halt worse than most other games. You can have your next 4 moves to build a mech or a structure, and then have to wait a tedious 20+ minutes for play to go around the table four times, which takes away your satisfaction of the process of achieving your goal.

To sum it all up, Scythe is a game with lots of variety, and touches upon many, many genres and tropes of board games, which is quite an accomplishment. However, for everything that Scythe does, there is another game out there that does it quite a bit better, and just leaves me wanting more from Scythe.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Scythe is a pretty straight forward game that initially looks very confusing. I enjoy the tactical aspects of it - you only have four different actions to choose between but they can result in so many different things. You'll have to relate those tactics to a strategic masterplan if you want to have any chance at winning, but the game has a strong tactical element of adjusting on the fly and making the best of the current board situation.

It's also a beautiful game. Purdyness definitely elevates a gaming experience for me.

The included automa system is pretty darn good too. (That danish guy is no joke!) I generally play this with two human players, and I've had as many as three automas thrown in the mix at the same time. Big thanks for including reference cards for all the automa actions.

The rule book does a great job too! Scythe and aviticulture have among the best rule books I've read.


I wish I was better at painting minis, because I would like to paint the mechs and characters. My SO is a natural at painting, but she's working through our massive Arcadia Quest collection. (I think she's finished 4-5 pets so far, so it'll be a while...)

I have a very hard time understanding the criticism aimed at Scythe. Really, I don't get it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Only one play.

Jamey clearly understands just how important pacing is in game design.  I'm also impressed with how the combat feels so intense, yet the players are not losing units.  Direct conflict in a multiplayer (3 or greater) game is a holy grail for many game designers.   It has probably near to the maximum level of direct conflict you are able to put in a game where players are building infrastructure, where the players do not feel bullied or extremely frustrated.  

Kemet might be overall a game that I prefer in this realm, but the losing players will not have a great experience.  Last game of Kemet I played someone at the table said "I f#@ing hate this game" after losing his second battle and the game.  This is likely not something you will hear in a game of Scythe.

There are some UI quirks like the spaces where your purchasable mechs are contain text.  I found myself (and everyone else at the table) placing their mech minis above or around each of these spaces.  I also think the player boards could have been done with no text at all, instead having more clear iconography on how they work, as having both text and icons in each area actually makes things more complex to understand for new players.

I would really like to play this again, and kinda regret not backing it on KS.

Jamey Stegmaier is the real deal and sets the bar for modern game publication.  He's talented with customer service, logistics, marketing, and community building.  But most importantly, he's a very good game designer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is in a word - fascinating. Everything about it fascinates me - the art, the mechanisms, the components. Even the retail version of the game boasts excellent components.

If you think about it, this games doesn't really offer anything innovative or new. Take one of its mechanisms and you can probably find a game that did it before (though I have yet to find an equivalent of the upgrading mechanism it uses). However, the way it seamlessly integrates these mechanisms in such a way that its theme shines through it is simply awesome.

This game encourages planning ahead and its nature differs for every player count and their behavior. While the threat of combat is emphasized rather than combat itself, combat can still be done by the more aggressive players, though they have to plan it accordingly and not just mindlessly throw their units around. I won't classify it as a war game though.

All in all, I enjoyed every aspect of the game and can't wait to play more of it. There's just something satisfying about going from one action a turn to suddenly doing a lot more as you make every action more efficient.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A GREAT game, one of the crowning jewels of my collection. Scythe is so, so easy on the eyes (this artist has really set himself and this game far ahead of the competition), and remarkably easy to teach. A couple flaws weigh this game down for me, though:

1. The faction abilities, while unique and intriguing, don't scale as well as the game does. I've found that Saxony becomes much more powerful at higher player counts, while Polania and Nordic (the latter already being clearly weaker than its counterparts) become more powerful at lower player counts. I like that the different player mats can alleviate this, but sometimes it backfires and propels an already dominant faction miles above the rest (e.g. Rusviet + Industrial). This could be dealt with by giving newer players more powerful factions, sometimes to no avail, however.

2. The game-ending star placement is frustrating, mostly for new players. I understand that the Wind Gambit expansion deals with this, and house rules are always an option, but I think Scythe's base should be equipped with a "one more turn for each player" mechanic, or something akin to the pretender token in Inis.

3. Two factions on the board not included in base game. Every time I introduce Scythe to someone new, I get asked "where are the other factions?" I have to tell them that they're not included, and that they're in one of the expansions. Trust me, NO ONE wants to play 7-player Scythe, but it does feel cheap and unwarranted to withhold essential bits of the game from the customers of the base game.

Despite these points, this is a fantastic game that I will be bringing to the table many times in the future. The subtle mechanics really make this a game that people want to eventually MASTER, rather than just improve!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Almost 'sandbox' feel, so many options and ways to play as well as to win the game. Scythe world and theme defined by art of Jacub Rozalsky is present. This is not area control game nor war game per se, environment interacts with players, players influence other players just by their presence and threat of confrontation. Combat resolution is very clever and fits the style of the game.

Automa is great bonus. Top production and components another bonus (Collectors Edition). And another...attention to detail (accross all parts and features) is spectacular and really enhances the experience.

Great solo, with human opponents even better.

One (dual) action system mitigates downtime and makes this game enjoyable even with 4/5 players. 2 to 3 hours playtime is more than acceptable considering the deepness of the game and many possible long term strategies to follow.

Great game !
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
i followed a favorite artist and bumped into Scythe on kickstarter. this game is often described as "over hyped," but, since i found it mostly by accident and it exceeded my every expectation, i'm rather of the opinion that it's not "over" at all. granted, it might not be the game you think. this is a pretty straight forward area control worker placement game with the shadow of military hanging over the board like smoke. every path you could take leads to stars, although i wouldn't call it a points salad. exploration, upgrades, popularity, and clever combat lead to many possible strategies. violence often takes the form of a cold war arms race with no one wanting to risk feeding another player one of the six stars they need to end the game. other times you'll see the day defined by repeated low-power skirmishes back and forth, defeat only ever a minor setback. it plays well 3-5 players, can handle 2-7 players, and the solo Automa deck makes for a challenge that is more than simply solving a puzzle. i consider this game money well spent and i'll own all three expansions.
