=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Euro about developing your action-selection engine.  Each player is basically trying to reach the same goal of optimizing their engine, by activating all your workers and mechs, improving your actions and reducing their costs (upgrade and enlist), and building buildings.  There is some customization in selecting a factory card mid-game which gives you an additional improved action only you have access to, but most of the variation in strategy is front-loaded in the combination of 2 starting boards you get, as each faction has a different ability and each board has quite a bit of variation in the costs of actions.  There is some player interaction in fighting for territory on the board and racing for exploration bonuses, but this game seems to me a lot more on the multiplayer solitaire end of the spectrum than the dudes on a map would imply.  Turns go by very fast, but there's a lot of planning several turns ahead to figure out the most effective ways to fully capitalize on each action (e.g. get an extra resource now with trade, so then when I produce next, I'll have just enough to pay for the bonus upgrade action when I boost, which will let me reduce the cost to enlist, etc.).  It's an interesting puzzle and the different factions and boards provide a lot of variability to explore, but for me the lack of interaction means I would see myself tiring of it pretty quickly.  

Production quality is amazing - I really like the double-layer boards with insets for pieces.  Minis are fine - I don't really care.  The art is great but the theme doesn't pull me in at all.  The focus is so much on cleanness of the mechanisms that there's really almost no flavor forcing you to immerse yourself into the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Scythe is an incredibly popular game set in a steampunk world of competing factions.  Players each take actions on their own player board that are different  than the  other players each taking actions that help the players build their empire by  gathering resources and using giant machines called Mech's to drive away other players.  This Game is a heavy Euro and the main focus is resource management and battling is an extremely  small part in this game. 

Pros: Variable Player Powers, Extremely Engaging worker placement mechanism, gorgeous components, Beautiful artwork, Fun resource management gameplay, Creative player interactions between turns. Multiple paths to victory,  Simple  Rule set yet deep  decision making 

Cons: Decision options can be overwhelming, Difficult to teach.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
So far, have only played 7 player and 6 player games with many new players which have created games that go on far too long. I really need to play with a lower player count with experienced players to get a real feel for this.

From what I've gleaned, it is a hyper polished design. Oddly enough, it's almost too polished. It's difficult to explain, but games lose something when you know all the quirky eccentricities have been hunted down and squashed. There is an attempt to make up for it with the amazing art and setting. It's great, but during the game, I tend not to notice things like that.

I did enjoy the game though. There are multiple paths to get what you want and there are many difficult decisions. Luck is at a minimum. Though I was in groups with much too much downtime, I can see how the turns would be lightning quick in the right group. I wish there was a bit more player interaction though.

Definitely willing to give this another go at a proper player count. My thoughts are not final here yet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
8/7/16 - Finally played this, and will probably not play again. This a quite awfully dry euro that is trying very hard to be a big, chrome-y Ameri-trash game. The game has some serious issues.

The engine build euro just isn't that interesting. The biggest issue is that the game is too strategy restrictive. You are given at random a race with a fixed starting location, and an action board. Then until you build a mech or a building you can't move out of a three hex zone. Like all games with variable races you need to exploit your abilities best to win, but your starting location and action board could easily work against one another. 

It also seems to always take lots of little micro actions to do things. I realized during this play this is why I don't like Stonemaier games. They all have this quality to a certain extent. I developed my strategy early on, but executing it was tedious. Most turns were simply spent setting up other turns, which just seemed to make the game feel artificially long.

And oh man, this is a fiddly game. At this point I'm full under the impression that Jamey Stegmaier enjoys making cool components and now has a reputation to uphold by doing so. That is fully working against this game though. Like I said, this a pretty dry engine optimization game. I'm not opposed to engine optimization games, but when I look across the table at the vast sea of pieces and components I get deflated. Tracking the game state is a struggle. On top of the ocean of pieces is a mushy, brown-ish color palette that tends to was together and look like mud. The box are and player board art is tremendous, but during game play the board is a jumbled up unclear mess.

And yep, this a completely pasted on theme. Yep, there are minis, and mechs, and cool art. But it all amounts to nothing. This could be any theme, even a non-combat oriented theme. The combat is the one area where theme could have come through, but it's essentially a more restrictive and unexciting copy of the combat from Dune. The combat in Dune was thrilling because of all the intrigue elements at play. Here, even with the dial and the combat cards, most fights are largely deterministic. The cards don't do anything interesting, just add x strength.

All in all, not a game for me. Fiddly, overlong, annoyingly restrictive, and derivative. I feel like this game wants to be Concordia, but has crammed in a lot of bloat to be shiny. Concordia is simpler, more streamlined and economical, and plays much smoother and faster.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

551/3430
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Took a while to get this to the table, and I definitely like it.  There's a lot of moving parts, and it takes a few turns to figure out the rhythm of play, and you need to be thinking two or three turns ahead, but that's my ideal planning horizon for games.  I really like the ergonomics and the UX of the game.  The way buildings and upgrade cubes clearly and visually track your technological progress by making your actions better and cheaper is really well designed, along with how as your worker population swells, it gets more expensive to get them to work.  The design of the pieces is great in that all the wooden bits are used for the eurogame mechanics, and the plastic bits are the ones that interact with the more ameritrash mechanics.  Combat is present, but you're not incentivized to go all-out, and the penalty for losing is comparatively mild.  I also like the design of the stars, as I like games that have multiple binary goals where you have to choose to pursue some of them and not others.  The clearly delineated nature of the list of goals also makes it clear what you should be doing during the game and serves as a teaching tool for new players, and having a lot of them gives you a broad strategy space where you can focus very differently in different plays of the game, guided by what your player board is good at doing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

ac3

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is another game that boost a great theme and great flavor on the paper and the cardboard, but after a couple of turns, going back and forth with the same action that gives you "command points" "popularity" or "money" feels just as lifeless as it sounds. It's jarring how much this game appears to have hidden depths and how much these fall flat when you get near to have build anything possible.
Moreover, i don't get all the emphasis this game puts in workers and mechs when the first aren't going to do anything special after the first turns (the only action directly tied with them is production, which is somehow quite situational), while the seconds aren't really going to have some real fights. It appears to me that this game real flaws are these: you got to do a lot of things, but nothing really interesting, and you got to see a lot of flavor, but never feel it in practice. Heck, when you want, or are invited, to have mech fights in a post-apocalyptic world, you would want to have REAL mech fights in a post-apocalyptic world, not to have mechs strolling around in cornfields while you watch how peaceful your farmers are sitting on their asses.
This recent trend of having badly designed Euro games that are...

1) Overcosted as they got tons of minis (nothing against those who likes them, but let's deal with it once and for all: good minis alone does not make a good game)
2) Disguised as an Ameritrash while having nigh to nothing of them

...got to stop sooner or later. One Blood Rage is enough, thanks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Neither the area control game I expected when I crowdfunded it, way back, nor the empty balloon of a Euro I feared when the first reviews started appearing on BGG. The production value is insanely high, especially in the Collector's Edition, and it's a very thought through product (and game). Very good replay opportunities, almost unlimited strategies and turn choices, easily induces analysis paralysis, can be intimidating to casual/ameritrash players, clear rulebook but still difficult to grasp gameplay until you've tried it at least once, difficult to gauge player scoring during a game (which I see as a plus). Even though turns fly by and you easily complete a multiplayer game in under two hours, it feels kind of heavy and grognard-y. Which, in my book, is another bonus. I don't really like Euros. This game, I liked. And it's absolutely gorgeous too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Very hard to rate this one. Cool idea and trappings, although I don't need minis and stars and such to have a good time. Counters would have been fine. 

The movement rules about crossing rivers into only certain terrains are absolutely ridiculous; you often can't even go back the way you came. And you start so slowly in this game, it might be better to be equipped with a mech or workers something right out of the gate. Still, there are some cool things about this, like many things to do and paths to victory. Not bad for someone who's not into engine-building games.  

But it's a slow one to start, and has an over-large footprint, and if played with few players seems to provide very little interaction. With 4, 5, 6 players, though, it seems rife with potential.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I normally dislike games that fall on the 4X spectrum, but I saw this one on kickstarter and decided to back it and give it a shot because it seemed to have the few things I liked from other 4x games I've played (dial combat) and didn't have the things I hated (loss of units/high focus on combat). I was not disappointed in my choice once the game arrived. The game is mainly about building your engine as efficiently as possible while going after the objectives of getting your stars on the board and setting yourself up for a sweet number of points at the end of the game. Having to do that while worrying about what the other players might be up to and work around them is just a nice extra challenge. I look forward to playing this game many more times.

RATING: 8
Like Jamey Stegmaier's other games the production value for Scythe is through the roof and it looks great on the table. Scythe is a fun efficiency puzzle to solve and compares well to other popular efficiency games like Terra Mystica or Tzolkin. Given that this is a dudes-on-a-map game, player interaction is perhaps surprisingly low, which is not a fatal flaw, but just something prospective buyers should be aware of.

RATING: 7.5
Scythe is a good game built on a euro engine and the threat of combat with a player driven end game. I don't personally like the solo game very much, but then, I don't like solo versions of games where the dummy player mostly serves as a timer. Some people object to how abruptly the game can end when someone places their sixth star, but so far it hasn't bothered me. I really consider this a 3-5 player game.

RATING: 6
Scythe is probably better than I rated it, if you haven't played the various games Scythe borrows from. Play it just made me want to play them. What Scythe does in two hours is admirable but I felt I was just scratching the surface of a larger game at the end. Would give it another go however.

If you think the combat in this game is good, do yourself a favor and play Rex, or better still, Dune. Then you see the combat sing and the result will actually mean something.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
FUN ★★★✰✰
I'm not sure whether it could be called "fun", but for sure this game provides some kind of interest. The issue I see here is the lack of interaction between the players. Each of them developp its faction for 2/3 of the game before we can feel more tension raising due to the scores and positions on the map. Despite of that, I enjoy putting the game on the table with friends. Don't expect to have many battles on the map, the mechs are more a threat than a means to kill other characters.

RULES ★★★★★
Rules are very well written, special cases are very easy to handle because they are easy to find in the rule book. I read them only once and we didn't have any issue to play seemlessly.

IMMERSION ★★★✰✰
I mostly play historical games. It's hard to define this one as such, but the design, the cards, the atmosphere are very special and put the players in a particular world. Very well done.

DEPTH ★★★✰✰
Along with the lack of interaction, this is the second negative point to this game that I could find. I am not sure to want to play this that often. The game is nice, but I'm afraid it would become quite repetitive on the long term once the optimal schemes found. We'll see.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Most options ingame usually have one optimal solution, so you don't really get much choices throughout the game. You get your starting combo at the beginning that limits you from doing certain strategies, even with later upgrades, leaving you one or two options to choose from, unless you intend to lose. This is also true for things like encounter cards: certain "choices" are not real choices, since the tradeback is that awful (especially if you have to give up hearts) you'll never choose certain things unless you're a beginner. In the first round you already know your first 15 rounds. It is a rare occasion that something changes during your turns, since player interactions are so scarce, and battles usually punish you, even tough one side usually unable to do anything: the attacker KNOWS for sure the outcome before the fight... If you have a new player this is even more tedious: your rounds are only 10 second long, with 10-15 minutes of pause between them. I'm confused: it is supposed to be a board game, yet it is almost like a slow and limited version of a single player pc game of a similar genre.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I know how popular this game is.

And I love games with multiple paths to victory.

My biggest beef with this game is the component quality, mainly the double cardboard that is poorlymade, and either breaks apart or completely warps. Making playing the game a bigger challenge than it has to be.

I am also privy to the fact that the people i played with factors in to this rating, but boy this game bored me and all the many times I had to sit and do booring rounds of Produce, next player and then waiting for the AP prone players before it was my turn again, while im bored shitless... I hope that this game will work well for others, and I know it does, but I have to say I am happy i didn't end up buying this game myself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Wrote a first impressions on this one. Mainly, the game is deceptive about what it actually is. If you are interested in a 4x game, or a Kemet-like experience, skip this game. It is an engine builder. There is little player interaction. The engine does not seem very interesting to replay as it clearly tells you what it wants you to do. There is no sense of progression or any stories that come forth out of playing it. All things considered, it is a forgettable experience. For every game it is inspired by, you are better off just playing its inspirations and have a far better time.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Scythe has been on my solo table every month since I got it.
To me it is the ultimate solo game, purely because I always want to play it.
Some reasoning behind that need:
1. Variety in factions - you can try out the different abilities and see how they interact with the playerboards. (finding workable strategies).
2. Variety in player boards - This can totally change what you need to do and how you manage your faction.
3. Variety in Automa difficulty - This will alter your strategy if only because the most significant change is time.
4. Variety in Automa actions - depending on the Automa card reveal, it can behave aggressively, expansively or defensively, each requiring a different solution.
5. Variety in Automa numbers - providing you can get extra decks or the app, you can play against 1 to 3 Automa for an enjoyable game. 4+ is a lot of work, but still fun! 
6. Variety in Events - not as powerful, but still a fun discovery process and a fantastic opportunity to deal it out to the Automa/s.
7. Variety in Structure Bonus - a simple Bonus that often changes a Loss into a win.

I know it won't suit everyone, and other games may fill some of the same aspects better.
But I it is a comprehensive game with a lot to like.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[1 play] Viticulture with territorial expansion and a slice of combat. I'll need another play before I can decide if it is worthy of an 8 or not. I enjoyed figuring it out and I always enjoy a well designed tech tree development system. 

Love the artwork on all the elements of the game. The mapboard itself could have more muted colors and be less distracting though.

Most recent play Jan '17.

RATING: 9
As an eurogame lover, I find this game very interesting and unique in comparison with the rest of my collection. It has all the elements that I like in a game (resource management, optimization of actions, engine building, etc.) but it adds other tings like combat and player confrontation over the map without making it it's main focus.

Overall the result is fantastic, this is a game that feels really special when you play it thanks to it's amazing components, art and unique combination of euro and 4X mechanics.

If you like eurogames and want to experience something with more player interaction, don't think about it and get Scythe right now.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Lots of points for style.  It really isn't window dressing: the theme fresh and it infused the game.  The concept and art are supercool.

There's also a couple of innovative mechanisms:  1)  the fact that you can sometimes take two actions on your turn if you planned things right (and no one foiled them).  2)  the upgrade mechanism of making one action more effective while simultaneously making another action cost less was great and provides for a lot of strategy.

But I'm afraid there aren't enough nice trees to add up to a forest.  Many mechanisms (movement, combat and the flow of controlling territory) are clunky and chaotic.  The way the game ends is simply unsatisfying.  The variable powers didn't sit right for me and seems a cheap way to get flavor and replayability at the expense of undue complexity and arguments about fairness.

There are also downtime issues...but I'm going to chalk this up to my poor patience and the fact that I've only played five player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I don't like that the "bottom-row actions" on the player boards become useless in the later part of the game. For example when you have built all your buildings, the build action is then pointless. Unfortunately this is true for ALL the bottom-row actions. Why can you do less after you developed your faction? This aspect of gameplay is highly unsatisfying for me. I will have to play the game a couple more times to see if this really bothers me.

Yes, you can keep using the bottom-row actions just for the money / bonuses, but they cost the same as if using them fully, which makes no sense: "So I use a build action paying materials required to build a building that I do not build. And then I get money."
This could be solved simply by "unlocking" some special ability or bonus when completing a bottom-row action.

I also don't like the game's combat system which I find too deterministic and boring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
The theme is original and interesting, but the game system is too derivative in my opinion. I've simply played too many similar games (TI3, Eclipse, Throneworld) with a hex board, resource collection, army building, a central "super hex", victory points through achievements, and so on. All of these games have a few unique rules of course, but they still play the same overall. Similar to TI3 the board gets quite crowded and there's too much "stuff" than is necessary to what the game is trying to achieve. It also seems like the game ending/winning move should always be the same, unless I'm missing something.

RATING: 8
[2017-03-19]
A Kaszára is sor került végre. Óriási rajongás övezete a játékot a megjelenése óta. A történet szerint az első világháború után járunk, amikor a fejlődés a lépegetők fejlesztése felé ment el. A játékosok területeket szereznek a hexás térképen és közben fejlődnek. Különböző fejlesztésekért, maximalizált haderőért, hírnévért lehet csillagokat szerezni, amiből ha valaki hatot megszerez kiváltja a játék végét azonnal, de egyáltalá nem biztos, hogy ő nyer, mert a csillagok számán kívül a birtokolt terület, nyersanyagaink és a minden játékban véletlenszerűen választott cél elérése is pénzt ad. A játékban bár lehet és csillagért érdemes is harcolni, viszonylag kevés a háború, így a nagy konfliktusosságtól nem kell félni. A játék bolti kiadása is nagyon szép, de a KS verzió hihetetlen gyönyörűen kivitelezett. A játékban mindenki egy-egy népet testesít meg és egy-egy véletlenszerű fejlődési akicótáblát is kap. E kettő jó kihasználása a játék kulcsa. És talán ez az egyetlen gyenge pont is, mert úgy érzem, hogy az egyes kombinációk nem teljesen kiegyensúlyozottak. A játék meglepően gyors. Jogos a rajongás, a Scythe jól sikerült játék, nagyon szép köntösben.

RATING: 1
I have played this game twice now and both times I had a terrible experience playing. The game would have been amazing if it did not have combat in it, but I feel as though the combat is a slippery slope to fight on.

You need to defend yourself, so you fight. But to do, you need to blow all of your might (which in turn is actually vp) to win a battle. After winning the battle, you notice that you have become an easy target, all because you needed to stop your goods from getting lost. 

Or you could use your goods. But wait, you cant because you just took that action, or worse, its a coin action and mind you, coins are VP.

My experience was so bad, I wont ever play this game again. I think it was a flaming pile of garbage. And only 1 game so far had topped it in terribleness : spinning monkeys. But not too far behind is marco polo.

RATING: 5
Played a 5P game once. It's a 5 for me so far. Might change score if I get a chance to play it again. 

The art is nice but doesn't really add much to the game experience imo. 

The theme, to me, is almost non-existent in this game. It didn't make me understand the rules/mechanism  of the game easier at all. The goal of the game is to get the most fame & wealth but I felt like the objectives we needed to achieve that are very arbitrary. (e.g. Deploy all 4 Mechs, Complete all 6 Upgrades, build structure on some predefined locations). Why deploying more Mech upgrades my ability to move around on the map? Why do I gain stuffs when the players next to me do the bottom action that I have already enlisted? The whole thing just feels unthematic to me. 

A game can be fun without any theme, but when the game try to force a theme on itself and utterly failed (imo), it gets some minus points.

I also agree with other negative reviews that say it could feel like a multiplayer solitaire (from the only 5p game i played anyway). Judging the game without the theme, the game play itself pretty average. Nothing I haven't see from other games. The implementation of the mechanic is alright.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Resisted giving any game a 10, because they can always be better, right?  But after 20 or so plays of Scythe it remains not only my favorite but my teenage kids' favorite as well.  There was a time 3 or 4 plays in when I was worried it was getting stale, but then a new level of depth appeared and hasn't let up.

Two things make this game great, besides the stellar art and top flight components.  One, everything is logical and well thought out with tie-ins to the theme.  Two, figuring out your action board is a fun puzzle every time (and with 5 factions and 5 player boards, there are a lot of combinations - 7 of each with the first expansion).  Unique in any game I've played, you select an action which is chained to another action (e.g., move, then build; or produce resources then deploy a mechanized unit), but the chaining is unique to each player (another may have produce with build).  Actions can have costs, so you may not be able to execute both actions in your turn, and the strategy of planning a couple of moves ahead to be able to maximize both actions keeps you thinking all the time, with lots of satisfying moments when you can pull it off.

I could do a longer review here, as there's so much to like.  I expect Scythe will continue to be our go-to weekend game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Terra Mystica + Kemet? Yes Please. The combat system is awful though.On first look its like Kemet/Game of Thrones, however Kemet has unique player powers that builds as the game progresses,and Game of thrones players has asymmetric power cards. Except for some very minor variation in the form of Mech upgrades, the Combat is just summation of cards + power dial numbers. Seriously, it bothers me that this game is praised so much but it has one of the most uninspired combat mechanics I have ever seen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Played it twice on Tabletopia. Didn't really grab me in any way. The design is ok I guess and the game works for sure. It just didn't excite me in any way.
Often felt like you were doing pretty much the same thing over and over again with a few variations. Nothing really spectacular happened during the game.

 
- Most of the upgrades were lackluster and the gains are very incremental. Move a cube from there to here and get a discount. The same goes for the buildings. The Mine is cool but the Monument and Armoury are very meh. 

- Also, popularity seems to be almost too important. The fact that you loose popularity everytime you force someone elses workers to retreat makes combat very difficult. Unless you're the white player, who doesn't get that penalty.   

Didn't like the endgame either. It get's kinda mathy when you have to calculate the other players scores, to make any judgement, wether to take the last star to end the game or not.

Theme is pretty thin. The encounter cards are cool, but they are pretty much the only element in the game that supports the theme.

I really wanted to like the game, but in the end it just didn't bring anything new or exciting to the table.

RATING: 10

RATING: 9
I really enjoyed my first play of this game. It's not the most sophisticated 4x, but I find the mechanics easy to grasp and I am sure some of my friends who normally don't play 4x games could easily wrap their heads around it. The components and art are stunning, and the game plays really fast. Multiple paths to victory and objectives to complete add more to the game. And while I have read that some people are dissatisfied with the lack of focus on combat, I like it, since usually in 4x games I always fall behind because I don't focus on combat enough...I like developing instead. So, this game is my cup of tea. :)

RATING: 10

The components in the Collector's Edition are excellent.  The game is full of tension and tough decisions, and it has a nice growth to its gameplay as it builds to a nail biting conclusion.  Stonemaier Games has another winner in Scythe.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the best of all time!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
If "Hansa Teutonica" and "Dune" had a baby, and that baby grew up to be kinda bloated and clumsy, but was really, really, ridiculously good looking, it would be "Scythe."

"Scythe" is undeniably one of the best looking games out there. Maybe THE best looking. Jakub Różalski artwork is impeccably gorgeous.

The biggest problem with "Scythe" is that the disparate mechanisms of the game constantly clash with each other.

The combat mechanism actively discourages conflict, as even if you win a conflict, by spending the resources required to do so you've weakened yourself. But then winning a battle is an easy way to get a star on the board, so you're going to want to fight an easy battle once.

And really those stars are the crux of the game. Once someone achieves their final star the game is over. So "Scythe" isn't really a 4x game. It's a racing game. Can you build an engine to get stars on the board faster than the other players?

The popularity track makes those stars worth more than anything else in the game. I've never seen someone win who wasn't in the top tier of popularity.

The secret objective cards are strange. Each player draws 2 at random before the game begins, maybe they're easy to complete, maybe they're nigh impossible, there is no way to obtain more so you better hope you're lucky. You're going to want to complete one because doing so gives you a star. If you do complete one you discard the other. Since there's no way to draw more of these, why is there a spot for the whole deck on the board?

I digress...

"Scythe" is NOT a bad game. But everything it does has been done better in other games. Maybe not all in the same game, but perhaps there's a reason for that.

Sure looks good though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Engine builder game. And I need to get better at this game.

RATING: 10
Scythe for me brings together my gaming experiences as a child (Risk) with my newer gaming experiences (Catan), yet also making it more competitive and more strategy based, less on luck.

The theming of the game is excellent, the symbols used are clear, and it is probably one of the few games that took over two hours the first time and left my entire group saying "Wow, can we play that again?". 

While it can be difficult to start out, especially with some more fiddly rules (Took me 3 games before I fully understood the Windmill), it is a game that learning the rules feels rewarding, and makes you want to play again.

RATING: 7
A fun, but (in my opinion) greatly overrated game. While there is a great amount of strategy, it is at the end of the day a worker placement/zone control/economy Euro. Sure, it has some extra bells and whistles, and due to its unprecedented success on kickstarter looks very pretty, but at the end of the day it can be very plodding, slow, and not all that engaging. There are a couple very optimal ways to play, and the various factions/factory cards don't alter that terribly much. 

Overall, it is undoubtedly a very solid game, but its ranking is greatly overinflated simply due to the bandwagon popularity of it following its kickstarter. I highly recommend anyone that is thinking about buying this game to first try it: play it a few times at your FLGS if they have a demo copy. If you love it, great, but don't be surprised if you come away from it thinking "Sure, that was fun, but am I missing something? Why all the hype?"

My exact opinion of this game is summarized pretty perfectly by Paul in the Shut Up and Sit Down review, easily found on YouTube.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is an area control and faction management game with little splashes of tons of other mechanics added to it.  There is some exploration, combat, and hidden objectives sprinkled in here as well as tons of other stuff.

This game absolutely blew me away.  I had a feeling and actually splurged for the second best edition of the game which included everything except the art book and even not getting that is seeming like a mistake with how beautiful this game is.  While we are on the subject let's talk about the game's art.  It seems like a great place to start because the story I've heard is this game came into being based solely on the beautiful art by Jakub Rozalski.  The designer wanted to use that art in a game and built around it.  On top of which with the Deluxe edition of the game I have a board extension to make the board even larger, nice chunky resource tokens to replace the cardboard, and metal coins.  The game looks absolutely amazing and there is a different piece of artwork on each of the encounter cards.  My personal favorite part is the pairing of this beautiful artwork with humorous satirical descriptions of your options when you draw an encounter card.  Everything from gaining popularity for your long, flowing hair fluttering in the wind to pushing an innocent cow under a marauding mech.

So enough about how the game looks, how does it play?  Incredible.  Which I have to admit when I heard that the game started with art and the gameplay was built around that I was somewhat skeptical.  But the game is almost perfectly designed.  First of all each player has their own faction and player board.  These vary slightly to greatly depending on what portion you look at but they all seem pretty well balanced.  That is not a minor task, being able to offer depth and breadth in play so the game has replayability while also balancing it all.  On top of which with so many of those mechanics sprinkled in there are a ton of ways to approach the game and win.  Something that stood out is in my first game I placed the final achievement star which immediately ends the game.  In theory this meant I did more than my two opponents, my closest competitor still had 2 fewer than me.  I still only came in second however.  There is a popularity track that gives more points based on the tier you are in and I was one tier lower.  Even with "doing less" he got more value out of what he did and beat me.  I lost but I love that the game doesn't have a runaway leader or lock to it that many other, even good, games have.  That is something else  very, very hard to design for.

Between just wanting to stare at this game and all the many ways you can play and the variability and replayability it offers this has immediately become one of my favorite games.

RATING: 7.4
Scythe is a fine game but it's not an exciting one. It doesn't have any glaring flaws, but just a bunch of minor ones. The biggest reason that I am not a huge fan is because it's a game that sets you up for so much, but ends up disappointing.

For example, the artwork and theme are so beautiful and have you believe that it's a thematic 4x game with combat and exciting swings, but really it's a slow resource generation game that could have been completely abstracted from its theme without any consequence. The split objectives are disconnected and make conflict between players feel arbitrary and meaningless, because other than the few moments of combat or vying for the factory in the center, there is rarely a shared objective that everyone is competing for so everyone is essentially in their own worlds.

When the end game is finally triggered, to me it feels anticlimactic, abrupt, and disappointing. No one realizes until a turn or two before the end of the game (and sometimes not until the game is over) that the game is going to end. I think it has to do with the disconnected objectives mentioned above

Lastly, the pace of the game is disappointing because of how slow it is throughout the whole game. There is no ramp up in Scythe. You basically take the same actions throughout the whole game. Upgrades and enlist options help a bit but not enough to make up for the slow pace. The game just plods along and then all of a sudden it's over. 

I think on paper it's a fine game. It plays well enough. It has a lot of interdependencies and there is some fun in trying to optimize your actions, but I never get sucked into it. At no point does it feel exciting or, for that matter, fun. Just my opinion.

RATING: 10
Scythe is one of the most beautifully designed board games I've ever seen. The theme and aesthetic are completely unique. The art is unlike anything out there. RATING: 9
This game has it all, and it's beautiful. Stonemaier Games is great. I emailed them and they were so friendly. Scythe has mechanics and elements from some of my favorite games, like Dungeon Lords, Puerto Rico and Catan. 

I played the KS edition and luckily was able to purchase an extra KS Deluxe version before they were all sold out. Managing dependencies, and choosing stretgies to achieve star goals is challenging. 

Each faction / player board has variation giving clear strength variation. 

One addition I would make is to add a player reference card that shows scoring system for star achievements. I took a photo of the Quick Start Guide to use as a reference while playing the game for the first time. 

Figurines are paintable.

RATING: 9.7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Scythe is a beautiful game with some interesting mechanisms, but it lacks  interaction and the end scoring system is anti-climactic.

The artwork in Scythe is instantly engaging.  Every inch of the board is beautiful and the cards and player faction mats pop with gorgeous thematic elements.  This is among my top games, visually.  Once you move beyond the artwork, the game sports a decent amount of icons that can make the rules seem imposing.  Fortunately learning the game is rather painless and the flow of the game lends itself well to learning as you play.  The main action mechanic of top action first then bottom is interesting, especially with the variable boards.  Each turn of Scythe gives you challenging decisions to make as you weigh top and bottom action combinations.  You must also consider that you can never do the same action in back-to-back turns (barring one faction ability) which leads to longer term planning, although this restriction seems somewhat forced just to make the game seem deeper.  Actions and mechanics are streamlined and play quickly, which helps minimize downtime (AP still can be a factor).  These qualities make Scythe a very engaging experience, and yet...

I can't really bring my self to praise Scythe thanks to the lack of interaction, the awful combat, and the obscure scoring system that completely clashes with the very nature of the rest of them game.  Scythe starts slow and movement is plodding.  With so many actions focused on improving your own faction, and the various options to essentially trade any good for any other through various actions, players will generally hang out in or near their starting areas for 80% of the game and just bounce between actions to improve themselves in the quest for 6 stars.  Each game will see people racing to getting 4 mechs, 4 enlistments, 6 upgrades, max dominance, and the other stars that can be achieved on a completely solitary basis.  I've found the game to be 4 people staring at their player boards and generally ignoring each other until the last few turns.  

Once interaction does occur, it happens through what the game generously refers to as combat.  Combat involves spending a secret amount of dominance and adding one combat card (if you have any) per combat unit with which you are attacking.  Add up the numbers to see who wins, attacker wins ties.  In fairness, there is the interesting choice to consider in which you may hold back everything in hopes that your opponent blows all his cards and dominance to beat you when you didn't mind losing, but the experience is otherwise disappointing.  Mechs and characters do nothing but add combat cards IF you have them in hand.  They offer no other benefit in combat, which really highlights that the mechs themselves are basically just another solitaire upgrade system in the game.  And otherwise, the super-simple system is just boring.  There's no real way to become a powerful and looming threat in Scythe.  There's no tactical positioning or protecting valuable hexes.  Because combat depends primarily on dominance and cards, your status on the map is almost entirely divorced from your ability to attack or defend based on unit positioning.  Attackers also usually suffer popularity penalties and there are almost no hexes that don't have an equivalent alternative within an easily reachable distance.  Add all of this up and combat generally only happens so that players can grab two of the needed six stars, which is an uninteresting reason to fight.  

Finally, and most unfortunately, the ultimate win condition in Scythe is atrocious.  After 2+ hours of building your faction, securing hexes and materials and gaining dominance and popularity, all done on a perfect information board that constantly displays player status and gives you a sense of faction progression, the game suddenly ends and then every faction sits down to do some math and figure out what their actual score was!  It turns out, the star race never really mattered (though it does provide points).  Instead, if a player has a mathematically optimized position in which his popularity multipliers combined with his stars, hexes, and materials plus some bonus conditions is the highest, he wins!  This scoring is a slap to the face, seriously.  It is terribly unsatisfying.  Two hours of building and upgrading and racing for objectives suddenly slams to a halt and everyone crosses their fingers in the hopes that their numbers add up the best.  I'm having trouble describing the frustration I've felt during scoring this game.  A close game isn't defined by a single battle on the last turn or a brilliant series of upgrades and moves, or conquering that last game long objective, it's determined by the red player having (numbers completely made up) 2x10+3x7+5x5 = 66  and blue having 3x8 + 2x10 + 2x10 = 64.  OH MAN SO CLOSE!  Ugh.

The relative solitude of this game, combined with my complete lack of desire to fight, and culminating in an obfuscated and unsatisfying scoring system, make Scythe a repetitive and unsatisfying overall experience.  Each game is a race to upgrade, which usually happens in the same general way, and then someone wins, somehow.  That's not to say it's boring.  Making the decisions on how to upgrade most efficiently is actually quite interesting, and after all else fails it's still pretty to look at.  I don't hate Scythe, and I really appreciate it's streamlined mechanics.  I'll still play it, but I won't ask to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

RATING: 4
A functional design but I can't see anybody who've been gaming for more than a decade being excited by this. Like most Stonemaier game, it's a rehash of stuff you've seen hundreds of time better before. Nothing particularly innovative here.

I'll admit I don't get the theme at all. Artwork is nice, but not particularly evocative. To me Caylus has a better theme than Scythe.

My major complains for the game is the way you get stars, which is about players maxing 6 categories. It makes for very linear gameplay outside the threat of an attack.

Again not a bad game, but rating on BGG scale means I have little interest of playing this again.

RATING: 4
Looks Great, Great Theme, problem is the game is very solo play.

I've played this game 7x times now and have got to admit for the first 3x games i thought ooh this is interesting but now i know the rules and have played it a fair few times I've got to say the game is quite dull.

You're nearly always solo playing, the random clan and distribution board can be make or break and some locations lean towards resources better than others, The game feels too self absorbed and with the combat mechanic it's rare to see too many people fighting for the win.

I'd play this game again but it's not as good as the hype train makes you believe, in summary it's a simplified version of Terra Mystica with random mechanics and no real serious play testing.

RATING: 9
This might actually be a 10 for me. I'm a few plays in and would like to play it quite a bit more. I enjoy the efficiency puzzle and the race in each game and am still getting a feel for the different factions and strategies. The game does a good job of encouraging exploration and conflict in various ways without every seeming to penalize a given player randomly.

I do worry that with repeat plays, there may be a few formulaic moves that prove to be much stronger than others, especially for individual factions. This could lead to a bit of sameness between matches. The randomized player mats do help alleviate this to a certain extent, however, as their strongest actions will frequently not match up with your factions strongest abilities or most readily available resources.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Whether with other gamers or against the Automa in solo mode, I am finding Scythe to be incredibly challenging and rewarding. An atypical 4X in that it emphasizes combat (and never eliminates units), it offers a plethora of choices and decisions only get harder (and the right ones more rewarding) as the game goes on. It's already crept from 8.5 to 9 in my estimation and once I give The Wind Gambit a try it could very well climb more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fantastic game with satisfactory AI. I can enjoy it with my ten year-old son. Great!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Clever design that mixes euro efficiency (action selection, engine-building, victory by completing X achievements) with diceless combat. The complaint, as ever, is that like most hybrid designs it is unsatisfying on all fronts -- too much randomness for a strategic euro and too little action for dudes on a map. It's a game I desperately want to like and I can see why it's popular, but just like Eclipse I think I have to resign myself to the fact that it's never going to be as enjoyable as I want it to be.

It's quite a hodgepodge and some parts work better than others. Resource production is cleverly tied to the area control, for example, and the shared (thievable!) resources adds another great incentive besides stars to fight. The recruitment bonus granted by adjacent players does not seem similarly necessary (or, rather, seems included to add a modicum more interest in other players actions but as mechanism feels inorganic and bolted-on). I'm not particularly convinced by the action boards in general, really (uninteresting choices about action efficiency to distract from the insufficiently compelling map), and particularly not by the asymmetry, as some combinations seem to play much better to specific faction strengths.

There is also undeniable luck in the various card draws.

Jakub Rozalski's spectacular artwork is the best reason to play, but cheaper to buy a print or an artbook.

RATING: 5.5
Tentative rating that I could see going up after a few plays.  There are a number of interesting ideas here, and the game pieces and boards are fantastic.  I don't really like how the end game works out, as it is too calculable, and it bogs down the game.  I'm not sure how I feel about most games that end when a player chooses to end it.  Often, like in the case in our play, they end it and someone else wins.  In order to combat that, a player might and probably should take an awful long time calculating out how not to have that happen.  

It felt too long, but I could very much see that problem being more group dependent.  4 seemed like the right number of players.  I liked aspects of it enough to play some more, but it may just not be my type of war game/Euro hybrid.  I'd rather play Eclipse for more 4x action or Kemet to pare down the complexity to just murdering my opponents nonstop.

RATING: N/A
Look what my 2016 BGG Santa got me!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Scythe’s beauty and theme really adds to the game experience. It is an efficiency race to build up as much as possible before a player ends the game. 

The first half of the game feels like a solitaire puzzle where the players build the foundation of their strategy to win. It is crucial that you right from the start have a plan for your first 3 - 4 stars and how to get there as fast as possible. For this you need to optimize the usage of your bottom row actions. Take too many single actions (top row only) and you fall behind.

The second half of the game opens up interaction with the other players. Try to be the player who ends the game with the move action and spread out to as many territories as possible. Otherwise keep an eye on the player that will and spread out just before they place their last star.

Each faction paired with different action boards give you a new puzzle to solve which I enjoy. Had a really good time playing it and would love to give it another go.

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 7
Only played it once - need to play it again to really "get it."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Almost universally loved! $110. But 2016 not the best for outstanding games.

For me, the classic game Wallenstein is far more interesting and just plain more fun. It does what Scythe essentially does but only in a far more interactive and fun manner. And in a more realistic manner, too. The game play and the theme interact perfectly! From the very beginning to the very end. Thus the players get territory that can be all over the map and next to your enemies. Some players may try to "turtle" quickly. But everyone is playing close attention to the map, both where they are and where the others are. Almost immediately some form of negotiating takes place. As players whose territories either are not near each other discuss how to work together against their more natural enemies whose territories are close to their own, as well as players whose territories might be inclined for combat and conquest try to divide up the board and turn attention to potentially easier territories, allowing the players to focus on building up castles, churches, and trading posts in their own territories for VPs. And, of course, the actual combat is "epic". Using the Tower. Where unexpected outcomes can happen. And where peasant forces may either fight with you or against you. Then there is the fact that you have to both tax and feed your populations. Choosing those specific areas from which taxes and food will be taken, which makes the peasants mad at you. Make them mad enough, and they revolt. And if you can't feed all your people, they'll start revolting. And just as in Scythe, you are limited in time, money, and resources. You can't either pay for all you want to buy (both guns and butter, so to speak, as controlling areas is worth VPs so you want big armies, but building castles, churches, and trading posts also earns VPs).
*********************
I came in the game with the wrong expectations. I was hoping for a game like Kemet, and got a functional victory point generator game like Seasons. The art is stunning, but the experience itself was not on par. Every time something was explained, I felt like I had seen this somewhere else before, and often better executed. I really missed having a story to tell about my Nords. Overall, I think despite its flaws, this game is still pretty good. It is competent, but somewhat bland and overshadowed by similar, better games. If you are new to boardgaming and want to try a more complicated game, this could be a good starting point. 
For everyone else, I would recommend leaving this one in the stores unless if you are really enamoured by the theme and the art. There are just better games in its genre out there. For 4X, try Space empires 4x or FF's Civilization. For area control and better combat, go play Kemet, Forbidden stars or Chaos in the old world. Or if you want something not quite like all of the above, but probably the most similar to to Scythe, but better, go play Eclipse and its expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
So simple but at the same time so deep.  There is a lot of strategy to be had in this game, so much planning and intricate detail to understand about each individual faction.  The differentiation in starting location in and of itself is going to inherently change how you play, and then there are asymmetrical powers, abilities and game boards.  I really enjoyed this game, and would like to play it again sooner than later, need to beat Chuck!

Second play through was just as good.  Saxony (black) is not exactly the faction that matches my play style, as it promotes confrontation and attacking.  Was able to take advantage of a player that consistently left himself and his resources vulnerable, which was unfortunate but from my perspective necessary.  I still had to learn as i was going and am far far from efficiently using my actions and resources.  Still need to play more.

RATING: 10
With a group of 3 sharp and focused players, we raced against the clock. The store close time approaching in 130min, we had to learn the game and storm through it. So, motivated as we were, we stumbled through our early turns, missing opportunities and reading rules during each others turns, by 1/4 of the way through, we'd comprehended most of the rules and many others, we applied logic and checked after, finding ourselves correct(bonus points, the rules make sense). 

Having skipped the Quick Play Setup page, we had distributed factions by "pick the animal you think is cool"(incorrectly) and then cluelessly distributed the lower boards at random(correctly!)

Turns disappeared quickly. One player, in his enthusiasm jumped into his turn before the previous player had started theirs, not once, but three times.

At the end, despite time spent on setup and rules, we pulled in only 5 minutes past our limit. The store owner didn't mind, and for his trouble, I bought the expansion to Scythe on the spot.


On my second play, it was myself and 4 fresh players, three of whom were inattentive and insisted that rules hadn't been explained. Thankfully, I was able to call on the players who had had those rules explained to them to back me up.

I would recommend only 2 new players per game, or hardcore gamers only for large fresh groups.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Had done 3 games thus far. All just with the base 5 factions. The 3rd game was played with recurring players who had played previously.

Scythe has kind of a weird feeling for me. On one hand, I like the presentation and it's definitely an overall amazing production. The rules are tight and easy for new players to get into. There's always various decisions to make during the course of the game, and the game plays fast, with players only doing a single action per turn it rounds-about fast.

On the other hand, it's extremely close to the good fun of "I've so much to do but so little actions" that some players may not enjoy. A few other things bug me as well, with how the game pacing went from building up and following some kind of player strategy at the start, to jostling to position and stuff, then the end is just mindlessly rotating actions to throw out as many stars as possible to end the game. Honestly, the pacing feels very weird to me. It kind of induce an anti-climatic end to the game. I wonder if the different resolutions in the wind gambit expansions would help.

Also for the 3rd game, almost no one bothered with their objectives. I'm contemplating about removing them, or making them public objectives instead (which requires a curated list so that pursuing the objectives but not getting it does not screw up the player's plans.) Maybe having a tighter amount of goals to pursue will force people to interact a little bit more. 

I feel very weirdly about the 4 actions, both the top and bottom ones. I've seen myself trying to cycle through maybe 2-3 of those 4. Also since faction and action boards are randomize, there will come situations where the pairing plays contrary to how the faction will attempt to abuse their powers. The faction abilities are all pretty interesting, and they will make players want to do certain actions more. But sometimes those actions may not be cost effective, and players have to do quite the opposite from their faction to play properly.

Still not so sure of the longevity of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Interesting game. First, it looks gorgeous (a friend of mine has the KS copy): the map, the artwork, the feel, the thematics, the various components all beautifully done.
Second, it has interesting decisions which don't bury you under loads and loads of options but keep things nice and tidy.
Third, it has this interaction as it is a struggle for resources and you will be looking at the progress of your competitors.

However, I felt a disconnect between the planning and the execution (battling it out with mechs). This game is not about battling, it is about scheming your euro engine in a battle-like setting. So in the end, it is multiplayer solitaire more than I like for a game with such a map and cool components. I want to DO stuff with them, not just gaze at the best way to get my next star. So to win, you are forced to make the decision: will I have fun with stompin' mechs or will I have fun by NOT doing that and winning the game instead. As a player who wants to win the game by having fun with stompin' mechs I feel kinda left alone by that choice that is forced upon you.

As a result, would not mind play it again, as it is always entertaining and a great way to spend your evening, but will not be suggested as a first option by me.

RATING: 7
An area domination game played with asymmetrical factions. While it's fascinating and tactical, with several different ways to win, the scoring is (intentionally) hard to read. It's a game where you can blaze to 6 stars, seemingly do everything right, and still end up in last place. It takes several playthroughs to figure out what "winning" looks like in this game.

The movement rules can be annoying, since every faction has a different way of crossing water. But all in all, it's a solid and deep game.

RATING: 8
This game is so good. It's basic is engine building and resource management but there is so much more. All components are nice and the cards are awesome. The theme of this game might be the best I have ever played. I played the game about 8 times now and it doesn't get boring. RATING: 8.5
Worker placement/movement, resource collection, battles, increase popularity by avoiding battles - this game has it all! There are different ways to win and each faction has their own special abilities which favor different strategies. Beautiful artwork and nice pieces. Interesting theme as well. Slightly heavy rules and setup takes a bit of time.

Automa deck is a nice addition which allows a single player to play against an "AI" of sorts.

RATING: 10
Has a spare #3 player mat
Has a second set of miniatures that I hand painted
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
tl;dr: worth the hype? Maybe...

Man, this game has quite the hype going on. It appears this is the best thing since sliced bread. It's already ranked #6 on the BGG ranking list of best games of ALL TIME! Why? Don't ask me, I don't know. I like it. I like it quite a bit. But the 6th best game ever? Not for me.
Anyway...
This is an engine building, resource management game with an optional combat element. The main mechanism is the action selection system where you have to select an action space that has a primary and a secondary action that can be executed independently from each other. On top of that, each race has a small special ability that does drive strategy in a certain direction (in some cases more than others).
The game ends as soon as someone gets 6 stars. Stars are like goals that you can achieve, like building all 4 buildings. But the aim is not to have the most stars, no, you want to have the most money. I found it interesting that I was able to win a game (by a very narrow margin) in which I had exactly 0 stars (though I was one action away on 4 stars).
I have now played the game 3 times. Once with each of 2-3-4 players. The game certainly is best with 4, and least interesting with 2. With 3 it is certainly worth playing as well.
I have enjoyed each play quite a bit. This certainly is a very solid design. There are lots of games that do elements from this game better, but very few that combine all of these elements is a package put together well as this game does it.
So I do like this game quite a bit, but is it worth all the hype? Meh, maybe, but I'm not sure it's worth as much hype as this is getting.

Initial rating: 7.8/10
BGG scale: 8/10

Factions are varied enough to keep them fresh each time you play but similar enough so as to not be unbalanced. The game is beautifully crafted and the pieces, card art and coins are all fantastic. I'll never turn down an opportunity to play.

RATING: N/A
overhyped and a bit overrated
theme is great, but a bit depressing
attempt of a fusion of American battle game and eurogame
gameplay looks a bit boring: "mechs on hexagons"


in short:
+ theme and artworks
+ some really nice ideas (achieve 6 of several different goals, popularity value, resources on board, different action boards, top and bottom actions, upgrades, encounter cards with choices, ...)
+ asymmetric player powers (factions + action boards) (!)
+ combat mechanic similar to "Dune"/"Rex" (wheel+card)
- "mechs on hexagons"
- fixed board with predefined positions for factions (feels wrong for this kind of game)
- game balance issues (start positions, bashing the weak, ...) ?
- very expensive
- not all factions included

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
This is a very nice looking game that is engaging, though not immersive, and clearly presented (other than the somewhat abstruse solitary/Automa booklet, which is far better conceived than explained).
Overall, Scythe is largely geared towards point gathering via private achievements (ie. resource gathering) that limit how much I am going to enjoy it. Unlike the modifier tallying of my favorite solitary game (Mage Knight), the combat here in Scythe is perhaps too simple, though clearly fighting is not the focal point. In none of my favorite games am I focused on points/achievements more than story, adventure, conflict, atmosphere, and characters, and what keeps Scythe from being Cave Evil or Mage Knight or Space Alert or Robo Rally is that I see numbers and score cards more than any imaginary world . Still, I enjoyed this solid game enough to play it twice in a row, and it's nice to manipulate the game pieces and to look at. Also, those player cards with the embedded slots for pieces/meeples are superb.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
So got my shiny new copy this weekend.  I was a bit worried about the hype factor.  A lot of games have a lot of hype to them and then you play them and they just don't live up tot he hype.  Scythe was one of those games that had been talked about for so long and almost universally well reviewed, that the hype factor was off the charts.  I approached it hopeful, but with a sense of trepidation.  I was worried about the level of confrontation being too little, or too much. I was worried about a number of factors.  If it was too complex I knew I could rarely get it to the table with most of my friends and if it was not complex enough I would be bored quickly.

I was happy that my worried were almost all proved to be unfounded.  The game was complex, but intuitive.  You could feel the way the mechanics worked together to make your unique play style.  Every action felt fairly impactful, and I almost had that old school RPG feel in how as I played my choices got better and more powerful by the previous choices I had made.  The play was fairly quick too.  While I could easily see someone having a bout of AP, often you are planning your turns out while you are on the current one and while others are taking theirs.  It made for fluid play.  Very pleased and can't wait to play this a lot more.

For anyone curious, I played this with three people.  Though I could see it being good with a variety of player counts.  Each player added will increase time of the game some.  I think for our first play we were just over an hour and a half time.  Two of us had watch the how to play video and explained the game to our third.

Edit 8/18/16- This has dropped a bit for me, it's still a great game, I just feel that there are some deficiencies, which don't really become apparent until lots of plays. (first post)I found the play of the game engaging, fun, and thoughtful.  Yes, I don't believe this is a 4x game, and direct conflict is low, but you do have to make decisions based upon your asymmetric starting position/resources. The setup, I believe, really allows a lot of plays. The production is top notch, on par with Stonemaiers other stuff.  This may or may not go up or down with more plays, but after playing it a Con (my copy was delivered as I was driving down to Orlando), I am really looking forward to getting this played with my core group and seeing how they feel about it.

RATING: 10
I get more and more impressed with this game each time I play it. Each faction really feels different from the others. I believe the factions are balanced for the most part but I also think some factions have an advantage based on the player count and based on which player board you get. At its heart this is an efficiency game, you are racing to accumulate victory stars. However, you also need to be reactive and opportunistic with regard to your opponents. Always look for ways to get an easy combat victory star or force your opponent to waste a turn. This is a great game which provides a new challenge with each play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Kickstarter
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Scythe is a solidly built game, and I'm not just talking about its components (especially if you have the deluxe Kickstarter version). The mechanics all fit together smoothly such that you always feel as though the designer and developers have done their jobs, and done them well. You feel like they are taking care of you while you play, whispering soft assurances into your ear: "Don't worry, we've thought of everything." I recommend the game, and I want to play it more.

That said, I have to admit, Scythe hasn't yet managed to capture my imagination -- hasn't managed to charm me -- and that is something I look for when I try out new board games nowadays. With so many games on the market, with so many designers mixing and matching mechanics from a variety of other designs, putting together a game that makes me sit up and say "Wow!" is increasingly important. Scythe is rock solid, it really is, but it's also a remix that, for me, hasn't quite connected (but is ever so close).

The comparisons are multitude. In its Euro-influenced engine building aspects, Scythe resembles Terra Mystica. In its 4x exploitation and extermination elements, it resembles any number of games. I'll choose Eclipse because Eclipse is another game celebrated for combining Euro systems with AT themes (I think you could also choose something like Sid Meier's Civilization). In its clever upgrade system, where you remove cubes from your player board to reveal discounts and better special powers, Scythe even resembles, of all things, Hansa Teutonica (weird, I know, but the parallels are there). Finally, in its action selection mechanic, Scythe resembles a rondel game. For me, the strongest comparison isn't Terra Mystica or Eclipse, but instead another game often labeled as 4x-lite: Antike.

But let's put all that aside for a minute and talk about what the game is trying to accomplish and how it gets there. I'm not going to detail specific mechanics. That would be a waste of your time when there are so many great video overviews. Instead, let's talk big picture. Scythe is yet another entry in the 4x-lite category with a heavy dose of Euro influence. It's a space well explored, but also immensely popular. To me, there are two factors to consider if you want to know if Scythe is the game for you.

First, how do you win? In many civ-games, wiping your enemy off the map is a good way to win, as is collecting "achievements" in various areas of technology and culture. Scythe is a bit of a hybrid. The object isn't so simple as killing your enemies or advancing up a tech tree. Like most things in the game, everything is interconnected. In one sense, the object is to score achievements, which could be anything from winning a battle to completing all of your "upgrades." For each achievement you place a star at the top of the board (just like in pre-school; gold star for Tim!). When one player has placed all of his or her stars on the board, the game ends immediately. But! Stars are not victory points. So let's clarify how you actually win...

Achievements give you the sense that the game is all about variety. However, there is a sneaking truth in Scythe that takes all that variety and condenses it into one overriding statistic. Like the Hunger Games, everything ultimately comes down to the popularity contest. Stars alone won't be enough to win because what you really need are points. To get points, you need popularity. Popularity is the master point multiplier, and therefore the most important thing you can earn. Want to know how many points all those stars you earned are worth? -- multiply the number times your popularity level. Want to know how many points your territories are worth? -- multiply the number times your popularity level. Want to know how many points... you get the idea. For a game that presents the players with so many options, the focus on popularity is oddly monochromatic. It doesn't wipe away variety, but it does ensure that everyone will be competing equally in at least one area they cannot afford to ignore.

The second thing worth considering is combat. If you are looking for a combat heavy 4x game, Scythe is not for you. Combat in any civ-lite or 4x-lite game is probably going to happen. How the game handles such a potentially devastating effect can, in my experience, determine whether I love or hate a game. A game like Eclipse, for example, leans heavily in the direction of combat, with fighting and fighting technology comprising a significant portion of play. On the other hand, Terra Mystica doesn't include combat at all, preferring to handle conflict indirectly through the aggressive claiming of territory. Scythe occupies the middle ground, but leans towards the Terra Mystica side of the equation. The game's focus is on engine building, but combat is just enough of a threat to make you worry. The battles are not so devastating to take anyone out of game, especially with a little bit of experience. In fact, you don't ever lose troops. They are instead merely sent back to your home base. That's not to say that losing a combat is no big deal -- it is! -- but it's something from which you can legitimately recover.

Personally, I like the balance that Scythe strikes between fighting and building. At times, it leans a little too heavily towards building, such that I start to worry that any fighting would upset my plans and feel out of place in the game. But that's a matter of misguided perception and overly timid players because combat certainly has its strategic place in the game. There is no other way to prevent someone from grabbing key locations on the board (especially the central factory). There are battles worth fighting, and without combat the game would veer dramatically into multi-player solitaire void of any asymmetrical challenge or overall tension. That said, as with any multi-player game with combat, beware of kingmaker situations. Group-think can easily turn the experience into a slugfest with one player beat down for no other reason than the other players felt like picking on him. Higher player counts alleviate this problem because, of course, too much combat by a few players opens up opportunities for the others (and you can only earn achievement stars for your first two combat victories). Still, it's worth mentioning the potential for abuse, which Scythe does nothing innovative to address.

Scythe isn't a clone of any of the games I've mentioned, but rather a mash-up of all them and more. There isn't anything wrong with a mash-up, especially if it's done well -- and Scythe is done well. But then why can't I get on board the Scythe train? I think the answer is actually quite simple. Scythe is so well put together, so well developed, so well polished, that... well... it's just too darn clean! Too symmetrical, too well-balanced, too clever, too well produced and packaged.

I know! I've lost my frickin' mind. But I want a game with some rough edges here and there. I want a game that doesn't have a perfectly symmetrical board with an even distribution of resources. Sure, players have special powers that make each side feel a little bit different from the others (and that helps!), but is it all just window dressing on top of an identical core? I think it might be.

Perhaps additional plays will help. For now, after a three-player and a five-player game, Scythe impresses, but also fizzles. I can't help but feel that I'm playing a well put together package of a game. On the other hand, I can't help but feel that I'm playing yet another 4x-lite game, remixed in a different way. So it fits comfortably in the same space occupied by many other games. The real decision you have to make is whether Scythe gets the mix right. Do you like the way it balances achievements against victory points? Do you feel it has just the right amount of combat? Like your favorite meal, you know what to expect. You just want to know if the cook put all the ingredients together in the proper way. It's personal taste at that point, and for me Scythe is just a little too safe, a little too mild. But that doesn't mean it isn't damn good eats.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
At first Scythe may seem deceiving, even clunky, as you try to figure out what it requires of you. Right down the line of the Ameritrash/Euro union, the combat has a 'cold war' type feel to it, as you build your engine and collect resource while trying to protect yourself from ever present danger. But nothing may ever come of that danger, or it may. 

I love the engine building, I love the tense, pivotal combat, the artwork is sensational, the variable player powers are interesting (though some seem stronger than others). Even the opening moves feel important and tense, yet turns are quick. I love the race to the middle, but the hesitation as well; should I get too close to that other player? Should I sit back and wait or rush in first?

The combat cards could have been a bit more interesting perhaps, with text based abilities, but as combat as rare this isn't essential. The fact that combat only occurs at certain points in the game makes those combat events feel all the more tense; they can essentially turn the tide of the game. 

The different paths to victory are also great to play around with, and make every game fresh and unique. I still feel like I am discovering more about this game every time I play it. I love it equally with two players or more, essentially any player count, while being a very different experience. At this stage I'm not a big fan of the solo play, but I will revisit it on harder difficulties.

RATING: 7.5
*quick, one-action turns; game never feels like it drags

*no "rounds" (i.e. no upkeep, no clean-up, no income phase, no combat step) smooths out gameplay and learning

*the art is fantastic

*I really like that all resources stay on the board and that you can spend those in the territories that you control.

*scoring system is interesting; I like the value of "coins" in-game vs. as victory points

*the flavor text seems a little forced and somewhat unnecessary

*even though it is outlined in the rulebook, player negotiation does not really seem likely, although giving someone coins does seem like it should be strong enough incentive

RATING: 8
I'm all sorts of conflicted about this one. I love most of what is going on. Turns are quick and choices are difficult. It's clearly an efficiency game, but I actually think there are many paths to take in your quest for efficiency. I love that combat is a piece of the game, but not the main goal, and that defeat doesn't necessarily mean disaster. So what's not to like? Well, players going first have a clear advantage, whether it manifests as reaching the factor or encounters first or at the end of the game, where those going first may get a critical extra turn. This is a huge deal, especially since in games with 4+ players, in my experience, the starting player is the one to reach six stars, finish the game and get the win a disproportionate number of times. I'm not sure what the solution is yet, but the end game/early player advantage issue does need to be addressed. That said, from the beautiful components to the variety of combination the player boards offer to the tough choices faced by players, I like Scythe enough that I want to somehow solve its end game issues and keep playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

SPIEL 2016
