RATING: 7
Gorgeous looking game, no doubt.  The aesthetics and setting were really the main thing that got me interested in the Kickstarter campaign in the first place.  

The game itself, though, feels less inspired, at least at the 2 or 3 player counts.  The process and structure of playing the game never slides into the background to let the lush theme shine through, which is disappointing.

I'm also not a fan of a few of the design choices; in particular, receiving ongoing benefits after doing an Enlist action whenever your neighbours conduct the same action going forward... thematically nonsensical and is mostly just annoying to keep track of.

Update: I do prefer the game with 5 players and have increased my rating accordingly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
It's a good game. It's just that some faction abilities are better or worse with a different player count whereas other abilities outright rock. The ability of Rusviet Union to always be able to use the same section comes in handy all the time whereas for example the Polish ability is awesome in a 2-player game but pretty much blows in a 5-player game.
Despite all its chrome, namely the fantastic artwork, the magnificent design of coins and resources, the awesome minis, Scythe is not an immersive experience in my book. Encounters are advantage a) through c). I'd say, Nevertheless, those components are divine (speaking of the metal coins and realistic resource tokens). Scythe works so well, because the theme doesn't thrust itself heavily on the player, so that turns can run along smoothly even at a player-count of 5.

RATING: 8
If as someone who hasn't tried it, it seems like praise for it is everywhere, just know it's warranted. Scythe is just an intensely fun strategy game with almost endless replay factor, only amped further by its Invaders expansion. The price tag is high, but hard to argue with the lovely art and high quality contents. Fun with any number of players including solo, open to any sort of strategy... War, explore, develop, rarely will a leader/faction combo lock you into an unwanted play style. play moves quick with veterans, and slow but not agonizingly so with rookies. Only real compliant is time investment... Setup and tear down are lengthy, so schedule time enough for it... Maybe to get a few sessions in at once for efficiency's sake.

RATING: 4
I was initially more positive on the game but after several more plays the issues really start to come out. I will admit that the over-the-top production helps the game tremendously.

The first few rounds are mostly automatic, some faction pairings can be overpowered, the battle system has some issues (the blind bidding doesn't work very well, and losing a battle can open up the victor to then be attacked before recovering) and the race element means that players earlier in turn order will get more turns overall.

I could give more details on each thing but most importantly my group just liked the game less and less each time we played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
The game came out with a lot of hype which had me interested in the first place. The artwork was captivating but when I saw the components it seemed like a 3-4 hr game which wasn't my type of game.

However, after purchasing it and having played through it the first time, I found it was rather easy to learn and teach. The turn order was simple: pay/do the top row action and if you can, do the bottom row action; next player. This simple mechanic keeps the turns short and reduces AP. 

Additionally, its classified as a 4X game but you can play it without engaging combat at all. Some players don't like conflict which is a good alternative so they can do their own thing.

An euro game with area control, resource management, gorgeous art, and high replayability hits all my sweet spot. Definitely recommend it and I can't wait for future expansions!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Of a similar lineage to Archipelago; less of a sandbox but more obvious how to play.  Enjoying it less the more I play it. Opening moves are rather scripted as, although the mix of player boards creates a slightly different script, it is nevertheless a script if you want to be anything approaching efficient.  As the game plays out, it ends up being unmemorable because everyone has everything in play so every play ends up looking and feeling exactly the same as the last.  The random combination of faction, action board and objectives can even create a "losing hand" situation from the start which is a significant flaw in a game of this length. Overall, not a bad game, but certainly not great. A triumph of marketing style over design substance.

RATING: 10
This is a superb, light-to-medium weight 4X game. Doubt I'll ever tire of it. It's gorgeous, well made, thematically resonant, well balanced, intricate and yet it only takes about 30 minutes to teach. For its elegance and relative mechanical simplicity, its surprisingly deep on strategic and tactical value (and with the right crowd, pretty engaging for player interaction as well). After finally getting a copy a couple weeks ago (a full year+ after its post-KS delivery) I've already clocked 10 plays, 5 of which were solitaire games using the astounding Automa developed solo variant. I could write 1000 words on just how good the solo variant is and still have more praise yet to be written. 10/10 and after just 10 plays its easily on my top 20 All Time list. Unbelievably great work Jamey S.!!!!

RATING: 10
July 2016. My first real Kickstarter! I was concerned that it wouldn't live up to the hype, but I'm happy to report that it met and exceeded my expectations. This is one of my favorite games right now. I look forward to playing it many more times over the years. July 2016

Returned rating to a 10. I've played 6 solo games, which is pushing it back up for me. I don't usually care about solo gaming that much, but with my limited time lately, it's nice to be able to knock out a game in the evening in about 90 minutes including setup and breakdown. August, 2016.

I'm still in love with this game. I haven't been able to play for over a month, but still have TWENTY NINE plays so far this year (that's just from late July through late October!). Solo mode has been great. I've also been solo-testing a campaign I've designed, playing 4-player games by myself. I've gotten a ton of use out of this, and I truly regret not going all-in on the Kickstarter. I've ordered the metal coins, and maybe someday I'll get the realistic resources. I love this game so much. December 4, 2016

RATING: 8.5
Don't be fooled this is a super smooth Euro game, with some fighting elements thrown in, not the other way around.

That said the mechanics and pace of turns are rock solid, there's a lot to like about the game, it has some good well implemented ideas like the upgrade system.

There's unique factions, the bits amazing (just ridiculous quality), the game runs smooth and is easy to teach.  The scoring has some pretty unique and innovative ideas behind it.

Very very solid euro game with a higher than normal level of player interaction, but even losing fights is NOT a big deal.

Just don't buy it if you are hoping it is going to be a big mech battle game, it is not.

RATING: 9
Very solid game. Not super-deep, but tense and challenging.

While the game is surprisingly easy to pick up and play, it does have quite a steep learning curve in order to figure out each faction's strategies/strength.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I came in with lukewarm expectations about Scythe. The universal fawning has become a bit nauseating and the SUSD crew wasn't blown away. I left with a positive impression of the game, however.

The rules were hefty but once the game began it moved at a steady clip, even at five players. The ability to "double dip" on an action if you properly planned your turn has a Concordia-esque feel to it and leads to a really fun, crunchy puzzle.

The reputation track and combat are both interesting and well implemented. The absurd nature of the randomized starting factions has been touted as a drawback, but it surely will lead to a ton of replayability.

My only reservation is that the game felt an awful lot like Terra Mystica, an all-time great game that I don't get to the table often enough. Is Scythe different enough to take game sessions away from TM? Is there room enough for both to exist?

RATING: 10
Scythe combines beautiful art, a wonderfully quirky theme and solid mechanisms into one promising game. I expect to play this solo, with my girlfriend (casual gamer) and my friends ("hardcore" gamers), whenever I can.

The Kickstarter campaign was one of the best I've seen to date, with the creator and artist actively discussing their decisions and even accepting feedback without getting upset.

As a bonus, the realistic resources and the metal coins in the higher-tier versions can be used with other games. I think the creator even offers a list of possible uses for the resource tokens.

I'm 100% sure I'll get the expansion to Scythe as well - just waiting for the information on when, where and how my money needs to be given to Stonemeier Games. ;)

RATING: 8
If you have the deluxe version, the artistic value is exceptional. The game is simple (but it will take some time to go through the rules). It has self-explained mechanisms due to the clever player-board design. The game itself is fast (about 3 hours for 5 people), and has mechanisms build in to advance the game end even if some players will try to extend the game-play. It is one of these games that you need at least 1 play to get the rhythm, so you can play well. It is more an economic game with some fighting (although there are strategies to become a fighting game with a lot of economic thinking). It well worth to be in your collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Kickstarter deluxe copy with metal coins and physcial resource markers.

I'm really enjoying this, have played 2 and 3 player games so far.  The art style is beautiful and I like the overall combination of elements.

The random player mat that gets distributed with the factions gives huge replay to this game, avoids the whole "here's the strategy to win with this team" issue that invariably finds its way into games.

The early sprint to the factory seems somewhat unbalanced.  If you get a hero in quickly, the factory feels like it could be a major runaway-leader issue, although I haven't played enough to say one way or the other.

The game borrows mechanics from several classics, including Doom's combat wheel and combat card system (which works very well here.)  I like how the designer's intent of "the threat of combat" being more persistent than actual combat seems to have been executed successfully.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A little hard to get to the table, perhaps too intimidating for some, but we always have a blast when it does.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
About [thing=169786][/thing]:

[b]1) What is it?[/b]
Is an optimization euro with asymmetric positions, costs and abilities and with some sprinkled combat, area control, random encounters and a tad of a race game. There were (and likely still are) plenty of arguments around the fact the designer said that [thing=169786][/thing] is a 4X game. I didn't see it. I wouldn't called it that way to others. But if one wants, hey, be my guess.

[thing=169786][/thing] has a light amount of interaction, mostly for board position. Yet, for the most part, you will do your thing, the others will do theirs, and rarely one will care to see what you are doing. It will be more an affair of "pass me 3 food", or "raise my popularity by 1", or "I'm building this, here". 

There is a high amount of decisions points offered by the game, and several paths to follow, though the nation and action board taken do narrow the possibilities, since the game rewards optimization, it pays better to make actions more suited to your advantages.

The game bits are great and the art on the card and player boards are, as expected, amazing. The kickstarter version comes with some awesome metal coins and special resource tokens.

Playing time, though not really short, sits comfortably in a game night, lasting around 2 hours, even with 5 players. Downtime increases the more players at the table, but isn't a big issue, as the actions are limited and executed quickly, most of the time (combat is also done fast).

The theme, while a big initial draw to many, due to Jakub's art, passes under the radar almost all the time during play. Rarely did we make a thematic connection between an action in game to what nation we were. The encounters have some nice tidbits of theme and worldbuilding, but we simply passed above many, as the next player was already carrying out his action, yet, eventually we heard a "So, I stopped to let the geese cross the road..." - seems proper.

Overall, the [thing=169786][/thing] works smoothly and well enough, even if it brings little actual theme and mechanical innovations to the table.

[b]2) How do you play?[/b]
Each player is represented by a nation, with special abilities, correlations and unique costs for building stuff. The goal of the game is to have more money at the end. Stars, areas controlled and resources are worth money at the end of the game - these are multiplied by the popularity the player has. Also, players gain money when doing things (building, encounters, etc) during the play, but some actions also cost money to be done.

The simple way to say what happens during the game is: each turn the player picks an area of her own player board to activate a main action, which are: move, trade, bolster and produce. Then, if able, the player can activate the secondary action associated with the main action (these change between the player boards, and are part of the asymmetry) - these always cost resources to be done, and isn't always possible to be made due to this, specially near the start of the game.

The tricky part is: once an (action) area of the board is activated, it can't be done again in the next turn - a different area must be used.

Mechas and heroes can initiate combat, and is done by, secretly, each player deciding the amount of power to use (adjusting a dial), to a maximum of 7, and if add a combat card (whose power varies from 2 to 5). The highest amount of power wins, and in case of a tie, the attacker wins. Defeated mechas, hero and workers return the the player starting position. Buildings, even from the defeated player, remain. For each worker sent away, the winner loses 1 popularity. All used power (in the dial) is lost, regardless of the result. Resources in the area in which the combat occurred are in possession of the winner.

There are 10 ways of getting stars - winning combat (x2), building all mechas, doing all upgrades, making all buildings, reaching the max popularity or max power, and others. Once a player reaches 6 starts, the game is over, and final scoring will happen. The player with the most money will be the winner!

[b]3) Which are the decisions made during play?[/b]
Several. What action to do each turn - and this is two fold, as every action on the board is divided in two - and, sometimes, you will truly want to make the action above, but won't be able to make the bellow, and in a optimization game, this is usually not a good thing. Therefore, it might be worth more to delay the coveted action for a turn or two, to make the best of it, as once used, the action can't be done (usually) again in the next turn.

And all actions also have connected decisions: where to move, what resources to take, which option to pick from an encounter, what to build and where (from proper buildings, to mechs, as each uncover a special ability, to upgrades and enlists), and many others. If a battle starts, there is considerations about the amount of power to use and if/which combat card to add.

Overall, there is plenty points of decisions - most not all that difficult, to the point to induce to some severe analisis paralisis, but enough to make each matter and have lasting effects in the board state and in your game.

[b]4) What are the good things in the game?[/b]
- Excellent components;
- Several options to choose from in each turn;
- Clear objectives that all players can go after;
- Asymmetric, as all nations have unique abilities and different costs for actions;
- Downtime is rather small;
- Combat causes little damage for the player that loses, and there is basically no player elimination;
- Little luck, kept in the draw of combat and encounter cards.

[b]5) Which are the bad news?[/b]
- Small interaction and even interest in what the other players are doing for most of the time;
- The art on the board can get in the way of seeing the situation of the play;
- A collage of mechanisms (from Kemet, Dune, Antike, euros of optimization, etc) in a whole that, while it works well enough, has little innovation;
- The theme is, sadly, lost during play.

[b]6) How do you feel while playing?[/b]
"So, popularity rises the amount of money you will get."
"Like [thing=24181][/thing]?"
"Yes, mostly, but just for you. 
"The board is big, as you can see, but every place is kind of near to each other, once Mines are made."
"Reminds me what happens in [thing=127023][/thing]."
"Close. There can be the same pressure and the thought that no place is truly completely safe. Anyway, in the battle you bid an amount of power and may or not add a card to boost the total."
"Ah, like [thing=121][/thing]?"
"But with phantom units - you don't handle armies, just a level of power. And without f***** traitor generals." (A sore spot.)
"The goal is to have the most money in the end. Yes, like [thing=24181][/thing], things in the board help, but money in the pocket is what counts. The game ends when someone reaches 6 stars, and stars you get when you do one of 10 objectives."
"Sort like the objectives in [thing=166857][/thing]."
"Hum, sure, sort of. There isn't such a race here, as is only the trigger to end, not the end goal itself."

(...) And a whole lot of this. It feels like playing parts of several top notch games, not all taken to the fullest, some being more waterdown, but I could still find connections: like trying to make the best of the main and secondary action and not being able to use them again for a time remind me of [thing=59294][/thing] (and also having heroes exploring the map); the resources on the board that can be taken and/or used by others, some economic and pick and deliver games; and so on.

At first the game seemed daunting, with so many options and branching paths to acquire money, resources, popularity, power, etc. But once we started playing, things fell nicely into place, and though there is a fine level of possibilities, each one is clearly defined, contained in a simple action to be carried on, to the point that even a friend of mine, who usually struggle to understand quickly the mechanics of a game, did learn the ways of [thing=169786][/thing] rather fast.

I can understand the hype around it, though I don't really share the same amount of love many have, as, for me, [thing=169786][/thing] is a well done game, interesting and smart, taking good parts of other games and making a whole that works nicely together. But not groundbreaking, particularly innovative or inventive, nor has an awesome factor besides the art, which just sits in the background, as does the rest of the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My 25th play was my first with a production copy. The gameplay was already top notch, and the fantastic production seals my love for it. More a euro with the ever present threat of war than a true waro. Saving military victories for the endgame is an important strategic consideration. However, you could beat each other to death with this game if your group were into that sort of thing. The heart of the game is in the way its structures interaction between players. The map and tech progression work together to create a watchful but safe early game for getting an engine going. The midgame sees players crossing out of their own territories to rub elbows on the mainland. Then the end game sees players either rushing for safe ground or chaotically clashing in battle to place last stars and expand. I have wanted one game to fill that Euro Trash niche. This is it. And my fancy version is easily the prettiest game I've ever played. Is it the best game? One of them, but not quite "the game." It's going to be my go-to for a lot of guests. But I think Caylus and Agricola are still holding the crowns.

RATING: 5
Really not impressed by this one.

First off, the obvious: the artwork is phenomenal. Beautiful and sets the mood wonderfully. I honestly think that whatever Stegmaier paid Rozalski couldn't have been 10% of what he deserved... The artwork drove the hype for the game.

As for the actual gameplay, well that's where it fell pretty flat to me. Action decisions on a given turn are boring and repetitive. The beginning of the game felt tedious as everyone makes tiny moves in their little silo as they begin to get their engine up and running.

But the biggest way in which this game fell flat for me is that the engine-building was severely constrained. You couldn't really specialize in any one area very much. Sure you could upgrade to save a cube here or there but there was no in-depth combos or chaining.

And the ending of the game is entirely anti-climactic. Scoring feels arbitrary. A single spot on the popularity track can lead to a huge swing in final position.

In short, so very disappointing and "meh."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Scythe is an engaging game that centers around an efficiency race to obtain your victory stars faster than anyone else, using the unique powers of your faction, as well as the unique strengths of your action board. As an engine builder with a racing element it resembles a euro game like Terra Mystica, but with more theme/narrative and beautiful artwork. The game's length, around 3 hours with 4 players, and depth/complexity ratio both hit my personal sweet spot. It really is not a hard game to teach, but a tough game to be good at for sure. I cannot say that it has me sitting on the edge of my seat while playing (like Forbidden Stars does), but it keeps everyone at the table involved and entertained the entire(!) time. Consequently, we are all looking forward to our next play! My 10 rating is only for a game with 4 or 5 players - it is probably an 8 with 3, and a 7 with 2 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the very best games out there in my book. Everything is top nodge for me!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Kickstarted
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Scythe is an extremely well designed 4x game. The tight design and mechanics make for a rich and streamlined experience.

Components: The game components are excellent quality and leave little to be desired. The plastic models are sturdy and very well detailed. The cards are of thick stock and beautifully illustrated. The player boards are double layered and feel innovative. The map board is also beautifully colored, clear and a lovely sight just to lay out.

Ease of learning/teaching: The game is fairly complex, but for the number of mechanics in the game, it's relatively straightforward to explain and learn. The iconography is intuitive. However, it is not a game for everyone. 

Theme: The faction powers feel strongly thematic. The encounter cards do a beautiful job of picturing scenarios without forcing a narrative through flavor text. The back stories for faction leaders are well described and I found the world immersive. 

Gameplay: The mechanics are streamlined and I appreciate splitting top and bottom row actions which contribute significantly to reducing downtime between turns. I like that there are numerous paths to victory and the key lies in maximizing efficiency in actions while maintaining focus on selected objectives. A good player will outshine the competent player by observing the map and leveraging events across the board. 

The game is also very well suited for solo play with adjustable difficulty settings.

All in all, I greatly enjoy this game and bringing it out. I paid a pretty penny for it but have no remorse. One of the most outstanding strategy games I've seen in a while.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Kickstarted 2015-10

Simply amazing.

Scythe is the pinnacle of Stonemaier Games' productions. Designer Jamey Stegmaier successfully captured the feel of Jakob Rozalski's alternate history world with a territory control game that marries the feel of Kemet and Terra Mystica.

The game is both a treat to play and to see. The title is appropriate for multiple gaming tastes, including area-control, upgrade mechanics, asymmetric powers, and streamlined gameplay.

By far the best Kickstarter project I have backed.

And the automa, despite its initially steep learning curve, is one of the best solitaire euro games ever.

RATING: 5.5
in this game it's about getting the most money. On your turn you can produce ressources, “buy“ force or renown, move your pawns (your chief, mechs or peasants). With the ressources you can build buildings, mechs or advance your options.
With all these actions you can also earn money. 
Fights are a good way to hinder your opponent and steal their ressources. Your chief can moreover have encounters which are like a big bonus where you get things like ressources, reputation, force or money.
For many things like winning a fight, get maximum force or reputation, enhance all options, build all buildings, build all mechs etc you get stars. The first to gather six stars triggers the game end. Then everybody compares what they have and the player with the most money is the winner.

This game has a lot of cool things. The gameplay is very simple once you understand the basics and you have a lot of possibilities to gather stars. 
I could not really enjoy this game however because the downtime is way too high for this game. It is just not interesting to watch the other players' turns. Somehow the gathering of the ressources is not good enough, you have to wait a lot of turns until you can really do the actions that give you stars and money... it all feels a bit mechanic and hindered...
But I can certainly understand why people like it that much, it is very well outthought amd clever and smooth and the factions' abilities are very cool.

To me it is not that good but I will certainly give it another shot

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Enjoyable enough experience, but nothing mind-blowing.  Components are solidly above average, so worth looking at if this is important to you.

Randomized board combinations offer variety, but can also set up solidly disadvantaged builds or awful hidden goals (a mechanic I consider very weak in general, though it works *okay* here.)  Combat is also solidly swingy - mindgames are neat and all, but the sheer range of difference possible can effectively give a random win or loss.  (It can also be swingy in terms of who can get targeted by who based on Riverwalk and such, giving an advantage to people not involved in combat at times.)

Player powers, as with many games that have them, feel neat but often heavily force your hand as far as what strategies you can pursue.  Endgame is excessively calculational, and the sudden stop (as well as potential races to factory or encounters) should give some advantage to earlier turn order.  The nonsense bandaid 'punish players for counting score' indicates the developers realized there was a problem here and then... didn't fix it.

The component quality is very high, but this isn't terribly important to my enjoyment of a board game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Highly enjoyable. Well made, well laid out, rules are easy to follow.

Donno.  May update later, but... yeah.  Just didnt happen for me.

RATING: 7
Initial rating after two plays, anxious to play some more and feel out the strategies more.  Has a lot of Terra Mystica feel, but seems to be lacking a bit of the full strategic grace.  Instead it adds Mechs/Combat and Area Control, which are my favorite type of genre.  You'd think that would be great... but I'm not entirely sure.  The end game always feels weak to me.  I tend to love games that are a race, but in this game it almost feels like it's robbing something from the experience.    The game is relatively tight, and it seems like someone just grabbing a really nice territory from someone in a last minute attack seems to swing it in their favor.  

My biggest gripe may be how anti-climactic the battles are, every fight I've seen so far, you know exactly who is going to win.  I think that sucks a lot of the excitement out of what this type of game usually offers me.  Because of that, while I'm always happy to play it, it's not really a game that has grabbed me and begged to be played more.

RATING: 4
Decent economic game with some nice mechanisms, really like how resources are kept on the map and can be taken away by other players and the tableau management is reasonably engaging.

Game is ruined by a lack of thought and effort in a few areas. The encounters are just art with 3 options very boring not to have some flavour text, miniatures are pretty bad, which may seem trivial but they are the centrepiece of the game so it does detract.

Biggest issue is the absolutely terrible combat system, basically a resource bidding war where often the winner loses more than the loser or both players end up making themselves vulnerable to further attack, counter intuitive and annoying.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Scythe is a beautiful, well-designed engine builder that I sold after a couple of plays because it didn't offer the kind of player interaction that I was looking for and in the end struck me as interesting, but hollow. 

There is player action in the game- various mechanisms provide opportunities to interact with the other players (combat, recruits, encounters), I just don't find it enhances the play experience for me as I prefer interaction that more strongly impacts the other players' decisions.

Recruits provide me a reason to stay engaged on other players' turns but really have a minor impact on strategy.

Combat is situationally worth the effort but is so easily disincentivized that it is rarely worth the hassle. The "cold war" threat of combat certainly exists, but is much more exciting in Eclipse, for example, where there is a reaction on multiple levels (pinning strategy, tech tree "cold war") in addition to unit posturing.

After playing Scythe I find myself yearning to play titles where the game is structured so that players need to act and react to the other players' choices to excel (don't get me wrong if you ignore the other players in Scythe you aren't playing well, but if you do it seems you will still bump into more roadblocks to trying to affect their gameplay than opportunities to do so).

In short the player interaction in Scythe isn't fulfilling for me. The interactions I experienced with the other players were neither memorable nor fun. I don't feel like I've done something clever or bested my opponent, rather I feel like I've upgraded another cube to make my mechs cost only 1 metal so that I can keep cranking them out (and what are the other players going to do about it)?

I can certainly see why so many seem to love the game but I guess in the end it really isn't the type of game that I like.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

My top game on my game shelf!

RATING: 9
2017 update: After a few plays, including 2 in a tournament format, I'm dropping the rating to 9. I've had some purely BAD games of Scythe. There's a few combos that are so pigeonholed, you lose almost all freedom to play how you'd like. The worst is Saxons with a board that doesn't reward mech building. Other players will almost always have an advantage, and your only hope is that they don't notice you building up for combat before you can attack. 

The rest of the game is great though, and I especially love the new Japanese-style faction. Still among my favorite games, but I've seen enough  failures in it's mechanics to break the 10-rating love I once felt.

RATING: 9.5
Great components, amazing artwork and varied gameplay with tons of replayability. Scythe is easily one of the best board games I've ever played.

It's also a feat of pure genious how a game as complex as Scythe has been made so easy to teach by a very visually helpful board and a game that builds on the mechanics as you play and doesn't force everything on you the second you start taking turns.

There's also a lot to be said about how amazing the visuals look when you think about how clearly and smartly everything is laid out. It's a perfect balance of gorgeous artwork mixed with helpful symbols in just the right places.

The minis and artwork are also oozing with interesting lore. It's a game where every little detail has a surprisingly practical meaning in terms of both worldbuilding and the mechanics.

RATING: 7
This game (and Lords of Waterdeep) convinced me to take bgg ratings with big bucket of salt. Its not bad - its a good game and I would usually play it, but its nowhere near as it was/is hyped up to be. It is not particularly interesting in terms of mechanics or gameplay (except for few minor innovations). To me it falls under the efficiency engine-building euros category (the 4x aspect is just barely there) but the experiences of playing it is not as satisfying or fun as in other engine builders e.g Caverna. With all the cool components, interesting theme, gorgeous artwork this game seem to have lot of potential but the actual experience of playing it leaves you underwhelmed.  

But as I said its not a bad game. It doesn't take a long for a complex game, has multiple paths to victory, there doest not seem to be any obvious problems with balance - its just that it is not as great as it is hyped up to be.

RATING: 6.3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Assuming you have the Kickstarter deluxe version, this is a gorgeous production. I'm happy to say that the gameplay is almost as good. The game is sort of a mix between Terra Mystica and Dune. Like Terra Mystica, the focus of the game is clearing your player board of buildings as efficiently as possible. The Dune side of things is the combat system. it is zero luck, with both sides bidding a number of troops and then adding a card or two to the bid, after which all are lost.

I think the most innovative thing about Scythe is the way it handles heroes and quests. Instead of the usual random card and wall of text, Scythe offers the players a beautiful painting to set the scene and then a couple of options for your hero to react to it. These usually fall along the Paragon/Neutral/Renegade decision tree found in many video games. How you behave determines your scoring opportunities in later rounds, which is a neat idea.

Another thing I like is the resource system. When goods are produced, they sit in their space of origin until a player uses them. This is a genius idea that opens up all sorts of strategies, both offensively and defensively.

My only concern is that it could get samey over multiple games, as there is probably a best path through every player board.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Would have been higher but I don't like the end game mechanic as once the 6th star is out the game is over.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Fave game ever: Mixes area control with some elements of 4X. Basically you get strategy, management and tactics in the same game without the complicated 4x systems (that i also love btw). Game uses easy rules but its deep and complex. Not a beginner game for sure (unless all are on the same level experienced players will absolutely dominate) but with experienced players its the type of game that when you lose will make you think "i totally deserved it". Only flaw is first turns of forced dominant strategy but Wind Gambit expansion totally fixes it. Deserves to become an eternal classic like Puerto Rico.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great theme of steampunkish 1920's Central Europe overlayed on a mechanical mashup of Euro, Ameritrash, and wargame.  Difficult to digest, but smooth Euro mechanics.  The [thing=121][/thing]-inspired combat fits nicely.  Leaders, mechs, and workers are uniquely detailed for each faction.  Fine detail throughout rewards taking a closer look at the map, the cards, and other components.  The many ways to score points allow for many different strategies.  Variable faction powers coupled with variable starting setup keep everyone from creating the same engine or playing the same game twice.  The map is relatively tight and players are in each others' grill sooner than later.  Shares some traits and feel with real-time simulation computer games.  A great Euro with BOTH theme and conflict!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It all fell flat. It's hyped as a 4X game. It's barely 2X and those two parts are half way done.

For me, this is an engine builder for the sake of building that engine. 

Pass.

RATING: 6
[i]Preliminary rating after one 2p game:[/i]

Scythe has some interesting and clever mechanics, but overall I was rather underwhelmed by this game. There's a lot going on here, but ultimately nothing is too exciting. It's one of these games in which you have to put a lot of effort to do anything, but the "fun factor" you get in return is pretty low. I know that it probably gets more interesting with more players, but it's not the "dudes on the map" part of the game that falls flat to me - it's the whole action selection system and the process of developing your own player board, it just feels tedious.

Also, the illustrations on the cards are beautiful, but you hardly ever get to look at them during the game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Extremely well stream-lined Euro game with head-to-head conflicts. It suffers from the balance problem like all asymmetric and low-randomness games do (e.g. Terra Mystica). I haven't played this game enough yet to comment on the balance, but it seems clear that Red and Yellow are more versatile and stronger than the rest given any player count.

I have some concerns about designer's comment on balance: "When we made Rusviet's unique ability cost 1 power, it was used 0 times". I am not saying it is definitely worth 1 power per usage, but it implies they didn't push their playtesters far enough. Veteran players seem to come up with balance solutions, and the meta is still actively evolving, so I'll keep following the forum.

RATING: 8
Kinda steep learning curve starting out but once you get it, it's an amazing game. I found it more fun just to play and not worry about actually winning than anything else. For this game it's all about the journey, not the destination.

I have now played 7 games. 4 of them the 1 player automata variation and 3 of them with 5 or less people. I can say the game plays just as good with 5 people as it does with 2 or 3. Also the 1 player game is really fun! It changes the way the game is played a little bit for the opposing automa and is really clever. 

One downside that I have found after playing numerous games. It seems that you really should put more focus into your popularity over everything else in the game. Since popularity has a strong dictation towards final score you are more likely to end up winning over the guy who has completely ignored popularity. That being said the endgame counting up points is by far my least favorite part of the game. I love the resource management and game play and honestly don't care if I win or lose because the fun I have with the game is more than enough for me.

Everything in the game has a purpose, and I find no 'wastful' mechanisms...the whole package comes together beautifully.

RATING: 6
Played it 3 times, which is quite a feat.
I kinda like it, I tought I would like it a bit better. Not sure why that is.
The board is beautiful and the turns are swift.
Maybe it's the fact that from looking at the box I expect a game with a different feel.

If you really like area-control and combat (which I don't) I think there are better suited games. I do like that combat is swift and not all too devasting if you lose a battle.

If you like tight euro games (which I sometimes do), I think there are also better games.

If you really like a streamlined combination of the two, I'd day "Try it out".

Still, so far this is the Stegmaier game I've played so far which I like best.
Will play when asked, but probably never with more than 5.

RATING: 9
This game is fun, and pretty well realized.  Keeping turns to a single top/bottom action selection and obfuscating the score standing prevents two of the games potential down sides - long turns/AP and the possibility of a runaway leader if you -know- you're ahead.  Both are well mitigated by thoughtful design thanks to thoughtful designers.
OK, now the gush for things that dont necessarily make the game, but are cool - great board and art, and this is one of the coolest and most original themes of any game in my collection.
Love it and cant wait to get it to the table with all the people who will appreciate it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After a couple of plays I think its a winner. Rating likely to go up
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Theme/Art:
Scythe is the most beautiful game I own. Jakub Rozalski is an amazing artist and the art is 11/10, if not more.  Same goes for the theme as the game sets place in an alternative history in the 1920s where countries build giant battle mechs.

Production quality:
Amazing production quality, the board has 2 sides with one having a bigger map so you have more space for resources (you need to purchase a board extension to use it), the miniatures are very good, and every faction has different worker meeples, which is a nice touch. Nothing feels cheap in Scythe.

Replayability:
There are 5 factions with different abilities and different starting resources and also 5 player mats with different top and bottom rows, as well as different action costs. So you have to take a different approach each game, even if you play the same faction twice.

Depth/Difficulty:
The game takes a bit to explain, but it is actually not that hard and once you get the hang of it it has a nice flow. Since everybody only takes one top row action and maybe a bottom one on his turn, you don't have to wait long until you are up again.
The game has very interesting mechanics, especially how the game ends. Once someone placed all their 6 stars it's over. So if you are ahead and only have one star to place you can end the game immediately, but if you are behind in money you can drag the game out by not placing your last star (unless someone else places all their stars of course).
The fact that you don't get resources you produced into your supply, but they are placed on the hex they are produced on, is also very interesting, because you can steal resources from others if they don't watch out.
I also like that the encounter cards have no text on them (aside from your options), but only a picture of the scene, so you have to interpret it in your own way.
I weight it 3/5.

Strategy:
Scythe is a strategy game, so of course their is a lot of strategy involved. Your strategy should depend on your faction, player mat, and starting position. There are 10 ways to plays stars, but you only need to place 6 to end the game, so focus on 6 of those ways. E.g. if you draw shitty objectives, ignore them.
Oh, and get your popularity up to at least 13, you need it for the scoring!

Luck:
Aside from your starting setup (faction and player mat) and the cards you draw (encounters, objectives, factory cards) there is no luck involved. Even combat is not luck, but using power and power cards (and knowing how much power your enemy will spend.

Scythe takes about 80-150 minutes to play, depending on player count and how familiar players are with the game. Teaching the rules takes about 20 minutes.

In summary I like Scythe very much and it is the best looking game I own at the moment. We will see if its rating stays that high after a few more plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
[microbadge=17587] [microbadge=40723] Collector's Edition
[b]Also owned:[/b]
* All promos associated with KS (Scythe Promo #1 - #5)
* Green and Purple Promo Power Dials (Scythe Promo #8)
* $2 promo coins (Scythe Promo #10)
* Meeplesource Action tokens (replaces generic pawns)
* Meeplesource Encounter and Expansion tokens
* Scythe Legendary Box (pre-ordered)

Like many others, I figured that Scythe was going to be pretty combat-driven. That was fine, because I like a lot of dudes-on-a-map (where they're fighting each other) games. But Scythe is not very combat-driven, despite having combat. It's more of a strategic objective completion game - and I love it far more than if it had been a streamlined dudes-on-a-map game. I love the engine-building part of the player boards, the fact that you (usually) can only complete each objective once, the exploration cards, the various faction abilities, the turns being lightning quick... the list goes on. It's a big, beautiful optimization puzzle to me, but a puzzle where your opponents can throw some wrenches into the gears. And I'm 100% down with that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
I got to play my copy of the [thing=169786][/thing] Collectors Edition twice last night and I'm happy that I did... and not for reasons that you might think immediately.

Scythe, at face value, seemed like a very complex machine of many intricate moving parts. The strategies didn't seem all that apparent to me and figuring out how to best manage the combination of upper-row actions with the bottom-row actions in concert with your specific faction abilities and their starting location resources, etc. seemed daunting. Needless to say... I struggled mightily in the first game and got thoroughly trounced. The surprising thing was that (a 3 player game, with teaching mind you) played out rather quickly. So... with time to spare in our game night, we decided to try it again and switch up factions and player mats.

This second game played out drastically different and allowed me to really see how Scythe will play over the long haul. Each and every faction has unique abilities and benefits in their starting positions. But, pair that with an action board that is random and provides drastically different pairings of actions and associated costs, and the puzzle and strategy really grows.

Having seen what some other players had benefited from in our first game, and trying to play to my faction's strengths, I ended up pulling off a pretty decent win. The one player that had thoroughly destroyed two of us in the first game seemed to be in the running to destroy us again in the early to mid game but ended up running their engine thin and struggled a bit at the end. This allowed my slow build-up to get steamrolling and come back for the victory.

I'll probably do a full review of the game at some point but these are my initial thoughts.

As I said at the beginning, I'm happy that we played the game twice last night because if we had ended it after the first play, I think that I wouldn't have enjoyed the game as much as I do now. Winning the second game aside, the second play actually gave me a feel for Scythe and what it has to offer moving forward. I wouldn't say that it's a 4X game by any stretch but it does feel like you're dipping your toe in that pond. My best description would be a less combat intensive [thing=127023][/thing] with resource management minus the robust tech-tree, or maybe [thing=72125][/thing]-lite. It definitely didn't have a ton of combat (in the 3 player game), although the second game did ramp up a bit. I imagine that would only increase with player count and/or with added experience though. And, the engine-building / resource management really came through quite a bit to me. The fact that it plays so quickly is also a bonus. Being able to knock two games out in less than 3 hours is amazing. One game of Eclipse would easily take at least that long!

All-in-all... I'm very excited about this game. From a cautiously optimistic view of the game after my first play to instant "Awesomesauce!" after the second. I can't wait to delve deeper in to the game and play it again soon!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Kickstarter Collector's edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Having only played this once here is my review.
For first timers, this game is very tricky to understand and can easily take an hour + just figuring out the game mechanics. However once you get passed all that, this game feels like a tabletop version of a video game and you can easily feel immersed in the landscape of Europa. I'd definitely like to play again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
2 player learning game had a dry, solitaire tinge to it. The artwork and components are exceptional - best art of the year. 

The game experience felt lopsided because you have a huge map game board with miniatures on the table but you spend most of the game durdling around on the little player board in front of you.

I look forward to playing this again so I can continue to form my opinion about the game.

Definitely a better game with 4-5 although I've taught this game a few too many times now and would prefer to play with those that know it (the rules explanation can take up to 30 mins if players want to know everything in advance). I look forward to trying the expansion factions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I dislike that this game looks like it has a lot of player interaction, but in reality is a boring slow overly long engine builder that does very little to inspire me to replay it let alone teach someone else how to play it so we can play together. Games need to look good enough to teach (this does), and have mechanics that inspire them being taught (this doesn't). If I want to play a basic engine builder I'll play something tighter in a smaller box with player interaction and some thoughtful variable game interactions that encourage replayability rather than this mess. I'll put this one down to just not being my cup of tea and accept that I just don't enjoy "Euro" games. A math puzzle VP fest is simply put not my kind of fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have mixed feelings about Scythe. The production is great, it plays with little downtime, and does a great job of balancing area control and worker placement.

On the other hand, the hybrid (worker placement, area control) design means it is not excellent in either category. For area control, I'd rather play Inis. For medium weight euro, Clans of Caledonia (CoC) does similar mechanics better.

In comparison to CoC, CoC provides more focus to the player with the Clan powers. This exists in Scythe with the different player boards, but either isn't as transparent or the powers aren't strong enough to really push the player in a specific direction. In CoC, I won't be able to do everything on my board, I have to focus on a specific strategy to be successful. In Scythe, I always upgrade everything on my player board 3/4's through the game.

My guess is that 2 player scaling is at the core of my issues (as we have not included Automa). The variable end conditions from The Wind Gambit may also help.

I will update my rating/thoughts once we have played with both.

RATING: 8
I really like the paired action selection spaces in Scythe.  Trying to maximize my chances of using every aspect of a space as often as possible really appealed to me.  I did have a lot of trouble reading the board state though as the tunnel warping and riverwalk made some things closer together and some things farther apart than one would expect at a glace.  But as I've gained experience with the game that's largely gone away (though I still need to ask "Where can you Riverwalk again?" a couple times a game...).  A very satisfyingly fast civ type game that I'm very much looking forward to exploring further!

RATING: N/A
Another sheep in wolf's clothing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fascinating game and have now played a variety of different factions. I find the game takes too long, seems almost lumbering, above 5. 4 or 5 is the sweet spot. 

We've also found the game bogs down near the end as everyone jockeys for the last few points trying to min-max everything. You can see the end coming and you just need to try to finish.

One annoying aspect is that you can start the game in a totally untenable situation. You can have goals that are simply unrealistic meaning something usually doable isn't. We resolved this by giving everyone 3 and letting them keep two, similar to Ticket to Ride. Helps more. We might opt for take 2 of 4 as one of the players got hosed last game again. 

It will definitely hit our table again but it's fallen a bit courtesy of length and some stronger games that have become group favourites of late.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Gyönyörű rajzokkal, komponensekkel teli, hevibe hajló euró. A frakciók és a hozzájuk kapcsolódó képességek sokszori újrajátszást biztosíthatnak az erre fogékonyaknak. A 2 órás játékidőből sokat nem lehet lefaragni, így ennek tudatában üljön le mki elé. A harcok kicsit furcsák (semmilyenek?) voltak elsőre, de igazából nem ront a játékélményen. A játék íve és a fejlesztések miatt az első fele határozottan izgalmasabb, a másodikra viszont kicsit leülhet a dolog, de lehet csak mi fáradtunk el az első szabálymagyarázattal teli játékban. Számomra mindenképpen még kipróbálós.
Egyelőre egy hájpos 8, aztán majd meglátjuk.

Egyre jobban tetszik, szinte bármikor szívesen ülök le elé.

RATING: 10
Collectors edition makes this game one of the top component quality games I have ever owned, and even my friends who shrink away from any game of over an hour, keep asking to bring this to the table again and again. My only caution is that the first time someone plays the game, they will make mistakes that can often impact their ability to win the game, so tread friendly with the strat and rules for a player's first time

RATING: 9
Kártyavédő: 44db 42x67
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Very much enjoyed our first play of this. Game reminds me a bit of Terra Mystica. The same puzzle how to start your engine going and plop your structures/workers etc down is in this game too, but I felt having a bit more variance in this game than in TM. I hope the variance (faction tech, objective, random player mat, encounter cards) will continue to have the effect that not every game with the same faction plays out the same. 

Love how the resources are placed on the board so you need to protect them. Factions feel different and interesting. Combat feels just right (even though I'm more into wargames), not punishing but an interesting tactical way to offset and block the others. Everyone felt always threatened like in a cold war style. It's more a matter of control and gives you a decision to make : spread out or keep together. 

I also love the little details in gamedesign for example how you get to hold 2 objectives so you still can switch strategy. It's a small something but it shows experience and insight in good gamedesign. 

Minor nitpick : felt like 6 stars ends the game just a little bit too early. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Plays very fast, looks great. Primarily an efficiency euro game. Your strategy is somewhat constrained by your starting boards (your action sets, which are slightly different for everyone). You can ignore the obvious efficiency incentives to make your own plan, but you probably won't win... The many different combinations of special powers and action boards does give it good immediate replayability.
